Authors: Ohgaki H., Noguchi T., Sugiyama S., Yamazaki T., Mikado T., Chiwaki M., Yamada K., Suzuki R., Sei N.
Title: Linearly polarized photons from Compton backscattering of laser light for nuclear resonance fluorescence experiments
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohgaki, H., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Noguchi, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Sugiyama, S., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Yamazaki, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Mikado, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Chiwaki, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Yamada, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Suzuki, R., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Sei, N., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba-shi, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: Elastically scattered photons from 208Pb(γpol, γ) have been measured with completely polarized photons. The polarized photons (laser Compton photons) can be generated by Compton backscattering of laser light. The energy of the polarized LCPs ranges from 1 to 10 MeV by using a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser and the storage ring TERAS at Electrotechnical Laboratory. We can rotate the polarization axis of the LCPs by using the laser polarization controller to diminish the systematic error in the measurement system. Parities of J = 1 levels in 208Pb, Ex = 5.514 and 4.841 MeV, were clearly determined to be negative. © 1994.

Authors: Kuznetsov S., Kadnikov A., Krylov Yu., Yupinov Yu., Levichev E.
Title: Control system of the synchrotron radiation source SIBERIA
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kuznetsov, S., Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Kadnikov, A., Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Krylov, Yu., Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Yupinov, Yu., Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Levichev, E., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation
Abstract: The SIBERIA accelerator complex includes a 80 MeV electron linac, a 450 MeV booster storage ring, a main 2.5 GeV storage ring and two transport lines for electron beams. The SIBERIA control system is based on distributed architecture and uses 24-bit CAMAC-oriented control computers and PCs as operator consoles. The paper describes the timing system, the control of the RF system and magnet power supplies, beam diagnostic and interlock systems, etc. Application software provides the control over beam characteristics, automatic energy ramping and monitoring of the parameters of elements and systems. With the use of the SIBERIA control system the electron beam was accelerated in the linac up to 68 MeV on December 1, 1992, and on December 18, 1992, a circulating beam was generated in the 450 MeV booster ring. © 1994.

Authors: Mignacco M., Abrami A., Dequal Z.
Title: The Elettra beam line control system
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Softeco-Sismat, via S. Barborino 7/82, 16149 Genova, Italy; Sincrotrone-Trieste, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy; Digital-Equipment, via Giambellino 7, 35100 Padova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Mignacco, M., Softeco-Sismat, via S. Barborino 7/82, 16149 Genova, Italy; Abrami, A., Sincrotrone-Trieste, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy; Dequal, Z., Digital-Equipment, via Giambellino 7, 35100 Padova, Italy
Abstract: Elettra is a third generation Synchrotron Light Source located in Trieste (Italy). It consists of a full energy linac injector and a storage ring with beam energies between 1.5 and 2 GeV. The facility is scheduled to be operational by end 1993. For the whole project 22 beam lines from insertion devices are foreseen, each of them is composed of a large number of measurement and controls instruments, most of them embedded in intelligent devices; in addition each beam line can be considered unique compared to the others, having been designed to provide a different kind of synchrotron radiation. This results in a large not homogenous environment where more than 200,000 physical points have to be controlled. A joint team composed of Softeco Sismat and Digital Equipment has developed a fully automated beam line control system able to give full remote controls, with different kind of access rights, to beam line users and beam line specialists as well as a full integration with experiment control systems. © 1994.

Authors: Bulfone D.
Title: Status and prospects of the ELETTRA control system
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Sincrotrone Trieste, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bulfone, D., Sincrotrone Trieste, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy
Abstract: The ELETTRA third-generation synchrotron light source facility consists of a linac injector, a transfer line and a storage ring with electron beam energies between 1.5 and 2 GeV. The ELETTRA control system, which is still under development, is being operated for the commissioning of the whole plant. After an overall description of the control system, the first operational results are reported. The present activities and future developments foreseen for beam quality enhancement are reported. © 1994.

Authors: Jan G.J., Chen J.S., Wang C.J., Chen J., Lin T.F., Pan K.T., Lin G., Kuo C.H., Huang G., Kuo K.Y., Hu K.H., Hsu K.T., Ueng T.S., Luo G.H.
Title: Computer control and instrumentation system at the SRRC
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Jan, G.J., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Chen, J.S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Wang, C.J., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Chen, J., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Lin, T.F., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Pan, K.T., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Lin, G., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Kuo, C.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Huang, G., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Kuo, K.Y., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Hu, K.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Hsu, K.T., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Ueng, T.S., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Luo, G.H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan
Abstract: A graphic control system with a graphical user interface has been set up to control and monitor the equipment on the storage ring, the beam transport line and the full energy electron injector system. This control and instrumentation system was used to commission the storage ring and got successful results. The stored beam current exceeded 300 mA with a beam life time of more than 5 hours for the nominal beam current. The status of the control and instrumentation system is presented in this paper. © 1994.

Authors: Zhang J., Zhu Z.
Title: Novel heptamethine thiapyrylium infrared laser dyes of superior photostability tunable from 1.35 to 1.65 μm
Affiliations: East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200237, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, J., East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200237, China; Zhu, Z., East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200237, China
Abstract: Three new heptamethine thiapyrylium dyes containing a disubstituted amino group on the meso position in their bridged chain were investigated. 4.30 to 5.10% of the pump energy was converted to an intense infrared pulse with wavelength between 1.35 and 1.65 μm. The relation between lasing efficiency and dye concentration was also studied. These dyes show a remarkable photostability upon 1.06 μm laser excitation and excellent storage stability without degassing. © 1994.
Index Keywords: Absorption spectroscopy; Aromatic compounds; Laser tuning; Light emission; Molecular structure; Neodymium lasers; Pumping (laser); Q switching; Spectrophotometers; Stability; Dye concentration; Heptamethine thiapyrylium dyes; Infrared pulse; Laser excitation; Lasing efficiency; Photostability; Storage stability; Wavelength; Dye lasers

Authors: Cavagna G.A., Heglund N.C., Harry J.D., Mantovani M.
Title: Storage and release of mechanical energy by contracting frog muscle fibres.
Affiliations: Istituto di Fisiologia Umana, Università di Milano, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cavagna, G.A., Istituto di Fisiologia Umana, Università di Milano, Italy; Heglund, N.C., Istituto di Fisiologia Umana, Università di Milano, Italy; Harry, J.D., Istituto di Fisiologia Umana, Università di Milano, Italy; Mantovani, M., Istituto di Fisiologia Umana, Università di Milano, Italy
Abstract: 1. Stretching a contracting muscle leads to greater mechanical work being done during subsequent shortening by its contractile component; the mechanism of this enhancement is not known. 2. This mechanism has been investigated here by subjecting tetanized frog muscle fibres to ramp stretches followed by an isotonic release against a load equal to the maximum isometric tension, T(o). Shortening against T(o) was taken as direct evidence of an absolute increase in the ability to do work as a consequence of the previous stretch. 3. Ramp stretches (0.5‐8.6% sarcomere strain, confined to the plateau of the isometric tension‐length relationship) were given at different velocities of lengthening (0.03‐1.8 sarcomere lengths s‐1). Isotonic release to T(o) took place immediately after the end of the ramp, or 5‐800 ms after the end of the largest ramp stretches. The length changes taking place after release were measured both at the fibre end and on a tendon‐free segment of the fibre. The experiments were carried out at 4 and 14 degrees C. 4. After the elastic recoil of the undamped elastic elements, taking place during the fall in tension at the instant of the isotonic release, a well‐defined shortening took place against T(o) (transient shortening against T(o)). 5. The amplitude and time course of transient shortening against T(o) were similar at the fibre end and in the segment, indicating that it is due to a properly of the sarcomeres and not due to stress relaxation of the tendons. 6. Transient shortening against T(o) increased with sarcomere stretch amplitude up to about 8 nm per half‐sarcomere independent of stretch velocity. 7. When a short delay (5‐20 ms) was introduced between the end of the stretch and the isotonic release, the transient shortening against T(o) did not change; after longer time delays, the transient shortening against T(o) decreased in amplitude. 8. The velocity of transient shortening against T(o) increased with temperature with a temperature coefficient, Q10, of approximately 2.5. 9. It is suggested that transient shortening against T(o) results from the release of mechanical energy stored within the damped element of the cross‐bridges. The cross‐bridges are brought into a state of greater potential energy not only during the ramp stretch, but also immediately afterwards, during the first phase of stress relaxation. © 1994 The Physiological Society
Index Keywords: animal tissue; article; controlled study; energy metabolism; frog; muscle contraction; muscle force; muscle isometric contraction; muscle stretching; muscle tone; nonhuman; priority journal; sarcomere length; temperature sensitivity; Animal; Elasticity; Energy Metabolism; Isotonic Contraction; Kinetics; Models, Biological; Muscle, Skeletal; Rana temporaria; Sarcomeres; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't; Temperature; Time Factors

Authors: Shirvan A., Laskar O., Steiner-Mordoch S., Schuldiner S.
Title: Histidine-419 plays a role in energy coupling in the vesicular monoamine transporter from rat
Affiliations: Alexander Silberman Institute of Life Sciences, Hebrew University, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Shirvan, A., Alexander Silberman Institute of Life Sciences, Hebrew University, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel; Laskar, O., Alexander Silberman Institute of Life Sciences, Hebrew University, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel; Steiner-Mordoch, S., Alexander Silberman Institute of Life Sciences, Hebrew University, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel; Schuldiner, S., Alexander Silberman Institute of Life Sciences, Hebrew University, Jerusalem, 91904, Israel
Abstract: Vesicular monoamine transporters (VMAT) catalyze transport of serotonin, dopamine, epinephrine and norepinephrine into subcellular storage organelles in a variety of cells. Accumulation of the neurotransmitter depends on the proton electrochemical gradient across the organelle membrane and involves VMAT-mediated exchange of two lumenal protons with one cytoplasmic amine. It has been suggested in the past that His residues play a role in H+ movement or in its coupling to active transport in H+-symporters and antiporters. Indeed VMAT-mediated transport is inhibited by reagents specific for His residues. We have identified one His residue in VMAT1 from rat which is conserved in other vesicular neurotransmitter transporters. Mutagenesis of this His (H419) to either Arg or Cys completely inhibits [3H]serotonin and [3H]dopamine accumulation. Mutagenesis also inhibits other H+-dependent partial reactions of VMAT such as the acceleration of binding of the high affinity ligand reserpine, but does not inhibit the [3H]reserpine binding which is not dependent on H+ translocation. It is concluded that His-419 plays a role in energy coupling in r-VMAT1. © 1994.
Author Keywords: Antiporter; Drug resistance; Energy coupling; H+ transport; Histidine; Neurotransmitter transport; TEXANS

Authors: Asenchik O.D., Mogilny V.V.
Title: Model of reversible medium with resonatorless polarization testability
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Belarus State University, Dept. of Physics, F. Scoriny avenue 4, Minsk, 220050, Belarus
Authors with affiliations: Asenchik, O.D., Belarus State University, Dept. of Physics, F. Scoriny avenue 4, Minsk, 220050, Belarus; Mogilny, V.V., Belarus State University, Dept. of Physics, F. Scoriny avenue 4, Minsk, 220050, Belarus
Abstract: Model of reversible recording medium based on photochromic molecules dispersed in glassy polymeric matrix is considered. It is shown that electron energy migration and quenching of electron-excited photochroms can lead to bistability of photoconversion extent and absorption dichroism under linearly polarized excitation. Applications of the model to optical information processing are analyzed. © 1994 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Kharkats Y.I., Pleskov Y.V.
Title: Electrochemical storage of solar energy
Affiliations: A.N. Frumkin Institute of Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, 117071 Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kharkats, Y.I., A.N. Frumkin Institute of Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, 117071 Moscow, Russian Federation; Pleskov, Y.V., A.N. Frumkin Institute of Electrochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, 117071 Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Electrochemical methods of energy storage as applied to photovoltaic solar energy conversion are discussed. A state-of-the-art of the plants consisting of solar cells, electrolyzers, and/or secondary batteries is presented. Recent progress in the simulation of the plant performance as well as its design optimization is surveyed. © 1994 Elsevier Science B.V.

Authors: Chernitskii Ye.A., Slobozhanina Ye.I., Fedorovich I.Ye., Novitskaya G.P.
Title: Vesiculation of erythrocytes on their storage and its link with other processes in the cell
Affiliations: Institute of Photobiology, Belarus Academy of Sciences, Minsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Chernitskii, Ye.A., Institute of Photobiology, Belarus Academy of Sciences, Minsk, Russian Federation; Slobozhanina, Ye.I., Institute of Photobiology, Belarus Academy of Sciences, Minsk, Russian Federation; Fedorovich, I.Ye., Institute of Photobiology, Belarus Academy of Sciences, Minsk, Russian Federation; Novitskaya, G.P., Institute of Photobiology, Belarus Academy of Sciences, Minsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The activational energies of three processes in erythrocytes were measured on incubation in a phosphate buffer in the range 4-37 °C: ATP-dependent vesiculation, release of K+ ions from the cell and formation of methaemoglobin. It is shown that for the first two processes the Arrhenius graphs have identical characteristics: a break in the region 18 °C and Ea = 58 kJ/mole at t > 18 °C. From the findings it is concluded that the rate of ATP-dependent vesiculation of erythrocytes is determined by the permeability of their membranes for monovalent cations. It was established that for the appearance in the extracellular medium of methaemoglobin, the activational energy has a different value (Ea = 120 kJ/mole) although at 37 °C the kinetics of this process is similar to that of vesiculation. The relationship between the processes considered and the interconnection between the ATP-dependent and the spontaneous vesicle are discussed. © 1994.

Authors: Bykadorov V.F.
Title: Power relationships associated with the discharge of a capacitive energy storage on a faulty cable line
Authors with affiliations: Bykadorov, V.F.
Abstract: A general view of power component distribution for a capacitive energy storage discharging on a faulty cable is determined. The quantitative relationships between the energy of the storage device and the energy of shock wave formation at the point of cable damage are derived. © 1995.
Author Keywords: cable line; calculation; Capacitive energy storage; discharge

Authors: Miyahara Y.
Title: Slow rise and negative feedback for stabilizing the radiation power of the storage ring free electron laser
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: JAERI-RIKEN SPring-8 Project Team, Honkomagome, 2-28-8, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyahara, Y., JAERI-RIKEN SPring-8 Project Team, Honkomagome, 2-28-8, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113, Japan
Abstract: Using FEL power equations definitely determined for a storage ring FEL, a method of stabilizing radiation power is discussed. It is shown in a computer simulation that a slow rise and a negative feedback of radiation power can successfully stabilize the radiation power. In this simulation the causes of unstable oscillation of the radiation power such as a rapid increase of the power in the initial stage of the FEL lasing and a sensitive response of the power to fluctuations in the gain and the energy spread of electron beam at a resonant frequency are taken into account. © 1994.

Authors: Beebe E., Liljeby L., Pikin A., Björkhage M., Engström Å., Paal A.
Title: Increased ion intensity and reliability of the Stockholm electron beam ion source
Affiliations: Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Beebe, E., Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Liljeby, L., Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Pikin, A., Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Björkhage, M., Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Engström, Å., Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Paal, A., Manne Siegbahn Laboratory, Stockholm University, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: The electron beam ion source, CRYSIS, produces highly charged ions for injection into the heavy ion storage ring - CRYRING at MSL, as well as low energy atomic physics experiments and the Stockholm-Mainz Penning trap recently installed at MSL. CRYSIS has produced ions up to Ar18+ and 136Xe52+. Pulsed beams of Ar13+ ions 60 μs in duration have been injected into CRYRING via an RFQ and ions of charge up to 136Xe44+ have been used in atomic physics experiments with pulse duration 10-250 ms. A vacuum separation of the cryostat and ionization volumes has been made. Temperature control and measurement of internal electrodes have increased the gas injection efficiency and reduced the memory effect associated with a cryogenic EBIS. External ion injection has been added as an alternative to neutral gas injection for introducing the species to be ionized to high charge states. Monitoring of the radio frequency noise signal with a spectrum analyzer has aided in the propagation of quiet, high current (450 mA) dc electron beams. These quiet electron beams have been used to produce extracted ion pulses of higher intensities than in previous operation.

Authors: Sharrock M.P.
Title: Time dependence of switching fields in magnetic recording media (invited)
Affiliations: Digital Media Laboratory, 3M, 236-3C-02, 3M Center, St. Paul, MN 55144-1000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sharrock, M.P., Digital Media Laboratory, 3M, 236-3C-02, 3M Center, St. Paul, MN 55144-1000, United States
Abstract: Coercivity and other experimental measures of switching field depend upon the time scale of interest. This time-scale dependence has practical importance in magnetic recording, because the effective time scales of writing and storage are very different. A simple model accounts for the time-scale dependence of coercivity in terms of the thermally assisted crossing of an energy barrier whose height is reduced by the applied field. Fitting this barrier-crossing model to data provides an estimate of the volume that must switch magnetization direction in overcoming the barrier. The assumption of Stoner-Wohlfarth reversal is used to obtain an initial estimate of the dependence of the barrier height on the field. With some adjustment of the resulting energy expression, the model gives good agreement between calculated switching volume and actual particle volume for advanced recording particles of three types: acicular oxide, acicular metal, and barium ferrite platelets. The model can be used to estimate minimum practical particle volumes for use in magnetic recording. Switching due to fields nearly perpendicular to the particle's preferred axis, sometimes used as a measure of the anisotropy field, also shows the effect of thermal assistance. The switching volume determined from such measurements, like that from coercivity, approximates the particle volume.

Authors: O'Sullivan J.A., Porter D.G., Indeck R.S., Muller M.W.
Title: Recording medium properties and capacity bounds
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130-4899, United States
Authors with affiliations: O'Sullivan, J.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130-4899, United States; Porter, D.G., Department of Electrical Engineering, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130-4899, United States; Indeck, R.S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130-4899, United States; Muller, M.W., Department of Electrical Engineering, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130-4899, United States
Abstract: The effect of such medium properties as magnetic unit size, film thickness, and strength of anisotropy, dipolar, and exchange interactions on the storage capacity limit of a thin-film recording medium is investigated. Relationships are derived for media with different properties that have equivalent capacity. The physically realizable range of material properties and their effect on the capacity bound are explored. Results on edge effects for capacity bound computations are presented. The results indicate that media for which anisotropy is the dominant source of magnetic energy have the greatest potential for information storage.

Authors: Kuhlmann P., Anlauf J.K.
Title: The number of metastable states in the projection rule neural network
Source title: Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and General
Affiliations: Phys. Inst., Julius-Maximilians-Universitat, Wurzburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kuhlmann, P., Phys. Inst., Julius-Maximilians-Universitat, Wurzburg, Germany; Anlauf, J.K.
Abstract: We calculate the direct average ((N)) of the number of metastable states in the projection rule neural network by means of the saddle-point method. ((N)) is obtained as a function of the Hamming distance g to a given pattern, stability gamma and energy E. The critical storage capacity of the model is calculated. The examination of the energy dependence of ((N)) leads to lower bounds for the energies of the spin-glass states.

Authors: Fajardo M.E., Tam S., Thompson T.L., Cordonnier M.E.
Title: Spectroscopy and reactive dynamics of atoms trapped in molecular hydrogen matrices
Affiliations: Propulsion Directorate, RKFE, Phillips Laboratory, CA 93524-7680, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fajardo, M.E., Propulsion Directorate, RKFE, Phillips Laboratory, CA 93524-7680, United States; Tam, S., Propulsion Directorate, RKFE, Phillips Laboratory, CA 93524-7680, United States; Thompson, T.L., Propulsion Directorate, RKFE, Phillips Laboratory, CA 93524-7680, United States; Cordonnier, M.E., Propulsion Directorate, RKFE, Phillips Laboratory, CA 93524-7680, United States
Abstract: Solid molecular hydrogens (SMH, i.e. H2 and its isotopomers) are fascinating host matrices for investigations of condensed phase photophysics and reactive dynamics. Spectroscopic studies in SMH matrices should elucidate the roles of quantum effects on the structure, energetics, and dynamics of guest/host systems. Reactive dynamics studies involving atomic guests provide opportunities to interrogate some of the most fundamental prototypical chemical reactions; the cryogenic solid environment emphasizing even subtle features of the relevant potential energy surfaces, as well as the influence of many-body interactions. We present a summary of previous and ongoing research into impurity atom (H, Li, B, C, N, O, Mg, Al) doped SMH, including our own new data supporting the trapping of Al, B, N, and O atoms. We develop our discussion in the context of a practical application of this research, and hope that ultimately such studies will lead to improvements in energy storage and rocket propulsion technologies. © 1994.

Authors: Tokita K.
Title: The replica-symmetry-breaking solution of the Hopfield model at zero temperature: Critical storage capacity and frozen field distribution
Source title: Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and General
Affiliations: Dept. of Pure and Appl. Sci., Tokyo Univ., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tokita, K., Dept. of Pure and Appl. Sci., Tokyo Univ., Japan
Abstract: The full replica-symmetry-breaking (RSB) solution of the Hopfield model at zero temperature (T=0) is investigated. By using the RSB scheme by de Dominicis, Gabay and Orland, a free-energy functional in the so-called Sompolinsky gauge and variational equations are formulated. The resulting equations are conveniently defined for numerical analysis since a singularity at T=0 is formally avoided. Elaborate numerical analyses provide a corrected storage capacity, order parameter functions and the frozen field distribution both in the spin-glass phase and the ferromagnetic retrieval phase.

Authors: Morisue T., Yajima T.
Title: A method of increasing magnetic energy of superconducting magnetic energy storage
Affiliations: Nagoya University, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-01, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Morisue, T., Nagoya University, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-01, Japan; Yajima, T., Nagoya University, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-01, Japan
Abstract: A solenoidal-type superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) using ferromagnetic material as an exterior magnetic circuit can store about 30% more magnetic energy than that using no ferromagnetic material. The amount of pure iron needed is 3.4 ton/MJ or 12 000 ton/MWH for the operating magnetic flux density of the solenoid between 4 and 5 T. Low grade ferromagnetic material containing more than 50% pure iron may be available for the SMES.

Authors: Dhandapani Sivakumar, Ogot Madara M.
Title: Modeling of a leg system to illustrate the feasibility of energy recovery in walking machines
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Design Engineering Division (Publication) DE
Affiliations: State Univ of New Jersey, Piscataway, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dhandapani, Sivakumar, State Univ of New Jersey, Piscataway, United States; Ogot, Madara M., State Univ of New Jersey, Piscataway, United States
Abstract: A key consideration in the design of walking machines is the minimization of energy consumption. Two main avenues of research have been pursued in the past (a) finding an optimal gait which reduces energy consumption or (b) the employment of energy storage devices to recover energy from one step to the next. This study follows the latter approach, which has hitherto concentrated on hopping machines. Several practical design considerations for energy recovery in multi-legged walking machines, where a stance phase prevents the immediate recovery of energy from one step to the next, are investigated. Two schemes, passive and active locking, are introduced. The simplified models presented serve to illustrate the feasibility of these schemes.
Index Keywords: Biped locomotion; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Machine design; Mathematical models; Optimization; Energy consumption; Energy recovery; Hopping machines; Walking machines; Locomotives

Authors: Kaurila T., Saisa L., Vayrynen J.
Title: Resonant photoemission from iron films on copper
Affiliations: Lab. of Mater. Sci., Turku Univ., Finland
Authors with affiliations: Kaurila, T., Lab. of Mater. Sci., Turku Univ., Finland; Saisa, L., Lab. of Mater. Sci., Turku Univ., Finland; Vayrynen, J., Lab. of Mater. Sci., Turku Univ., Finland
Abstract: The resonant photoemission of iron films on copper has been examined near the 3p to 3d excitation threshold using synchrotron radiation from the MAX storage ring. Resonant profiles are presented in the photon energy range 46-150 eV. Special attention has been paid to the position of the destructive minimum before the enhancing resonance. The results reveal that the interaction between the valence bands of iron and copper is weak in terms of autoionization. Moreover, our data do not support the conclusion about the subthreshold Auger emission reported earlier for iron.
Index Keywords: Auger emission; Autoionization; De excitation channels; Destructive minimum; Photon energy; Threshold energy; Valence band; Band structure; Copper; Ferromagnetic resonance; Interfaces (materials); Ionization of solids; Iron; Metallic superlattices; Phase transitions; Photoemission; Photons; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Metallic films

Authors: Herrmann K.-H., Rau W.D., Sikeler R.
Title: On-line image readout in CTEM
Source title: Proceedings - Annual Meeting, Microscopy Society of America
Affiliations: Univ of Tuebingen, Tuebingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Herrmann, K.-H., Univ of Tuebingen, Tuebingen, Germany; Rau, W.D., Univ of Tuebingen, Tuebingen, Germany; Sikeler, R., Univ of Tuebingen, Tuebingen, Germany
Abstract: Yttrium aluminum garnet (YAG)-fiber plate-charged coupled devices (CCD), YAG-lens optics-CCD and YAG-micro objective CCD are investigated assuming the CCD TEK 1024/2048 but differing both in optics and thickness of the aluminized YAG single crystal. A table showing the number of electron-hole pairs, detection quantum efficiency, storage limit for saturation and storage limit for 50% decay is presented. The adaptability of CCD to different electron energies using the proper light optical transfer element is inferred.

Authors: Holtz Joachim, Stamm Michael, Stielau Oskar
Title: Performance of high-power GTOs operated as fast turn-off thyristors
Affiliations: Univ of Wuppertal, Wuppertal, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Holtz, Joachim, Univ of Wuppertal, Wuppertal, Germany; Stamm, Michael, Univ of Wuppertal, Wuppertal, Germany; Stielau, Oskar, Univ of Wuppertal, Wuppertal, Germany
Abstract: The series resonant dc link inverter is an attractive circuit topology for interfacing a Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) inductance with the utility. The principle of Zero Current Switching (ZCS) ensures low switching losses at high switching frequency, provides power factor correction capability, and reduces the harmonic line currents. For applications at high power level, the use of GTOs as semiconductor switches is mandatory. High-power devices behave differently at switching than the smaller GTOs treated in previous publications. The device losses in the kiloampere range are reduced by gate-assisted forward recovery. The dynamic performance of different power switch topologies is experimentally evaluated.

Abstract: In an effort to model the SDC data acquisition system, the DAQSim simulation effort was formed. This project used the MODSIM II simulation language to represent the flow of data from front-end models through an event builder to a processing farm, with attached storage. Trigger communications and event data flow control were fully modeled. The purpose of DAQSim was to determine or confirm the numbers, sizes, and speeds of the various buffers, links, processors, etc. in the data acquisition system, with better accuracy than spread-sheet estimations. This paper describes the history of the effort, the reasoning behind the key decisions, and state of the project since the SSC termination. All of the simulation models, documentation, and results are available to others for future studies.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Computer simulation languages; Computer software; Computer systems; Data acquisition; Decision making; High energy physics; Nuclear instrumentation; Software engineering; Spreadsheets; System program documentation; Data acquisition system; Event data flow control; Solenoidal detector collaboration; Superconducting super collider; Trigger communications; Computer simulation

Box 131, Cheongryang, Seoul, South Korea; Choi, S.S., Division of Electronics and Information Technology, Korea Institute of Science and Technology, P. O. Box 131, Cheongryang, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: Long optical pulses have been generated in a XeCl excimer laser by using a simple capacitor-transfer discharge circuit consisting of storage capacitors charged at 26 kV and discharged through the electrodes, tightly coupled to the variable small peaking capacitors. By adjusting the [HCl] concentration and capacitance ratios, the typical pulse duration (20 ns) is stretched up to 150 ns (full width at half-maximum). The transfer behaviors of the pulse duration from short pulse to long pulse are presented and analyzed extensively by measuring the discharge voltage profile, output energy, overall efficiency, optical waveform, and pulse duration, as functions of [HCl] concentration and capacitance ratios. © 1994 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Experimental model of a harmonic neutralised statcon
Affiliations: Aston Univ, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hill, J.E., Aston Univ, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Chileshe, C.M., Aston Univ, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Boardman, S.M., Aston Univ, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Westrick, M.P., Aston Univ, Birmingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: Reactive power compensation in power transmission is usually achieved through the use of static V Ar compensators (SVCs). Alternative schemes called advanced SVCs (ASVCs) or statcons have been proposed. These use power electronics to facilitate a reduction in the size of the energy stores, compared with conventional SVCs, at the expense of significant harmonic generation. These harmonics can be eliminated by multiple inverter connections and the use of zig-zag transformers. This paper outlines the experimental arrangement and early results for a 24 pulse statcon.

Authors: Aceves Salvador M.
Title: Analysis and optimization of an adsorption air conditioner for electric vehicle applications
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Aceves, Salvador M., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Abstract: This paper shows an analysis of the applicability of an adsorption system for electric vehicle (EV) air conditioning. Adsorption systems are designed and optimized to provide the required cooling for four combinations of vehicle characteristics and driving cycles. The resulting adsorption systems are compared with vapor compression air conditioners that can satisfy the cooling load. The objective function is the overall system weight, which includes the cooling system weight and the weight of the battery necessary to provide energy for air conditioner operation. The system with the minimum overall weight is considered to be the best. The results show the optimum values of all the variables, as well as temperatures and amounts adsorbed, for the adsorption and desorption processes. The results indicate that, for the conditions analyzed in this paper, vapor compression air conditioners are superior to adsorption systems, not only because they are lighter, but also because they have a higher COP and are more compact.
Index Keywords: Adsorption; Coolants; Cooling; Cooling systems; Desorption; Electric vehicles; Energy storage; Heat exchangers; Heat transfer; Heating; Specific heat; Thermal conductivity; Adsorption air conditioner; Cooling load; Heat transfer coefficient; Mass flow rate; Vapor compression air conditioners; Air conditioning

Authors: Mueller C.
Title: Insights on radiological risks of U.S. department of energy radioactive waste management alternatives in the environmental management programmatic environmental impact statement
Source title: SERA, Safety Engineering and Risk Analysis
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mueller, C., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: A Facility Accident Analysis (1) was performed in support of the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) Environmental Management (EM) Programmatic Environmental Impact Statement (PEIS). It used an integrated risk-based approach (2) to allow risk comparisons of EM PEIS strategies for consolidating the storage and treatment of wastes at different DOE sites throughout the country. This approach was developed in accordance with the latest National Environmental Protection Act (NEPA) compliance guidance from DOE (3), which calls for consideration of a spectrum of accident scenarios that could occur in implementing the various actions evaluated in the EM PEIS. This paper discusses our insights with respect to the likely importance of the relative radiological risks to human health of the different treatment technologies, waste management facilities and operations, and waste consolidation strategies considered in the EM PEIS.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Environmental impact; Hazardous materials; Health hazards; Management; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Standards; Environmental management; Programmatic environmental impact statement; Radioactive waste management; Radiological risks; Risk assessment

Source title: Electrical Contacts, Proceedings of the Annual Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts
Affiliations: Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Dervos, C.T., Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece
Abstract: I-V curves of a well documented device was used as a tool in examining the validity of the asperity contact model and the implications of the interfacial layer, the axial contact force, the interfacial field and the relative permittivity of the surrounding space, on the injection process. Investigation was carried out under UHV environment using cleaved silicon samples. The applied axial forces were controlled by electromagnets which displaced stainless steel electrodes to contact the prepared Si sample. The significance of the interfacial fields was examined using Si and GaAs samples. The effect of the relative permittivity of the surrounding space was studied through application of sinusoidal 50 Hy high current densities both in the laboratory and UHV environment. Results obtained are in good correlation with the expected implications of the studied factors.

Authors: Alakula Mats
Title: Vector controlled AC/AC converters with a minimum of energy storage
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Lund Inst of Technology, Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Alakula, Mats, Lund Inst of Technology, Lund, Sweden
Abstract: Increasing use of power electronic equipment causes an increasing harmonic load on the line. Regulations acknowledge this problem with limits for this harmonic load, expected to make it impossible to use directly connected diode rectifiers as in conventional frequency converters. An alternative solution is selfcommutated rectifiers. In this paper a control strategy for a frequency converter with selfcommutated line side is discussed, in order to minimize the necessary dc link energy storage. It is shown that synchronized modulation of both the line side and load side inverters together with load information feed forward from load side to line side current controllers has the potential to minimize the need of energy storage. A part from minimized energy storage, higher power rating, bidirectional power flow and active filter capabilitys are results of the topology discussed. Simulations and measurements are presented.

Abstract: In conducting its review of the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) license application, the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission staff will rely, not only on the information presented in the application, but on a foundation consisting of its ongoing work during the pre-license consultation phase. Within the NRC program, the NRC staff is working in many different areas to develop its review capability. This paper provides an overview of the work presently being carried out at the NRC to accomplish its mission in the high-level waste repository program.

Authors: Vlahakis John G., Palabrica Ricardo J.
Title: Avoiding dual regulation of the Civilian Radioactive Waste Management program
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vlahakis, John G., Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Palabrica, Ricardo J., Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: The Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (RW) has successfully negotiated the issuance of a Department of Energy (DOE) Headquarters Order that provides for exemption of RW from certain DOE directives. This exemption assures precedence of Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) requirements in radiation protection, nuclear safety (including quality assurance), and safeguards and security of nuclear materials. This Order is necessary to avoid the unwarranted cost and potential confusion resulting from dual regulation of RW facilities and activities by DOE and NRC. Development of this Order involved a systematic review of applicable DOE directives and NRC requirements to identify potential overlaps and duplication when applied to the RW program. Following this review and extensive negotiations with appropriate DOE organizations responsible for directives development, this Order was issued as HQ 1321.1 on December 22, 1993.

Authors: Sundbom Todd A., Ebeling Jerry A.
Title: Increasing capacity sales with inlet air cooling
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, International Gas Turbine Institute (Publication) IGTI
Affiliations: Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sundbom, Todd A., Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States; Ebeling, Jerry A., Burns & McDonnell Engineering Co, Kansas City, United States
Abstract: Rising electrical demands have created a growing need for low cost peaking capacity in the power utility industry. Cogeneration facilities are supplying an ever increasing portion of this capacity due to the economic benefits of electrical generation combined with steam production. Predominantly these facilities use combustion turbines. The problem with combustion turbine based capacity is that the highest electrical peak demands often occur during times of high ambient temperature. High ambient temperatures result in substantially lower combustion turbine output from ISO rating. Combustion turbine inlet air cooling can reverse this degradation and increase electrical output by 20% to 30% with a constant or even increased steam production. Cooling combustion turbine inlet air using ice thermal energy storage can increase the peaking capability for between $150/kW and $250/kW. This paper discusses the economic and flexibility advantages of combustion turbine inlet air cooling based on the authors' experience with two major inlet air cooling installations.
Index Keywords: Cogeneration plants; Electric load distribution; Electric load management; Electric power generation; Heat storage; High temperature effects; Industrial economics; Intake systems; Performance; Productivity; Combustion turbine; Inlet air cooling; Gas turbines

Authors: Laouadi Abdelaziz, Lacroix Marcel, Galanis Nicolas
Title: Thermal performance of a planar latent heat storage unit with electric heat sources
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Universite de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Laouadi, Abdelaziz, Universite de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada; Lacroix, Marcel, Universite de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada; Galanis, Nicolas, Universite de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada
Abstract: A one-dimensional conduction model has been used to study the cyclic performance of a planar latent heat storage unit. An electrical energy source embedded in the PCM is employed for heat storage. The unit is discharged to the surroundings by radiation and/or convection. Results show that for a given thickness and heat transfer coefficient, melting of the entire PCM mass is achieved only if a threshold value of the electrical power source is exceeded. As the intensity of the power source increases, the temperature in the unit increases while the charge period becomes shorter and the discharge period increases. The heat losses from the unit reach a peak at the end of the charge period and depend mostly on the convection coefficient.
Index Keywords: Electric heating elements; Heat convection; Heat losses; Heat radiation; Mathematical models; Thermal cycling; Planar heat storage unit; Heat storage

Authors: Kramer A., Sabatini M., Canegallo R., Chinosi M., Rolandi P.L., Zabberoni P.
Title: Flash-based programmable nonlinear capacitor for switched-capacitor implementations of neural networks
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Kramer, A., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Milan, Italy; Sabatini, M., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Milan, Italy; Canegallo, R., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Milan, Italy; Chinosi, M., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Milan, Italy; Rolandi, P.L., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Milan, Italy; Zabberoni, P., SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, Milan, Italy
Abstract: The use of Flash devices for both analog storage and analog computation can result in highly efficient switched-capacitor implementations of neural networks. The standard Flash device suffers from severe limitations in this application due to relatively large parasitic overlap capacitances. This paper introduces the computational concept, circuit and architecture we are exploring as well as a novel Flash-based programmable nonlinear capacitor with much improved charge domain characteristics for our application. These devices are demonstrated in a novel circuit consisting of only two devices and capable of computing a 5-bit absolute-value-of-difference at an energy consumption of less than 1 pJ.
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Energy utilization; Neural networks; Nonvolatile storage; PROM; Switching circuits; Flash based programmable nonlinear capacitor; Switched capacitor; Capacitors

Authors: Masa P., Hoen K., Wallinga H.
Title: 70 input, 20 nanosecond pattern classifier
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Neural Networks - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Univ of Twente, Enschede, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Masa, P., Univ of Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; Hoen, K., Univ of Twente, Enschede, Netherlands; Wallinga, H., Univ of Twente, Enschede, Netherlands
Abstract: A CMOS neural network integrated circuit is discussed, which was designed for very high speed applications. This full-custom, mixed analog-digital chip implements a fully connected feedforward neural network with 70 inputs, 6 hidden layer neurons and one output neuron. The neurons perform inner product operation and have sigmoid-like activation function. The 70 network inputs and the neural signal processing are analog, the synaptic weights are digitally programmable with 5 bit (4 bits + sign) precision. The synaptic weights are stored on on-chip static RAM cells. The combination of analog and digital techniques results unique computing power with ease of use. Programming can easily be performed with the help of a spreadsheet or other suitable interface program from a PC. The resolution of the input signals is mainly determined by the signal to noise ratio which lies typically between 8-12 bits. Therefore the equivalent input bandwidth can be as high as 28-42 Gbits/second. The system is designed for very high speed vector classification and the feasibility of a single chip neural network photon trigger for nuclear research is shown. Because of the fully parallel architecture and the fast analog signal processing the network achieves unique computing performance and classifies up to 70 dimensional vectors within 20 nanoseconds, performing 20 billion (2 1010) multiply-and-add operations per second. The circuit occupies 10×9mm2 silicon area with 1.5μm CMOS process and dissipates only 1W at 5V supply.
Index Keywords: Analog to digital conversion; CMOS integrated circuits; Computer architecture; Computer software; Energy dissipation; Parallel processing systems; Personal computers; Random access storage; Semiconducting silicon; Signal processing; Signal to noise ratio; Vectors; Analog signal processing; High speed vector classification; Pattern classifier; Sigmoid like activation function; Static random access memory; Neural networks

Abstract: The design, manufacture and testing of a composite material flywheel for kinetic energy storage are described. The flywheel consists of two graphite epoxy interference assembled rings and inner metallic ring for magnetic suspension and power transfer. The composite rings were manufactured using a wet filament winding process. To evaluate the composite material properties, acid digestion and digital imaging tests were used to determine void content and volume fraction, and NOL tension tests were used to determine tensile strength and the stiffness in the fiber direction.

Authors: Lou Kang-Ning, Perez Ronald A.
Title: On the artificial neural networks for structural analysis
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Natl Chung Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lou, Kang-Ning, Natl Chung Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan; Perez, Ronald A., Natl Chung Cheng Univ, Chia-Yi, Taiwan
Abstract: This work is concerned with the employment of the continuous Hopfield network and the continuous bidirectional associative memory (BAM) system, in order to establish two novel methods for structural analysis. The development of these two novel techniques is, actually, based on the analogous relationship resulted from comparing the energy functions of the above two models with that of the structural displacement method (i.e. the so-called stiffness matrix method), respectively. Several experimental examples related to structural deformation are also used to illustrate the superiority of the BAM-based neural networks to the other traditional numerical methods and the Hopfield model, especially for the case of large dimensional stiffness matrices. Furthermore, classical numerical methods do not have the characteristics of parallel computation as the artificial neural networks do.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Associative storage; Computer aided analysis; Deformation; Mathematical models; Neural networks; Numerical methods; Stiffness matrix; Bidirectional associative memory (BAM) system; Hopfield network; Structural displacement method; Structural analysis

Abstract: At the South Clive, Utah, site, Envirocare of Utah, Inc., (Envirocare), currently operates a commercial low-activity, low-level radioactive waste facility, a mixed waste RCRA Part B storage and disposal facility, and an 11e.(2) disposal facility. Envirocare is also in the process of constructing our Mixed Waste Treatment Facility. As the nation's first and only commercial treatment and disposal facility for such waste, the information presented in this segment will provide insight into our current and prospective operations.

Authors: Malcolm Scott A., Anandalingam G.
Title: Decision support system for evaluating non-utility investment in electricity production
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man and Cybernetics
Affiliations: Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Malcolm, Scott A., Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States; Anandalingam, G., Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States
Abstract: This paper describes C-STEM (Cogeneration and Storage Technology Evaluation Model), a menu-driven, macro-controlled Lotus123 spreadsheet based model for evaluating the economics and load impacts of electricity production by the customers of an electric utility. The main purpose of the decision support system described is to evaluate one of the newest and most promising DSM strategies: self-generation of electricity by customers that allows utilities to clip peaks and fill valleys in the loads that they would otherwise face. Economic benefits are possible by exploiting the difference in cost between electricity generated in peak and off-peak periods. We have incorporated a heuristic within the decision support system that obtains a near-optimal design of an electric-thermal storage system.

Authors with affiliations: Wetzel, H., Aachen Univ of Technology, Aachen, Germany; Bonert, R., Aachen Univ of Technology, Aachen, Germany; Dawson, F.P., Aachen Univ of Technology, Aachen, Germany
Abstract: A new technology may provide capacitors to build serial hybrid vehicle drives using a capacitor as energy storage device instead of a battery. This paper discusses the required power converter configurations for such a drive system. The main factors and parameters influencing the converter design will be discussed. The paper presents in detail two selected configurations. The configurations are discussed for two scenarios, one for a capacitor with lower voltage and one for higher voltage. A design example is provided to compare the proposed configurations.

Title: Economic operation of a power system with a significant amount of controllable load
Affiliations: Technische Hochschule, Leipzig, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gottschalk, H., Technische Hochschule, Leipzig, Germany; Heine, S., Technische Hochschule, Leipzig, Germany; Fox, B., Technische Hochschule, Leipzig, Germany; Neumann, I., Technische Hochschule, Leipzig, Germany
Abstract: This paper describes a system for load forecast and short-term planning of controllable load-groups in the time range up to 24 hours. The capabilities of this solution are characterized by: Forecast of the non-controlled load by means of neural nets (NN), Prediction of the controlled load by means of an adaptive fuzzy system, Optimisation of the scheduled controllable electrical storage heatings, Forming of the total load curve by aggregation of the forecast of the non-controlled load and the optimised schedule of the controlled load, Several data manipulation, diagnostic, and data display capabilities. Objectives are: 1. To achieve high accuracy of the forecast of the total load, which is required for the economic operation of electric utilities, 2. To avoid peak loads by an optimum embedding of the controlled loads in valleys of the load curve, and should be reached by the integration of new knowledge based techniques in the energy management system.

Abstract: This paper addresses the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission's requirements for the dry storage and transportation of spent fuel, focusing on how the performance standards differ between storage and transportation. Title: New learning algorithm for bidirectional associative memory neural networks

Affiliations: Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Khorasani, K., Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada; Cuffaro, A., Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada; Grigoriu, T., Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: A new algorithm is proposed for improving the learning capability of a Bidirectional Associative Memory (BAM) neural networks. The proposed approach, unlike other methods in the literature, is not based on minimizing the energy function of the stored patterns. The proposed technique is the generalization of an auto-associative learning algorithm that has been developed for Hopfield networks. The BAM network is extremely robust to noise, almost guaranteeing perfect recall of all stored patterns with as much as 49% noise. The learning algorithm when applied to a number of test patterns used by other researchers provided satisfying results.

Abstract: A hybrid power plant generation has been designed with the aim to construct a laboratory facility that allows the physical simulation of an isolated grid. The plant is supplied by a combined power system utilising multiple renewable energy sources including Wind, Photo voltaic, and also Diesel. The control of such a system requires also the regulation of a dump load, that is needed to maintain at a fixed value the grid frequency when the energy generated by the renewable sources exceeds the load demand. In this paper the regulation of the dump load by a microcontroller is faced. Several typical transients are simulated in order to test the validity of the proposed approach, and realise the actual dump load controller.

Authors: Endoh T., Shimizu K., Iizuka H., Watanabe S., Masuoka F.
Title: New write/erase method for the reduction of the stress-induced leakage current based on the deactivation of step tunneling sites for flash memories
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting
Affiliations: Toshiba R & D Cent, Kawasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Endoh, T., Toshiba R & D Cent, Kawasaki, Japan; Shimizu, K., Toshiba R & D Cent, Kawasaki, Japan; Iizuka, H., Toshiba R & D Cent, Kawasaki, Japan; Watanabe, S., Toshiba R & D Cent, Kawasaki, Japan; Masuoka, F., Toshiba R & D Cent, Kawasaki, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes a new write/erase method to improve the read disturb characteristics by means of drastically reducing the stress-induced leakage current in the tunnel oxide. With the proposed write/erase method, the degradation of the read disturb life time after 106 write/erase cycles can be drastically reduced to 50% in comparison with the conventional bipolarity write/erase method. The features of the proposed write/erase method are as follows: (1) applying an additional pulse to the control gate just after a completion of the write/erase operation, (2) the voltage of the additional pulse is higher than that of a control gate in a read operation, and lower enough than that of a control gate in a write operation. (3) the polarity of the voltage is the same as that of the control gate voltage in the read operation. This proposed write/erase method is based on the deactivation mechanism of the leakage current, which will be discussed in detail in this paper.
Index Keywords: Degradation; Electric field effects; Electron energy levels; Electron tunneling; Leakage currents; Nonvolatile storage; Oxides; Polarization; PROM; Stresses; Control gate; Electron injection; Electronically erasable programmable read only memory (EEPROM); Tunnel oxide; Write/erase method; Data storage equipment

Authors: Feldman David Lewis
Title: Using planning scenarios for DOE radioactive waste management: The case of the Advanced Neutron Source
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Feldman, David Lewis, Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, United States
Abstract: The Advanced Neutron Source (ANS) is a proposed Department of Energy (DOE) research reactor to be built at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL) in Tennessee. It will be a basic materials research tool and a major source of radioisotopes. ANS will generate liquid, solid and gaseous radioactive wastes that will be managed by DOE's waste management system. This system is overburdened by R&D, production, and environmental restoration activities. Moreover, its future is beset by major uncertainties that affect capacity assurance for new waste generators. To resolve these uncertainties, planners should employ a `scenario' approach to waste management that encompasses technical and political variables affecting future capacity planning. After discussing how this approach was used in the environmental report prepared for ANS in compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969, I examine its significance for DOE waste management.

Abstract: Proceeding from an analysis of the present energy system of Lithuania, the prospects for economic development and its main influencing parameters are investigated. Comprehensive data on the actual situation of the primary energy supply, the conversion into intermediate forms and the final consumption is provided, based on latest official information. For the next steps towards a market economy, the official energy pathway for Lithuania is analysed and additional projections are given on the basis of a macroeconomic model for the transition period. Special emphasis is put on the influences of pricing policy and structural changes in the energy sector.

Abstract: In the SINUS family of pulsed, high current electron beam accelerators [1], the energy stored within a coaxial forming line (usually oil-insulated) is delivered to a load by means of a high voltage pressurized spark gap switch. For better matching to the load, a transmission line having a nonuniform wave impedance may be included between the switch and the load. Numerical simulation of the system described above has been performed with the use of 2.5D version of 2.5 & 3D, fully electromagnetic PIC-code KARAT [2]. Geometrical parameters of several SINUS accelerators were used. Actual spatial configurations of the gas switch were considered, but the time dependent spark resistance between the electrodes was included as a variable. The obtained results are compared with actual pulse shapes from experiments. Conclusions are drawn about how the spark resistance as the function of time effects the pulse observed.
Index Keywords: Codes (symbols); Electric impedance; Electric lines; Electric resistance; Electrodes; Energy storage; Mathematical models; Coaxial forming lines; Pulse generation; Spark resistance; Particle accelerators

Authors: Peterson G.G., Rostoker N., Tahsiri H.
Title: Spin control of the Rayleigh-Taylor instability in a dense z-pinch
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Univ of California, Irvine, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peterson, G.G., Univ of California, Irvine, United States; Rostoker, N., Univ of California, Irvine, United States; Tahsiri, H., Univ of California, Irvine, United States
Abstract: Imploded, annular z-pinches are always subject to the Rayleigh-Taylor instability, the growth of which is determined by the initial perturbations and the linear growth rate γ = √gk where g is the acceleration and k is the wave number. By imparting a spin to the plasma, the initial perturbations can be greatly reduced. Furthermore, the centripetal acceleration will reduce the growth rate at the end of the implosion. This idea could benefit pinch schemes that require uniform compressions, such as x-ray laser and fusion programs that are based on staged pinches and pinches with trapped magnetic fields. A summary of the spin concept is presented along with a zero-dimension implosion analysis for pinches with imparted spins and trapped magnetic fields.
Index Keywords: Argon; Diodes; Electric generators; Electron energy levels; Ionization; Streak cameras; X ray cameras; X rays; Filtered x ray diodes; Gas puff implosion; Inductive storage generators; X ray pinhole camera; Gases

Authors: Whittenberger J.D.
Title: Tensile properties of haynes alloy 230 and inconel 617 after long exposures to LiF-22CaF2 and vacuum at 1093 K
Source title: Journal of Materials Engineering and Performance
Affiliations: NASALewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Whittenberger, J.D., NASALewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States
Abstract: As a part of a study of a space-based thermal energy storage system utilizing the latent heat of fusion of the eutectic salt LiF-20CaF2 (mole%), the two wrought Ni-base superalloys Haynes alloy 230 and Inconel 617 were subjected to molten salt, its vapor, and vacuum for periods as long as 10,000 h at 1093 K. Following exposure, the microstructures were characterized, and samples from each superalloy were tensile tested between 77 and 1200 K. Neither the structure nor mechanical properties revealed evidence for additional degradation due to exposures to the salt. Although some loss in tensile properties was noted, particularly at 77 K, this reduction could be ascribed to the influence of simple aging at 1093 K. © 1994 ASM International.

Abstract: We introduce the concept of energy per operation as a measure of performance of an asynchronous circuit. We show how to model energy consumption based on the high-level language specification. This model is independent of voltage and timing considerations. We apply this model to memory design. We show first how to dimension a memory array, and how to break up this memory array into smaller arrays to minimize the energy per access. We then show how to use cache memory and pre-fetch mechanisms to further reduce energy per access.

Authors: Shaver Steven R., Armacost Lorna L., Konynenbelt Heidi S., Wehrman Robert R.

Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shaver, Steven R., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Armacost, Lorna L., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Konynenbelt, Heidi S., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Wehrman, Robert R., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Abstract: This paper describes systems analysis and simulation model development for a proposed solid waste management system at a U.S. Department of Energy Site. The proposed system will include a central storage facility, four treatment facilities, and three disposal sites. The material managed by this system will include radio-active, hazardous, and mixed radioactive and hazardous wastes. The objective of the modeling effort is to provide a means of evaluating throughput and capacity requirements for the proposed treatment, storage, and disposal facilities. The model is used to evaluate alternative system configurations and the effect on the alternatives of changing waste stream characteristics and receipt schedules. An iterative modeling and analysis approach is used that provides macro-level models early in the project and establishes credibility with the customer. The results from the analyses based on the macro models influence system design decisions and provide information that helps focus subsequent model development. Modeling and simulation of alternative system configurations and operating strategies yield a better understanding of the solid waste system requirements. The model effectively integrates information obtained through systems analysis and waste characterization to provide a consistent basis for system and facility planning.

Abstract: This paper presents an overview of the Phillips Laboratory compact toroid experiment and results obtained for converging electrode CT accelerators at the 1-MJ stored energy and 3-MA discharge current levels. Other parameters associated with the experiments are 10 μs time scale, 50-cm initial major radius, 10-cm initial minor radius, 100-cm gun length, 1-mg CT mass, and various gas loads. Achievements include terminal speeds of 40 cm/μs (limited by accelerator length), simultaneous compression in radius and thickness of factor 9 each, and X-ray yields of 10 kJ of approximately 1-keV photon energy.

Abstract: The theory of averaging and motion control on Lie groups is applied to the problem of controlling energy transfers between dynamic storage elements in switched electrical networks. Affiliations: Pace Univ
Authors with affiliations: Basheer Ahmed, S., Pace Univ; Cohen, Joseph M., Pace Univ
Abstract: Renewable energy technologies are receiving increased attention as an attractive electricity supply option for meeting the electricity needs of the 1990s and beyond. The wide variety of renewable technology options available are discussed here, classified according to the sector that has use for them. Also, the technical, economic, and institutional planning constraints that can hinder the full achievement of the potential of renewable technologies are identified. Against this background, a distributed utility structure is proposed which would involve combining central generation, transmission and distribution with modular local generation systems, local storage systems and central and targeted local demand-side management (DSM) programs.

Abstract: In this work the method of statistical simulation allowing someone to calculate an interaction of laser pulse with nonlinear absorbing many-level medium when the time duration of pulse is equal to longitudinal characteristic relaxation time is suggested and realized. The space and time characteristics of this inverted medium of plane geometry were calculated. The amplification coefficient of forbidden transition versus different parameters of this problem was obtained. The second problem was the calculation of many-steps selective photoionization of the atomic beam. Under specific conditions a superradiance had an effect on output of ions during decay of resonant exciting level into metastable level.

Title: Latch design for transient pulse tolerance
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cha, Hungse, Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States; Patel, Janak H., Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States
Abstract: Previous work on radiation hardening has focused on designing memory elements to tolerate direct hits by high energy particles. The study of latch designs to tolerate high energy particle induced transient pulses arising in the combinational part of the circuit and traveling to the inputs of DFFs has been ignored. In this work, we look at ways to slow down the input stage of latches by inserting resistances to tolerate transient pulses. Fault injection experiments indicates that most of the transient pulses can be tolerated with 7.5 ns penalty in performance, at least for the ISCAS-89 benchmark circuits. In circuits for critical systems, this penalty may be acceptable. Furthermore, this is not the best case penalty since the DFF can be individually optimized for the circuit and the transient pulse width can be somewhat shortened through redesign. Therefore, this is a viable approach for tolerating transient pulses in VLSI circuits used in critical systems.

Abstract: Plans for the nation's first high-level nuclear waste repository have called for permanently closing and sealing the repository soon after it is filled. However, the hydrologic environment of the proposed site at Yucca Mountain, Nevada, should allow the repository to be kept open and the waste retrievable indefinitely. This would allow direct monitoring of the repository and maintain the options for future generations to improve upon the disposal methods or use the uranium in the spent fuel as an energy resource.

Abstract: A new algorithm is proposed for improving the learning capability of a Bidirectional Associative Memory (BAM) neural networks. The proposed approach, unlike other methods in the literature, is not based on minimizing the energy function of the stored patterns. The proposed technique is the generalization of an auto-associative learning algorithm that has been developed for Hopfield networks. The BAM network is extremely robust to noise, almost guaranteeing perfect recall of all stored patterns with as much as 49% noise. The learning algorithm when applied to a number of test patterns used by other researchers provided satisfying results.

Abstract: This paper presents a nonlinear, fully three-dimensional aquifer thermal energy storage model, in which not only the forced advection, heat conduction and mechanical dispersion are considered, but the natural advection and the fluid-solid heat transfer are examined as well. The characteristic Douglas-Brian ADI scheme together with the improved Picard iterative approach is used to solve the model. Finally, the model is applied to a field experiment in Shanghai. The simulated temperatures match well with the observed data. Model validation shows that the buoyancy effect of heated water can not be overlooked in simulation and that scale effect may exist in the experiment. Moreover, the simulation of fluid-solid heat transfer is of some theoretical value.

Abstract: A diode-pumped Nd:YAG laser for use as a driver for a soft x-ray projection lithography system is described. The laser will output 0.5 to 1 J per pulse with about 5 ns pulse width at up to 1.5 kHz repetition frequency. The design employs microchannel-cooled diode laser arrays for optical pumping, zigzag slab energy storage, and a single frequency oscillator injected regenerative amplifier cavity using phase conjugator beam correction for near diffraction limited beam quality. The design and initial results of this laser's activation experiments are presented.

Authors: Morash Richard T.
Title: Motor-generator set uses written-pole technology to ride through 15 second power blackouts
Affiliations: Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morash, Richard T., Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Abstract: 'Written-Pole'TM technology has been patented and demonstrated for electric motors and generators. It advances the state-of-the-art for electrical energy storage systems. Efficient use is made of the inherent flywheel energy stored in the rotor of a written-pole motor-generator set. The machine is a continuous on-line power conditioner, and is also an electro-mechanical battery that delivers useful precise frequency AC power for extended time during utility power sags, surges and blinkouts. If momentary power interruptions extend into blackouts after 15 or more seconds, the motor-generator allows time to transfer to a dual feeder system, or to tie into an engine generator for a no-break transfer. Also called the Roesel Motor-GeneratorTM (RMG), it is used as an Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) system without batteries. The machines have been applied and demonstrated to provide at least 15 seconds of ride-through with exact 60 Hz frequency and full voltage at full load. The written-pole motor is synchronous and reflects a unity power factor, sine wave load to the utility, while the generator mitigates harmonic loads imposed by modern electronic devices. This paper discusses the written-pole technology, and shows an operational design with specifications and test results. Applications in power generation and industrial areas are discussed, with details of a site at Public Service Electric & Gas Company.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric energy storage; Electric exciters; Electric power generation; Electric rectifiers; Electric surges; Electromechanical devices; Flywheels; Fossil fuel power plants; Industrial applications; Online systems; Rotors; Blinkouts; Generator excitation systems; Power interruptions; Uninterruptible power supply; Utility power sags; Written pole technology; AC generator motors

Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference

Abstract: The Department of Energy (DOE) is implementing the National Environmental Protection Act (NEPA) in its management of spent nuclear fuel. The DOE strategy is to address the short-term safety concerns about existing spent nuclear fuel, to study alternatives for interim storage, and to develop a long-range program to manage spent nuclear fuel. This paper discusses the NEPA process, the environmental impact statements for specific sites as well as the overall program, the inventory of DOE spent nuclear fuel, the alternatives for managing the fuel, and the schedule for implementing the program.

Abstract: The FERMI system has been designed to perform acquisition and DSP of calorimeter data in high energy collision experiments, planned at the LHC collider (CERN, Geneva, CH). The system relies mainly upon the FERMI chip, a dedicated VLSI multi-chip device: it requires rad-hard features due to the critical application, to the difficulties in maintenance, and to the operating environment. In this paper, a modular approach to support policies for self diagnosis and fault tolerance is discussed.
