Authors: Liaw C.M., Chiang S.J., Huang S.C.
Title: Three-phase multi-functional battery energy storage system
Affiliations: Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Liaw, C.M., Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chiang, S.J., Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Huang, S.C., Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: A three-phase (3φ) multi-functional battery energy storage system (BESS) is designed and implemented in this paper. When the utility power is in normal condition, the proposed BESS can be arranged to shave the peak load or charge the battery bank. In either case, since the load unbalanced, harmonic and reactive powers can be compensated through the proposed active power filtering control, the power factor is maintained nearly unity and the line currents drawn from the utility are balanced and sinusoidal with very low distortion. As the utility power failure happens, the proposed BESS can immediately supply uninterruptible power to the loads. In this case, an instantaneous control technique is developed to yield good three-phase voltage waveforms. The determination of reactive components, the dynamic modeling, and the design of controllers for the proposed BESS are made. Some experimental results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed BESS.

Abstract: A decision analysis approach has been proposed for planning the retrieval of hazardous, radioactive, and mixed wastes from underground storage tanks. This paper describes the proposed approach and illustrates its application to the single-shell storage tanks (SSTs) at Hanford, Washington.

Authors: Houston E.Scott, Hadley Jennifer D.
Title: Confirmation of MRS/MPC transfer facility sizing using simulation modeling
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Duke Engineering & Services, Inc, Charlotte, United States
Authors with affiliations: Houston, E.Scott, Duke Engineering & Services, Inc, Charlotte, United States; Hadley, Jennifer D., Duke Engineering & Services, Inc, Charlotte, United States
Abstract: The Nuclear Waste Policy Act (NWPA) of 1982, as amended, requires the Department of Energy to begin receiving spent nuclear fuel (SNF) from utilities in January 1998. A repository will not be completed in time for the scheduled receipt of SNF. A Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) Facility is therefore a feasible solution to bridge the gap between the 1998 date for fuel acceptance and the startup of the repository. SNF will be stored temporarily at the MRS and later retrieved from storage and shipped to the repository. To simplify fuel handling and to standardize components, the multi-purpose canister (MPC) concept was investigated. The MPC would be a sealed, metallic canister containing multiple SNF assemblies in a dry inert environment. MPCs would be placed into different overpacks for transportation, storage, and disposal at the repository. The MRS transfer facility MPC and SNF throughput requirements, assumptions, and operating concepts were used to initially determine the size of the facility and the major equipment contained within the facility. This initial estimate was based on simplified calculation techniques. The adequacy of the design configurations were then confirmed using SLAM2 simulation modeling software. Modeling incorporates uncertainties in task durations, the effects of equipment reliability, availability of personnel and equipment, and system breakdowns. This paper describes how the model was developed and how it is used to verify the transfer facility size. It also illustrates how problems with the facility design, operational concepts, and staffing are identified with the results of the model.

Abstract: 1993 has been yet another year of major change in the Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) project. The change in administration has brought a new Secretary of Energy to the Department. Secretary O'Leary has brought a strong leadership background and fresh ideas to address the Department's many complex challenges, including the Civilian Radioactive Waste Management System (CRWMS). Dr. Daniel Dreyfus was named Director of the Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management. Mr. Richard Stallings has been named, as the new, Nuclear Waste Negotiator under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act, Amendments of 1987. The overall mission of the Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM) has not changed. OCRWM is tasked with finding technically sound, environmentally responsible and economically viable solutions to spent nuclear fuel and high-level radioactive waste storage and disposal.

Authors: Paine Jeffrey S.N., Rogers Craig A.
Title: Low velocity perforating impact response of shape memory alloy hybrid composite materials
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Aerospace Division (Publication) AD
Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paine, Jeffrey S.N., Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Rogers, Craig A., Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Abstract: Recently, multi-functional shape memory alloy (SMA) hybrid composites have been investigated for use in improving the impact damage resistance of brittle thermoset matrix composite materials. A continued investigation of the improvement of composite materials' impact resistance using SMA hybrid composites is presented here. Because graphite/epoxy composites lack a mechanism for dissipating impact strain energy such as plastic yielding, damage from impact type loading can be very severe. Initially, damage develops in the form of delamination and resin crazing which methods such as rubber toughening or creating a thermoplastic fiber-matrix interphase can reduce. At higher energy levels, impact loading causes fiber fracture and material puncture. Few methods exist to reduce the material perforation once the elastic strain energy storage capacity of the fibers has been exceeded. Embedding or laminating layers of superelastic SMA wire/epoxy composite in or on the composite has been shown to be effective in increasing the impact energy needed to cause fiber fracture and material puncture. The experimental results from an investigation of the low velocity impact response of hybrid SMA composite materials is presented. The results are compared to hybrid composites of graphite-kevlar /epoxy and graphite-aluminum/epoxy. The SMA hybrid demonstrates significantly higher impact perforation energies than the other hybrid composite materials.
Index Keywords: Alloys; Crazing; Delamination; Energy storage; Epoxy resins; Graphite; Impact resistance; Shape memory effect; Strain; Hybrid composite materials; Shape memory alloys; Fiber reinforced plastics

Authors: Schaible Uwe, Szabados Barna

Affiliations: McMaster Univ, Hamilton, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Schaible, Uwe, McMaster Univ, Hamilton, Canada; Szabados, Barna, McMaster Univ, Hamilton, Canada
Abstract: This paper provides a design outline and implementation procedure for a flywheel energy storage system using a high speed interior permanent magnet synchronous machine, torque-controlled through the use of a vector control algorithm. The proposed flywheel energy storage system can be used to meet the peak energy requirements of an electric vehicle during both acceleration and regenerative braking. By supplying the peak energy requirements from a secondary source, the life cycle of the electric vehicle's batteries may be extended considerably. A torque control algorithm is presented and preliminary implementation through a commercially available microcontroller is described. Preliminary testing of the proposed system has been very promising and has proven that bidirectional peak power transfer can be rapidly accomplished.

Affiliations: Universite de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Brousseau, Patrick, Universite de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada; Lacroix, Marcel, Universite de Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Canada
Abstract: A computational model for the prediction of the thermal behavior of a compact multi-layer latent heat storage unit is presented. The model is based on the conservation equations of energy for the PCM and the HTF. Electrical heat sources embedded inside the PCM are used for heat storage (melting) while the flow of a HTF is employed for heat recovery (solidification). Parametric studies are performed to assess the effect of various design and operating conditions on the thermal behavior of the unit. Results indicate that the average output heat load during the recovery period is strongly dependent on the minimum operating temperature, on the thermal diffusivity of the liquid phase, on the thickness of the PCM layer and on the HTF inlet mass flow rate and temperature. It is, on the other hand, nearly independent of the wall thermal diffusivity and thickness and of the maximum operating temperature.

Abstract: The requirement to optimise the operation of a hydro electric generation system of storages and power stations fed by a network of rivers and canals, requires prediction of inflows in the short term. The Hydrol time series management system connects remote climate and riverflow stations directly through telemetry software to a central database from which a network based rainfall runoff model operates to provide flow forecasts. This paper describes the main features of the WindowsTM based Hydrol Modelling system and its use in the Energy Control System (ECS).

Abstract: A novel absorption refrigeration system has been designed to utilize energy from the internal combustion engine exhaust gases and the engine's cooling-water to provide cooling for passenger car compartment. Refrigerant and absorbent storage tanks are incorporated to provide an adequate transient response to variations in the input energy due to variable engine speed and extreme cooling load requirements. A mathematical model based on mass, species (lithium bromide), and energy balance equations for each component of the system is developed to predict the performance of this absorption cycle. Results show that the system can meet the required cooling load, even for the worst case scenario such as the cool-down period after an initial heat soak of a sub-compact car during engine warm up and idling under extreme environmental conditions. The system constraints are also discussed.

Authors: Yedidia Joseph M.
Title: Testing and analysis for advanced passive safety systems: a mid 1994 status report
Affiliations: Electric Power Research Inst, Palo Alto, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yedidia, Joseph M., Electric Power Research Inst, Palo Alto, United States
Abstract: The testing and analysis which are being performed for the certification and confirmation of the next generation of light water reactors (LWRs) are discussed in this paper, which provides a summary of the present status. While testing and analysis are performed mostly by the reactor plant designers, the utilities who sponsor the Advanced Light Water Reactor (ALWR) program have a major stake in the proper validation of the advanced, passive designs. These designs include a significant number of innovative safety features, which rely on gravity, natural circulation, stored energy or evaporation. They do not require, therefore, emergency electric power in the case of an accident or other transients. Over the past several years, the utilities have defined requirements for the passive designs and are continuously monitoring the conformance of these designs with the requirements. Additionally, the utilities have concluded that they must be assured that the portions of the designs and the related analytic tools, which have not been proven by earlier applications or tests, are going to be tested in appropriately designed test facilities. This paper provides an overview of the utility effort related to this aspect of the ALWR Program and an overall status report, updated to mid-1994.

Abstract: Due to the limitation of the dynamic range of VLSI circuits in the implementation of the exponential bidirectional associative memory (eBAM), the optimal radix must be found in order to get the maximal dimension for the eBAM. It is also necessary to update the radix when new pattern pairs are to be stored. An optimal updating algorithm for the radix is also present. Besides, a pattern pair training algorithm is proposed to ensure every trained pair stored in the eBAM will be recalled when an input pair is located in its basin with radius r.

Authors with affiliations: Yen, Gary G., USAF Phillips Lab, Kirtland AFB, United States
Abstract: In the present paper we investigate the qualitative properties of a class of bidirectional associative memories. Networks are described by a system of first order ordinary difference equations which are defined on a closed hypercube of the state space with solutions extended to the boundary of the hypercube. For the present model, a systematic analysis method is developed to completely characterize a given network, i.e., the distribution of equilibria in the state space, and the stability properties of the equilibrium points. In addition, we establish a computationally efficient synthesis procedure utilizing the eigenstructure decomposition method. The proposed algorithm possesses several advantages, since it is possible to exert control over the number of spurious states, since it is possible to estimate the basins of attraction of the stable memories, and since it is possible, under certain constraints, to effectively store a number of desired stable memories which by far exceed the order of the network. The applicability of the present results is demonstrated by means of a specific application in flexible structures.

Abstract: This paper introduces the double-fed adjustable speed system for pumped storage and the application utility of RPVC (Rotary Power and Var Compensator) and ROTES (Rotary Energy Storage System). Recently the double-fed adjustable speed system is adopted to the pumped storage system in Japan because of the various advantages such as the adjustable pump input and improved turbine efficiency. Besides these advantages proper for pumped storage, the double-fed adjustable speed machine has superior characteristics of quick response power output for not only reactive power but active power. This advantage greatly contributes to the power system stabilization. The RPVC and ROTES, without pump turbine, are the application systems which enable the stabilization of voltage and frequency fluctuation. These are expected to be effective and suitable for the power system stabilization in the future.

Abstract: This paper addresses the design of resonant pole inverter cells at the pc-board level, including loss modeling and resonant component selection. Tradeoffs between operating frequency, minimum switching current, inductor energy storage, and converter losses are described for selecting resonant components. Two methods are presented for estimating converter losses as a function of resonant components and operating point. The first method uses closed-form equations based on very simple device models, while the second is based on simulation of the converter over one switching cycle using more complex device models.

Authors: Williamson Thomas M., VanCamp Gil April
Title: Repository program licensing approach
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Las Vegas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williamson, Thomas M., Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Las Vegas, United States; VanCamp Gil, April, Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Las Vegas, United States
Abstract: Yucca Mountain, Nevada is currently being studied by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) as a potential site for a mined geologic repository for high-level nuclear waste. DOE has the responsibility to determine the suitability of the site and to develop a license application (LA) for authorization to construct the potential repository. If the site is suitable, the license application would be submitted to the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC). The repository program licensing approach is focused on the timely acquisition of information needed in licensing and the resolution of potential licensing issues with the NRC staff. Licensing involves an iterative process requiring refinements as data are acquired, analyzed, and evaluated. The repository licensing approach presented in this paper ensure that the information is available when needed to facilitate the licensing process. Identifying the information needed to evaluate compliance with the performance objectives in 10 CFR 60, monitoring the acquisition of such information, and developing a successful license application are integral elements of DOE's repository program licensing approach. Activities to characterize the site are being systematically conducted as planned in the Site Characterization Plan (SCP)2. In addition, DOE is implementing the issue resolution initiative, the license application annotated outline (LA AO) process, and interim licensability evaluations to update the early planning in the SCP and to focus site characterization, design, and performance assessment activities on the acquisition of information needed for a site suitability determination and licensing. Collectively, the issue resolution initiative, LA AO process, and interim licensability evaluations are key elements of a transition to the iterative process to answer the question: `When do we have enough data to support licensing?'
Index Keywords: Engineering geology; Information use; Laws and legislation; Public policy; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Site selection; Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC); Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982; Site characterization plan (SCP); United States Department of Energy (DOE); Yucca Mountain, Nevada; Geological repositories

Abstract: This paper discusses a static simulation model that predicts several performance measures of environmental restoration activities over different remedial strategies. Abstract: Rockford Technology Associates, Inc. (RTA) has been doing experiments on the Dense Plasma Focus (DPF) device. Recently, experiments aim at exploring the potential of DPF device as a magnetoplasma dynamic (MPD) thruster and as an x-ray source for lithography have investigated various alternative ways of injecting gas between the electrodes. As a result, it was found that the plasma collapses into a pitch at the same tune as in conventional experiment using static fill. The singularity in the current waveform is slightly smaller with tip injection, but its size and shape are easily reproducible. Further details and comparison of this operation with conventional pulsing will be presented.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Energy storage; Hydrogen; Vacuum pumps; X rays; Dense plasma focus; Gas infection; Magnetoplasmadynamic thruster; Pulsing; Rogowski coil; X ray source; Plasma devices

Abstract: Slow wave structure supporting the beam-wave interaction in a relativistic backward wave oscillator (BWO) requires a carefully designed output waveguide in order to couple the electromagnetic wave to a radiating antenna. The coupling between these two sections determines the quality factor (Q) of the slow wave structure and affects the starting current and the saturation processes occurring when the electron beam is injected into the device. The goal of this paper is to study the end reflection and quality factor of a practical slow wave structure both experimentally and theoretically. Consequently, the outcome was summarized in a simple analytic form, which shows good agreement with experiment over all resonant frequencies.
Index Keywords: Electric losses; Electromagnetic wave reflection; Energy storage; Perturbation techniques; Q factor measurement; Resonance; Waveguides; Beam wave interaction; Ohmic heating; Quality factor; Relativistic backward wave devices; Saturation; Slow wave structure; Electromagnetic waves

Title: Compilation techniques for low energy: An overview
Source title: IEEE Symposium on Low Power Electronics

Authors with affiliations: Tiwari, Vivek, Princeton Univ, Princeton, United States; Malik, Sharad, Princeton Univ, Princeton, United States; Wolfe, Andrew, Princeton Univ, Princeton, United States
Abstract: Recent years have witnessed a rapid growth in research activity targeted at reducing energy consumption in microprocessor based systems. However, this research has by and large not recognized the potential energy savings achievable through optimization of software running on the microprocessor. This paper presents an overview of techniques used in our work and in other recent research in this area. Using the results of a recent work as a basis, several possible techniques for energy reduction through code compilation are presented. Examples with energy reduction of up to 40% on an Intel 486DX2 based system, obtained by rewriting code, demonstrate the potential of these ideas. Several additional avenues for reducing CPU and memory system energy through code compilation are identified. The effect of traditional compilation techniques on energy reduction is discussed and some of these techniques that can be beneficial in this regard are reviewed.

Abstract: This paper proposes a novel rotor time constant estimation method for the vector control of an induction motor, which is effective for both load and no-load conditions. The approach is based on regulating the variation of the magnetizing energy stored in the magnetizing inductance to a suitable assigned value. The proposed estimation method is completely robust to the stator resistance and magnetizing inductance. Moreover the method has excellent performance under low speeds because pure integrator circuit is not used in the method. The effectiveness and the characteristics of the proposed method are investigated by experiment and simulation.

Abstract: The principle disadvantage of storage ring SR is the sharp angular nonuniformity of SR polarization components. The difficulties can be softened by using a SR source with wider angular distribution and consequently lower electrons energy. The most promising decision of the problem is the using of a specialized SR source with optimized parameters - TROLL type synchrotron. The proposed decision will be especially suitable for small radiometrical or optical laboratories.

Authors: Schmidt R., Jenni F., Riatsch J.
Title: Control of an optimized converter for modular solar power generation
Affiliations: Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Schmidt, R., Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland; Jenni, F., Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland; Riatsch, J., Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: Important drawbacks of solar power generation are the DC-wiring and fusing needed for the serial and parallel connection of solar panels. These problems can be reduced to AC-wiring and fusing by using a modular set up of panels together with integrated single phase DC-AC converters on a power level of approximately 200W. A general applicable model has been developed for the coupling of two single phase systems by a voltage link with small storage capacitance. It allows the decoupling of the pulsating mains power from the panel. Based on this model, which avoids the need of large filters, a sophisticated control principle has been developed. The result is a converter, which allows the operation in the maximum power point without any power pulsation in the solar panel. The required reactive elements, and therefore the size of the converter, are very small.
Index Keywords: DC wiring; Maximum power point; Pulsating mains power; Solar panels; Switching frequency; Voltage link; Capacitance; Current voltage characteristics; Electric filters; Electric losses; Electric wiring; Energy storage; Frequencies; Mathematical models; MOSFET devices; Optimization; Solar power generation; Solar radiation; Electric converters

Abstract: The paper describes a concept to improve the present photon-induced scanning Auger- microscope, a high-flux micro-spectroscope which allows electron spectroscopy with high spatial resolution, in-situ chemical mapping, and microstructuring of organic and organometallic compounds. It utilizes high-brightness, quasi-monochromatic undulator radiation from BESSY storage ring. The present electron energy resolution (≥ 0.5 eV) appears sufficient but the spatial resolution (≥ 3 μm) can be significantly improved. The new concept compromises grazing incidence optics in a two stage reduction scheme in order to combine an increase of photon flux with an increase of the spatial resolution to 0.2 μm. The key component of the improved instrument is an ellipsoidal grazing incidence mirror for which optimization calculations have been performed. These include diffraction, surface roughness and slope errors as well as manufactural limitations taking technical realizability into account.
Index Keywords: Microstructure; Optimization; Organic compounds; Organometallics; Scanning electron microscopy; Spectrographs; X ray spectroscopy; Grazing incidence mirrors; Microspectroscopes; Scanning Auger microscopes; Soft X ray undulator radiation; Mirrors

Abstract: The Department of Energy commissioned a Conceptual Design Study in February 1993 from the Management and Operating (M&O) Contractor for the Civilian Radioactive Waste Management System (CRWMS) to develop multi-purpose canister (MPC) conceptual designs and to provide feasibility, cost and schedule evaluations for implementation of an MPC program. Source title: IEEE Workshop on Power Electronics in Transportation

Authors with affiliations: Farkas, Alon, Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Canada; Bonert, Richard, Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Canada
Abstract: New types of electric capacitors may provide within several years power capacitors which could be used as energy storage devices in serial hybrid electric car drives instead of a battery. This paper discusses how to determine the required size of such a capacitor used as the sole energy storage device. The performance requirements and parameters influencing the size of the capacitor are defined and a model of a hybrid car system is proposed to determine the size of the capacitor. Simulation results are presented to demonstrate the choices selecting the capacitor size and to provide an estimate of the performance of a hybrid vehicle with capacitive energy storage.

Title: Soft-switched current-fed PWM inverter with space vector modulation

Abstract: A soft-switched PWM converter structure is presented, which is useful for current-fed inverters and rectifiers. Typical applications include power supplies for magnets and SMES systems, high-power ac motor drives and active power filters with magnetic energy storage. Soft switching, which is provided at the expense of a limited increase of the circuit complexity, makes possible commutation frequencies considerably higher than for hard-switched solutions. Moreover, full-range regulation of the ac currents is obtained, owing to a suitable current vector modulation technique. Lastly, a proper switching sequence is derived, which minimizes power loss and switch overvoltages. Simulated results demonstrate the converter capabilities.

Abstract: We present the building blocks for an analog continuous-time micropower CMOS Hopfield associative memory with local adaption and storage of weights: A synaptic connection circuit, an analog memory, a memory programming circuit and an artificial neuron. The building blocks are modular, allowing a net of any size to be built. The weight adaption is by the outer product rule. The analog memory works by exposure to UV-light. A six neuron net, intended for storage and retrieval of two patterns, was implemented in a standard 2μ CMOS process.

Authors: Conlon Michael F.
Title: Dynamic stability enhancement in power systems by application of superconducting magnetic energy storage
Affiliations: Monash Univ, Clayton
Authors with affiliations: Conlon, Michael F., Monash Univ, Clayton
Abstract: Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) involves the short or long-term storage of energy in the magnetic field of a superconducting coil. The energy flow between the coil and the power network is regulated by a converter bridge. The benefit of such a device is highly dependent on the switching strategy and control of the converter bridge. As part of a research project involving the construction and operation of a SMES unit at Monash University, independent active and reactive power control has been demonstrated for a converter bridge operating under a Pulse Width Modulation switching strategy. This paper investigates the application of such a device to the problem of dynamic stability enhancement of a power network. Under a reactive-power only mode of control, the SMES device is similar to a Static Var Compensator (SVC). However, under simultaneous active and reactive power control, use can be made of the energy storage aspect of the device to increase its benefit in dynamic stability improvement. An optimal control approach is adopted for the design of the controller and the effect of simultaneous active and reactive power control is assessed.
Index Keywords: Electric coils; Electric converters; Electric power transmission networks; Energy storage; Magnetic fields; Power control; Pulse width modulation; Superconducting materials; Active power control; Converter bridge; Dynamic stability enhancement; Reactive power control; Superconducting coil; Superconducting magnetic energy storage; Switching strategy; Electric power systems

Abstract: Neural networks have shown success in solving some difficult optimization problems. As problems become more complex, it is increasingly difficult to find a suitable encoding of constraints into an energy function, which will effectively guide the network to a desired solution. In previous work by Gassen and Carothers [1], a difficult scheduling problem in VLSI design was encoded into a Hopfield-type neural network. In this paper, we report significant enhancements which allow additional design constraints to be considered and more flexibility for considering the specific design under development.

Abstract: This paper describes a systems analysis tool that is being developed with Teledyne Brown Engineering funds to address top-level system cost and safety issues associated with the storage, transportation and disposal of high-level spent fuel from a network of nuclear power plants. STRANDNET is described in terms of its generic output results plus an illustrative example comparing two hypothetical radioactive waste management systems, both using Multi-Purpose Canisters but one system with and one without a Monitored Retrievable Storage facility. Although tailored specifically to address current U.S. Department of Energy concerns, the STRANDNET approach applies to any waste management network where the overall cost and risks of operation are desired.

Abstract: Site assessments were conducted by the Department of Energy (DOE) at locations on two Indian Tribal Reservations in the Western U.S. These assessments were conducted, as part of a voluntary, negotiated siting process, to make a preliminary determination of the technical suitability of these sites for development of a Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) facility. Authors: Abeyratne S.G., Aydemir M.T., Lipo T.A., Murai Y., Yoshida M.
Title: Current clamped, PWM, quasi-resonant DC link series resonant converter
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abeyratne, S.G., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Aydemir, M.T., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Lipo, T.A., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Murai, Y., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Yoshida, M., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a new High Frequency Series Resonant DC Link Topology derived from [1], wherein the resonant tank does not bring about peaky currents in any portion of the system. The characteristic overall-clamping mechanism permits lower-current-rating for the semiconductor devices, resonant capacitor and filter capacitors, easing the cost burden. Moreover, the values of the resonant inductor and the capacitor can be reduced substantially, limited only by the di/dt ratings of the devices, since the resonant current peaks, which would otherwise have risen to a higher value (tank storage energy burden) no longer appear in this configuration. In the paper, converter is digitally simulated using 'ACSL' and output performance is investigated. The voltage stresses across the auxiliary switches are estimated using the 'SABER' simulator on a mono-phase model. PWM-capable other series resonant topologies are compared with the new topology for voltage stresses across the auxiliary switches, using the SABER simulation code.

Authors: Wilamowski Bogdan M., Zurada Jacek M., Malinowski Aleksander
Title: Steepest descent retrieval algorithm for autoassociative neural memory
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Neural Networks - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Univ of Wyoming, Laramie, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilamowski, Bogdan M., Univ of Wyoming, Laramie, United States; Zurada, Jacek M., Univ of Wyoming, Laramie, United States; Malinowski, Aleksander, Univ of Wyoming, Laramie, United States
Abstract: The proposed steepest descent retrieval algorithm is shown to improve the recovery of stored patterns in autoassociative recurrent neural memories. The algorithm implements the steepest reduction of the computational energy function rather than an ordinary random and unqualified update. The experiments indicate that this update mode is the more efficient when compared to the conventional asynchronous update. Specifically, it performs better in recovery of vectors at smaller Hamming distance and in rejection of stable but spurious memories.
Index Keywords: Associative storage; Computational methods; Computer architecture; Computer system recovery; Discrete time control systems; Encoding (symbols); Information retrieval systems; Matrix algebra; Neural networks; Probability; Robustness (control systems); Vectors; Autoassociative neural memory; Bipolar binary pattern; Computational energy function; Degree of incorrectness; Steepest descent retrieval algorithms; Algorithms

Authors: Mongia R.K., Ittipiboon A., Cuhaci M., Roscoe D.
Title: Radiation Q-factor of rectangular dielectric resonator antennas: theory and experiment
Source title: IEEE Antennas and Propagation Society, AP-S International Symposium (Digest)
Affiliations: Communications Research Cent, Ottawa, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Mongia, R.K., Communications Research Cent, Ottawa, Canada; Ittipiboon, A., Communications Research Cent, Ottawa, Canada; Cuhaci, M., Communications Research Cent, Ottawa, Canada; Roscoe, D., Communications Research Cent, Ottawa, Canada
Abstract: In this paper, a closed form expression is derived for the radiation Q-factor of a rectangular dielectric resonator (DR) antenna. The method used for determining the Q-factor is based on replacing the DR by a polarization electric current source. Experiments were conducted on dielectric resonators having a value of εr ≈ 38 to verify the accuracy of the expression. The measured results are found to be in fairly good agreement with theory.
Index Keywords: Dielectric waveguides; Dipole antennas; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric fields; Electromagnetic wave polarization; Magnetism; Mathematical models; Models; Resonators; Magnetic wall model; Okaya/Barash second order model; Radiation Q factor; Rectangular DR antenna; Antenna radiation

Authors: Weston S.C.
Title: Assessing the firm yield of Tasmania's hydro-electric system
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Hydro-Electric Commission of, Tasmania
Authors with affiliations: Weston, S.C., Hydro-Electric Commission of, Tasmania
Abstract: The capability of a hydro-electric generating system to supply electrical energy reliably depends on the statistical characteristics of system inflows - in particular the frequency and severity of drought, available storage capacity, and access to emergency sources of supply when stored energy reserves are low. This paper reviews the historical development of methodologies for the assessment of the firm yield of the Tasmanian hydro-electric system. This development is traced from early methods based on the survival of design droughts to concepts of economic system rating. The paper points out the difficulties in applying each method both in general and in relation to the Tasmanian situation.
Index Keywords: Drought; Economics; Electric power utilization; History; Societies and institutions; Statistical methods; Strategic planning; Water resources; Economic system rating; Hydroelectric generating system; Statistical characteristics; Storage capacity; System inflows; Hydroelectric power plants

Authors: Jefferson C.M., Neilson K.
Title: Supercapacitor energy storage system
Affiliations: Univ of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Jefferson, C.M., Univ of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom; Neilson, K., Univ of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: The development of electric and hybrid vehicles is currently dependent on the improvement in the performance of electrochemical storage, which presently lacks the energy density, recharge power density, cycle life and storage efficiency needed in order that electric vehicles can match conventional vehicles in range and performance. A supercapacitor energy storage system is described, which could be used to enhance the performance of batteries, or, in the case of hybrid vehicles, replace batteries altogether. The ability of a capacitor to store energy is well known, showing high power density, cycle life and storage efficiency. While capacitors presently lack the energy density needed to meet the requirements of electric vehicles, supercapacitors are now being developed which may well meet the requirement of hybrid vehicles. Current progress in supercapacitor development is reviewed and an energy storage system suitable for hybrid vehicles described, comprising a capacitor bank and DC-DC converter. Its performance is predicted by computer simulation.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Efficiency; Electric batteries; Electric energy storage; Electric vehicles; Performance; Power converters; Capacitor bank; Cycle life; High power density; Hybrid vehicles; Storage efficiency; Supercapacitor energy storage system; Capacitors

Authors: Roberts John P., Morgan Robert G., Birch Mary L., Desell Linda J.
Title: Regulatory issues associated with the Multi-Purpose Canister system
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roberts, John P., Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Morgan, Robert G., Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Birch, Mary L., Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Desell, Linda J., Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management is developing a Multi-Purpose Canister system to promote compatibility between the waste program elements of storage, transportation, and disposal. The development of a Multi-Purpose Canister system requires meeting various regulatory requirements. These regulatory requirements are set forth in environmental and Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) regulations. This paper discusses the more significant regulatory issues that must be addressed in the development of a Multi-Purpose Canister system by the Department of Energy.
Index Keywords: Containers; Environmental protection; Laws and legislation; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste transportation; Spent fuels; Civilian Radioactive Waste Management System (CRWMS); MultiPurpose Canister (MPC); Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC); Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Hand Frank R., Barr Gerald W.
Title: Tru waste system models
Affiliations: Los Alamos Technical Associates, Inc, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hand, Frank R., Los Alamos Technical Associates, Inc, Albuquerque, United States; Barr, Gerald W., Los Alamos Technical Associates, Inc, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: Transuranic waste is currently generated and/or stored at several sites throughout the Department of Energy complex. The goal of the DOE National Transuranic Waste Program is to effect a safe, integrated, and economical disposal system for these wastes. Several alternatives are being considered. The selection process will involve tradeoffs of cost, risk, dose, and system efficiency. Simulation models are being used to aid in the analysis of the various options. In addition to modeling the material flow, the simulation tracks many specialized operational parameters related to the material processed or the elapsed time. These parameters track the radiological and chemical exposure dose to workers; the radiological, chemical, and hazardous risk associated with processing and storing drums; and the capital and operating costs of the facilities. The system being modeled has a timeline of approximately 30 years to fund, design, construct, operate, and decommission the needed facilities. The intent is to model this timeline and to include facility costs not directly related to processing. The tracking of these parameters is piggybacked onto the main simulation engine. Flexible simulation models, controlled by the user at run time, were developed. Two such models are presented here. No analysis results are presented.
Index Keywords: Containers; Industrial waste disposal; Materials handling; Parameter estimation; Pilot plants; Radiation effects; Radioactive waste storage; Risk assessment; Transuranic waste; TRU waste system models; Computer simulation

Authors: Roberson Gary D., Brown Jim, Roberson Dana S.
Title: Tank waste information network system (TWINS)
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Dep of Energy, Germantown, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roberson, Gary D., Dep of Energy, Germantown, United States; Brown, Jim, Dep of Energy, Germantown, United States; Roberson, Dana S., Dep of Energy, Germantown, United States
Abstract: Department of Energy (DOE) High-Level Waste (HLW) is stored in underground tanks at Hanford (Washington), Savannah River (Georgia), Idaho Falls (Idaho), and West Valley (New York). These tanks are 1) temporary, 2) unsafe, 3) leaking, 4) filled with an undetermined amount and type of radio-nuclides, and 5) are in need of immediate attention. Tank waste characterization activities reveal the waste composition, temperature, level or depth in the tank, and other information required to solve safety issues associated with the tanks and to model tank waste. Scientists and engineers require timely information from multiple HLW databases across the DOE complex. To address this requirement, the Pacific Northwest Laboratory developed the Tank Waste Information Network System (TWINS). The system architecture developed for TWINS is not only related to the DOE HLW problem, but can apply to other information systems, either local, national, or international in scope.
Index Keywords: Environmental protection; Industrial management; Information retrieval systems; Information use; Materials handling; Mathematical models; Public risks; Radioactive waste disposal; Safety factor; Tanks (containers); Underground structures; Double shell tanks; High level waste (HLW); Single shell tanks; Tank waste information system (TWINS); United States Department of Energy (DOE); Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Zahedi Ahmad
Title: 'Energy, people, environment' development of an integrated renewable energy & energy storage system, an uninterruptable power supply for people and for better environment
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Systems, Man and Cybernetics
Affiliations: Energy-Efficiency Research Group Dep, of Electrical and Computer Systems, Engineering Monash Univ, Caulfield
Authors with affiliations: Zahedi, Ahmad, Energy-Efficiency Research Group Dep, of Electrical and Computer Systems, Engineering Monash Univ, Caulfield
Abstract: Energy continues to be an essential key to worldwide development approaching higher standard of life. In this paper, latest development and the results obtained from a project of an integrated renewable energy & energy storage (IREES) system were presented. IREES system, which is total renewable energy based electricity supply system, finds so many applications as it can be used as a large scale power supply being connected to national grid as well as small scale power supply for remote areas. Findings and results arising from this research project will be of practical value for both power suppliers and people as energy users as this system not only conserves energy but also helps preserving the environment.

Authors: Hensel S.J., Thomas J.K.
Title: Development and application of a deflagration pressure analysis code for high level waste processing
Source title: SERA, Safety Engineering and Risk Analysis
Affiliations: Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hensel, S.J., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States; Thomas, J.K., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Abstract: The Deflagration Pressure Analysis Code (DPAC) was developed primarily to evaluate peak pressures for deflagrations in radioactive waste storage and process facilities at the Savannah River Site (SRS). Deflagrations in these facilities are generally considered to be incredible events, but it was judged prudent to develop modeling capabilities in order to facilitate risk estimates. DPAC is essentially an engineering analysis tool, as opposed to a detailed thermal hydraulics code. It accounts for mass loss via venting, energy dissipation by radiative heat transfer, and gas PdV work. Volume increases due to vessel deformation can also be included using pressure-volume data from a structural analysis of the enclosure. This paper presents an overview of the code, benchmarking, and applications at SRS.

Authors: Johnson K.H.
Title: Jahn-teller symmetry breaking and hydrogen energy in γ-PdD 'cold fusion' as storage of the 'latent heat' of water
Affiliations: Massachusetts Inst of Technology, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, K.H., Massachusetts Inst of Technology, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: Ab initio quantum-chemical computations for the potential energy surface of the tetrahedrally coordinated 'γ-phase' of PdD, in conjunction with the dynamic Jahn-Teller effect, suggest that observed 'excess heat' from cold fusion cells is equivalent to the stored chemical latent heat of vaporization of water.

Authors: Belyaev L.S., Rudenko Yu., Sinyak Yu.
Title: Concept of the world energy system
Source title: International Journal of Global Energy Issues
Affiliations: Siberian Energy Inst, Irkutsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Belyaev, L.S., Siberian Energy Inst, Irkutsk, Russian Federation; Rudenko, Yu., Siberian Energy Inst, Irkutsk, Russian Federation; Sinyak, Yu., Siberian Energy Inst, Irkutsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The nature of future energy development in different regions of the world are rather uncertain due to unclear results of technological progress in nuclear and renewable energy sources, environmental consequences including CO2 emissions, etc. Nevertheless, further growth in energy demands, mainly in developing countries, with a corresponding extension of the global energy supply is expected in the next century. Together with uneven distribution of energy resources throughout the planet this may cause further development of large energy systems of various kinds. And one possibility is the formation of a multiproduct world energy system that integrates specialized energy systems of power-, gas-, oil- and heat-supply into a single technologically interconnected aggregation. The concept of such a system is discussed in the paper.

Authors: Hargreaves T.A., Scheitrum G.P., Bemis T., Higgins L.
Title: 95 GHz, 4th harmonic gyro-oscillator
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Litton Systems, Inc, San Carlos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hargreaves, T.A., Litton Systems, Inc, San Carlos, United States; Scheitrum, G.P., Litton Systems, Inc, San Carlos, United States; Bemis, T., Litton Systems, Inc, San Carlos, United States; Higgins, L., Litton Systems, Inc, San Carlos, United States
Abstract: A 95 GHz, 4th harmonic oscillator based on a coaxial magnetron cavity was designed to test the cavity design of a 4-cavity gyro-amplifier being investigated by Litton. A small-signal code was developed to study the oscillation threshold sensitivity to cavity dimensions and electron beam parameters. A large-signal code initially developed at the Naval Research Laboratory was modified to study the high-power operation of the oscillator. In addition, capacitive probes will be added to the beam tunnel to provide information on the beam concentricity with the drift tube axis and average perpendicular and parallel electron velocities.

Authors: Whittenberger J.D.
Title: Mechanical properties of haynes alloy 188 after 22,500 hours of exposure to LiF-22CaF2 and vacuum at 1093 K
Source title: Journal of Materials Engineering and Performance
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Whittenberger, J.D., NASA Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States
Abstract: As a continuation of a study of a space-based thermal energy storage system centered on a LiF-CaF2 eutectic salt contained by Haynes alloy 188, this Co-base superalloy was subjected to molten salt, its vapor, and vacuum for 22,500 h at 1093 K. Samples from all three exposure conditions were tensile tested between 77 to 1200 K; in addition, vacuum and molten-salt exposed specimens were vacuum creep rupture tested at 1050 K. Comparison of these mechanical properties with those measured for the as-received alloy reveals no evidence for degradation beyond that ascribed to simple thermal aging of Haynes alloy 188. This behavior is identical to the 10,000 h results (Ref 3); hence, Haynes alloy 188 is a suitable containment material for an eutectic LiF-CaF2 thermal energy storage salt. © 1994 ASM International.
Author Keywords: Haynes alloy 188; heat treatment; long term exposure; mechanical properties; superalloy; thermal energy storage

Title: Electromagnetic field analysis of a microwave oven by the FD-TD method - a consideration on steady state analysis -

Abstract: A simulation program for a model of a microwave oven was developed using the FD-TD method. In this simulation program, both numerical and experimental results were similar. The sum of Poynting's vector were calculated, also the convergence to the steady state from the energy flow balancing were determined. It was shown that through application of correlation coefficient and regression coefficient, the similarity on the electromagnetic field patterns between different time steps was judged numerically.

Authors: Jacob E., Bouquet S., Tortel B.
Title: Global theoretical approach for the plasma of the electrothermal gun: scaling laws and a O-D time-dependent model
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science
Affiliations: Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, France
Authors with affiliations: Jacob, E., Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, France; Bouquet, S., Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, France; Tortel, B., Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, France
Abstract: In this paper theoretical analysis of the physical processes taking place in the Electrothermal Gun (ET Gun) is presented. In a first step, using the basic conservation equations (energy, mass, charge) integrated over the whole time of the discharge, scaling laws are derived. These laws provide the temperature, the mass, the resistance of the plasma and the current going through it, as functions of the storaged electrical energy. In a second step, a OD-time-dependent model is presented. This model takes into account the evolution of the complete system consisting in the electrical source, the plasma burner and the motion of the projectile. A special attention is given to the ablation phenomena and a microscopic description which differs from the one used previously by Loeb and Kaplan (IEEE Trans. Magnetics, 25, 342, 1989) or Zoler and Cuperman (J. Pl. Phys., 48, 215, 1992) is derived. Finally, comparisons with experiments are given and good agreements are obtained.
Index Keywords: Ablation; Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Integral equations; Microscopic examination; Numerical analysis; Basic conservation equation; Electrical sources; Electrothermal gun; O-D time dependent model; Physical processes; Scaling laws; Time dependent model; Plasma guns

Authors: Papadrakakis M., Babilis G., Braouzi G.P.
Title: Efficiency of refinement procedures for the p- version of the adaptive finite element method
Source title: International Conference on Computational Structures Technology - Proceedings
Affiliations: Natl Technical Univ, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Papadrakakis, M., Natl Technical Univ, Athens, Greece; Babilis, G., Natl Technical Univ, Athens, Greece; Braouzi, G.P., Natl Technical Univ, Athens, Greece
Abstract: The paper presents an efficiency study of different refinement procedures for the p-version of the adaptive finite element method in two-dimensional elasticity problems. The refinement strategy, based on the estimated error in energy norm, attempts an optimal distribution of the nodeless degrees of freedom associated with the basic approximation parameter of the order p of the hierarchic shape functions. This procedure is combined with appropriate matrix handling techniques and equation solvers in order to achieve a solution of a given accuracy with the minimum computational resources in terms of computing time and storage. To this extend convergence studies are performed with constant and variable adaptivity indices, with error estimators based on global and elemental approaches and with domain decomposition matrix handling techniques and the preconditioned conjugate gradient solver.
Index Keywords: Convergence of numerical methods; Degrees of freedom (mechanics); Elasticity; Hierarchical systems; Iterative methods; Stiffness; Conjugate gradient method; Error estimation; Linear equations; Finite element method

Authors: Ramadan Bassem H.
Title: Analysis of an underground electric heating system with short-term energy storage
Affiliations: Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ramadan, Bassem H., Michigan State Univ, East Lansing, United States
Abstract: A slab-heating system was analyzed for varying design parameters. This system was also optimized based on life-cycle costs. The suitability of using this system for a warehouse in four representative cities in U.S. was considered in which optimum insulation levels were determined. Due to the difficulty of controlling the energy release from the heating mats, the system may be inefficient for heating residential and office buildings but may be suitable for heating maintenance and storage facilities.

Authors: Strand R.K., Pedersen C.O., Coleman G.N.
Title: Development of direct and indirect ice-storage models for energy analysis calculations
Affiliations: Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strand, R.K., Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States; Pedersen, C.O., Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States; Coleman, G.N., Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, United States
Abstract: The development of models for both direct and indirect ice-storage systems is described and their salient features as applied to energy analysis calculations are discussed. These models have been implemented in the Building Load Analysis and System Thermodynamics (BLAST) energy analysis program. Relevant control strategies used by the ice-storage models are presented, and an example of matching the model parameters to the manufacturer's performance data is discussed.

Authors: Hittle D.C., Smith T.R.
Title: Control strategies and energy consumption for ice storage systems using heat recovery and cold air distribution
Affiliations: Colorado State Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hittle, D.C., Colorado State Univ, United States; Smith, T.R., Colorado State Univ, United States
Abstract: This paper reports the results of an investigation into the energy consumption of an ice storage system, with and without heat recovery and with and without cold air distribution systems. Simulation of a prototypical building in several different climates provided the basis for comparison. Results showed that a 'smart' control strategy is needed to make ice storage with heat recovery efficient. This strategy tries to melt just enough ice so that the recovered heat generated to remake this ice is enough to meet the daily heating demand. As expected, cold air distribution significantly reduced energy use. Cold deck reset proved disadvantageous in this case.
Index Keywords: Climate change; Control systems; Cooling systems; Energy utilization; Heating; Ice; Melting; Simulation; Waste heat utilization; Cold air distribution; Daily heating demand; Ice storage; Cold storage

Authors: Spark S.N., Cross A.W., Phelps A.D.R., Ronald K.
Title: Megawatt, 330 Hz PRF tunable gyrotron experiments
Source title: International Journal of Infrared and Millimeter Waves
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Applied Physics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, G4 0NG, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Spark, S.N., Department of Physics and Applied Physics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, G4 0NG, United Kingdom; Cross, A.W., Department of Physics and Applied Physics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, G4 0NG, United Kingdom; Phelps, A.D.R., Department of Physics and Applied Physics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, G4 0NG, United Kingdom; Ronald, K., Department of Physics and Applied Physics, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, G4 0NG, United Kingdom
Abstract: Repetitively pulsed and cw gyrotrons have hitherto used thermionic cathodes, whereas cold cathode gyrotrons have normally operated as 'single shot' devices. The novel results presented here show that cold cathode gyrotrons can be successfully pulsed repetitively. A tunable gyrotron with a pulse repetition frequency (PRF) of 150Hz is demonstrated. This system developed >4MW mm-wave output pulses at 100GHz. The gyrotron is based on a two-electrode configuration comprising a field-immersed, field emission, cold cathode and a shaped anode cavity. A superconducting magnet was used to produce the homogeneous intra-cavity magnetic field and a cable pulser was used to drive the electron beam. This pulser produced up to a (200±20)kV pulse with 10ns rise time, a 100ns flat top, a 10ns decay with a characteristic impedance of 200Ω. The energy storage capacity of the cable pulser was 35J. The charging unit limited the maximum PRF to 330Hz. Due to spark gap switching limitations 330Hz was only obtainable in 5 to 10 pulse bursts. For substantial periods of the order of 30 seconds, 100Hz PRF was achieved over an oscillating range of 28 to 100GHz and 150Hz PRF was achieved at 80GHz. No degradation effects on the mm-wave output pulse was evident due to diode recovery time throughout this series of results. A subsequent conclusion is that the diode recovery time in our cold cathode gyrotron is less than 3ms. © 1994 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Author Keywords: Gyrotron; Megawatt Gyrotron; Repetitively pulsed gyrotron
Index Keywords: Anodes; Electric impedance; Electron beams; Energy storage; Frequencies; Magnetic fields; Millimeter waves; Superconducting magnets; Thermionic cathodes; Cable pulser; Pulse repetition frequency; Gyrotrons

Authors: Krishnan R., Lee S.
Title: Analysis and design of a single switch per phase converter for switched reluctance motor drives
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Krishnan, R., Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Lee, S., Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Abstract: One of the unique features of the switched reluctance motor (hereafter referred to as SRM) is that it requires only unipolar current for its four quadrant operation thus simplifying the converter topologies. This paper considers the analysis and design of one such converter with minimum switches which is known as C-dump converter for use in non-bifilar wound SRM drive. The analysis of this topology includes the evaluation of the switching losses of the power switching devices and diodes, their current and voltage stresses, relationship between the energy storage capacitor, inductor and the duty cycle of the energy recovery circuit and the efficiency of the overall system for a given switching frequency. From the analysis, design procedure for the converter circuit is developed. The theoretical analysis and design procedure both validated with experimental results obtained from a laboratory prototype are presented in this paper.
Index Keywords: Choppers (circuits); Electric drives; Electric losses; Electric network analysis; Electric network synthesis; Electric network topology; Machine windings; Reluctance motors; Transients; C dump converter; Single switch per phase converter; Switched reluctance motor drives; Switching losses; Power converters

Authors: Andrepont J.S.
Title: Performance and economics of CT inlet air cooling using chilled-water storage
Affiliations: Chicago Bridge & Iron Co, Plainfield, United States
Authors with affiliations: Andrepont, J.S., Chicago Bridge & Iron Co, Plainfield, United States
Abstract: An analysis of combustion turbine (CT) inlet air cooling is presented for a specific electric utility application using existing CTs. Key design parameters are quantitatively analyzed, including storage medium, daily cycles versus weekly cycles, new storage tanks versus converted fuel oil tanks, the cooled temperature of the inlet air, and the hours of CT cooling per day. Capital cost estimates are based on a comprehensive design-build project procurement inclusive of design, equipment and material, installation, project management, QA/QC, O&M training, start-up, and commissioning. For this application, chilled-water storage configured as a daily cycle provided the optimum results, approximately a 20% increase in net peak power output for the facility, a 5% reduction in heat rate (specific fuel consumption), 40% less off-peak energy consumption than for alternative storage technologies, and a unit capital cost 50% below that of new CT capacity.
Index Keywords: Costs; Economics; Electric load management; Electric power utilization; Heat storage; Installation; Performance; Temperature; Turbines; Chilled water storage; Combustion turbine; Electric power utilities; Inlet air cooling; Inlet air cooling installation; Inlet air temperature; Peaking power generation capacity; Cooling

Authors: Brady T.W.
Title: Achieving energy conservation with ice-based thermal storage
Affiliations: Brady Consulting Services, Inc, Westchester, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brady, T.W., Brady Consulting Services, Inc, Westchester, United States
Abstract: In the last few years, studies have reported that, while reducing on-peak instantaneous demand for electrical energy, some existing ice-based thermal storage systems significantly increase overall annual energy consumption. It is thus feared that incentives offered by various electric utility companies to reduce on-peak demand for electricity, and thereby cost to the customer, will actually increase electrical generating requirements and lead to a waste of natural resources and increased environmental pollution. In this report, actual data collected from buildings that have at least two years of operating experience will be used to demonstrate that the negative impacts recognized by these studies can be avoided when designers take full advantage of the unique technological features offered by an ice-based thermal system. Specifically, it will be shown that a thermal storage system that is fully integrated with the total building design will reduce annual energy consumption, reduce peak demand, reduce annual operating costs, and reduce the environmental impact from the use of mechanical systems. The net impact of thermal storage systems upon the environment at the generation source will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Electric load management; Electric utilities; Electricity; Energy utilization; Environmental impact; Heat storage; Natural resources; Systems analysis; Technology; Ventilation; HVAC system; Ice-based thermal energy storage; On peak demand; Energy conservation

Authors: Tay H.C., Conlon M.F., Bonwick W.J.
Title: Development of a SMES device for application to problems of load unbalance
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Monash Univ, Clayton
Authors with affiliations: Tay, H.C., Monash Univ, Clayton; Conlon, M.F., Monash Univ, Clayton; Bonwick, W.J., Monash Univ, Clayton
Abstract: In electrical distribution networks, unbalanced loads are often encountered and are occasionally unavoidable. Unbalanced current flow can result in unbalanced voltage at the point-of-common-coupling. Dynamic compensation methods used have involved thyristor-controlled admittance networks. In this paper, a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) device is proposed as an alternative unbalanced load compensator. Using pulse width modulation (PWM) switching strategy, the SMES device has the advantages of controlled generation of low order harmonics and fast dynamic response. It also has the ability to supply short-term energy. Unbalanced load compensation is achieved by supplying the load negative sequence current. The paper also describes the development of the SMES device and experimental results of unbalanced load compensation. Further development of this study and potential application of a SMES device in the electric supply industry is also discussed.
Index Keywords: Dynamic response; Electric currents; Electric load flow; Electric power distribution; Harmonic generation; Power converters; Pulse width modulation; Switching networks; Switching systems; Dynamic compensation; Load unbalance; Point of common coupling; Superconducting magnetic energy storage device; Thyristor controlled admittance networks; Unbalanced current flow; Unbalanced voltage; Superconducting devices

Authors: Bahnfleth W.P., Joyce W.S.
Title: Energy use in a district cooling system with stratified chilled-water storage
Affiliations: ZBA, Inc, Cincinnati, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bahnfleth, W.P., ZBA, Inc, Cincinnati, United States; Joyce, W.S., ZBA, Inc, Cincinnati, United States
Abstract: Thermal storage clearly benefits cooling system owners by reducing electric demand charges. However, the use of thermal storage is widely believed to increase overall cooling plant energy consumption. Data from the first full season of operation of a 4.4-million-gallon (16,676-m3) stratified chilled-water storage addition at a U.S. university demonstrates that a well-designed and operated system can actually improve plant efficiency. Energy penalties associated with thermal storage were offset by more efficient chiller operation. Design features and operational procedures that tend to minimize energy consumption in stratified chilled-water storage systems are discussed and illustrated with data from the university system.
Index Keywords: Cooling systems; Costs; Energy conservation; Energy efficiency; Energy policy; Heat storage; Systems analysis; Thermal stratification; Chilled-water storage; District cooling system; Efficient chiller operation; Energy penalties; Plant energy consumption; Energy utilization

Affiliations: Texas Instruments, Inc, Dallas, United States

Abstract: Recent developments have produced more efficient and better integrated thermal energy storage systems that use less electricity and natural gas than conventional cooling/heating systems. In order to appraise engineers of the technology's potential for energy conservation, this paper studies the design and operation of a thermally stratified chilled-water storage system in an industrial retrofit application.

Affiliations: Calmac Manufacturing Corp, Englewood, United States

Abstract: A means of generating additional on-peak power for utilities and cogenerators is being tested on combustion turbines (CTs) with considerable energy savings. The preferable inlet temperature when cooling is approximately 47°F so as to avoid the high cost of coils and an excessive lower temperature latent heat requirement. It is found that gas turbines with generators appear to be the power generation method of the future with efficiency comparable to steam plants and at a far lower cost, easier siting and fast response.

Authors with affiliations: Menictas, C., Univ of New South Wales, Kensington; Hong, D.R., Univ of New South Wales, Kensington; Yan, Z.H., Univ of New South Wales, Kensington; Wilson, Yan J., Univ of New South Wales, Kensington; Kazacos, M., Univ of New South Wales, Kensington; Skyllas-Kazacos, M., Univ of New South Wales, Kensington
Abstract: Redox flow battery systems have been under investigation for use in energy storage application for some time. The early systems had certain limitations such as electrolyte cross-contamination however, the vanadium redox flow battery system does not suffer from such limitations due to the common element in both positive and negative half-cell electrolytes. Various components of the vanadium battery have been developed by methods suitable for large scale commercialisation. A 5kW/13kWh system has been installed in a solar demonstration house and its suitability for application in energy self sufficient housing is currently being evaluated. A 4kW/4kWh vanadium battery system has also been installed in a golf cart and initial vehicle road trials have shown its viability in traction applications. Presently a 4kW vanadium battery system is under development for evaluation as a back-up battery in submarines.

Abstract: A commercially available household refrigerator was modified to include a Thermal Energy Storage device in its fresh food compartment. Abstract: The design of efficient switched capacitor power converters is addressed. It starts with a review of the fundamental limitation of switched capacitor circuits which shows that the topology of such circuits and the forced step changes of capacitor voltages are inherent attributes of power loss. Also discussed is a simple version of lossless topology that achieves isolation between the source and the load. An experimental AC/DC switched capacitor converters based on an improved efficiency over other existing switched capacitor converters is presented. The proposed AC/DC converter contains no inductors and is suitable for custom IC implementation for very low power applications.

Abstract: Resonant soft switched high power Inverter Based Static VAR compensators (ISVC's) can provide higher switching frequencies than present hard switched ISVC's. This allows a faster transient response so that the ISVC can also be used simultaneously as an active filter to reduce supply harmonics and random flicker caused by arc furnaces. System sub-synchronous resonance compensation can be implemented at the same time and precise injected current control will result in faster damping of alternator torsional mode oscillations than is presently possible.

Abstract: An extensive review of published material on electrical residential water heating was performed, and comments are presented concerning critical issues of water heating. First, the phenomenon of Legionella pneumophila bacteria is studied. Second, electrical energy consumption is reviewed. Finally, the energy savings of improved technological devices are considered. The objective of this survey is to provide an organized report on the aforementioned aspects of electrical water heating in residential homes, thus forming a basis for conducting future research.

Abstract: Thin films of lead zirconate stannate titanate (PSZT) with slight additions of niobium and lanthanum have been prepared by the sol-gel, spin coat process. Antiferroelectric tetragonal and orthorhombic compositions have been evaluated on the criteria of P-E loop squareness, maximum polarization and field induced strain for the applications of energy storage and conversion in integrated devices. The orthorhombic compositions in both the niobium and lanthanum doped systems have shown square loop hysteretic behavior with large switchable polarizations (30-40μC/cm2), and field-induced strains of 0.33% have been measured in the niobium doped system, thus both systems provide attractive possibilities for practical use.

Title: Linear control of series resonant converter
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Computers in Power Electronics
Affiliations: EIVL, Blois, France
Authors with affiliations: Tahri, D., EIVL, Blois, France; Drissi El Khamlichi, K., EIVL, Blois, France; Gaubert, J.P., EIVL, Blois, France; Jaafari, A., EIVL, Blois, France
Abstract: A new method called 'linear control' is suggested to command a series resonant converter operating super the resonant frequency. Its principle is to control simultaneously the levels of energy storage elements L and C in a simple way: a linear combination of the two state variables of the resonant circuit. This process notably favors the high-frequency DC-DC conversions, giving also fast dynamics close to those of the optimal trajectory control. In addition, this method is very easy to apply analogically as well as numerically and in both cases the cost is minimal. Numerical simulation results confirm the performances of the linear control as for transient regime. This strategy can be easily applied to other types of resonance (parallel or series-parallel) operating at frequencies sub and super the resonant frequency.

Abstract: A PV Grid connected system with small battery bank has been set up in a rural district, North Thailand in order to demonstrate a 2-mode operation concept. The objective is to gain experience on the PV Grid connected concept with out battery storage. However, due to the evening peak demand and a rather weak distribution grid which is typical in rural areas, small battery bank is still required to enable 'the maximum energy transfer to grid' for the time being before moving fully to the no Battery mode. The analyzed data seems to indicate possible performance improvement by re-arranging the number of PV modules and battery in the string.

Authors: Daryanian Bahman, Norford Leslie K.
Title: Minimum-cost control of HVAC systems under real time prices
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Control Applications
Affiliations: Tabors Caramanis & Associates, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Daryanian, Bahman, Tabors Caramanis & Associates, Cambridge, United States; Norford, Leslie K., Tabors Caramanis & Associates, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: Dynamic optimal control strategies for HVAC equipment can be derived to minimize electrical power usage or cost of operation. By accounting for the thermal dynamics of the building structure and furnishings and any dedicated thermal storage systems, dynamic approaches permit equipment use to be rescheduled, within constraints of equipment size and permissible indoor temperature variations, in order to improve part-load performance or to operate equipment when the price of electricity is lower. Rescheduling equipment operation must account for storage losses, particularly when the building mass is the storage element and stored energy leaks to the environment. This paper focuses on the rescheduling problem under a very general rate structure known as real-time pricing, designed to accurately express short-term variations in the cost to the utility for producing and transmitting electricity. It examines the mathematical properties of the set of linear difference equations used to model thermal dynamics which are to be asymptotically stable, positive dynamic systems. This permits a much more rapid and elegant series of calculations to establish the optimal schedule than is possible with conventional linear programming techniques. Also presented are results from a hypothetical case study and from actual performance of an HVAC control system with storage.
Index Keywords: Asymptotic stability; Calculations; Climate control; Constraint theory; Difference equations; Electric power utilization; Linear algebra; Linear programming; Numerical analysis; Performance; Real time systems; Variational techniques; Dynamic optimal control strategies; Linear difference equation; Minimum cost control; Night setback control; Peak cooling power; Real time prices; Storage losses; Temperature variations; Thermal dynamics; Thermal storage systems; Optimal control systems

Title: Annual cycling characteristics of components in gas-fired combination space/water heating systems
Authors with affiliations: Pietsch, J.A.; Talbert, S.G.; Stanbouly, S.H.
Abstract: An analysis has been made to predict the number of fan/pump cycles, the number of burner/gas-valve cycles, and the burner operating hours that combination (combo) heating systems utilizing a gas-fired water heater may experience in a typical year of operation. The cycling characteristics were determined for reasonable ranges of climates, equipment sizing ratios, and hot water usage rates. The climatic data represented the six heating regions of the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) that are used for rating the heating performance of appliances. The combination heating system cycling characteristics were predicted for a wide range of variables utilizing a bin calculation method similar to that used for evaluating furnace or heat pump performance. An understanding of these operating parameters will give those who design and install combo systems important insights into system and component cycling characteristics.

Title: Novel soft-switched PWM current source rectifier/inverter
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
