Authors with affiliations: Moschopoulos, Gerry, Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada; Joos, Geza, Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: A novel soft-switched PWM current source rectifier/inverter (CSR/I) is proposed in this paper. It reduces switching losses without requiring costly and complex energy recovery circuitry. Soft-switching operation is, instead, achieved by using an auxiliary circuit consisting of only two additional switches and a few passive components. The proposed converter can be operated with any known PWM technique for CSR/Is, unlike other CSR/Is which can only operate with dedicated and complex PWM schemes or with discrete pulse modulation. In this paper, the modes of operation of the converter are explained and analyzed, and a set of design guidelines is developed. The feasibility of the converter is shown with results obtained from an experimental prototype.

Abstract: Optimal dynamic building control strategies were compared with night setback control through experiments at a test facility representative of a room in a large office building. Two optimal dynamic control strategies were considered: minimum total energy costs and minimum peak electrical demand. Results showed that up to 51% of the total cooling load could be shifted to off-peak hours through optimal control. The reduction in the peak cooling load was found to as much as 40%. Occupant thermal comport was also measured during the experiments and maintained within acceptable limits for all control strategies tested. Measured cooling loads compare well with those predicted by the simulation and validate the simulation method.

Authors: Liaw C.M., Chiang S.J.
Title: Design and implementation of a single-phase three-wire transformerless battery energy storage system
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Liaw, C.M., Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chiang, S.J., Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: This paper presents a single-phase three-wire (1φ3 w) transformerless battery energy storage system (BESS). Its power circuit is simple, since it consists of only one converter. It has three legs to provide 1φ3 w 220/110 V output without using transformer. For switching control, the BESS is decoupled into differential-mode and common-mode subsystems. Each subsystem has its own inner-loop current-forced switching control mechanism, their current commands at various operating modes are generated by outer-loop controllers. The controllers of differential-mode are designed to control the main voltage (220 V) source, and meanwhile to achieve the desired functions of BESS. As to the common-mode subsystem, its controllers are used to maintain the voltage balance of two subcircuits (110 V circuits) when utility grid failed, and to keep the current in neutral line of utility grid be zero when utility grid is in normal condition. The operation principle of the proposed BESS and the design of controllers in various operating modes are described in detail. Some experimental results are provided to show the performance of the proposed BESS.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric converters; Electric current control; Electric load management; Electric utilities; Environmental protection; Voltage control; Common mode subsystems; Differential mode subsystems; Single phase three wire transformerless battery energy storage system; Electric energy storage

Authors: Kelsey Jim
Title: Understand power management to optimize performance and power savings
Affiliations: SystemSoft Corp, Natick, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kelsey, Jim, SystemSoft Corp, Natick, United States
Abstract: Power-management equipped systems incorporate special chipsets and firmware that can put the computer into a variety of dozing or sleep states depending upon the amount of system activity they detect. This monitoring places special constraints on users to understand what constitutes activity so they can predict when machines go to sleep and when they wake up. For engineers using PC-based tools or building systems incorporating embedded PCs, the incorporation of power-management capabilities could have dramatic effects on how they develop code and interact with add-on peripherals. The basics of what happens when a PC goes to sleep is explained here, and a simple example of how to configure a PC to recognize an add-on peripheral card is provided.
Index Keywords: Computer aided software engineering; Computer monitors; Computer peripheral equipment; Control equipment; Energy conservation; Energy management; Performance; Random access storage; Shift registers; User interfaces; Central processing unit; Firmware; Nonmaskable interrupt; Power management; System activity; Personal computers

Authors: Lachs W.R., Sutanto D.
Title: Energy storage for future power system applications
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Univ of NSW, Sydney
Authors with affiliations: Lachs, W.R., Univ of NSW, Sydney; Sutanto, D., Univ of NSW, Sydney
Abstract: The present evolution of power systems, as well as introducing a competitive market, is adding to the difficulties of power system control. The fast changes of demand and its high level during the daily peak periods require major expenditures by utilities on generators and the power network. On the other hand, because of its short duration, the peak load period absorbs only a tiny percentage of the daily energy consumption, so making energy storage attractive. The coming introduction of electric vehicles in cities from 1998, triggered by the 'California Initiative' will introduce growing amounts of battery energy storage. If electricity utilities take advantage of this opportunity to access portion of their stored energy, important operational and cost benefits could be gained. Accessible energy storage could curtail the daily load peaks as well as damping out fast changes of load, but additionally it would provide a reservoir, allowing optimum utilisation of renewable energy sources.

Abstract: It is desirable to extract maximum power from solar cells under various sunlight insolation conditions, for battery charging applications. An economical solar battery charger and its control principle are proposed and implemented by the authors. The operating principles, effects of circuit parameters and comparative test results are presented in the paper. The test results show that the proposed charger improves the energy utilization at both low and high insolation conditions.

Authors: TenWolde A.
Title: Ventilation, humidity, and condensation in manufactured houses during winter
Affiliations: Dep of Agriculture Forest Service, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: TenWolde, A., Dep of Agriculture Forest Service, Madison, United States
Abstract: Many manufactured homes have lower natural ventilation rates than those in site-built houses. This, combined with high occupancy levels, may lead to moisture problems, which can cause structural damage and health problems. This study (1) obtained information on the moisture behavior of manufactured houses and moisture release from occupants and other sources and (2) evaluated the effect of mechanical ventilation. Measurement of the ventilation and indoor humidity in six manufactured houses during winter indicated that ventilation in manufactured homes is often less than recommended. To improve ventilation, manufactured houses should be supplied with balanced mechanical ventilation with an automatic control and manual override. In the absence of an inexpensive alternative, a humidistat control may be used during winter to prevent condensation without excessive heat or comfort loss. However, a humidistat control does not ensure that ASHRAE minimum ventilation levels will be achieved.
Index Keywords: Atmospheric humidity; Automation; Condensation; Effects; Energy dissipation; Energy utilization; Health hazards; Houses; Mathematical models; Moisture; Moisture control; Automatic control; High occupancy levels; Humidistat control; Manual override; Mechanical ventilation; Mechanical ventilation effects; Moisture problems; Moisture release; Moisture storage rates; Ventilation

Authors: Zaheer-uddin M., Zheng G.R.
Title: Dynamic model of a multizone VAV system for control analysis
Affiliations: Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Zaheer-uddin, M., Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada; Zheng, G.R., Concordia Univ, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: A transient model of a two-zone variable-air-volume (VAV) system is developed. The system consists of two environmental zones, a cooling and dehumidifying coil, a chiller and storage tank, a fan, and a ductwork system. A total of 328 nonlinear time-varying equations are used to describe the dynamics of the VAV system. Nine control inputs to the system (six dampers, fan and chiller energy inputs, and mass flow rate of chilled water) can be varied to study their effects on zone temperatures, humidity ratios, supply air conditions, mass flow rates, fan speed, chilled-water temperature, outdoor airflow rates, and mixed air conditions. The disturbances acting on the system are those due to variations in outdoor temperature, sensible and latent loads on the zones, plenum temperature, and the temperature of the water returning from the cooling tower. Results are given showing the open-loop responses of the system subject to the constant inputs and disturbances cited above.

Authors: Ishibashi Akira

Source title: Conference Digest - IEEE International Semiconductor Laser Conference
Affiliations: Sony Corp Research Cent, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ishibashi, Akira, Sony Corp Research Cent, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: For the next generation of Conventional LDs, the short wavelength, green and blue will be much needed for purposes of higher density disk systems. This is so because, the shorter the wavelength becomes, the higher the density of those optical disks can be, thus leading to either a long time or a high definition recording. Moreover, with the green and the blue LDs, human race is entering a new paradigm where RGB full-color all-solid-state light sources are at hand in an inexpensive, mass productive, and highly compact manner.
Index Keywords: Charge carriers; Density (optical); Display devices; Energy gap; Heterojunctions; Laser recording; Light sources; Microprocessor chips; Optical disk storage; Reliability; Semiconductor device structures; Blue green laser diodes; Continuous wave; High density disk systems; High density recording; Separate confinement heterostructure structure; Solid state light sources; Semiconductor lasers

Authors: Simmonds P.
Title: Comparison of energy consumption for storage priority and chiller priority for ice-based thermal storage systems
Affiliations: RTB Van Heugten b.v., Groningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Simmonds, P., RTB Van Heugten b.v., Groningen, Netherlands
Abstract: Chilled water can be produced either by a storage-priority or a chiller-priority system. Both systems have partial storage to optimize plant capacity and minimize capital costs. But the operating strategies for both systems differ; the parameters controlling the production and utilization of chilled water are functions of the intended strategy for production and use of chilled water. Load control optimizes the plant's electrical power use by using the load profile produced from simulation results. It is possible to use a predictable control strategy that minimizes the cooling plant load.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Cooling systems; Electric power utilization; Heat storage; Optimization; Predictive control systems; Production control; Chilled water; Chiller; Cooling plant load; Ice-based thermal storage; Operational strategies; Optimize plant capacity; Plant electrical power; Energy utilization

Authors: Stewart Jr. William E., Cai Lihong, Sohn C.W.
Title: Thermal stratification of chilled-water slot flows into storage tanks
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stewart Jr., William E., Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Cai, Lihong, Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Sohn, C.W., Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States
Abstract: A numerical model was used to simulate the two-dimensional flow of chilled water into a storage tank initially filled with warm water. The inlet flow is from a small slot in one vertical wall at the bottom of the tank. The numerical model employs a transient stream function-vorticity formulation to predict the streamline and temperature distributions in the tank as a function of time. Turbulence was modeled using the turbulent kinetic energy and turbulent length scale equations. The model results for a side-slot inlet to the tank reveal that the Archimedes number should be greater than 5 and the Reynolds number should be smaller than 1,000 to ensure thermal stratification of the hot and cold water. When stratification is achieved, the temperature distribution varies only in the vertical direction of the tank, where the water temperature is approximately uniform in the horizontal direction. The numerical results are in reasonably good agreement with some experimental data available in the literature.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Computer simulation; Flow of water; Mathematical models; Reynolds number; Temperature distribution; Turbulence; Turbulent flow; Archimedes number; Chilled water; Kinetic energy; Storage tank; Transient stream function vorticity formulation; Thermal stratification

Authors: Holler Paul T., Lee Hyun
Title: Digital CMOS programmable clock generator
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual IEEE International ASIC Conference and Exhibit
Affiliations: AT&T Bell Lab, Allentown, United States
Authors with affiliations: Holler, Paul T., AT&T Bell Lab, Allentown, United States; Lee, Hyun, AT&T Bell Lab, Allentown, United States
Abstract: The digital CMOS software programmable clock generator (PCG) was designed as a macro cell to provide quadrature clocks for the HobbitTM based Personal Communicators. The PCG produces a highly accurate variable frequency system clock from 20KHz to 100MHz (10KHz to 50MHz in quadrature), while using a single inexpensive crystal oscillator as a reference. Both the frequency and tolerance of PCG can be programmed by the user. This cell resides inside the system control chip and has a bus interface allowing local storage of programmed data. Control signals which start and stop operation come from a power management portion of the chip. The output frequency can be changed on the fly.

Authors: Byrne John, Wang Young-Doo, Letendre Stephen, Govindarajalu Chandrasekar, Nigro Ralph, Bottenberg William
Title: Deployment of a dispatchable photovoltaic system: technical and economic results
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States
Authors with affiliations: Byrne, John, Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States; Wang, Young-Doo, Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States; Letendre, Stephen, Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States; Govindarajalu, Chandrasekar, Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States; Nigro, Ralph, Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States; Bottenberg, William, Univ of Delaware, Newark, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the incorporation of PV as a demand-side management (DSM) tool. The valuation of the benefits provided by PV in a DSM role indicates that it is much closer to commercial viability than was thought from economic analyses focusing exclusively on this technology as a supply-side option. However, in order to realize PV's potential, this technology must be deployed in high-value DSM applications; in particular, applications that promise dispatchable peak-shaving capability. Our analysis of the performance of a prototype system installed by Delmarva Power, indicates that small-scale, commercial customer-sited DSM systems incorporating this technology are approaching competitive cost levels.

Authors: Schroll Craig R.
Title: Fuel cell power system for UUVs
Affiliations: Int Fuel Cells Corp, South Windsor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schroll, Craig R., Int Fuel Cells Corp, South Windsor, United States
Abstract: International Fuel Cells Corp has successfully demonstrated a 10-kW prototype of a 20-kW fuel cell power plant designed to be installed in a 44-in unmanned underwater vehicle. The power plant features multiple proton-exchange-membrane fuel-cell stacks and supporting ancillary components. The power plant is fueled by hydrogen and oxygen and produces only heat and potable water as byproducts of the electrochemical reaction. Energy efficiency of up to 68% has been demonstrated at rated power. The power plant is based on a passive system concept requiring no circulation of gases for thermal management and minimal water management, enhancing reliability and durability and maximizing energy density and vehicle range.
Index Keywords: Control equipment; Energy storage; Heat exchangers; Hydrogen; Ion exchange membranes; Oxygen; Power plants; Submersibles; Bill of material stack; Fuel cell power systems; Plant design; Proton exchange membranes; Unmanned undersea vehicles; Fuel cells

Abstract: The use of mathematical models in enhancing the performance of building services systems is discussed. In particular a full-scale HVAC system is studied to demonstrate the potential of such methods with emphasis on controller design. The paper objectively assesses the model-based predictive on/off control strategy against the standard on/off controller by directly comparing the implementational results from the test system.

Authors: Mizany Anoosh
Title: Living on PV power in comfort and style
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Solar Depot Inc
Authors with affiliations: Mizany, Anoosh, Solar Depot Inc
Abstract: The Solectrogen House near San Francisco was conceived, designed and built by Solar Depot as an offgrid renewable energy house. It is powered by a Solectrogen Hybrid Power System consisting of a 3kW PV array, two 1kW wind powered generators, a 50kWH storage battery bank and a 6.5kW LP-fueled engine generator for back-up. Two 4kW sinewave DC to AC inverters are utilized, with 24VDC input and 120/240 VAC 60Hz output. The inverters are equipped with built-in battery chargers and microprocessors for controlling the engine generator operation. The water supply of the house is a well pumped by a PV powered submersible DC pump. The swimming pool filtration system utilizes a 3/4HP DC pump powered by a separate dedicated PV array of 640 Watts at 90V. Energy efficient lighting and refrigeration used in the house minimize the power requirements of the house. The house also utilizes a solar thermal system consisting of 640 sq. ft. of glazed solar collectors and a 500 gallon storage tank. The thermal system is utilized for heating water year round, for space heating in the winter and for swimming pool heating in the summer.
Index Keywords: Electric generators; Electric inverters; Electric lighting; Electric space heating; Energy efficiency; Microprocessor chips; Refrigeration; Solar cell arrays; Solar collectors; Submersible pumps; Wind power; Engine generator; Storage battery bank; Swimming pool filtration system; Water heating; Wind powered generator; Electric power plants

Authors: Tsuda Izumi, Kurokawa Kosuke, Nozaki Ken
Title: Development of intermittent redox flow battery for PV system
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Lab
Authors with affiliations: Tsuda, Izumi, Electrotechnical Lab; Kurokawa, Kosuke, Electrotechnical Lab; Nozaki, Ken, Electrotechnical Lab
Abstract: Redox flow battery has been developed as a storage device for photovoltaic systems. The pump loss is the greatest problem for redox flow battery under the low current condition. An intermittent flow redox battery has been developed for the reduction of the pump loss. The experimental results of this battery show that the efficiency under the intermittent pump operation increases higher than the continuous pump operation. Moreover, inert gas bubble technology has been introduced to improve the performance under the high current condition. It is clear from the experiments that this technology increases the efficiencies. The simulation results of these technologies are coincident with experimental results. It is shown by the simulation that they can improve the Faradic and energy efficiencies of a number of stacks in series.

Authors: Rudischer Rainer, Ulbrich Guenter
Title: Transportable stand-alone solar immission measuring station with optimised photovoltaic energy supply
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Inst for Air Conditioning and, Refrigeration (ILK), Dresden, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rudischer, Rainer, Inst for Air Conditioning and, Refrigeration (ILK), Dresden, Germany; Ulbrich, Guenter, Inst for Air Conditioning and, Refrigeration (ILK), Dresden, Germany
Abstract: The damage of forest ecosystems by aerosol wastes and contaminants is increasing. This fact led to an alarming situation in Europe and world-wide, which made it necessary to install measuring stations to investigate causes and observe the ecological immission situation mainly in silvicultures at desirable locations distant from grid connection and urbanisation. The presented measuring station satisfies those requirements by means of an emission-free, self-sufficient and optimised photovoltaic energy supply in combination with an absolute maintenance-free, long-live battery-storage system. The energy demand was minimised by means of a variable clocked measurement operation and modification of measuring instruments. Further, a so called PMPP- (Programmed MPP) control system, implemented into the overall control system, optimises the energy supply.
Index Keywords: Aerosols; Ecology; Ecosystems; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy utilization; Installation; Optimal control systems; Solar cells; Solar energy; Combustion emission; Grid connection; Photovoltaic stand alone; Solar immission; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Rafalovich A., Longardner W., Keller G., Schmidter T.C., Fleming F.
Title: Thermal management of electric vehicle's batteries using phase change materials
Source title: Winter Annual Meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers
Affiliations: SHAPE, Inc, Indianapolis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rafalovich, A., SHAPE, Inc, Indianapolis, United States; Longardner, W., SHAPE, Inc, Indianapolis, United States; Keller, G., SHAPE, Inc, Indianapolis, United States; Schmidter, T.C., SHAPE, Inc, Indianapolis, United States; Fleming, F., SHAPE, Inc, Indianapolis, United States
Abstract: SHAPE, Inc. and Hawker Energy Products Ltd. have successfully developed a passive thermal management system for sealed lead acid batteries featuring Phase Change Materials (PCM's). The system utilizes a reversible, high energy density PCM with a transition temperature that is comparable to the optimum operating temperature of lead acid batteries. SHAPE's thermal storage, containing non-toxic, non-hazardous, non-flammable PCM, absorbs excess heat generated by a battery and thus provides a substantial improvement in thermal stability, operating performance, and battery life. A mathematical model has been developed to accurately predict the thermal behavior of a battery, with and without PCM, during cycling. The results of this model have been verified through experimental battery cycling as well as through actual battery testing. The success of the model permits analysis of a thermally managed battery through an extreme range of ambient temperatures (-40 °C to 40°C).
Index Keywords: Electric vehicles; Energy absorption; Energy management; Equipment testing; Forecasting; Heat transfer; Mathematical models; Performance; Service life; Thermodynamic stability; Battery testing; Heat absorption; Lead acid batteries; Phase change materials; Thermal management; Transition temperature; Secondary batteries

Authors: Papageorgiou L.G., Shah N., Pantelides C.C.
Title: Optimal Scheduling of Heat-Integrated Multipurpose Plants
Affiliations: Centre for Process Systems Engineering, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London SW7 2BY, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Papageorgiou, L.G., Centre for Process Systems Engineering, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London SW7 2BY, United Kingdom; Shah, N., Centre for Process Systems Engineering, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London SW7 2BY, United Kingdom; Pantelides, C.C., Centre for Process Systems Engineering, Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine, London SW7 2BY, United Kingdom
Abstract: A systematic mathematical framework for scheduling the operation of multipurpose batch/ semicontinuous plants involving heat-integrated unit operations is presented. The approach advocated takes direct account of the trade-offs between maximal exploitation of heat integration and other scheduling objectives and constraints. Both direct and indirect heat integration are considered. In the former case, heat transfer takes place directly between the fluids undergoing processing in the heat-integrated unit operations, and therefore a degree of time overlap of these operations must be ensured. It is shown that this involves only relatively minor modifications to existing detailed scheduling formulations. Indirect heat integration utilizes a heat transfer medium (HTM) which acts as a mechanism both for transferring heat from one operation to another and for storing energy over time. This provides a degree of decoupling with respect to the timing of the operations involved. The mathematical formulation presented in this paper is based on a detailed characterization of the variation of the mass and energy holdups of HTM over time. In particular, it takes account of the limitations on energy storage due to heat losses to the environment. A modified branch-and-bound procedure is proposed for the solution of the resulting nonconvex mixed integer nonlinear programming problem. © 1994, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Heat losses; Heat storage; Heat transfer; Mass transfer; Mathematical models; Nonlinear programming; Scheduling; Heat integrated unit operations; Industrial plants

Authors: Gretarsson S.P., Pedersen C.O., Strand R.K.
Title: Development of a fundamentally based stratified thermal storage tank model for energy analysis calculations
Affiliations: Doenges GmbH Consulting Engineers, Biebertal, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gretarsson, S.P., Doenges GmbH Consulting Engineers, Biebertal, Germany; Pedersen, C.O., Doenges GmbH Consulting Engineers, Biebertal, Germany; Strand, R.K., Doenges GmbH Consulting Engineers, Biebertal, Germany
Abstract: Stratified thermal storage systems utilize the temperature dependence of water density to store both warm return water and cold supply water in a single tank. Manifolds and diffusers at the tank inlets minimize turbulence and mixing in the tank, resulting in a relatively small thermocline between the hot and cold layers. A discrete time step model based on previous work by Wildin and Truman (1985) was developed for implementation in an hourly energy analysis program. The model numerically solves the one-dimensional, time-dependent equation for the tank water temperatures using a Runge-Kutta method. Appropriate time scaling was required to achieve stability. Sensitivity to model and environmental parameters is discussed. The performance of the model is compared to experimental data and a finite difference model.
Index Keywords: Calculations; Diffusers (fluid); Energy storage; Finite difference method; Intake systems; Mixing; Numerical methods; Tanks (containers); Thermal effects; Thermal stratification; Turbulence; Water supply; Energy analysis; One dimensional; Runge Kutta method; Stratified thermal storage systems; Time dependent equation; Time scaling; Time step model; Mathematical models

Authors: Ameen Ahmadul
Title: Development of a solar-powered freezer
Affiliations: Nanyang Technological Univ, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Ameen, Ahmadul, Nanyang Technological Univ, Singapore
Abstract: This paper describes a contribution to the development of a solar-powered freezer suitable for storing 20 pounds (9.1 kg) of medicine and vaccine at -10°C in remote tropical areas where electricity is not available. The system comprises a freezer unit and a solar-powered conversion/storage system that includes an array of photovoltaic cells and a battery. The freezer unit employs a conventional vapor-compression refrigeration cycle using R-12 as a refrigerant and a capillary tube as an expansion device. The length of the capillary tube and the refrigerant charge were optimized at 11.18 ft (3.41 m) and 0.144 lb (65.2 g), respectively, for the most efficient operation. The effectiveness of photovoltaic cells in charging lead acid batteries to supply power to the freezer compressor was also investigated and, based on the findings, recommendations were made to modify the configuration. The paper highlights the methodology used in the optimization procedure and describes the performance tests carried out on the solar-powered freezer.
Index Keywords: Capillary tubes; Charging (batteries); Compressors; Electricity; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Optimization; Photovoltaic cells; Refrigerants; Solar energy; Solar refrigeration; Charging lead acid batteries; Freezer compressor; Refrigerant charge; Solar powered freezer; Vapor compression refrigeration cycle; Refrigerating machinery

Title: Gas-fired water heater performance studies used to validate a computer program
Authors with affiliations: Paul, D.D.; Murray, J.G.; Whitacre, G.R.; Crisafulli, J.J.; Holderbaum, G.S.; Hemphill, R.J.; Rinholm, R.C.
Abstract: A computer program that can predict the performance of gas-fired, storage-type water heaters has been developed (Paul 1993), and the objectives of this paper are to describe some of its capabilities and to provide some comparisons between its predictions of water heater performance and the laboratory tests on three different types of water heaters. The water heaters tested were a conventional single-flue water heater, a conventional single-flue water heater equipped with a powered sidewall vent, and a triple-flue water heater. The performance parameters used for comparison were the water heater's energy factor, its recovery efficiency, and its average water temperature during the DOE 24-hour simulated use test for water heaters (DOE 1990).

Authors: Funato Hirohito, Kawamura Atsuo
Title: Control of variable active-passive reactance (VAPAR) and negative inductance
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Yokohama Natl Univ, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Funato, Hirohito, Yokohama Natl Univ, Yokohama, Japan; Kawamura, Atsuo, Yokohama Natl Univ, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: The concept of the variable active-passive reactance (VAPAR) has been proposed in, which behaves like a two-terminal reactive element, and the produced active reactance works as a passive reactive component, including in transient state. In this paper first, authors propose the equivalent resistance control method for the capacitor DC voltage regulation when a capacitor is used as an energy storage element of the VAPAR. The series equivalent resistance is added to the produced virtual inductance, and the capacitor voltage is controlled by changing the series equivalent resistance. The proposed scheme is verified by simulations and experiments. Second, the realization of the negative inductance is proposed. Through simulations and experiments, it is verified that the VAPAR can generate negative inductance, which may be applied to FACTS. The effects of negative inductance are compared with that of series capacitance used in power system.

Authors: Hall A.D., Stover J.C., Breisch R.L.
Title: Gas turbine inlet-air chilling at a cogeneration facility
Affiliations: Texaco Cogeneration and Power Co
Authors with affiliations: Hall, A.D., Texaco Cogeneration and Power Co; Stover, J.C., Texaco Cogeneration and Power Co; Breisch, R.L., Texaco Cogeneration and Power Co
Abstract: Combustion gas turbines are constant-volume engines for which shaft horsepower is proportional to the combustion air mass flow. Engine output improves if the air temperature is depressed at the compressor inlet to increase the air density. When a combustion turbine generator is used in a power plant, increased engine output increases the electrical generating capacity. That is the concept presented in this case study of an inlet air-chilling system installed in a cogeneration plant in California. The plant also uses a thermal energy storage (TES) system with the inlet air chiller to optimize the plant's economic performance. This application has improved the hot weather generating capacity by 10%.

Authors: Armstrong Steven, Marston Matthew A., Miaoulis Ioannis N.
Title: Heat recovery for automotive applications using reversible hydration reactions
Source title: Winter Annual Meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers
Affiliations: Tufts Univ, Medford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Armstrong, Steven, Tufts Univ, Medford, United States; Marston, Matthew A., Tufts Univ, Medford, United States; Miaoulis, Ioannis N., Tufts Univ, Medford, United States
Abstract: A prototype of the 'Tufts Thermal Battery' was developed and laboratory tested for possible use in automobile application. This system utilizes heat from the exhaust of the automobile which would otherwise be wasted into the environment. Thermal energy from the exhaust is stored during engine operation in the form of chemical energy through the dehydration of lithium bromide. This energy can be stored indefinitely with no insulation and be recovered through the re-hydration of the lithium bromide. Upon hydration, heat is evolved which can be used to heat the catalytic converter prior to a vehicle cold start. By preheating the catalytic converter by 15°C cold start emissions levels can be reduced by as much as 45%. The bench top prototype was installed in a test vehicle and the feasibility of this application was studied. After many tests were conducted it was determined that the system could work effectively when ambient temperatures were above 10°C. Preliminary research was then conducted on a system using lithium bromide that could operate at low temperatures.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Automobile engines; Automotive engineering; Catalytic converters; Energy storage; Environmental protection; Exhaust systems (engine); Hydration; Lithium compounds; Particulate emissions; Temperature; Ambient temperature; Lithium bromide; Reversible hydration reactions; Thermal energy storage; Vehicle cold start; Waste heat utilization

Authors: Olesen B.W.
Title: Comparative experimental study of performance of radiant floor-heating systems and a wall panel heating system under dynamic conditions
Affiliations: D.F. Liedelt 'Velta' Produktions und, Vertriebs GmbH, Norderstedt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Olesen, B.W., D.F. Liedelt 'Velta' Produktions und, Vertriebs GmbH, Norderstedt, Germany
Abstract: This paper reports on a study of the dynamic behavior of radiant floor heating systems and a wall panel heating system. Earlier publications have reported on thermal comfort conditions and energy consumption in test rooms heated by different types of systems. In real life, the conditions are often dynamic due to changing outdoor temperatures, sunshine through windows, heat from lights and occupants, use of night thermostat setback, etc. In the present project, these influences were experimentally studied in a test room that was heated by different systems and where the previously noted dynamic conditions could be simulated. The results showed that both the wall panel heating system and the floor heating systems were able to maintain a comfortable thermal environment under dynamic conditions. The tested systems also had similar energy consumption levels.

Authors: Mohammed Osama A., Park Dong C., Merchant Riaz S.
Title: Implementation of an adaptive neural network short-term electric load forecasting system in the energy control center

Affiliations: Florida Int Univ, Miami, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mohammed, Osama A., Florida Int Univ, Miami, United States; Park, Dong C., Florida Int Univ, Miami, United States; Merchant, Riaz S., Florida Int Univ, Miami, United States
Abstract: The practical aspects related to the implementation of an adaptive neural network based short-term electric load forecasting system in a utility company are presented. The system is developed and implemented for Florida Power and Light Company(FPL). Implementation experiences with the system are discussed. The system accounts for seasonal and daily characteristics, as well as abnormal conditions such us cold fronts, heat waves, holidays and other conditions abnormal conditions. It is capable of forecasting load with a lead time of one hour to seven days. The adaptive mechanism is used to train the neural networks when on-line. The results indicate that the load forecasting system presented gives robust and more accurate forecasts and allows greater adaptability to sudden climatic changes compared with statistical methods. With appropriate training data sets, the system could ported and can be modified to suit the requirements of other utility companies.

Authors: Ebeling J.A., Beaty L., Blanchard S.K.
Title: Combustion turbine inlet air cooling using ammonia-based refrigeration for capacity enhancement
Affiliations: Burns and McDonnell Engineering Co
Authors with affiliations: Ebeling, J.A., Burns and McDonnell Engineering Co; Beaty, L., Burns and McDonnell Engineering Co; Blanchard, S.K., Burns and McDonnell Engineering Co
Abstract: Combustion turbines have historically been used to meet peak demands of electric utilities. Combustion turbine capacity is directly affected by inlet air temperature, and performance degrades as the inlet air temperature rises. Inlet air cooling using thermal energy (ice) storage (TES) can be used to counteract this performance decline. Inlet air cooling systems were constructed for eight combustion turbines, six of which are combined cycle units. These turbines are installed in a plant, an intermediate load and peak load shaving facility. An engineering firm provided project management, design, and procurements services for the project.

Authors: Rudd A.F.
Title: Development of moisture storage coatings for enthalpy storage wallboard
Affiliations: Florida Solar Energy Cent, Cape Canaveral, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rudd, A.F., Florida Solar Energy Cent, Cape Canaveral, United States
Abstract: Two moisture-storage coating mixtures that could provide a low-cost, building-integrated method of managing indoor humidity in hot and humid climates were investigated. Approximate loading curves for the moisture-storage mixtures, the base materials alone, and regular gypsum wallboard were experimentally determined in an environmental chamber, using digital balances to monitor weight change as a function of relative humidity. Silica gel desiccant was mixed with base materials of flat latex paint and vinyl joint compound. Preliminary results showed that although both base materials reduced desiccant utilization, the coatings have potential for moisture storage.

Authors: Hopkins Douglas C., Root Jr. Daniel W.
Title: Synthesis of a new class of converters that utilize energy recirculation
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference

Authors with affiliations: Hopkins, Douglas C., State Univ of New York, Binghamton, United States; Root Jr., Daniel W., State Univ of New York, Binghamton, United States
Abstract: A new class of switchmode power electronic circuit topologies, here in named Energy Recirculation and Storage Circuits (ERSCs), are described which have the characteristic of storing and recirculating energy in a return path to augment the source. A port reduction technique is developed which connects output to input and is applied to buck and boost derived converters. A description of circuit operation is given for an ideal boost/buck ERSC. Two possible applications for ERSCs are for in-situ testing of power devices and for power factor correction. The second utilizes a cascaded boost/buck ERSC as an output-regulated power-factor correction (PFC) circuit. The PFC-ERSC is evaluated and a detailed description with key equations included.

Title: Performance improvement of soft-switched PWM rectifiers with inductive load
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: State Univ of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Pomilio, J.A., State Univ of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil; Rossetto, L., State Univ of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil; Tenti, P., State Univ of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil; Tomasin, P., State Univ of Campinas, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: A new soft-switched ac/dc PWM converter structure is presented. It is useful for current-fed inverters and PWM rectifiers. Typical applications are magnet power supplies, high-power ac motor drives and active power filters with magnetic energy storage. Soft switching is provided at the expense of a limited increase of the circuit complexity as compared to usual hard-switching solutions. A discussion of the soft commutation process is presented. By a proper switching sequence, overvoltages across the converter switches can fully be eliminated. Moreover, light-load operation can be achieved. Both typical limitations of soft-switched current-fed topologies are therefore overcome. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate the actual converter capabilities.
Index Keywords: Electric commutation; Electric converters; Electric network analysis; Electric network topology; Electric waveforms; Overvoltage protection; Thyristors; Voltage control; Current fed inverters; Inductive loads; Soft switched pulse width modulated rectifiers; Soft switching; Electric rectifiers

Authors: Ise Toshifumi, Nakade Masanobu, Murakami Yoshishige
Title: Soft switching AC/DC converter with energy recovery snubber circuit for superconducting magnetic energy storage
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ise, Toshifumi, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Nakade, Masanobu, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Murakami, Yoshishige, Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: This paper proposes to utilize the AC/DC converter circuit with energy recovery snubber for a superconducting magnetic energy storage. In this circuit, both di/dt and dv/dt stress on switching devices are very low compared with conventional circuits, and energy in the snubber capacitors can be fully recovered. Operating characteristics of the circuit were studied experimentally. Multi-parallel configuration was studied in order to achieve high current handling capability and reducing harmonics.
Index Keywords: Electric commutation; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric network analysis; Electric network topology; Equivalent circuits; Superconducting devices; AC/DC converter; Energy recovery snubber circuits; Soft switching; Superconducting magnetic energy storage; Power converters

Authors: Anon
Title: Technigaz Mark III membrane LNG carrier 'Aman Bintulu'
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The 18800 cu. m LNG Carrier S/S 'Aman Bintulu' is the first LNG tanker in the world to use the Technigaz Mark III membrane cargo containment system. Some LNG projects for local city gas in Japan are described. The principal dimensions and outstanding features of the ship are presented. The main features of the Technigaz Mark III membrane system are also described.
Index Keywords: Deformation; Energy resources; Failure (mechanical); Natural gas transportation; Tanks (containers); Technology; Thermal load; Thermal stress; Aman Bintulu; Center for promotion of natural gas; City gas companies; Corrugated membrane; Storage tanks; Technigaz Mark III membrane; Liquefied natural gas

Authors: Guven H.M., Spaeth S.T.
Title: Commissioning process and roles of players
Affiliations: San Diego State Univ, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Guven, H.M., San Diego State Univ, San Diego, United States; Spaeth, S.T., San Diego State Univ, San Diego, United States
Abstract: A commissioning process for the development of an energy system is recommended. The process involves the identification of important persons involved and their respective roles. Separate tasks are envisioned for a design engineer, design review engineer, field supervision engineer and commissioning engineer. The desired flow of information among these engineers is discussed. It is believed that the process can assure a cost of commissioning acceptable to the owner and energy industry alike. To demonstrate the potential of the process, the cost of commissioning of thermal energy storage system is described.
Index Keywords: Heat storage; Linguistics; Performance; Professional aspects; Project management; Specifications; Commissioning process; Definitions; Engineering tasks; Heating ventilating and air conditioning system; Information flow; Thermal storage systems; Ventilation

Authors: Radulovic Zarko, Sabanovic Asif
Title: Active filter control using a sliding mode approach
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Aiwa Co, Ltd, Saitama-ken, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Radulovic, Zarko, Aiwa Co, Ltd, Saitama-ken, Japan; Sabanovic, Asif, Aiwa Co, Ltd, Saitama-ken, Japan
Abstract: Load distortion currents in the three phase system can be suppressed by employing active power filters. This paper describes sliding mode control strategy of the three phase voltage source converter. The validity of the control circuit is verified by simulation results. Considering the new control approach, the dynamics of the active filter as well as its compensating characteristics are also analyzed through energy storage elements. The system performance is valid for steady and transient states in the three phase circuits.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric distortion; Electric energy storage; Electric network analysis; Electric variables control; Electric waveforms; Power converters; Reactive power; Vectors; Active filter control; Compensating principle; Load distortion currents; Sliding mode approach; Active filters

Authors: Piszczor Michael F., Kohout Lisa L., Manzo Michelle, Colozza Anthony J.
Title: Development and operation of a photovoltaic power system for use at remote antarctic sites
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Piszczor, Michael F., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Kohout, Lisa L., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Manzo, Michelle, NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; Colozza, Anthony J., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: A photovoltaic power system, designed and built at the NASA Lewis Research Center, has successfully operated over the past two summer seasons at a remote site in Antarctica, providing utility-type power for a six-person field team. The system was installed at the Lake Hoare site for approximately five weeks during late 1992, put into storage for the Antarctic winter, and then used again during the 1993 season. The photovoltaic power system consists of three silicon photovoltaic sub-arrays delivering a total of 1.5 kWe peak power, three lead-acid gel battery modules supplying 2.4 kWh, and an electrical distribution system which delivers 120 Vac and 12 Vdc to the user. The system worked extremely well in providing quiet, reliable power. The experience gained from early system demonstrations such as this should be beneficial in accelerating the transition toward future PV systems in Antarctica and other similar areas.
Index Keywords: Electric loads; Electric power distribution; Electric power systems; Electric utilities; Energy efficiency; Environmental impact; Silicon solar cells; Solar cell arrays; Systems analysis; Antarctic; Lead acid gel batteries; Photovoltaic power systems; Remote site; Silicon photovoltaic sub-arrays; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Gunther Peter, Mathewson Alan
Title: Novel coatings for solar cells with the capability of controlled charge storage
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: University Coll, Cork, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Gunther, Peter, University Coll, Cork, Ireland; Mathewson, Alan, University Coll, Cork, Ireland
Abstract: Functional coatings for solar cells namely thermally grown SiO2, cold plasma deposited SiO2 and amorphous Teflon AF are introduced as passivation layers as well as materials for electric charge storage. These so called electrets, originally investigated for electret-condenser microphones, have been applied to MIS-solar cells. Layer preparation, controlled corona charging, and thermal and optical charge storage characteristics are described. These electret films are stable for several years and resists photons with energies of less than 3.0 eV and at least 5 eV for positively or negatively charged films, respectively. On solar cell test structures it is shown, that the I-V-characteristic is drastically influenced by electret charge polarity and density. Numerical simulations revealed the potential of this concept.
Index Keywords: Amorphous materials; Annealing; Computer simulation; Current voltage characteristics; Electric charge; Numerical methods; Passivation; Photons; Silica; Surface measurement; Charging method; Electret charge polarity; Electret films; Microwave/radio frequency plasma system; Optical charge storage characteristic; Thin oxide grown; Solar cells

Authors: Stone K.W., Leingang E.F., Kusek S.M., Drubka R.E., Fay T.D.
Title: On-sun test results of McDonnell Douglas' prototype solar thermophotovoltaic power system
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stone, K.W., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States; Leingang, E.F., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States; Kusek, S.M., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States; Drubka, R.E., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States; Fay, T.D., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, Huntington Beach, United States
Abstract: A solar thermophotovoltaic (STPV) power system has many attractive attributes for both space and terrestrial applications including high efficiency, high reliability, low mass, low operating costs, solar/gas hybrid operation and thermal storage capability for dispatchability. This paper describes the basic components and operation of a STPV system. It also presents the results of on-sun testing with a testbed prototype at operating temperatures of 1350°C. The design and expected performance of the next generation testbed prototype is discussed. System analysis based upon the test data indicates that power performance in the 23% to 32% can be achieved with a STPV power conversion system using existing technology.

Abstract: The contribution to the realization of a climatically benign energy supply in Middle Europe by the inland use of photovoltaics (PV) has been assessed and will serve as a base study for political decisions.

Authors: Byrne John, Letendre Steven, Nigro Ralph, Govindarajalu Chandra, Wallace William, Wang Young-Doo
Title: Photovoltaics for demand-side management utility markets: a utility/customer partnership approach
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Delaware, United States
Authors with affiliations: Byrne, John, Univ of Delaware, United States; Letendre, Steven, Univ of Delaware, United States; Nigro, Ralph, Univ of Delaware, United States; Govindarajalu, Chandra, Univ of Delaware, United States; Wallace, William, Univ of Delaware, United States; Wang, Young-Doo, Univ of Delaware, United States
Abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) systems located at customer sites can be used to meet utility needs for demand-side management (DSM) applications. PV-DSM can also represent a high-value intermediate market for PV in the utility sector. Maximum value for PV in DSM applications can be achieved by incorporating a dispatching capability to PV systems (through the addition of storage). This enables utilities to evaluate PV systems as a peak-shaving technology. To date, peak-shaving has been the higher value DSM application for U.S. utilities. Our analysis of the value of dispatchable PV-DSM systems indicates that small-scale, customer-sited systems are approaching competitive cost levels in several regions of the U.S. that have favorable load matching and peak demand pricing characteristics. This paper presents the results for PV-DSM systems located within the service territories of five case study utilities.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Costs; Electric utilities; Energy storage; Management; Demand side management; Energy supply; High value intermediate market; Peak shaving technology; Solar insolation; Utility partnership approach; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Zaininger H.W., Barnes P.R.
Title: Integrating photovoltaics into utility distribution systems
Source title: Conference Record of the IEEE Photovoltaic Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Zaininger Engineering Co, Inc, San Jose, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zaininger, H.W., Zaininger Engineering Co, Inc, San Jose, United States; Barnes, P.R., Zaininger Engineering Co, Inc, San Jose, United States
Abstract: Electric utility distribution system impacts associated with the integration of distributed photovoltaic (PV) energy sources vary from site to site and utility to utility. The objective of this paper is to examine several utility-and-site-specific conditions which may affect economic viability of distributed PV applications to utility systems. Assessment methodology compatible with technical and economic assessment techniques employed by utility engineers and planners is employed to determine PV benefits for seven different utility systems. The seven case studies are performed using utility system characteristics and assumptions obtained from appropriate utility personnel. The resulting site-specific distributed PV benefits increase nonsite-specific generation system benefits available to central station PV plants as much as 46%, for one utility located in the Southwest.
Index Keywords: Costs; Economics; Electric loads; Electric power distribution; Electric utilities; Energy storage; Renewable energy resources; Solar power generation; Assessment methodology; Operating costs; Solar insolation; Utility system characteristics; Solar energy

Authors: Claudio-Sanchez A., Li J.M., Lafore D.
Title: Behavior analysis of the IGBT in hard and soft switching modes by a soft modelling concept
Affiliations: Technopole de Chateau-Gombert, Marseille, France
Authors with affiliations: Claudio-Sanchez, A., Technopole de Chateau-Gombert, Marseille, France; Li, J.M., Technopole de Chateau-Gombert, Marseille, France; Lafore, D., Technopole de Chateau-Gombert, Marseille, France
Abstract: This paper presents an investigation of IGBT behavior in hard switching (on, off) and soft switching both ZCS and ZVS. We are aiming towards an IGBT physical description which would be useful to power electronic engineers for circuit design improvement: power losses, switching frequency. A simple analytical model (soft modelling) where essential physical phenomena are taken into account has been developed. The modelling is given for each commutation mode: hard (on, off) and soft switching (ZCS and ZVS). Using a special testing circuit design experimentation is performed in single-shot mode. The advantages of this technique is that junction temperature θj component is determined through the case temperature and very low energy consumption. Finally simulated and experimented results are qualitatively verified.

Authors: Sasaguchi Kengo, Kusano Koji, Kitagawa Hideaki
Title: Solid/liquid phase-change heat transfer around two horizontal, vertically spaced cylinders - an experimental study on the effect of density inversion of water
Affiliations: Kumamoto Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sasaguchi, Kengo, Kumamoto Univ, Japan; Kusano, Koji, Kumamoto Univ, Japan; Kitagawa, Hideaki, Kumamoto Univ, Japan
Abstract: Solid/liquid phase-change heat transfer around cylinders occurs in many systems including latent-heat thermal-energy storage systems. In such systems, interactions of the heat transfer around the cylinders is often observed. Although several studies have reported on the heat transfer around a single cylinder and two or more cylinders, there have been no systematic studies to examine the effect of initial water superheat for the solidification and the effect of the surface temperature of the cylinders for the melting on the heat transfer. Therefore, in the present study, systematic experiments have been carried out to examine the effects of the parameters mentioned above and the density inversion of water on the solid/liquid phase-change heat transfer using a single and two horizontal, vertically spaced cylinders in a rectangular enclosure.
Index Keywords: Cylinders (shapes); Effects; Heat storage; Liquids; Melting; Phase transitions; Solidification; Solids; Density inversion of water; Rectangular enclosure; Heat transfer

Authors: Spaargaren D.H.
Title: Metabolic rate and body size - A new view on the 'surface law' for basic metabolic rate
Affiliations: Netherlands Institute for Sea Research, PO Box 59, Den Burg, Texel, 1790 AB, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Spaargaren, D.H., Netherlands Institute for Sea Research, PO Box 59, Den Burg, Texel, 1790 AB, Netherlands
Abstract: In larger animals a considerable part of the total body mass (e.g. body water, dissolved substances, mineral and organic deposits) does not consume significant amounts of oxygen. These materials can be considered to form a metabolically inert infrastructure which mainly serves three functions: (1) structural support to the organism, (2) storage of nutrients (building material and energy stores) and (3) transport and distribution of these materials. Considering the transport and support function of the metabolically inert structures and their interconnections it is likely that the infrastructure will basically show some tree-like, branching building plan. The weight of the metabolically inert infrastructure of an organism, can be given by bW/(c+W), in which W=body weight, b and c are constants. With increasing size the weight of the metabolic inert infrastructure increases disproportionably. Experimental data concerning basic metabolic rate (M) in relation to body weight (W) better fit the equation M=a W(1-bW)/(c+W), (a=constant) than the conventional power law. © 1994 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: body weight; branching structures; metabolic rate; solute exchange; surface law
Index Keywords: animal; article; basal metabolic rate; biological model; body constitution; body weight; physiology; species difference; Animal; Basal Metabolism; Body Constitution; Body Weight; Models, Biological; Species Specificity

Authors: Kaino Koji
Title: Similarity curve in a solidification process of a latent-heat energy-storage unit with longitudinally straight fins (Effect of fin on the applicability of the similarity rule)
Affiliations: Toyota Technological Inst, Nagoya-shi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kaino, Koji, Toyota Technological Inst, Nagoya-shi, Japan
Abstract: The similarity rule states that a similarity curve representing the relationship between a similarity function and the frozen fraction is independent of the Biot number under four specified conditions, including uniform distribution of heat flux over the heat-transfer surface of a latent-heat storage unit. A storage unit with straight fins, which has the nature of losing such spatial uniformity of heat flux inherently, has been analyzed numerically. The effects of the thickness, thermal conductivity and the number of fins on the applicability of the similarity rule have been examined, following a previous investigation describing the effect of the heat-transfer tube. The results show that the relative difference between similarity curves for different Biot numbers is reduced with decreases in the thickness and/or thermal conductivity of the fin; that is, the similarity rule becomes more and more applicable with a reduction in the thermal conductance of the fin. The distributions of both temperatures, inside the storage unit and surface heat flux, have been shown for the purpose of discussing the results.
Index Keywords: Fins (heat exchange); Heat transfer; Mathematical models; Solidification; Temperature distribution; Thermal conductivity of solids; Heat flux distribution; Latent heat energy storage unit; Longitudinally straight fins; Similarity curve; Similarity rule; Heat storage; Fins; Heat Exchangers; Heat Transfer; Solidification

Authors: Saitoh Takeo S., Kato Hideki
Title: Numerical analysis for combined natural-convection and close-contact melting in a horizontal cylindrical capsule
Affiliations: Tohoku Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, Takeo S., Tohoku Univ, Japan; Kato, Hideki, Tohoku Univ, Japan
Abstract: Close-contact-melting heat-transfer characteristics, including natural convection in the liquid region of cylindrical capsules, were studied theoretically. Elucidation of such heat-transfer mechanisms is of great importance from the viewpoint of cost-effective ice-storage and heat-storage employing the latent heat-of-fusion thermal-energy storage (TES) concept. The Growth Ring Method (GRM) was used as a numerical tool to handle the moving interface between the liquid and solid regions. The computed isotherms, streamlines, and stored-heat fractions were clarified in detail. In particular, special attention was focused on the role of natural convection in the upper liquid region. Hitherto, no exact numerical analysis has been made to clarify the contribution of natural convection.
Index Keywords: Heat transfer; Isotherms; Liquids; Melting; Natural convection; Numerical analysis; Phase interfaces; Solids; Close contact melting; Cylindrical capsule; Growth ring method; Ice storage; Moving interface; Phase change; Stored heat fractions; Streamline; Thermal energy storage; Heat storage; Analysis-Mathematical; Convection; Cylinders

Authors: Manwell James F., McGowan Jon G., Baring-Gould Edward I., Jeffries Williarn, Stein William
Title: Hybrid systems modeling: development and validation
Affiliations: Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States
Authors with affiliations: Manwell, James F., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; McGowan, Jon G., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; Baring-Gould, Edward I., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; Jeffries, Williarn, Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; Stein, William, Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the analytical basis and experimental validation procedure for HYBRID1 (Version 1.04), a computer simulation model for hybrid power systems developed at the University of Massachusetts. This module based computer model initially was developed for wind/diesel systems, and now includes battery storage and photovoltaics while employing a combined time series and statistical approach. The model allows the simulation of non-identical diesel generators and the inclusion of multiple, non-identical wind turbines whose output may or may not be correlated. System architecture and control includes storage or no storage options. A summary of the validation work on this model is presented. The validation experiments were based on the use of a specially designed experimental wind/diesel system test bed.

Authors: Lopez Daryl A., Abbott David G.
Title: Feasibility of using MPCs for DOE research and production fuel
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: INEL-EG&G Idaho, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lopez, Daryl A., INEL-EG&G Idaho, Idaho Falls, United States; Abbott, David G., INEL-EG&G Idaho, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) is responsible for receiving and disposing of spent nuclear fuel (SNF) from U.S. commercial reactor facilities, some foreign reactors, and internal operations. The DOE Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM) is responsible for the commercial SNF and has undertaken the development of a multipurpose canister (MPC) system for its disposition. OCRWM anticipates that the robust and flexible design of the MPC will allow it to meet the future Mined Geologic Repository System (MGDS) Waste Acceptance Criteria (WAC). This report is a limited feasibility evaluation of using the MPC principle for handling most of the noncommercial DOE fuel, which is the responsibility of the DOE Office of Spent Fuel Management and Special Projects. DOE is evaluating the MGDS repository program to determine its applicability to disposing of DOE-owned fuel not currently scheduled for disposal under the OCRWM program. It is assumed for purposes of this report that the OCRWM MPC will meet the future MGDS WAC and that the noncommercial DOE fuel will be disposed of in the OCRWM MGDS. Under these assumptions, the noncommercial DOE-fuel MPC will be designed to the same requirements as the OCRWM MPC. Six noncommercial DOE fuel types were selected for this evaluation. The evaluation resulted in three new DOE-fuel MPC preconceptual designs: one is identical to the large conceptual OCRWM MPC design for commercial Boiling Water Reactor (BWR) fuel, and two are new, shortened versions of the large conceptual OCRWM MPC with different internal fuel-holding basket designs. These designs were based on physical fuel packaging requirements and on preliminary evaluations of structural, criticality, thermal, and shielding performance. The infrastructure of the applicable DOE-fuel storage facilities was also studied to determine MPC capabilities and any required new equipment, modifications, or upgrades.
Index Keywords: Boiling water reactors; Codes (standards); Materials handling; Packaging; Performance; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste transportation; Spent fuels; DOE Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM); DOE Office of Spent Fuel Management and Special Projects; Internal fuel holding basket designs; Mined Geologic Repository System (MGDS); Multipurpose canisters (MPCs); United States Department of Energy (DOE); Containers

Title: Systems modeling for the DOE spent nuclear fuel program
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Evans, Dennis, Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Beebe, Corey, Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Caldwell, Michael, Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Carlsen, Brett, Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Ban, Gina, Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Van Haaften, David, Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Gladson, Scott, Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: The United States Department of Energy (DOE) owns over 90 different types of spent nuclear fuel (SNF), having a range of 235U enrichments, sizes, and cladding materials. The SNF is stored in basins and dry storage facilities at a number of different sites. The Integrated Spent Nuclear Fuel Systems Model, currently under development, is a dynamic system simulation model of the DOE SNF complex. The model is a planning tool designed to facilitate the development and assessment of SNF management strategies. This paper discusses the current status of the model, shows the results of typical analyses, and draws appropriate conclusions.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Project management; Radioactive waste storage; Spent fuels; Systems analysis; Uranium; Integrated Spent Nuclear Fuel Systems Model; Planning tool; United States Department of Energy (DOE); Nuclear fuel accounting

Authors: Chen W.W., Huang S.N., Lindquist M.R.
Title: Seismic qualification of ventilation stack
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, W.W., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, United States; Huang, S.N., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, United States; Lindquist, M.R., Westinghouse Hanford Co, Richland, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the method to be used to qualify the 105 K ventilation stack at the U.S. Department of Energy's Hanford Site, near Richland, Washington, under seismic and wind loadings. The stack stands at 175 ft (53.34 m), with a diameter tapering from 22 ft (6.71 m) at the foundation to 12.83 ft (3.91 m) at the top. Although the stack is classified as Safety Class 3 (low hazard), it is treated as a Safety Class 1 (high hazard) component, as failure could damage a Safety Class 1 facility (the irradiated fuel storage basin). The evaluation used U.S. Department of Energy criteria specified in UCRL 15910 (1990). The seismic responses of the stack under earthquake loading were obtained from modal analyses with response spectrum input that used the ANSYS (1989) finite-element computer code. The moments and shear forces from the results of seismic analysis were used to qualify the reinforcement capacity of the stack structure by the ultimate-strength method. The wind forces acting on the stack in both along-wind and crosswind directions were also calculated. Presented are evaluations of the soil bearing pressure, the moment, and the shear capacity of the stack foundation.
Index Keywords: Bearing capacity; Computer aided analysis; Dynamic response; Earthquake resistance; Finite element method; Shear stress; Soil mechanics; Ventilation; Wind effects; Shear capacity; Software package ANSYS; Soil bearing pressure; Ultimate strength method; Ventilation stack; Structural analysis

Source title: European Quantum Electronics Conference - Technical Digest

Authors with affiliations: Miesner, H.-J., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany; Grieser, M., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany; Grimm, R., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany; Gruber, A., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany; Habs, D., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany; Hochadel, B., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany; Horvath, C., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany; Madert, M., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany; Schwalm, D., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany; Wanner, B., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany; Wolf, A., Max-Planck-Inst fuer Kernphysik and, Physikalisches Inst der Universitaet, Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: Standard laser cooling experiments with stored ion beams lead to a fast reduction of longitudinal beam temperatures but do not directly affect the transverse motion of ions. However, the Coulomb interaction between the ions results in a coupling between the longitudinal and the transverse degrees of freedom. Thus energy of the transverse motion can be dissipated by the longitudinal cooling force in an indirect way. This paper presents such scheme.

Authors: Ewing Ronald I.
Title: Burnup verification using the FORK measurement system
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ewing, Ronald I., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: Verification measurements may be used to help ensure nuclear criticality safety when burnup credit is applied to spent fuel transport and storage systems. The FORK measurement system, designed at Los Alamos National Laboratory for the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards program, has been used to verify reactor site records for burnup and cooling time for many years. The FORK system measures the passive neutron and gamma-ray emission from spent fuel assemblies while in the storage pool. This report deals with the application of the FORK system to burnup credit operations based on measurements performed on spent fuel assemblies at the Oconee Nuclear Station of Duke Power Company.
