Authors: Vuchkov N.K., Astadjov D.N., Sabotinov N.V.
Title: Pulsed discharge excitation processes in the CuBr vapor laser
Source title: Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics Europe - Technical Digest
Affiliations: Inst of Solid State Physics, Tzaridragsko, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Vuchkov, N.K., Inst of Solid State Physics, Tzaridragsko, Bulgaria; Astadjov, D.N., Inst of Solid State Physics, Tzaridragsko, Bulgaria; Sabotinov, N.V., Inst of Solid State Physics, Tzaridragsko, Bulgaria
Abstract: The paper presents a comparative study involving experimentation and computer simulation of the output characteristics, electric parameters, and main kinetic plasma processes concerning the CuBr laser performance during the excitation pulse with four electric circuits namely: WPC (without peaking capacitor); OC (ordinary circuit); IPC (interacting peaking circuits); and IC (interacting circuits), for CuBr vapor laser excitation. The investigated circuits have shown an increase in CuBr-laser efficiency (and power, respectively) from 1% (for OC) to 1.6% (for IC). Reasons for the improved laser performance from WPC to IC excitation are also discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electron transitions; Energy dissipation; Energy storage; Laser pulses; Networks (circuits); Optical pumping; Oscillations; Performance; Kinetic plasma process; Pulsed discharge excitation processes; Gas lasers

Authors: Easterling J.Bennett, Poles James S.
Title: Environmental justice: Implications for siting of Federal radioactive waste management facilities
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Easterling, J.Bennett, U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Poles, James S., U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: Environmental justice is a term that has developed as a result of our need to address whether some of the environmental decisions we have made - and others we will make - are fair. The idea of environmental justice has been actively pursued by the Clinton Administration, and this consideration has resulted in Executive Order 12898, which was signed by President Clinton on February 11, 1994. The Executive Order calls for adverse impacts of Federal actions on minority or low-income populations to be identified before decisions implementing those actions are made. Numerous studies show that noxious facilities, such as incinerators and landfills, have been constructed in minority or low-income communities. And since the Department has not yet decided on sites for high-level waste storage or disposal facilities, it will have to take the new Executive Order into consideration as another piece in the complicated quilt of requirements that cover facility siting. An interesting twist to this is the fact that twenty Native American Indian Tribes expressed interest in voluntarily hosting a high-level radioactive waste management facility for temporary storage. They made these expressions on their own initiative, and several Tribes continue to pursue the idea of negotiations with either the Federal Government or private entities to locate a temporary storage site on Tribal land. The Executive Order goes beyond simply studying the effect of siting a facility and addresses in spirit a criticism that the Federal Government has been guilty of `environmental racism' in its siting policies - that it has intentionally picked minority or low-income communities for waste management facilities. Environmental justice provisions contained in the Executive Order place responsibility on officials who site Federal facilities to conduct their activities in a manner that does not discriminate or have the effect of discrimination against low-income or minority populations, and makes provisions for disadvantaged populations to have an opportunity to participate fully in decisions affecting their health and environment. What Department of Energy staff and others may have considered foregone conclusions in terms of interim storage facility siting and transportation options will have to be reevaluated for compatibility with provisions of the new Executive Order.
Index Keywords: Environmental protection; Facilities; Laws and legislation; Public policy; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste transportation; Site selection; Environmental justice; Executive Order 12898; Low income communities; Minority communities; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Vanhaudenarde A., Frey R.
Title: Optical storage in semiconductor doped glasses
Source title: Proceedings of the International Quantum Electronics Conference (IQEC'94)
Affiliations: Ecole Nationale Superieure des, Telecommunications, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Vanhaudenarde, A., Ecole Nationale Superieure des, Telecommunications, Paris, France; Frey, R., Ecole Nationale Superieure des, Telecommunications, Paris, France
Abstract: Permanent gratings have already been successfully stored in semiconductor doped glasses, and their origin assigned to the creation of an absorptive grating due to the photodarkening effect which occurs at high laser intensities in such media. In this paper, we demonstrate that these diffraction gratings are rather due to refractive index changes and we examine experimentally and theoretically the possibilities of increasing the diffraction efficiency. The physical mechanism underlying the creation of the refractive index grating is the following. When the first electron hole pair is created through one-photon absorption in the semiconductor nanocrystallite, the electron and hole move owing to diffusion. The electron can then be trapped in the host glass, whereas the hole is trapped inside the semiconductor dot. As observed experimentally, this physical mechanism leads to a two peak behavior of the diffraction efficiency plotted as a function of the number of write pulses (see Fig. 1). Evidently, such a behavior which is predicted by our model, cannot be observed for an absorptive grating. Figure 1 also demonstrates that the maximum diffraction efficiency is obtained in the early stage of the photo-darkening process. In the following, we review the influence of several parameters which could allow an increase of the maximum diffraction efficiency ρM of such gratings. Firstly, ρM increases linearly with the grating wavelength up to 7 μm and remains constant for larger values. This low response at high spatial frequencies, which prevents the use of such media in this frequency domain, is probably due to the low dot concentration (few 10-3). Secondly, ρM is independent of the 'write' beam's mean intensity but increases linearly with the fluence of the 'write' pulses. This is probably due to the onset of Auger relaxation occurring at high fluences, which can help the trapping of electrons in the glass matrix. Finally, ρM increases near the band gap resonance, thus demonstrating the importance of the choice of the write laser wavelength. In conclusion, as the use of a high dc electric field is also expected to strongly increase the refractive index change, the storage of efficient gratings in semiconductor doped glasses seems to be possible, especially if picosecond duration pulses delivered by frequency doubled mode-locked Ng-YAG lasers are used as the 'write' beams.
Index Keywords: Electric fields; Electric space charge; Electron transport properties; Energy gap; Glass; Laser mode locking; Laser pulses; Neodymium lasers; Photochromism; Refractive index; Relaxation processes; Semiconductor doping; Auger relaxation; Electron hole pair; Electron trapping; Optical storage; Static Kerr effect; Diffraction gratings

Authors: Roy Ajit K., Fish Robert L., McCright R.D.
Title: Waste package materials selection process
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: B&W Fuel Co, Las Vegas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roy, Ajit K., B&W Fuel Co, Las Vegas, United States; Fish, Robert L., B&W Fuel Co, Las Vegas, United States; McCright, R.D., B&W Fuel Co, Las Vegas, United States
Abstract: The office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM) of the United States Department of Energy (USDOE) is evaluating a site at Yucca Mountain in Southern Nevada to determine its suitability as a mined geologic disposal system (MGDS) for the disposal of high-level nuclear waste (HLW). The B&W Fuel Company (BWFC), as a part of the Management and Operating (M&O) team in support of the Yucca Mountain Site Characterization Project (YMP), is responsible for designing and developing the waste package for this potential repository. As part of this effort, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) is responsible for testing materials and developing models for the materials to be used in the waste package. This paper is aimed at presenting the selection process for materials needed in fabricating the different components of the waste package.

Authors: Kruse Brian J., Stringer Joe B., Childress Giles G.
Title: MPC closure weld model study
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Charlotte, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kruse, Brian J., Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Charlotte, United States; Stringer, Joe B., Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Charlotte, United States; Childress, Giles G., Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Charlotte, United States
Abstract: The United Stated Department of Energy (DOE) commissioned a Conceptual Design Study in February 1993 from the Management and Operating (M&O) Contractor for the Civilian Radioactive Waste Management System (CRWMS) to develop multi-purpose canister (MPC) conceptual designs and to provide feasibility, cost and schedule evaluations for implementation of an MPC program. This paper will describe results of the MPC closure weld model study which was completed in conjunction with the MPC conceptual design. Three weldments were produced to model the inner closure weld detail for the Multi-Purpose Canister (MPC). The purpose was to model the distortion that naturally occurs from welding and to obtain accurate welding production data. Three weldments were made: one using the Gas Tungsten Arc Welding process (GTAW), one using the Shielded Metal Arc Welding process (SMAW), and one using an automatic GTAW process. Finite element analysis was used to model the configuration of the test welds and the closure lid conceptual design for the MPC. This was done to determine the effect of the canister shell distortion due to welding on the MPC canister.
Index Keywords: Containers; Deformation; Finite element method; Inert gas welding; Mathematical models; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste transportation; Spent fuels; Welds; Automatic GTAW process; Canister shell distortion; Civilian Radioactive Waste Management System (CRWMS); CRWMS Management and Operating (M&O) contractor; Gas Tungsten Arc Welding process (GTAW); Multipurpose canister (MPC) closure weld model study; Shielded Metal Arc Welding process (SMAW); United States Department of Energy (DOE); Radioactive waste storage

Authors: King Ginger P.
Title: High-level radioactive waste curriculum usage, evaluation, and customer focus
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: King, Ginger P., U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: In August 1992, the U.S. Department of Energy's Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM) issued for educator use, a secondary school resource curriculum entitled `Science, Society, and America's Nuclear Waste.' This resource curriculum was developed in response to years and thousands of teacher, student, and general public requests for facts about nuclear waste - specifically, what the United States was doing and why. The curriculum materials when issued were the result of six years of development and testing by science and social studies teachers as well as multi-state field-testing and international critique. The curriculum is provided only to educators who specifically request it; and in the first one-and-a-half years following its availability more than 500,000 curriculum documents have been requested. Of all the requests for information received by OCRWM for any information or materials, most requests received are from educators or students. So one might consider educators and students to be `customers,' that is, as the business world might define customers: anyone expecting a product or a service from us. To determine usefulness and content for future editions of `Science, Society, and America's Nuclear Waste,' the Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management has undertaken a usage evaluation to ensure that it focuses on the needs of the `customer;' that is, those who need and request it. This paper presents preliminary findings based on a formal evaluation provided to and requested from educators, unsolicited comments received from educator requesters of the material, and comments from others.
Index Keywords: Project management; Radioactive waste storage; Safe handling; Spent fuels; Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982; Office of civilian radioactive waste management; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Payne Stephen A.
Title: Physics and performance of new solid-state laser gain media
Source title: Proceedings of the International Quantum Electronics Conference (IQEC'94)
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Authors with affiliations: Payne, Stephen A., Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States
Abstract: Many new solid state laser media have been identified during the last decade, and it is now possible to usefully generate laser light from the ultraviolet region to the mid-infrared. These new laser media have become available in part because of the improved understanding of the solid state physics issues that impact the laser performance. The physics and performance of the new tunable ultraviolet-emitting laser crystal, Ce3+:LiSAF, will be discussed, as will the critical physics issues pertaining to the operation of 3 μm Er3+ and Ho3+-based crystals. We also show that Yb-doped apatite crystals offer a viable alternative to 1.05 μm Nd-lasers. Since the realization by Dubinskii and coworkers that Ce3+-doped colquiriite-structure hosts exhibit reliable laser action in the ultraviolet region, the interest in developing UV solid state media has been revived. As a consequence, we have examined the gain and efficiency of lasers based on Ce3+-doped LiSrAlF6 (Ce:LiSAF). The gain spectrum was measured by pumping at 266 nm, as shown in Fig. 1, where it is revealed that the extracting field must be polarized as E∥c for useful laser operation. As a result, we measured the quantum yields, η, and branching ratios, β, for the 2.7-3.0 μm transitions for several Er and Ho-doped crystals, as reported in Table 1. From this data we see that the Er-doped gallium garnets (Gd3Ga5O12 and Gd3Sc2Ga3O12) offer much higher quantum yields than Y3Al5O12. As expected, the low phonon frequency of fluorides leads to η values of unity. The last two entries show that Ho-doped crystals generally offer 3 μm branching ratios of about one-half that available from Er. Of course, the overall merit of each material depends on many other optical and physical parameters. While Nd-doped materials have long been considered the laser ion of choice to generate light near 1.05 μm, Yb-doped apatite crystals are now able to offer a viable alternative. Yb offers the advantages associated with a longer energy storage time and a lower quantum defect, although the quasi-four-level nature of the system must be taken into account. In summary, the physics and performance of solid state laser media operating in the UV, near-infrared, and mid-infrared regions will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Crystals; Doping (additives); Gain measurement; Garnets; Light absorption; Light polarization; Lithium compounds; Optical pumping; Performance; Solid state lasers; Solid state physics; Ultraviolet radiation; Solid state laser gain media; Optical materials

Authors: Mount Richard P.
Title: Data storage and management for high-energy physics: Technical and sociological requirements
Source title: Digest of Papers - IEEE Symposium on Mass Storage Systems
Affiliations: California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mount, Richard P., California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, United States
Abstract: The requirements for data storage and management in experimental high-energy physics (HEP) are examined. Current and future needs for storage and access to data are presented briefly from both technical and sociological standpoints. Questions such as `file management or database management?' and `distributed or centralized data management?' are of vital interest to HEP and probably to other disciplines and businesses. These questions are discussed but inevitably are not fully answered.

Authors: Morkoc H.
Title: III-V nitrides for optical emitters
Affiliations: Univ of Illinois, Urbana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morkoc, H., Univ of Illinois, Urbana, United States
Abstract: The paper discusses the application of wide bandgap semiconductors for use as optical emitters. Due to the increasing need for high density optical storage and full color display technologies, research is being undertaken to use these display technologies, research is being undertaken to use these semiconductors in the green, blue and ultraviolet wavelengths. Results of the research show that all three primary colors can be generated using semiconductor technology and that InAsN/AlGaN DH LEDs produced by Nichia Chemical Industries, Ltd., are now capable of producing 2 cd of luminosity at blue and blue-green wavelengths of the visible spectrum.

Authors: Miller Charles A., Costantino Carl J.
Title: Seismic induced earth pressures in buried vaults
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: City Coll of New York, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, Charles A., City Coll of New York, New York, United States; Costantino, Carl J., City Coll of New York, New York, United States
Abstract: The magnitude and distribution of earth pressures acting on buried structures and induced by a seismic event are considered in this paper. A soil-structure-interaction analysis is performed for typical Department of Energy high level waste storage tanks using a lumped parameter model. The resulting soil pressure distributions are determined and compared with the static soil pressure to assess the design significance of the seismic induced soil pressures. It is found that seismic pressures do not control design unless the peak ground acceleration exceeds about 0.3 G. The effect of soil non linearities (resulting from local soil failure) are also found to have little effect on the predictions of the seismic response of the buried structure. The seismic induced pressures are found to be very similar to those predicted using the elastic model in ASCE 4-86.
Index Keywords: Dynamic response; Earthquake resistance; Mathematical models; Pressure effects; Radioactive waste storage; Soil structure interactions; Structural design; Tanks (containers); High level waste storage tanks; Seismic induced earth pressures; Soil pressure distributions; Underground structures

Authors: Lord D.L., Carter J.A., Ermold L.F.
Title: Dry storage of highly enriched uranium fuel
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Inc, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lord, D.L., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Inc, Idaho Falls, United States; Carter, J.A., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Inc, Idaho Falls, United States; Ermold, L.F., Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Co, Inc, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: Over the past 40 years the Department of Energy (DOE) has operated test reactors using high enriched uranium (HEU) fuel. Originally the spent fuel was reprocessed for uranium recovery and reuse. With the discontinuation of reprocessing, long-term storage of the spent fuel needs to be addressed. Presently the spent fuel is being stored in water cooled storage basins. Recent inspections of existing fuel shows evidence of degradation, indicating water storage may not be the most viable method for long-term storage. Dry fuel storage (DFS) has been performed with commercial low-enriched fuel but not on high enriched government fuels. This paper summarizes the strategy adopted by Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Company (WINCO) to demonstrate the safe dry storage of DOE HEU fuels.
Index Keywords: Containers; Degradation; Spent fuels; Uranium; Dry storage; High enriched uranium fuel; Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Company; Radioactive waste storage

Abstract: Westinghouse Idaho Nuclear Company (WINCO) is working with private industry to recycle contaminated metal from the dismantling and decommissioning of Department of Energy sites and commercial reactors. The recycled metal could be used in many applications such as fabrication of canisters and waste boxes for the storage of spent nuclear fuel and radioactive waste. Management of technical projects similar to this is difficult because these projects consist of a myriad of complex and interrelated issues ranging from technical feasibility to stakeholder acceptance. Systems Analysis provides a way to deal with many complex issues and supports effective decision making.

Abstract: In this paper, two special types of heterogeneity are considered. Abstract: In view of the developments in femtosecond excimer lasers several techniques were developed to overcome the inherent energy extraction problem of excimers. Authors: Qaddouri A., Roy R., Marleau G., Goulard B., Mayrand M.
Title: Multigroup flux solvers on parallel architecture
Source title: Proceedings - Annual Conference, Canadian Nuclear Association
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Montreal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Qaddouri, A., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Montreal, Canada; Roy, R., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Montreal, Canada; Marleau, G., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Montreal, Canada; Goulard, B., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Montreal, Canada; Mayrand, M., Ecole Polytechnique de Montreal, Montreal, Canada
Abstract: Using a cluster of processors with a distributed memory, parallelization for multigroup flux computations is investigated. The parallel performance will be studied in cases where the neutron transport equation is discretized using the collision probability technique. Particular techniques pertinent to the two-step process of solving a multigroup linear equation, as well as a fixed source solver, are described. Parallelization is achieved by distributing different energy groups on a set of workstations using PVM. Typical run times will be provided for 1-D CANDU cell test case. Finally, conclusions are drawn for realistic applications of parallel multigroup flux solvers.

Authors: Williams Jeffrey R., Kane Dan, Smith Jr. Thomas B.
Title: Stakeholder involvement in the evaluation of a multipurpose canister system
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williams, Jeffrey R., U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Kane, Dan, U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Smith Jr., Thomas B., U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE), Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM), began evaluating a multipurpose canister (MPC) concept in October of 1992. This followed recommendations by the Nuclear Waste Technical Review Board (NWTRB) and the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) that DOE develop a nuclear waste management system that achieves system integration, standardization, and reduced fuel-handling operations. Industry organizations such as Edison Electric Institute (EEI) and Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) had conducted earlier studies that concluded advantages to the nuclear waste management system may be offered by such a concept. The MPC concept involves a metal canister which would contain multiple spent nuclear fuel assemblies. The canister would be sealed at the nuclear power plant and would not be reopened. The MPC would then be placed inside separate casks or overpacks for storage, transportation, and disposal. An important factor in DOE's evaluation of the MPC concept was the involvement of external parties. This paper describes that involvement process for the OCRWM's MPC implementation program. External parties who have an interest or stake in the program are referred to as stakeholders.

Authors: Keyhani M., Luo L.
Title: Numerical study of convection heat transfer within enclosed horizontal rod-bundles
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keyhani, M., Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, United States; Luo, L., Univ of Tennessee, Knoxville, United States
Abstract: Numerical simulations have been carried out for the buoyancy driven fluid flow and heat transfer with air or helium (Pr≈0.7) in arrays sizing from 3×3 to 9×9 for a fixed pitch-to-diameter ratio of P/d = 1.33. The isothermal square outer enclosure with a width of W was fixed to a W/d = 20.33 in all the calculations. Pure conduction results were also obtained for rod-bundles from 3×3 to 13×13. It is found that the conduction Nusselt number for the Edge-Column-Bottom rod (rod ECB) decreases with increases in N from 3 to 7. However, the trend reverses and Nusselt number begins to increase for N>9. This form of Nusselt number variations with N is generally applicable to the outer-edge rods in the array. The convection flow regime in the N = 3 to 9 arrays has been studied for a limited range of modified Rayleigh number (Ra*d<320). It should be added that Ra*d approximately 1500 is a typical value for atmospheric pressure air convection in a unit cell of a PWR cask. The streamlines show that there is significant flow activity in the enclosure, especially in the top half region. It may be noted that for arrays with N = 3 to 9 significant convection heat transfer is observed even at Ra*d = 1. It is suspected that this horizontal orientation with distributed energy sources within the enclosure may be an inherently unstable natural convection phenomenon. Therefore, for this enclosure the range of the modified Rayleigh number investigated is for a high convection flow regime. The isotherms clearly show that the majority of the energy generated within the enclosure is transferred to the top and side plates. This indicates that, as suspected, convection is a major factor in heat transfer in transportation casks.
Index Keywords: Confined flow; Containers; Enclosures; Heat convection; Mathematical models; Nuclear fuel elements; Radioactive waste storage; Spent fuels; Buoyancy driven fluid flow; Horizontal rod bundles; Nusselt number; Rayleigh number; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Abbott David G., Bringhurst Alan R., Fillmore Denzel L.
Title: Paper summary inventory assessment of DOE spent nuclear fuels
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference

Abstract: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) has determined that it will not longer reprocess its spent nuclear fuel. This decision made it necessary to manage this fuel for long-term interim storage and ultimate disposal. DOE is developing a computerized database of its spent nuclear fuel inventory. This database contains information about the fuels and the fuel storage locations. There is approximately 2,618 metric tons initial heavy metal of fuel, stored at 12 locations. For analysis in an environmental impact statement, the fuel has been divided into six categories: naval, aluminum-based, Hanford defense, graphite, commercial-type, and test and experimental. This paper provides a discussion of the development of the database, and includes summary inventory information and a brief description of the fuels.

Abstract: In this work, investigated is the physical origin of such large values of K (otherwise known as the excess noise factor). The confocal unstable slit resonator is considered using example of Southwell's virtual source method to generate mode profiles in a first approximation, and refining them by means of a standard Kirchoff-Huygens diffraction procedure. Also considered here is the extension of the results to two transverse dimensions and the wider significance of the excess noise phenomenon.

Authors: Derrington Susan B., Thompson James E., Coates Cameron W.
Title: Fabrication options for depleted uranium components in shielded containers

Authors with affiliations: Derrington, Susan B., Oak Ridge Y-12 Plant, Oak Ridge, United States; Thompson, James E., Oak Ridge Y-12 Plant, Oak Ridge, United States; Coates, Cameron W., Oak Ridge Y-12 Plant, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: Depleted uranium (DU) is an attractive material for the gamma-shielding components in containers designed for the storage, transport, and disposal of high-level radioactive wastes or spent nuclear fuel. The size and weight of these components present fabrication challenges. A broad range of technical expertise, capabilities, and facilities for uranium manufacturing and technology development exist at the Department of Energy laboratories and production facilities and within commercial industry. Several cast and wrought processes are available to fabricate the DU components. Integration of the DU fabrication capabilities and physical limitations for handling the DU components into the early design phase will ensure a fabricable product.

Authors: Squier J., Rudd J.V., Kane S., Korn G., Mourou G., Pinkos D., Schumacher D., Bucksbaum P., Kohler B., Yakovlev V.V., Wilson K.R.
Title: High average power chirped pulse amplification systems
Source title: Proceedings of the International Quantum Electronics Conference (IQEC'94)
Affiliations: Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Squier, J., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Rudd, J.V., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Kane, S., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Korn, G., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Mourou, G., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Pinkos, D., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Schumacher, D., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Bucksbaum, P., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Kohler, B., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Yakovlev, V.V., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Wilson, K.R., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Abstract: Femtosecond pulse manipulation techniques have made it possible to take advantage of the superior energy storage characteristics of solid-state materials in order to produce energetic, and robust high peak power laser systems. In particular, femtosecond kilohertz Ti:Al2O3 amplifier systems have been developed which produce average powers of 2 W or greater. One of the interesting capabilities of these chirped pulse amplification systems is the ability to produce shaped, amplified pulses. Plane simultaneous amplitude and phase control of the frequency components of the pulse is possible. This method of producing programmable optical pulse shapes was first demonstrated by Weiner et al. We have adapted this technique and designed two liquid crystal modulators which provide independent amplitude and phase control and can work within the diffractive stretcher system of the laser. This system has enabled us to produce amplified, shaped pulses. One of the most critical diagnostics in a laser system capable of producing arbitrarily shaped pulses is a correlation technique for determining the amplitude and phase of the amplified light. This enables us to determine how closely the shaped pulse approximates the ideal target pulse shape. We incorporate spectrally resolved autocorrelations, and/or frequency resolved optical gates in our system in order to accomplish this.
Index Keywords: Amplification; Crystals; Iodine; Laser mode locking; Laser pulses; Light amplifiers; Light modulators; Molecules; Optical correlation; Optical variables measurement; Phase modulation; Amplitude reshaping effects; Chirped pulse amplification systems; Crystal modulator; Vibrational wave packet; Solid state lasers

Authors with affiliations: Grodek, Tamir, Hebrew Univ, Jerusalem, Israel; Inbar, Moshe, Hebrew Univ, Jerusalem, Israel; Schick, Asher P., Hebrew Univ, Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: Data from two small ephemeral streams in Israel indicate that step pool geometry in bedrock channels is similar, in its salient features, to that in alluvial channels. For steep (>0.10) bedrock channels the average step length is quasi-constant. Well developed steps found in very small, lithologically homogeneous channels suggest that low magnitude high frequency events play a role in their formation. In Nahal Meshushim (drainage area 14 km2) the water surface reconstructed from the highest flood marks indicates that all steps, though partly submerged, retain clear discontinuities between moderately sloping segments.

Authors: Outhred H.R.
Title: Principles of a market-based electricity industry and possible steps toward implementation in Australia
Affiliations: Univ of New South Wales, Sydney
Authors with affiliations: Outhred, H.R., Univ of New South Wales, Sydney
Abstract: The recent New Zealand Wholesale Electricity Market study identified a converging international trend towards a 'Facilitated Market' electricity industry model which would combine nodal spot and forward markets for electricity with government guidance on long term policy issues. However the principles of a market-based electricity industry are not well understood. This paper reviews those principles, considering technical issues such as quality of supply pricing, inter-temporal issues such as the operation of storage under uncertainty and spatial issues such as nodal pricing. A key result is that the network should be seen as allowing arbitrage between nodal markets rather than as providing a separately priced transmission service. Transition from a traditional industry structure is discussed in the Australian context.

Abstract: An evolutionary approach to synthetic biology consists of inoculating the process of evolution by natural selection into the logical/informational medium of the digital computer. Thus, these new instances of evolution are not subject to the same physical laws as organic evolution. Examples are cited that provide an exercise in experimental comparative evolutionary biology and a means of harnessing the evolutionary process for the production of complex computer software.

Abstract: This paper describes a theoretical framework for analyzing and predicting jitter in ring oscillators. These oscillators are becoming more popular in low jitter applications, but the mechanisms underlying their jitter performance have been poorly understood. A comparison with analysis techniques for harmonic and relaxation oscillators shows that a different approach is needed to design for low jitter in rings. The approach taken is in the time domain, considering each delay stage to add a uniform amount of phase in a varying an amount of time. The theory is applied to experimental results from ring oscillators of several different lengths.

Abstract: The paper describes work being done at the Kola Mining Institute to mitigate environmental problems related to nuclear wastes disposal and to assure the continued safe production of energy from nuclear resources. The Kola Peninsula provides a natural location for the storage of nuclear materials and a site for the production of abundant, inexpensive nuclear power. The Kola Mining Institute, located in the northwest part of Russia, has devoted many years to the conceptual design of nuclear waste facilities. The subsurface provides both a safe place to store and recycle radioactive materials and an ideal location for nuclear power plants.

Authors: Carnes Sam A.
Title: Negotiating equity for management of DOE wastes
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carnes, Sam A., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: One important factor frustrating optimal management of Department of Energy (DOE)-complex wastes is the inability to use licensed and permitted facilities systematically. Achieving the goal of optimal use of DOE's waste management facilities is politically problematic for two reasons. First, no locale wants to bear a disproportionate burden from DOE wastes. Second, the burden imposed by additional wastes transported from one site to another is difficult to characterize. To develop a viable framework for equitably distributing these burdens while achieving efficient use of all DOE waste management facilities, several implementation and equity issues must be addressed and resolved. This paper discusses stake-holders and equity issues and proposes a framework for joint research and action that could facilitate equity negotiations among stakeholders and move toward a more optimal use of DOE's waste management capabilities.

Abstract: The United States Department of Energy (DOE) owns over 90 different types of spent nuclear fuel (SNF), having a range of 235U enrichments, sizes, and cladding materials. The SNF is stored in basins and dry storage facilities at a number of different sites. The current plan is to dispose of all DOE-owned SNF in a geological repository. This paper discusses regulations pertaining to criticality safety, relates them to storage of high-enriched uranium (HEU) in a geological repository, and summarizes the results of calculations made to define emplacement package reactivities in a repository.

Authors: Herzik Eric B., Dobra John L.
Title: What's science got to do with it?: The use of public opinion in developing nuclear waste policy
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Nevada, Reno, United States
Authors with affiliations: Herzik, Eric B., Univ of Nevada, Reno, United States; Dobra, John L., Univ of Nevada, Reno, United States
Abstract: Public perceptions have played a large role in delaying the siting process for the proposed high-level nuclear waste repository. Reported levels of public opposition and distrust in the Department of Energy have been used as arguments against the repository program. We reanalyze and augment prior public opinion data and show reported opposition levels are linked to selective samples of `affected' populations, lack of knowledge by survey respondents and in no way correlated with actual behaviors concerning the nuclear waste repository. Until public opinion samples are expanded to cover the full context of the policy domain, conclusions drawn are premature.
Index Keywords: Economic and social effects; Public policy; Public risks; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Surveys; High level nuclear waste repository; Nuclear waste policy; Public opinion; Geological repositories

Abstract: The Light Duty Utility Arm (LDUA) is a remote manipulator which is being designed and fabricated to perform surveillance and characterization activities in support of the remediation of underground storage tanks at the Hanford site as well as other U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) sites. The LDUA is a highly dexterous manipulator which utilizes an advanced control system to safely and reliably deploy a series of sensors to characterize underground storage tanks. The electrical components of the in tank system are radiation hardened and the mechanical components are designed to operate in the corrosive environment which exists in the tanks. The use of this system will allow the DOE to sample and characterize the waste material in the tanks prior to the initiation of waste retrieval operations.

Title: Transmission series power flow control
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Power Engineering Society Transmission and Distribution Conference
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electric Corp, Orlando, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nelson, R.J., Westinghouse Electric Corp, Orlando, United States; Williams, S.L., Westinghouse Electric Corp, Orlando, United States; Bian, J., Westinghouse Electric Corp, Orlando, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the characteristics of two gate turn-off (GTO) thyristor voltage-sourced inverter-based series power flow control devices, namely the Series Power Flow Controller (SPFC) and the Unified Power Flow Controller (UPFC). These devices represent series extensions of the STATCON, an inverter-based shunt device developed under a tailored collaboration by EPRI, TVA and the Westinghouse Science and Technology Center, which will soon be placed in service on the TVA 161kV transmission system for transmission voltage control. Operation of the SPFC and UPFC is illustrated through the use of easily-constructed circle diagrams on the P-Q plane. The circle diagrams provide the transmission planning engineer with a simple means to assess the performance of these devices on the transmission system. A concluding example illustrates that the UPFC provides a level of power flow control which is unattainable with more conventional devices.

Authors: Fries Michael
Title: Simulation of one-dimensional Euler-flow by means of multidimensional wave digital filters
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Ruhr-Universitaet Bochum, Bochum, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fries, Michael, Ruhr-Universitaet Bochum, Bochum, Germany
Abstract: Multidimensional Wave Digital Filters (MDWDF) are used for the integration of partial differential equations (PDE). A new approach based on the integration of systems of conservation laws is presented. For each conservation law a separate lossless Kirchhoff network is used as reference circuit for the derivation of the MDWDF. In each network the energy stored in the network represents the property that is conserved by the corresponding conservation law. The networks do not exchange stored energy. Nevertheless, the networks are coupled because they all are described by the same variables. This approach is used for the integration of the one-dimensional Euler-equations, describing inviscid, non-heatconducting flow. Simulation results are presented, showing that this approach leads to correct shock speeds and shock intensities in the well known shock-tube problem.

Authors: Lazar M.S., Bruton L.T.
Title: Three-dimensional linear trajectory filtering using the DWT and the mixed-domain approach
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Univ of Calgary, Calgary, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Lazar, M.S., Univ of Calgary, Calgary, Canada; Bruton, L.T., Univ of Calgary, Calgary, Canada
Abstract: A method is proposed which combines the two-dimensional (2-D) orthogonal discrete wavelet transform (DWT) and mixed-domain (Mixed-D) filtering to selectively enhance or attenuate a 2-D signal moving along a linear trajectory at a constant velocity. Such signals are common in video coding applications. The 2-D DWT is applied separately to each frame of the three-dimensional (3-D) input sequence, resulting in a set of multiresolution (subband) image sequences. Mixed-D filtering is then used to enhance or reject linear trajectory signals within each subband image sequence. The output for each frame is formed by inverting the wavelet transform using the Mixed-D processed sequences. This method of filtering lends itself to use in subband video coding systems, which are becoming increasingly popular, and permits selective Mixed-D filtering of the subband signals depending upon the energy content within the subbands. In this contribution, we present an overview of the proposed algorithm and present preliminary results which compare favourably in terms of arithmetic complexity, storage requirements, and the subjective quality of output, to those obtained using the Mixed-D technique.
Index Keywords: Computational complexity; Image coding; Image processing; Mathematical models; Mathematical transformations; Video signal processing; Discrete wavelet transform; Mixed domain filtering; Three dimensional linear trajectory filtering; Video coding systems; Signal filtering and prediction

Authors: Wada Y., Anraku Y.
Title: Chemiosmotic coupling of ion transport in the yeast vacuole: Its role in acidification inside organelles
Affiliations: Department of Life Sciences, Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, University of Tokyo, Komaba, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 153, Japan; Department of Plant Sciences, Graduate School of Science, University of Tokyo, Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Wada, Y., Department of Life Sciences, Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, University of Tokyo, Komaba, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 153, Japan; Anraku, Y., Department of Plant Sciences, Graduate School of Science, University of Tokyo, Hongo, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo, 113, Japan
Abstract: Acidification inside the vacuo-lysosome systems is ubiquitous in eukaryotic organisms and essential for organelle functions. The acidification of these organelles is accomplished by proton-translocating ATPase belonging to the V-type H+-ATPase superfamily. However, in terms of chemiosmotic energy transduction, electrogenic proton pumping alone is not sufficient to establish and maintain those compartments inside acidic. Current studies have shown that the in situ acidification depends upon the activity of V-ATPase and vacuolar anion conductance; the latter is required for shunting a membrane potential (interior positive) generated by the positively charged proton translocation. Yeast vacuoles possess two distinct Cl- transport systems both participating in the acidification inside the vacuole, a large acidic compartment with digestive and storage functions. These two transport systems have distinct characteristics for their kinetics of Cl- uptake or sensitivity to a stilbene derivative. One shows linear dependence on a Cl- concentration and is inhibited by 4,4′-diisothiocyano-2,2′-stilbenedisulfonic acid (DIDS). The other shows saturable kinetics with an apparent Km for Cl- of approximately 20 mM. Molecular mechanisms of the chemiosmotic coupling in the vacuolar ion transport and acidification inside are discussed in detail. © 1994 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Author Keywords: ΔpH; anion transport; chloride transport; membrane potential; protonmotive force; V-ATPase; Vacuolar acidification

Abstract: An effective way of obtaining near-optimal solutions for the control of multi-zone HVAC systems with substantial energy storage, where a period of discounted energy price occurs daily has been shown by the aggregation/disaggregation method. In this paper, the given simulation results shown that substantial energy-cost savings can be achieved by a near-optimal control scheme.

Authors with affiliations: Van Alstine, M.N., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States; Gromada, R.J., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Abstract: Westinghouse Savannah River Company developed a hydride transport vessel (HTV) for Department of Energy bulk tritium shipments. The HTV contained 493 grams of uranium that provided capacity for 18 grams of tritium as solid uranium tritide. Transportation efficiency was significantly improved with the 0.75-liter HTV when compared to the existing 50-liter gaseous transport vessel. Elevated temperature restrictions associated with tritium and uranium use were addressed. Design and construction complied with ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code Section VIII, Division 1, fabrication criteria of Section III for Class 1 components, and NRC Regulatory Guide 7.6 stress criteria. Facility conditions included a maximum temperature of 600 °C with a 65.2 kPa internal gage pressure. Normal transport conditions were less stringent.

Authors: Rodriguez Ernesto L.
Title: Glass transition temperature of glassy polymers using dynamic mechanical analysis
Affiliations: BFGoodrich Co, Avon Lake, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rodriguez, Ernesto L., BFGoodrich Co, Avon Lake, United States
Abstract: Dynamic Mechanical Analysis (DMA) is presented for four glassy polymers. Poly(vinyl acetate), poly(vinyl chloride), poly(styrene), and poly(carbonate) were studied as a function of the heating rate using ramp and step heating programs and a constant frequency of 1 Hz. The effect of frequency on the dynamic mechanical parameters was also examined from 0.01 Hz to 10 Hz. The dynamic elastic storage modulus (E′), the dynamic elastic loss modulus (E″) and the tanδ (E″/E′) were affected by both the heating rate and the frequency. Apparent activation energies for the glass transition were also determined for the four polymers which were in the range from 98 of 194 kcal/mol.

Authors: Kojima Hirotsugu, Tanaka Satoshi, Sasaki Katsuro

Source title: IEEE Symposium on VLSI Circuits, Digest of Technical Papers
Affiliations: Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kojima, Hirotsugu, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Tanaka, Satoshi, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Japan; Sasaki, Katsuro, Hitachi Ltd, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The paper proposes a new clocking scheme in which the supply voltage only for the clock driver is reduced to half of the LSI supply voltage and the entire clock loads are driven by a half swing clock. This technology allows the users to reduce the clocking power consumption by 75%. The degradation in speed is very small because the random logic circuits in the critical path are still supplied by the full voltage. Half swing clocking scheme can give a great amount of power savings for the most CMOS digital LSIs including microprocessors, digital signal processors with little degradation in speed.

Authors: Williamson Douglas A.
Title: Selecting the design basis fuel for the multi-purpose canister
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: E. R. Johnson Associates, Inc, Fairfax, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williamson, Douglas A., E. R. Johnson Associates, Inc, Fairfax, United States
Abstract: In 1993, the U. S. Department of Energy (DOE) instructed the Civilian Radioactive Waste Management System (CRWMS) Management and Operating (M&O) contractor to perform a conceptual design of a multi-purpose canister (MPC) for possible inclusion in the CRWMS. This MPC would be designed for use in the transportation, storage, and disposal regimes, and would help reduce the number of individual spent fuel handlings performed over the life of the CRWMS. For the purposes of this conceptual design, a design basis fuel was desired which would serve as a design reference and establish the minimum acceptable fuel characteristics for the MPC. The critical parameters of the design basis fuel were the fuel assembly dimensions, weight, burnup, initial enrichment, and age. The values selected for these parameters for the conceptual design specified a fuel inventory sufficient for nearly 20 years of CRWMS operations at the currently projected waste acceptance rates.

Abstract: We have recently built two tunable CW UV laser systems, which can produce up to 90 mW. Each system consists of a ring dye laser, which is frequently doubled in an external resonator containing a KDP-crystal. The storage ring incorporates an RF-cavity, which can be used to longitudinally focus the ion beam. Ions will then perform oscillations (so-called synchronous oscillation) around the synchronous energy (defined by the RF frequency). These findings have paved the way for producing space charge dominated stored beams by laser cooling.

Abstract: A new type of plasma light source produced by a sliding surface discharge on ferrite rods has recently been developed for various applications such as gas laser excitation. Studies on the subject have given rise to investigations of the efficiency of a blue-green XeF laser pumped by the formed-ferrite plasma source whose strong emission around 158 nm fits to the maximum of the photodissociation cross section of the XeF2 molecule. In this work, a laser device has been constructed and both model and numerical code have been developed to simulate the physical processes leading to the stimulated emission centered on 480 nm.

Abstract: Fuels have been stored in the Idaho Chemical Processing Plant since the 1950's prior to reprocessing for uranium recovery. Authors: Vallee F., Flytzanis Ch.
Title: Phonon-polariton transmission through a vacuum layer
Source title: Proceedings of the International Quantum Electronics Conference (IQEC'94)
Affiliations: Lab d'Optique Quantique du Cent Natl, de la Recherche Scientifique, Palaiseau, France
Authors with affiliations: Vallee, F., Lab d'Optique Quantique du Cent Natl, de la Recherche Scientifique, Palaiseau, France; Flytzanis, Ch., Lab d'Optique Quantique du Cent Natl, de la Recherche Scientifique, Palaiseau, France
Abstract: Propagation of polaritons in inhomegeneous artificial media is becoming an important issue in the transmission, redistribution and storage of electromagnetic energy and may also have applications in devices. The polariton being an hybrid matter-radiation mode these aspects may be drastically altered as its material support is altered for instance in the course of its propagation in inhomogeneous media. In this context the polariton transmission through an interface or a layer is a key problem. We have extended and applied to this problem the nonlocal time-resolved nonlinear technique we previously used for the study of polaritons in bulk crystals. This technique is in essence a 'time of flight' experiment consisting in separating in space the coherent excitation and probing stages of the picosecond time-resolved CARS, the excited polariton wave-packet being tracked in real time and space during its propagation. Here we have exploited the spatial and temporal selectivity of this technique to investigate the transmission of a phonon-polariton pulse through a vacuum layer separating two identical halves of an ammonium chloride (NH4Cl) crystal. The coherent excitation of the phonon-polariton is performed in the one half by coherent Raman scattering of two picosecond pulses and the transmitted wave-packet is tracked in the other half by measuring coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering of a third picosecond pulse. The nonlocal probing allows a separation of the temporal and spatial features and gives a direct and independent access to the influence of the interface on the polariton envelope. The transmission was studied for two layer thicknesses (d = 3 mm and 1 mm) and two different polariton modes of the same branch; the figure shows the intensity of the CARS signal as a function of the probing point for d = 3 mm. The second maximum (probing point displacement around 2.5 mm) corresponds to probing in the second crystal of the phonon-polariton wave-packet excited in the first one and transmitted through the vacuum layer. The above technique can be extended to measure polariton transmission and reflection coefficients on interfaces or dielectric layers that separate different crystalline media or other inhomogeneous configurations. Such information is very important when envisaging polariton pulse processing and interaction with other injected pulses.
Index Keywords: Ammonium compounds; Crystals; Dielectric materials; Interfaces (materials); Phonons; Quantum theory; Raman scattering; Vacuum; Phonon polariton transmission; Polaritons; Vacuum layer; Electromagnetic wave transmission

Authors: Taylor Edward C., Sinnock Scott, Ramspott Lawrence D., Sprecher William M.
Title: Integrating scientific results for a post-closure safety demonstration
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: TRW Environmental Safety Systems Inc, Vienna, United States
Authors with affiliations: Taylor, Edward C., TRW Environmental Safety Systems Inc, Vienna, United States; Sinnock, Scott, TRW Environmental Safety Systems Inc, Vienna, United States; Ramspott, Lawrence D., TRW Environmental Safety Systems Inc, Vienna, United States; Sprecher, William M., TRW Environmental Safety Systems Inc, Vienna, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) is developing a nuclear waste management system that will accept high-level radioactive waste, transport it, store it, and ultimately emplace it in a deep geologic repository. The key activity now is determining whether Yucca Mountain, Nevada is suitable as a site for the repository. If so, the crucial technological advance will be the demonstration that disposal of nuclear waste will be safe for thousands of years after closure. Recent regulatory, legal, and scientific developments imply that the safety demonstration must be simple. The scientific developments taken together support a simple set of hypotheses that constitute a post-closure safety argument for a repository at Yucca Mountain. If the understanding of Yucca Mountain hydrology presented in the Site Characterization Plan proves correct, then these hypotheses might be confirmed by combining results of Surface-Based Testing with early testing results in the Exploratory Studies Facility.

Abstract: A coincidence data acquisition system, incorporating a position sensitive detector and a custom-built data acquisition card installed in an IBM-PC 486 computer, has been implemented in a coincidence experiment in which scattered electrons and Auger electrons are detected in coincidence. Three analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) are used to digitize all the timing and energy information, and custom-designed and written control software is used to accumulate the data, display it in real time, and store it in expanded memory. The new system has ben used to measure the energy and angular distribution of Auger electrons ejected from argon after electron impact ionization.

Abstract: A new beamline for radiometric applications (e.g., detector calibration and reflectometry) has been installed and characterized at the laboratory of the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt at the electron storage ring BESSY. The beamline is equipped with a SX700 type plane grating monochromator and a toroidal mirror behind the exit slit of the monochromator for collimating the radiation to allow angle resolved reflectometry. A divergence of 0.1 mrad has been achieved. The beamline has been optimized for high spectral purity of the radiation. Within the photon energy range from 40 to about 1500 eV the total amount of stray light and higher order radiation stays below 1%. A photon flux of up to 1011 s-1 has been measured in the focal point of the toroidal mirror. It corresponds to a radiant power of a few μW and thus allows use of a cryogenic radiometer for detector calibration. The details of the beamline layout and the results of the performance characterization are presented.

Authors: Zhang Y., Spencer C.A., Ghosal S., Casstevens M.K., Burzynski R.
Title: Photorefractive properties of a thiapyrylium-dye-sensitized polymer composite
Affiliations: Laser Photonics Technology, Inc., 1576 Sweet Home Road, Amherst, NY 14228, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Y., Laser Photonics Technology, Inc., 1576 Sweet Home Road, Amherst, NY 14228, United States; Spencer, C.A., Laser Photonics Technology, Inc., 1576 Sweet Home Road, Amherst, NY 14228, United States; Ghosal, S., Laser Photonics Technology, Inc., 1576 Sweet Home Road, Amherst, NY 14228, United States; Casstevens, M.K., Laser Photonics Technology, Inc., 1576 Sweet Home Road, Amherst, NY 14228, United States; Burzynski, R., Laser Photonics Technology, Inc., 1576 Sweet Home Road, Amherst, NY 14228, United States
Abstract: The detailed photorefractive properties of a thiapyrylium-dye-sensitized photorefractive polymeric composite are presented. The composite contains an ionic thiapyrylium dye, 4-(4-dimethylaminophenyl)-2,6-diphenylthiapyrylium perchlorate, as a photocharge generation sensitizer, 4-(N,N-diethylamino)- (β)-nitrostyrene as a second-order nonlinear optical chromophore, and poly(9-vinylcarbazole) as a host polymer as well as a charge transporting agent. The electrooptic and photoconductive properties of the composite have been studied and an apparent sublinear dependence of the photoconductivity on the illumination power density has been observed. Both degenerate and nondegenerate four-wave-mixing experiments have been carried out and a holographic diffraction efficiency of 1.1% has been achieved in a 160-μm-thick film at an external field of 62.5 V/μm. A nonlocal character of the photorefractivity has been established through the asymmetric energy transfer with a gain of 7 cm -1 in a two-beam coupling experiment. The dynamics of the formation and erasure of the holographic gratings has been studied. The rise time and erasure time for the space-charge field have been measured as a function of the writing and erasure beam intensities, respectively. The sublinear character of these dependencies can be explained by the apparent sublinear photoconductivity of the composite. The dependence of the grating rise time on the applied electric field is attributed to the field dependence of both the photocharge generation quantum efficiency and the charge mobility in the polymer matrix. The application of this material to information storage and image processing has been explored with demonstrations of holographic image recording and retrieval.

Abstract: A new approach of all-solid-state generation of yellow radiation which matches the sodium D2 transition wavelength is proposed in this article. We study the possibility of producing 589 nm light by an intracavity sum-frequency generation in Nd:YAG laser, operated simultaneously at two lines: 1064 and 1319 nm. This technique combines the advantages of better efficiency due to the higher intracavity power and the simplicity of the single oscillator design. We present preliminary experimental results which confirm the possibility of stable two wavelength operation with a simultaneous frequency mixing at 589 or 592 nm.

Abstract: For reducing the critical diameter of the written domain in magnetic garnet films for magneto-optical (MO) recording, double-layered garnet films were investigated. The coercivity of the double-layered garnet film was increased, when the upper layer was crystallized. This increase of the coercivity is caused by the increase of the uniaxial anisotropy energy. The increase of the uniaxial anisotropy energy also leads to a decrease in the noise level of the MO readout signal. As a consequence, the critical diameter of written domains was reduced to 0.2 μm. This critical diameter is smaller than the reading out beam spot for the case with a green laser and a high numerical aperture objective lens. The garnet films are sufficient for high density next generation MO recording.

Authors: Zhou G.F., Bakker H.
Title: Atomically disordered nanocrystalline Co2Si by high-energy ball milling
Affiliations: Van der Waals Lab., Amsterdam Univ., Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, G.F., Van der Waals Lab., Amsterdam Univ., Netherlands; Bakker, H., Van der Waals Lab., Amsterdam Univ., Netherlands
Abstract: The initially ordered intermetallic compound Co2Si with orthorhombic structure was mechanically milled in a high-energy ball mill. The structural changes with milling time were followed by X-ray diffraction, high-field magnetization measurements and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). Ball milling results in a continuous increase of the magnetization at 4.2 K in a field of 21 T with milling time. This gives evidence that by mechanical milling anti-site disorder is generated in Co2Si, similar to the case of orthorhombic Co2Ge. X-ray diffraction reveals that the number of diffraction peaks decreases with increasing milling time and that all diffraction peaks broaden. The absence of a large number of diffraction lines supports the creation of atomic disorder. The average crystallite size derived from the fine width shows a drastic decrease in the early stage of milling and tends to become constant with a value of 8-10 nm upon further milling. The material remains in the same structure as the starting compound even after prolonged periods of milling. Exothermic heat effects due to both atomic reordering and nanocrystallite growth are evident in the DSC scans of ball-milled samples. Well defined atomically disordered nanocrystalline Co 2Si is produced by ball milling. Since the amount of heat released in reordering and grain growth is comparable, it can be concluded that both anti-site disorder and grain boundaries are the important sources of energy storage in Co2Si during high-energy ball milling.
Index Keywords: Atomic disorder; Cobalt silicide; Differential scanning calorimetry; Heat release; High energy ball milling; Nanocrystalline materials; X ray diffraction; Ball milling; Calorimetry; Cobalt compounds; Crystalline materials; Energy storage; Grain boundaries; Grain growth; Magnetic variables measurement; Magnetization; Order disorder transitions; Silicon compounds; X ray analysis; Intermetallics

Authors: Thoms M., Von Seggern H.
Title: Method for the determination of photostimulable defect center concentrations, production rates, and effective formation energies
Affiliations: Siemens AG, Corporate Research and Development, ZFE BT MR 6, 91052 Erlangen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Thoms, M., Siemens AG, Corporate Research and Development, ZFE BT MR 6, 91052 Erlangen, Germany; Von Seggern, H., Siemens AG, Corporate Research and Development, ZFE BT MR 6, 91052 Erlangen, Germany
Abstract: A new method is proposed to determine radiation-induced defect center concentrations in solids which exhibit photostimulable luminescence. The technique relies on the determination of the number of photons released by spontaneous and photostimulated luminescence. A comparison with the x-ray-absorbed energy yields the effective formation energy of spontaneous luminescence photons and photostimulable centers. The method is applied representatively to BaFBr:Eu2+, which is utilized commercially as photostimulable x-ray storage phosphor in image plates for x-ray, γ-ray, electron, and neutron radiography. It is shown that in the utilized material on average 8 photostimulable F(Br-) centers (color centers based on bromine vacancies) and about 5 spontaneously emitted photons are generated by the absorption of 1 keV x-ray energy. Taking recent investigations into account which show that the x-ray generation of spontaneous luminescence and photostimulated luminescence centers is accompanied by the creation of approximately 36 nonphotostimulable defect centers, an average formation energy of about 20 eV per defect center can be calculated.

Abstract: A soft x-ray beamline designed principally for gas phase measurements has been constructed and tested at the 550-MeV MAX I electron storage ring in Lund, Sweden. The beamline uses synchrotron radiation from a short 35-period undulator with a magnetic period of 24 mm. The photon energy range of the undulator is about 60-600 eV covering, e.g., the important C, N and O 1s ionization regions. The beamline is based on a modified SX-700 plane grating monochromator with a plane elliptical focusing mirror. The beamline has been tested by measuring total ion and electron yield spectra from the rare gases Kr and Ar in the resonance excitation regions just below the Kr M4,5 and Ar L 2,3 ionization thresholds. These results show that the monochromator has very high resolution, E/ΔE≈4800 at 244 eV and ≈7600 at 91 eV, comparable with the best spherical and plane grating monochromators. The beamline is equipped with an effective differential pumping system for the gas phase experiments combined with a refocusing mirror in order to provide a small spot size (φ<1 mm) at the sample region.

Abstract: A simple model of atomic motion has been used to calculate the velocity autocorrelation function, its frequency spectrum, the associated memory function, and the self-diffusion coefficients for liquid alkali metals. There are no adjustable parameters in the model and the only inputs required are the interatomic potential and the pair correlation function. The predicted results are in good agreement with recent computer simulation data. The self-diffusion coefficients are found to be very close to actual experimental values for all liquid alkaline metals, including lithium, and they seem to scale, the scaling being determined by energy and length parameters for the interatomic potential and the mass.
Index Keywords: Atomic motion; Interatomic potential; Pair correlation function; Velocity auto correlation function; Alkali metals; Associative storage; Atomic physics; Computer simulation; Correlation methods; Diffusion in liquids; Lithium; Mathematical models; Velocity; Liquid metals

Authors: Partovi A., Erdogan T., Mizrahi V., Lemaire P.J., Glass A.M., Fleming J.W.
Title: Volume holographic storage in hydrogen treated germano-silicate glass
Affiliations: AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Authors with affiliations: Partovi, A., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Erdogan, T., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Mizrahi, V., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Lemaire, P.J., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Glass, A.M., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States; Fleming, J.W., AT and T Bell Laboratories, Murray Hill, NJ 07974, United States
Abstract: Strong permanent gratings (index change Δn∼3×10 -3) have been formed in bulk hydrogen treated germano-silicate glass with 242 nm exposure. Diffraction efficiencies of 6% and initial sensitivity (Δn/incident energy density) of 2×10-5 cm2/J have been obtained. The observed sensitivity is comparable to the values achieved in other holographic storage materials such as LiNbO3. It is estimated that by more uniform hydrogen loading of the sample, diffraction efficiencies of 100% can be obtained in 3 mol % GeO2 samples of only 175 μm thickness. These materials are potentially useful as fast access time (sub-μs), high capacity (∼0.8 Tbits), robust, inexpensive write-one-read-many storage media, narrow (subangstrom) linewidth optical filters, and other optical components.
Index Keywords: Fused silica; Germanium; Holograms; Holography; Hydrogen; Laser beams; Lithium compounds; Optical image storage; Radiation effects; Refractive index; Sensitivity analysis; Ultraviolet radiation; Germanium silicate glass; Holographic storage; Storage capacity; Diffraction gratings

Authors: Seki H., Oohashi T., Shirakura T., Takemori S., Midorikawa Y., Kameyama H., Yamamura G., Kotani K., Sugawara H.
Title: Development of a pulsed power supply for a large-bore copper vapor laser

Abstract: A pulsed power supply has been developed for exciting a copper vapor laser with a bore diameter of 80 mm and a discharge length of 2890 mm. The pulsed power supply has two thyratrons, an LC-inversion circuit and a two-staged magnetic pulse compression circuit. An efficiency of 82% has been obtained which is defined as the ratio of energy stored in the storage capacitor to the output energy of the magnetic pulse compression circuit, with a voltage greater than 40 kV, averaged output power of 24 kW, and voltage rise time of 70 ns. The pulsed power supply was successfully operated for more than 2000 h and an optical output power of 272 W was obtained.

Authors: Collier J.L., Herbert S.K., Fork D.C., Grossman A.R.
Title: Changes in the cyanobacterial photosynthetic apparatus during acclimation to macronutrient deprivation
Affiliations: Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, 92093-020, CA, United States; Department of Biological Sciences, University of Idaho, Moscow, 83843, ID, United States; Department of Plant Biology, Carnegie Institution of Washington, 290 Panama Street, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Collier, J.L., Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California, San Diego, La Jolla, 92093-020, CA, United States; Herbert, S.K., Department of Biological Sciences, University of Idaho, Moscow, 83843, ID, United States; Fork, D.C., Department of Plant Biology, Carnegie Institution of Washington, 290 Panama Street, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States; Grossman, A.R., Department of Plant Biology, Carnegie Institution of Washington, 290 Panama Street, Stanford, 94305, CA, United States
Abstract: When the cyanobacterium Synechococcus sp. Strain PCC 7942 is deprived of an essential macronutrient such as nitrogen, sulfur or phosphorus, cellular phycobiliprotein and chlorophyll contents decline. The level of β-carotene declines proportionately to chlorophyll, but the level of zeaxanthin increases relative to chlorophyll. In nitrogen- or sulfur-deprived cells there is a net degradation of phycobiliproteins. Otherwise, the declines in cellular pigmentation are due largely to the diluting effect of continued cell division after new pigment synthesis ceases and not to net pigment degradation. There was also a rapid decrease in O2 evolution when Synechococcus sp. Strain PCC 7942 was deprived of macronutrients. The rate of O2 evolution declined by more than 90% in nitrogen- or sulfur-deprived cells, and by approximately 40% in phosphorus-deprived cells. In addition, in all three cases the fluorescence emissions from Photosystem II and its antennae were reduced relative to that of Photosystem I and the remaining phycobilisomes. Furthermore, state transitions were not observed in cells deprived of sulfur or nitrogen and were greatly reduced in cells deprived of phosphorus. Photoacoustic measurements of the energy storage capacity of photosynthesis also showed that Photosystem II activity declined in nutrient-deprived cells. In contrast, energy storage by Photosystem I was unaffected, suggesting that Photosystem I-driven cyclic electron flow persisted in nutrient-deprived cells. These results indicate that in the modified photosynthetic apparatus of nutrient-deprived cells, a much larger fraction of the photosynthetic activity is driven by Photosystem I than in nutrient-replete cells. © 1994 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: cyanobacteria; cyclic photophosphorylation; nutrient deprivation; photoacoustic spectroscopy; photoinhibition; Photosystem I

Authors: Wang S.B., Houde E.D.
Title: Energy storage and dynamics in bay anchovy Anchoa mitchilli
Affiliations: Chesapeake Biological Laboratory, University of Maryland, P.O. Box 38, Solomons, 20688-0038, Maryland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, S.B., Chesapeake Biological Laboratory, University of Maryland, P.O. Box 38, Solomons, 20688-0038, Maryland, United States; Houde, E.D., Chesapeake Biological Laboratory, University of Maryland, P.O. Box 38, Solomons, 20688-0038, Maryland, United States
Abstract: The energy of the body components and the energy costs of spawning and overwintering in the bay anchovy Anchoa mitchilli, the most abundant fish in Chesapeake Bay, were studied to determine seasonal variability during the different stages of its life cycle. Bimonthly samples were collected by trawl from April 1990 through October 1991. Fish condition and body energy levels fluctuated seasonally, and were related to anchovy size. Energy equivalents (cal g-1 dry wt) was highest in December, before the overwintering period. The somatic weight component increased by 32 to 33% and total body weight by 26% during the spawning season, indicating that feeding not only met energy requirements of daily spawning but also provided surplus energy for growth. The overwintering loss of energy was 33 to 35% of total body calories, and was primarily derived from deposit fat in somatic and visceral tissues. © 1994 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: Anchoa mitchilli

Authors: Althoff D.M., Thompson J.N.
Title: The effects of tail autotomy on survivorship and body growth of Uta stansburiana under conditions of high mortality
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, Washington State University, Pullman, 99163, WA, United States; Department of Botany and Zoology, Washington State University, Pullman, 99163, WA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Althoff, D.M., Department of Zoology, Washington State University, Pullman, 99163, WA, United States; Thompson, J.N., Department of Botany and Zoology, Washington State University, Pullman, 99163, WA, United States
Abstract: We examined the effects of tail autotomy on survivorship and body growth of both adult and juvenile Uta stansburiana by directly manipulating tail condition. Tail loss decreased neither survivorship nor rate of body growth for individuals in two natural populations. Lack of an influence of tail loss on survivorship in these two populations may be the result of high mortality. Under high mortality any differential effects of tail loss will be lower than in populations facing lower mortality. Growth experiments in the laboratory demonstrated that, under conditions of minimal environmental variation and social interactions, there is no tradeoff between body growth and tail regeneration as has been suggested for other species of lizards. One possible reason for this difference is that U. stansburiana does not use the tail as a storage organ for lipids. The original and regenerated tails are composed mainly of protein. In general, any differential body growth between tailed and tailless individuals may be due to social interactions and not a diversion of limited energy into tail regeneration. © 1994 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Body growth; High mortality; Survivorship; Tail autotomy; Tail content
Index Keywords: autotomy; survivorship; Uta stansburiana

Authors: Carrillo R.E., Pearson D.W., Deluca Jr. P.M., MacKay J.F., Lagally M.G.
Title: Response of thermoluminescent lithium fluoride (TLD-100) to photon beams of 275, 400, 500, 600, 730, 900, 1200, 1500, and 2550 eV
Affiliations: Dept. of Med. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carrillo, R.E., Dept. of Med. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, United States; Pearson, D.W., Dept. of Med.
