Authors: Bouwknegt K.
Title: The line-interactive concept, an optimal approach to UPS
Source title: TELESCON 1994 - 1st International Telecommunications Energy Special Conference - A Satellite Conference to INTELEC
Affiliations: HOLEC HSC, P.O.Box 23, Hengelo, 7550 AA, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Bouwknegt, K., HOLEC HSC, P.O.Box 23, Hengelo, 7550 AA, Netherlands
Abstract: The majority of present day UPS systems is based on the traditional dual conversion topology. In this concept, all the energy for the critical loads is converted twice: first from AC power into some kind of intermediate energy that can be stored as kinetical or chemical energy, and than, in a second conversion, again into stabilised AC power for the loads. This concept is now widely used and appreciated, however, improvements to the complexity and losses of the dual conversion and to the relatively high harmonic content of the AC input current is possible. An alternative topology is proposed, in which there is only one bidirectional power converter between AC power and storage means, that is still capable to stabilise and filter the AC input power without the above stated disadvantages. UPS systems based on this "line-interactive" concept are now available as three phase units ranging from 20kVA as static UPS systems with battery to over 10 MVA as rotary systems with kinetic energy storage and an integrated diesel engine. © 1994 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Diesel engines; Kinetic energy; Kinetics; Topology; Bi-directional power converter; Chemical energy; Critical load; Dual-conversion; High harmonics; Intermediate energies; Optimal approaches; Rotary systems; Uninterruptible power systems

Authors: Marinov P., Pavlov S., Draganov V.
Title: Efficiency of a multiple flywheel recuperation system
Source title: Journal of Mechanical Design, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Theory of Mechanisms and Machines Dept, Technical University, Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Marinov, P., Theory of Mechanisms and Machines Dept, Technical University, Sofia, Bulgaria; Pavlov, S., Theory of Mechanisms and Machines Dept, Technical University, Sofia, Bulgaria; Draganov, V., Theory of Mechanisms and Machines Dept, Technical University, Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: A multiple flywheel has been studied for the purpose of storing and recuperating kinetic energy. The objective of the design of such systems is a maximum storage and recuperation of the stored energy. Dynamic models of the proposed and the conventional systems are compared regarding energy losses. A coefficient of recuperating efficiency is introduced for demonstrating the advantages of the multiple flywheel system. © 1994 by ASME.

Authors: Howell L.L., Midha A.
Title: A method for the design of compliant mechanisms with small-length flexural pivots
Source title: Journal of Mechanical Design, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Elastic Mechanisms Laboratory, School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, 47907, United States
Authors with affiliations: Howell, L.L., Elastic Mechanisms Laboratory, School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, 47907, United States; Midha, A., Elastic Mechanisms Laboratory, School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, 47907, United States
Abstract: Compliant or flexible-link mechanisms gain some or all of their motion from the relative flexibility of their joints rather than from rigid-body joints only. Unlike rigid-body mechanisms, energy is not conserved between the input and output ports of compliant mechanisms because of energy storage in the flexible members. This effect and the nonlinearities introduced by large deflections complicate the analysis of such mechanisms. The design of compliant mechanisms in industry is currently accomplished by expensive trial and error methods. This paper introduces a method to aid in the design of a class of compliant mechanisms wherein the flexible sections (flexural pivots) are small in length compared to the relatively rigid sections. The method includes a definition and use of a pseudo-rigid-body model, and the use of a large-deflection finite element type algorithm. An example is used to illustrate the design technique described. © 1994 by ASME.

Authors: Nakanishu T.
Title: Present Status of CWM Development and Commercialization in Japan
Source title: International Journal of the Society of Material Engineering for Resources
Affiliations: Technical Development Dept. Center for Coal Utilization, Japan Ohkubo 2-3-4, Tokyo, Shinjuku-ku, 169, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakanishu, T., Technical Development Dept. Center for Coal Utilization, Japan Ohkubo 2-3-4, Tokyo, Shinjuku-ku, 169, Japan
Abstract: CWM demonstration tests such as Tomakomai project, Ube prtoject, etc. have been operated while accumulating various imformation data. In fact, present level of CWM for production, storage, transportation and combustion technologies, may be satisfactorily high for practical applications. However, users are less intereted in converting fuels to CWM at present because of the fall of oil prices since 1986 and recent recession in economy. Under these circumstances, a new test for CWM distribution relay system, or West Japan Project, has been launched since fiscal 1991 to appeal CWM to users as a more attractive commodity. On the other hand, a commercial project, or Nakoso project in which CWM is being used at a power station has been conducted since several years ago. And some feasibility studies to import large amount of CWM from China and Australia, are planning. Forecasting future aspect on energy in Japan where there are very few energy resources, CWM has been regarded gradually as one of the most important oil-substitute energy resources even if oil prices does'nt high enough. This paper describes CWM projects started from 1987 in Japan. © 1994, The Society of Materials Engineering for Resources of Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: additive; combustion; CWM; de-ash; derating; handling; NOx; production; relay station; SOx; storage; transportation

Authors: Aceves-Saborio S., Nakamura H., Reistad G.M.
Title: The Effect Of Freezing And Melting On The Efficiency Of Latent Heat Storage Systems
Source title: JOURNAL OF CHEMICAL ENGINEERING OF JAPAN
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Daido Institute of Technology, Nagoya 457, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Aceves-Saborio, S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Daido Institute of Technology, Nagoya 457, Japan; Nakamura, H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Daido Institute of Technology, Nagoya 457, Japan; Reistad, G.M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Daido Institute of Technology, Nagoya 457, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a thermodynamic analysis of latent heat storage systems (LHSSs). The study is based on a model that, although simplified, takes full account of the physics of the phase-change process that takes place in the LHSS during charge and discharge. The model characterizes an LHSS with only two parameters and four operating temperatures. This simplicity allows a detailed study of the unit. Two different situations are analyzed. The first is an LHSS in which the phase-change material (PCM) is stored in a single container. The second is an LHSS with many small cells containing the phase-change material. The simplified model presented in this paper is successful in describing the effects of the physics of the phasechange process on the performance of LHSSs. Optimum efficiencies and phase change temperatures in the LHSSs related to the inlet temperature of the charge fluid are obtained based on exergy analysis. The results also indicate that the insulating effect of the solid layer during the discharge process reduces both the exergetic efficiency and the storage capacity of the unit. On the other hand, the study points to enhanced heat transfer inside the unit as very important for improving LHSSs performance. © 1994, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Energy; Exergy; Freezing and Melting; Heat Transfer; Latent Heat Storage; Thermodynamics

Authors: Nagao M., Horikawa H., Harada K.
Title: Photovoltaic system using buck-bost PWM power inverter
Affiliations: Oita University, Japan; Kumamoto Institute of Technology, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nagao, M., Oita University, Japan; Horikawa, H., Oita University, Japan; Harada, K., Kumamoto Institute of Technology, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a buck-boost PWM power inverter and its application for residential photovoltaic system. The PWM power inverter is realized by driving a inverter constructed with a high frequency buck-boost chopper in the discontinuous conduction mode (DCM). Photovoltaic system with the power inverter has the following advantages: (1) The power generated by the photovoltaic array can be transfered to the load and the utility line under any array voltage, (2) Isolation between the photovoltaic array and the utility line is performed by a small high frequency reactor operating as energy storage element, (3) There is no need of a reactor to link the utility line, (4) Unity power factor operation is provided, (5) So the system configuration is very simple. The input-output characteristics of the system is analyzed. As the result, the ripple component of the array current and the power flow between the interface and the utility line are derived, and verified experimentally. © 1994, The Institute of Electrical Engineers of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Takeno K., Ohtsu S., Yamashita T.
Title: Input and output circuits of SMES for dc lines
Affiliations: Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takeno, K., Japan; Ohtsu, S., Japan; Yamashita, T., Japan
Abstract: Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is considered the next generation technology for storing electrical energy because its energy storage efficiency is higher than that of any conventional energy storage system and its charging and discharging times are short. This paper discusses the input and output circuits of SMES for DC lines, and it discusses their circuit control methods. The main items in this paper are the follows: (1) An input circuit using a high-frequency switching control method is proposed, and its stable condition (depending on the voltage range of the capacitor in the input circuit) is derived. (2) A frequency modulation method for an output circuit is proposed, and simulated results show that this circuit supplies stable power and a constant ripple voltage. (3) Experimental results of the input and output circuits using a normal-conducting coil and a current-generator are shown to confirm the analysis of the input and output circuits. © 1994, The Institute of Electrical Engineers of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Saito A., Hong H., Yamashita K.
Title: Performance of Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage System with Split Fins
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series B
Authors with affiliations: Saito, A.; Hong, H.; Yamashita, K.
Abstract: The effect of the split heating plate is tested in the application of the latent-heat-thermal energy storage system in order to enhance performance in the melting process. A heating plate with a number of split fins is devised having both the fin and the split-heating-plate effect as well as being feasible to manufacture. Its performance was verified by a variety of experiments: The melting rate is successfully increased by using this heating plate with split fins compared with the case of nonsplit fins. Observed melting patterns illustrated how the size of the fin should be determined in order to achieve uniform melting along the fin surface. Moreover, by examination of the influence of the inclination angle from the horizontal, it was determined that the inclination of the fins induces no improvement in melting rate. © 1994, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Direct Contact Melting; Energy Storage; Heat Transfer; Heat-Transfer Enhancement; Phase Change

Authors: Funato H., Kawamura A.
Title: Variable active-passive reactance for power circuit without DC voltage source
Affiliations: Yokohama National University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Funato, H., Yokohama National University, Japan; Kawamura, A., Yokohama National University, Japan
Abstract: The concept of the variable active-passive reactance (VAPAR) has been proposed in(1), which behaves like a two-terminal reactive element, and the produced active virtual reactance works as a passive reactive component, including in transient state. However, in these analysis and experiments, the DC voltage source was used as an energy storage element. If a DC voltage source is replaced with a capacitor, VAPAR can be considered as a complete two-terminal element. In this paper, authors propose the equivalent resistance control method for the capacitor DC voltage regulation when a capacitor is used as an energy storage element of VAPAR. The series equivalent resistance is added to the produced virtual inductance, and the capacitor voltage is controlled by changing the series equivalent resistance. The proposed scheme was verified by simulations and experiments. © 1994, The Institute of Electrical Engineers of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Miura Y., Sakoda M., Shimada R.
Title: Study of the superconducting force-balanced coil for high field magnets
Affiliations: Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miura, Y., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan; Sakoda, M., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan; Shimada, R., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan
Abstract: The force-balanced coil using multi-helical variable pitch windings for generating the high magnetic field and applying to Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage is proposed. This toroidal-poloidal field hybrid coil for the torus-type superconducting magnetic device can be made capable of not only greatly reducing the global electromagnetic forces in the major radius direction, but also dispersing the local over-concentration of forces with variable pitch windings. The computer code that calculates the windings pitch of the force-balanced coil by disassembling the current density to both toroidal and poloidal directions and optimizing the current distribution is developed. The feasibility of this idea was verified through the model experiments. © 1994, The Institute of Electrical Engineers of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Shirai Y., Nitta T., Shibata T., Yajima S., Okada T.
Title: Voltage Ripple Reduction Control of Energy Transfer Circuit with Inductor Converter Bridges Between Superconducting Magnets
Affiliations: Kyoto University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shirai, Y., Kyoto University, Japan; Nitta, T., Kyoto University, Japan; Shibata, T., Kyoto University, Japan; Yajima, S., Kyoto University, Japan; Okada, T., Kyoto University, Japan
Abstract: Energy transfer circuits between two superconducting magnets have been proposed, discussed and tested. We have studied on power supplies for superconducting magnets which consists of a small power converter, a superconducting magnet for an energy storage, and an energy transfer circuit of inductor converter bridges (ICB). We derived analytical solutions on the basic characteristics of ICB energy transfer circuits. In this paper, from the analytical solutions, a new control method of ICB trasnsfer circuit to reduce voltage ripples across a load superconducting magnet is proposed and discussed. Availabilities of the proposed control method are confirmed by the computer simulations. © 1994, The Institute of Electrical Engineers of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Kryukov P.G.
Title: Coil study in Russia
Affiliations: P.N.Lebedev Physical Institute, Russia Academy of Sciences, Leninsky Pr. 53, Moscow, 117924, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kryukov, P.G., P.N.Lebedev Physical Institute, Russia Academy of Sciences, Leninsky Pr. 53, Moscow, 117924, Russian Federation
Abstract: An overview of works on COIL in Russia is given. They include the following problems: development and studies of sing1et oxygen generators, CW and pulsed COIL operation, second harmonic generation. Special emphasis is made on consideration of possible using of COIL as a pump source for solid-state lasers. It based on the fact that the second harmonic of the COIL radiation coincides with pump bands of some efficient. laser materials viz. Orystal-Is doped ions Cr3+. Hence one can create a hybrid laser of the COIL and the solid-state laser. It combines high, efficiency, specific energy storage, and self sufficiency of chemical pumping and excellent performances pecullar to solid-state laser, namely, temporal regime including CW and pulsed operation with pulse duration of μs (free running), ns (Q-switch), ps and fs (mode-looking and chirped pulse amplification), wavelength range from near IR up to uv (using harmonics generation) with tuning over rather wide spectrum regions, highly collimated beam resulting via single mode operation. Such hybrid laser can be considered as one of successful solutions of short-wavelength chemical laser problem. As an example of possible application of such pump source a proposal of the laser-driver for ICP research is presented. © 1994 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Chemical lasers; Chirp modulation; Harmonic analysis; Laser chemistry; Magnetohydrodynamics; Nonlinear optics; Optical pumping; Pulsed lasers; Pumping (laser); Q switching; Ultrashort pulses; Chirped pulse amplifications; Following problem; Harmonics generation; Oxygen generators; Pulsed operation; Short wavelengths; Single mode operation; Wavelength ranges; Solid state lasers

Authors: Czarnecki L.S.
Title: Comments on “apparent and reactive powers in three‐phase systems: in search of a physical meaning and a better resolution”
Authors with affiliations: Czarnecki, L.S.
Abstract: It is shown in this comment that it is not so obvious that the apparent power S “has a clear physical meaning “ as it is asserted in the paper “Apparent and Reactive Powers in Three‐Phase Systems: In Search of a Physical Meaning and a Better Resolution “ published by A. E. Emanuel in ETEP 3 (J993) no. I. Moreover, the author of the discussed paper misinterprets power properties of unbalanced systems. He asserts in Section 2 that, apart from the active power P, each power in systems with sinusoidal waveforms represents the amplitude of an oscillation of power. The apparent power S in unbalanced systems may be higher than the active power P, however, despite of the lack of any oscillation of instantaneous power, since the direction of energy flow may not change with the load unbalance. The unbalanced power of a resistive unbalanced load cannot occur as a consequence of power oscillation since such a load does not have any capability of energy storage. Copyright © 1994 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

Authors: El-Gassier M.M.
Title: Effect of Gas Kinetic Energy on Flow and Storage Capacity of Pipelines
Source title: Journal of The Japan Petroleum Institute
Affiliations: Petroleum Engineering Dept., College of Engineering, King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: El-Gassier, M.M., Petroleum Engineering Dept., College of Engineering, King Saud University, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: Equations of flow capacity and storage capacity of gas pipelines including the gas kinetic energy are presented. The influence of flow parameters on flow and storage capacities when the kinetic energy is included is discussed. For short pipelines, an overestimation of flow capacity and an underestimation of storage capacity occur when the kinetic energy is neglected. These errors increase with diameter and decrease with friction factor. © 1994, The Japan Petroleum Institute. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Flow capacity; Gas kinetic energy; Gas pipeline; Storage capacity

Authors: Schneider M.G., Bland T.J.
Title: Preliminary test results of reflux-cooled electromechanical actuator
Source title: AIAA/ASME 6th Joint Thermophysics and Heat Transfer Conference, 1994
Affiliations: Sundstrand Aerospace, 4747 Harrison Avenue, Rockford, IL  61125, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schneider, M.G., Sundstrand Aerospace, 4747 Harrison Avenue, Rockford, IL  61125, United States; Bland, T.J., Sundstrand Aerospace, 4747 Harrison Avenue, Rockford, IL  61125, United States
Abstract: A major goal of the U.S. Air Force More Electric Airplane (MEA) program is the replacement of hydromechanical actuators with electric actuators. Without the hydraulic fluid as an available heat sink, the thermal management of electrical actuators, especially the motor, becomes a critical issue. The challenge in integrating electromechanical actuators into an airframe and providing adequate cooling for ail mission segments is to provide a passive, lightweight and rugged heat transfer mechanism between the actuator motor and available heat sinks such as the aircraft structure or skin. The short duty cycles and transient nature of actuator heat loads makes the use of sensible and latent thermal energy storage attractive. A two-phase thermosyphon cooler coupled to a phase change material (PCM) was built to demonstrate a concept for cooling a 26 kW actuator motor. A 3M Corporation Fluorinert®*, FC-75, was used as the working fluid to transfer heat to the phase change material, acetamide. The PCM was contained in alternating layers of a plate-fin compact heat exchanger core. This structure provided both good thermal access to the PCM and a means to prevent its migration during liquid-solid cycles. It also provided the flow path for the vapor to rise to the condenser. For this demonstration, upper and lower oil cooled heat exchangers were available as the heat sinks for the thermosyphon condenser. The oil temperature and flow rate to these finned coolers could be controlled to simulate aircraft heat sinks. Sight glasses on the containment vessel allowed for the visualization of two-phase bubbly or slug flow when present in testing. The test article was mounted on a one-axis articulating fixture to enable testing in different attitudes. Preliminary transient test results are being used to validate the analytical thermal model. Future testing and data analysis will provide insights and guidelines for aircraft application. Key parameters in the preliminary tests are the condenser oil flow rate, the fluid fill level, the transient cycle period and the test article orientation. At the 50 percent power condition the peak motor temperature was within 50°C of the heat sink, showing good source to sink thermal coupling by the thermosyphon and conductive links. Testing shows that the PCM material provides additional useful thermal inertia during the melting process. Preliminary thermal time constants and other transient response characteristics are available from the test results. Heat load magnitude, heat load input profile, sink temperature, cooler orientation, and PCM mass will be parameters in future tests. Also, the motor will be mounted on a drive line for operation underloaded conditions. © 1994 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics. Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Aircraft; Aircraft manufacture; Airframes; Capillary flow; Cooling systems; Digital storage; Electric actuators; Electromechanical devices; Heat sinks; Heat storage; Heat transfer; Hydraulic actuators; Phase change materials; Siphons; Testing; Thermal load; Thermosyphons; Transient analysis; Aircraft applications; Compact heat exchanger; Electrical actuators; Heat transfer mechanism; Latent thermal energy storages; Thermal time constants; Transient response characteristics; Two-phase thermosyphon; Electromechanical actuators

Authors: Glaister D.S., Bell K.D., Bello M., Edelstein F.
Title: The development and testing of a cryogenic brilliant eyes thermal storage unit
Source title: AIAA/ASME 6th Joint Thermophysics and Heat Transfer Conference, 1994
Affiliations: The Aerospace Corporation, El Segundo, CA, United States; Grumman Aerospace Corporation, Bethpage, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Glaister, D.S., The Aerospace Corporation, El Segundo, CA, United States; Bell, K.D., The Aerospace Corporation, El Segundo, CA, United States; Bello, M., The Aerospace Corporation, El Segundo, CA, United States; Edelstein, F., Grumman Aerospace Corporation, Bethpage, NY, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a summary of the design, development, and ground verification of the BETSU (Brilliant Eyes Thermal Storage Unit) experiment. The BETSU utilizes 2-methyl pentane as a 120 K PCM (Phase Change Material) and will be flown on board the Shuttle in early 1994. There has been very limited experience with the space flight of cryogenic phase change materials. Space applications for a cryogenic TSU include the storage of energy for the cooling of temperature sensitive sensor components such as focal planes, optics, mirrors, and telescopes. Based on ground test data, trade studies were performed which show the significant weight and cost benefits of the BETSU technology. © 1994 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Cryogenics; Digital storage; Heat storage; Space applications; Space flight; Storage (materials); Cost benefits; Development and testing; Focal Plane; Ground tests; PCM (phase change material); Temperature sensitive; Thermal storage units; Trade-study; Phase change materials

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference, 1994
Abstract: The proceedings contain 329 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering. The topics include: Enhancing access to space; nasa's advanced space transportation program; the four rivers energy project in clean coal v; space science mission power requirements and issues; utility battery storage applications; a comparison of several alternative fuels for fuel-cell vehicle applications; operating experience with a 10 KW hermetic stirling engine; stirling machine operating experience ii; a solar heated amtec spacecraft power system; integration of the topaz 2 space nuclear reactor with the nepstp spacecraft; high power communication satellites power systems study; sodium modulated amtec electrode deposition; alternative transportation fuels from biomass; enhanced nanoscale catalyst precursor powders generated using a flowthrough hydrothermal process; technology providing global energy solutions; air force nickel hydrogen cell low earth orbit life test update; spacecraft electrical power system environmental control and protection; tests of effectiveness of thermionic heat pipe modules; role of polystyrene on the product composition of solid wastes during thermal destruction; a 3d compressible Euler solver for turbomachinery cascades; propulsion-motor options in battery-powered electric bicycles; the utility-scale joint-venture program; status of MCFC technology at m-c power 1994; update on ESA nickel-cadmium life test data and an integrated analysis of the kalina cycle in combined cycles.

Authors: Barazande-Pour M., Mark J.W.
Title: Adaptive MHDCT coding of images
Source title: Proceedings - International Conference on Image Processing, ICIP
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON  N2L 3G1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Barazande-Pour, M., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON  N2L 3G1, Canada; Mark, J.W., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON  N2L 3G1, Canada
Abstract: An adaptive coding scheme, based on a modification of the discrete cosine transformation, is used to encode image signals. The coding performance is compared with those of the DCT and the Walsh-Hadamard transform. The proposed coding scheme is simpler than the DCT, but its performance is quite close to that of the DCT. The adaptivity in our coder is achieved by using a suitable classification method and distributing the available channel capacity to different classes according to their energy level. © 1994 IEEE.

Authors: Pak C., McGuirk M.
Title: The use of computer aided design for the high energy transmission grating (HETG) spectrometer
Source title: AIAA Space Programs and Technologies Conference and Exhibit, 1994
Affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pak, C., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; McGuirk, M., Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Abstract: The HETG Spectrometer utilizes the AXAF High Resolution Mirror Assembly (HRMA) and the Advanced CCD Imaging System (ACIS) with a grating assembly (HETG) to provide resolution up to 1000 over the energy range 0.4 to 8.0 keV for astrophysical point sources. The HETG Spectrometer is also useful for some extended sources. HETG includes both Medium Energy and High Energy grating elements, each approximately one inch square, and tailored to optimize use of the HRMA effective area and the ACIS-S detector spatial resolution. The grating element support structure holds each of the 336 grating elements in a faceted approximation to a segment of a torus. The structure achieves 93% weight reduction from the solid, provides robust safety margins on design loads and minimizes the sensitivity to thermal loads. The structure also provides for convenient handling, contamination control during assembly and storage, and alignment references. The paper describes the role of CAD in the evolution of the design through several stages. © 1994, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Image resolution; Spectrometers; CCD imaging systems; Contamination control; Energy transmission; Extended sources; High resolution mirror assemblies; Spatial resolution; Support structures; Weight reduction; Computer aided design

Authors: Casacca M.A., Salameh Z.M., Capobianco M.R., Losch R.
Title: Optimum battery configuration for maximum utilization of photovoltaics
Source title: Progress in Photovoltaics: Research and Applications
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell, One University Avenue, Lowell, Massachusetts, 01854, United States; Solar Resources, 28 Burlington Avenue, Wilmington, Massachusetts, 01887, United States
Authors with affiliations: Casacca, M.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell, One University Avenue, Lowell, Massachusetts, 01854, United States; Salameh, Z.M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell, One University Avenue, Lowell, Massachusetts, 01854, United States; Capobianco, M.R., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell, One University Avenue, Lowell, Massachusetts, 01854, United States; Losch, R., Solar Resources, 28 Burlington Avenue, Wilmington, Massachusetts, 01887, United States
Abstract: Various photovoltaic (PV)‐powered battery storage configurations are analysed to determine if the percentage of available energy stored in the battery can be improved. Both deep‐cycle and shallow‐cycle lead‐acid batteries are considered. Computer simulation techniques are used to model the characteristics of the PV array, daily loads and environmental conditions. Three configurations were tested: one 60 ampere‐hour (Ah) battery, two 60 Ah batteries in parallel and two 60 Ah batteries that switch between the PV array and the load. Results show that the conventional PV‐powered configuration, where one battery is charged, wastes enormous amounts of energy by reaching a charged state while the PV array can still provide energy. A dual battery system enables the excess energy to be shunted into the battery under load while concurrently ensuring that one battery is constantly under charge until a full state of charge is achieved. Copyright © 1994 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

Authors: Kawakita Y., Ohsawa Y., Arai K.
Title: Power‐system stabilizing control by SMES using fuzzy techniques and neural networks
Affiliations: Kobe University, Kobe, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kawakita, Y., Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Ohsawa, Y., Kobe University, Kobe, Japan; Arai, K., Kobe University, Kobe, Japan
Abstract: It has been clarified that a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is very effective for power system stabilization. The control methods proposed for power system stabilization by SMES include the pole assignment, the optimum control, and so on, each of which, however, has its drawbacks. The application of fuzzy control is considered to overcome these drawbacks. This paper considers the power system stabilization by fuzzy control of the active and reactive power of SMES. First, the adequate fuzzy control rules of an SMES for the model power system is derived. Then, to alleviate the dependence of the fuzzy control on the operating condition and the fault, a method is proposed which adjusts the fuzzy parameter according to the operating condition and the fault using a neural network. The validity of the proposed method is examined by computer simulations. Copyright © 1994 Wiley Periodicals, Inc., A Wiley Company
Author Keywords: fuzzy control; neural network; Power system stabilization; power/reactive power control; SMES

Authors: Ogimoto K., Masuda T., Inabe H., Komukai T., Tsuruta S., Momotake T.
Title: Power oscillation damping by superconducting magnetic energy (SMES) storage unit
Affiliations: Electric Power Development Co, Japan; Toshiba Corporation, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ogimoto, K., Electric Power Development Co, Japan; Masuda, T., Electric Power Development Co, Japan; Inabe, H., Electric Power Development Co, Japan; Komukai, T., Toshiba Corporation, Japan; Tsuruta, S., Toshiba Corporation, Japan; Momotake, T., Toshiba Corporation, Japan
Abstract: With the increase in the size and capacity of electric power systems and the growth of widespread interconnections, the problem of power oscillations due to the reduced system damping has become increasingly serious. Since a Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) unit with a self‐commutated converter is capable of controlling both the active (P) and reactive (Q) power simultaneously and quickly, increasing attention has been focused recently on power system stabilization by SMES control. This paper describes the effects of SMES control on the damping of power oscillations. By examining the case of a single generator connected to an infinite bus through both theoretical analyses and experimental tests (performed with a SMES unit with maximum stored energy of 16 kJ and an artificial model system), the difference in the effects between P and Q control of SMES is clarified as follows: In the case of P control, as the SMES unit is placed closer to the terminal of the generator, the power oscillations will decay more rapidly. In the case of Q control, it is most effective to install the SMES unit near the midpoint of the system. By comparing the P control with Q control, the former is more effective than the latter based on the conditions that the SMES unit location and the control gain are the same. Copyright © 1994 Wiley Periodicals, Inc., A Wiley Company
Author Keywords: active power control; power oscillation; reactive power control; Superconducting energy storage system (SMES)

Authors: FOUCAT L., RENERRE M., GATELLIER P., ANTON M.
Title: 1H‐NMR study of bovine myoglobin autoxidation. Influence of muscle type and time post mortem
Source title: International Journal of Food Science & Technology
Affiliations: Station de Recherches sur la viande, Ceyrat, 63122, France
Authors with affiliations: FOUCAT, L., Station de Recherches sur la viande, Ceyrat, 63122, France; RENERRE, M., Station de Recherches sur la viande, Ceyrat, 63122, France; GATELLIER, P., Station de Recherches sur la viande, Ceyrat, 63122, France; ANTON, M., Station de Recherches sur la viande, Ceyrat, 63122, France
Abstract: 1H NMR spectroscopy was used to determine first order rate constants at four temperatures (300, 304, 308, 312 K) and activation energies of the autoxidation reaction for oxymyoglobin. the haeminic pigment was purified from two bovine muscles with different colour stabilities (psoas major (PM) and longissimus lumborum (LL)) at 2h (day 0) and 192 h (day 8) post mortem. to characterize this autoxidation reaction, we have focused attention on the time‐temperature dependent disappearance of the Val‐E11 methyl group signal. This study showed that, whatever the time post mortem, although the myoglobin autoxidation rate was greater for PM than for LL muscle, the activation energies were similar. It was also worth noting that, in the range 300–312 K, the average ratio of autoxidation rate constants between day 8 and day 0 was near 1.6 for the two muscles studied. It is reasonable to think that oxidative processes developed during 8 days meat storage have led to a structural change within the cavity of the heme pocket of the myoglobins. Moreover, only one orientation of the porphyrin within the heme pocket was noted for the two muscles studied. Copyright © 1994, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Activation energy; autoxidation rate constants; haem pocket; meat colour; met‐/oxy‐myoglobin; porphyrin orientation

Authors: Larson Donald.C., Weinberger C.B., Lawley A., Thomas D.H., Moore T.W.
Title: Fundamentals Of Engineering Energy
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Atmospheric Science; Department of Chemical Engineering Materials; Department of Materials Engineering; Department of Mechanical Engineering and Mechanics Systems; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Drexel University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Larson, Donald.C., Department of Physics and Atmospheric Science; Weinberger, C.B., Department of Chemical Engineering Materials; Lawley, A., Department of Materials Engineering; Thomas, D.H., Department of Mechanical Engineering and Mechanics Systems; Moore, T.W., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Drexel University, United States
Abstract: Three new Fundamentals of Engineering courses, entitled Energy, Materials and Systems are presented in the sophomore year of the Drexel University E4 program. The first focuses on the concept, manifestations, uses, conservation, storage, transformation, and transfer of energy. The second focuses on materials to establish, interpret and utilize the relationships that exist between processing/synthesis, microstructure, properties, and performance‐for metals, ceramics, polymers and composites. The third focuses on systems, capitalizing on the up‐front‐engineering theme of the E4 curriculum and the extensive use of computer methods to equip students with concepts and methods of analysis which are common to all branches of engineering. All courses integrate mathematics, science, and engineering as a central theme. The subject matter builds upon the freshman courses to prepare a common strong foundation in the fundamentals of engineering for all students regardless of major. Faculty from science and engineering collaborate in preparing and presenting these courses. This interdisciplinary communication, frequently lacking in the traditional program, is an important feature of the E4 program. Student performance in these and upper‐division courses indicates that the educational objectives are being achieved. Surveys of student opinions show a high degree of interest in the subject matter and satisfaction with the methodologies adopted. 1994 American Society for Engineering Education

Authors: HOLMSTRÖM M., FREDRICSON I., DREVEMO S.
Title: Biokinematic differences between riding horses judged as good and poor at the trot
Affiliations: The Swedish National Stud, Flyinge, S-240 32, Sweden; Swedish University of Agricultural Science, Uppsala, S-750 07, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: HOLMSTRÖM, M., The Swedish National Stud, Flyinge, S-240 32, Sweden; FREDRICSON, I., The Swedish National Stud, Flyinge, S-240 32, Sweden; DREVEMO, S., Swedish University of Agricultural Science, Uppsala, S-750 07, Sweden
Abstract: The trotting gait of 4 approved Swedish Warmblood stallions with a mean gait score ≥8.67 (maximum score = 10) at official performance tests and 4 horses with poor gaits (mean gait score ≤6.5) was recorded by high speed film (250 frames/s). Angular patterns and hoof trajectories of the left fore and hind limbs were analysed and presented as mean and standard deviation curves. The good horses had longer stride duration (p<0.001) and larger positive diagonal advanced placement (p<0.01). The swing phase retraction in the forelimbs was longer in the good horses. The most important differences in the forelimb angular patterns were found in the elbow and carpal joint angles. They were considerably more flexed in the good horses at the beginning of the swing phase retraction. Larger decrease of the pelvis inclination, increase of the femur inclination and larger flexion of the hock and hind fetlock joints during the stance phase were correlated with high trot scores. This indicates that storage of elastic strain energy during the stance phase may be important for the elasticity, energy and propulsion in trot. © 1994 EVJ Ltd
Author Keywords: biokinematics; gait analysis; horse; trot

Authors: Woods J.L., Favier J.F., Briggs D.E.
Title: PREDICTING THE GERMINATIVE ENERGY OF DORMANT MALTING BARLEY DURING STORAGE
Source title: Journal of the Institute of Brewing
Affiliations: Department of Agricultural and Environmental Science, Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, NE1 7RU, United Kingdom; School of Biochemistry, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, B15 2TT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Woods, J.L., Department of Agricultural and Environmental Science, Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, NE1 7RU, United Kingdom; Favier, J.F., Department of Agricultural and Environmental Science, Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, NE1 7RU, United Kingdom; Briggs, D.E., School of Biochemistry, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, B15 2TT, United Kingdom
Abstract: The management of dormant barley stocks for malting requires a method of predicting germinative energy under given conditions during storage. A method of quantifying the relationship between storage temperature and the dormancy period is developed based on probit analysis. The experimental data were obtained using Triumph barley. The conditions covered in the experimental work were 8°C to 38°C storage temperature at 12% moisture content, wet basis. Combined use of the dormancy model with an existing viability model allows the prediction of germinative energy as a function of storage temperature and moisture content given the initial germinative energy and capacity values. The effects of storage temperature on the variation in germination over time of dormant bariey samples with various initial germinative capacities, and storage moisture contents are investigated using the model. The results indicate that storage at moisture contents below 12% give significant increases in the germination level that can be achieved. 1994 The Institute of Brewing & Distilling
Author Keywords: computer simulation; dormancy; Malting barley; modelling; moisture content; storage temperature; viability

Authors: SANCHEZ‐PINEDA‐INFANTAS M.T., CANO‐MUÑOZ G., HERMIDA‐BUN J.R.
Title: Blanching, Freezing and Frozen Storage Influence Texture of White Asparagus
Affiliations: Dept. of Food Science & Technology (Bromatología y Tecnología de Alimentos), Universidad de Córdoba, Córdoba, Spain
Authors with affiliations: SANCHEZ‐PINEDA‐INFANTAS, M.T., Dept. of Food Science & Technology (Bromatología y Tecnología de Alimentos), Universidad de Córdoba, Córdoba, Spain; CANO‐MUÑOZ, G., Dept. of Food Science & Technology (Bromatología y Tecnología de Alimentos), Universidad de Córdoba, Córdoba, Spain; HERMIDA‐BUN, J.R., Dept. of Food Science & Technology (Bromatología y Tecnología de Alimentos), Universidad de Córdoba, Córdoba, Spain
Abstract: We studied effects of three methods of blanching in conjunction with freezing, on texture of white asparagus as defined by three measures: maximum shear force, cutting energy, and total fiber content. We also assessed shelf life of asparagus kept in frozen storage at ‐22°C. Methods of blanching were total immersion in hot water, progressive immersion in hot water and steam. An increase in total fiber content was found throughout frozen storage. This increase correlated with lignification of vascular bundles in the basal segment of spears, even during frozen storage. This was reflected in an increase in maximum shear force and cutting energy required. The shelf life of frozen asparagus was 12 mo using total fiber content as a criterion. Copyright © 1994, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: asparagus; blanching; freezing; storage; texture

Authors: YOON S.H., LEE C.H., KIM D.Y., KIM J.W., PARK K.H.
Title: Time‐Temperature Indicator using Phospholipid‐Phospholipase System and Application to Storage of Frozen Pork
Affiliations: Dept. of Food Science & Technology and Research Center for New Bio-Materials in Agriculture, College of Agriculture & Life Sciences, Seoul National Univ, Suwon, 441-744, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: YOON, S.H., Dept. of Food Science & Technology and Research Center for New Bio-Materials in Agriculture, College of Agriculture & Life Sciences, Seoul National Univ, Suwon, 441-744, South Korea; LEE, C.H., Dept. of Food Science & Technology and Research Center for New Bio-Materials in Agriculture, College of Agriculture & Life Sciences, Seoul National Univ, Suwon, 441-744, South Korea; KIM, D.Y., Dept. of Food Science & Technology and Research Center for New Bio-Materials in Agriculture, College of Agriculture & Life Sciences, Seoul National Univ, Suwon, 441-744, South Korea; KIM, J.W., Dept. of Food Science & Technology and Research Center for New Bio-Materials in Agriculture, College of Agriculture & Life Sciences, Seoul National Univ, Suwon, 441-744, South Korea; PARK, K.H., Dept. of Food Science & Technology and Research Center for New Bio-Materials in Agriculture, College of Agriculture & Life Sciences, Seoul National Univ, Suwon, 441-744, South Korea
Abstract: A novel time‐temperature indicator (TTI) using phospholipid‐phospholipase was developed to monitor quality change of frozen foods during storage. The ITI was more reliable than the lipase system and monitored quality changes of frozen pork during storage. The TTI was designed for reactions at sub‐zero temperatures because the substrate emulsion would be stable at such temperatures. The TTI contained glycerol and sorbitol as anti‐freeze reagents and was designed to show distinctive color changes according to pH by mixing bromothymol blue, neutral red, and methyl red. The TTI had an activation energy of 32.12 kcal/mol, suitable for many food reactions. Copyright © 1994, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: phospholipase; phospholipid; pork; time‐temperature indicator

Authors: ARVANITOYANNIS I., BLANSHARD J.M.V.
Title: Rates of Crystallization of Dried Lactose‐sucrose Mixtures
Affiliations: Government Industrial Research Institute Osaka, Functional Polymer Section, Midorigaoka 1-8-31, Nottingham, Osaka, 563, Japan; Dept Food Science, Univ. of Nottingham, Sutton Bonington Campus, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: ARVANITOYANNIS, I., Government Industrial Research Institute Osaka, Functional Polymer Section, Midorigaoka 1-8-31, Nottingham, Osaka, 563, Japan, Dept Food Science, Univ. of Nottingham, Sutton Bonington Campus, United Kingdom; BLANSHARD, J.M.V., Government Industrial Research Institute Osaka, Functional Polymer Section, Midorigaoka 1-8-31, Nottingham, Osaka, 563, Japan, Dept Food Science, Univ. of Nottingham, Sutton Bonington Campus, United Kingdom
Abstract: The isothermal crystallization kinetics of glassy lactose/sucrose mixtures were studied at several storage temperatures (close to Tg and Tm). The kinetic parameters implicit in the Avrami equation were determined. Activation energies for transport (ED) and surface nucleation (W*) were also found and correlated to the molar composition of the lactose/sucrose mixtures. A monotonic increase in the half crystallization time (t1/z), Avrami index (n), % crystallization per day, activation energy for transport (ED) and surface nucleation energy (W*) and a decrease in the crystallization velocity constants (K) were related to the increase in the lactose content of lactose/sucrose mixtures. Copyright © 1994, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: crystallization kinetics; DSC; lactose; sucrose; thermal analysis

Authors: King S.D., Yuen D.A.
Title: Computing in the geosciences kindles interdisciplinary discussion
Affiliations: Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, United States; University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States
Authors with affiliations: King, S.D., Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, United States; Yuen, D.A., University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States
Abstract: Researchers from different backgrounds met to share information about large‐scale numerical simulations in mantle convection, algorithmic developments, scientific visualization, data‐processing, and seismic wave propagation at a special session devoted to high‐performance computing in geosciences at the 1994 AGU Spring Meeting. The session sparked discussions between diverse segments of the community and is very timely in view of the high‐performance computing activities recently sponsored by the National Science Foundation, Department of Energy, and NASA. As S. Balachandar pointed out, there are three main issues for high‐performance computing: efficient and accurate computations, data compression and storage, and interpretation and post‐processing of large data sets. The first issue naturally comes to mind when the phrase “high‐performance computing” is heard, but data compression and postprocessing present equally important challenges. Storing output from a three‐dimensional computation that has 256 nodes along each side with four variables at each node—be it for mantle convection, ocean or atmospheric circulation, or seismic wave modeling—for 5000 time steps requires 2.6 Terrabytes of storage. While computers and algorithms to consider such a grid may exist, storing the results of such a computation are not feasible given the current networking and disk storage infrastructure. ©1994. American Geophysical Union. All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Winwood R., Benstead R., Edwards R., Letherman K.M.
Title: Building fabric thermal storage: Use of computational fluid dynamics for modelling
Affiliations: E A Technology, Capenhurst, Chester CH1 6ES, United Kingdom; University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, PO Box 88, Manchester M60 1QD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Winwood, R., E A Technology, Capenhurst, Chester CH1 6ES, United Kingdom, University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, PO Box 88, Manchester M60 1QD, United Kingdom; Benstead, R., E A Technology, Capenhurst, Chester CH1 6ES, United Kingdom; Edwards, R., University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, PO Box 88, Manchester M60 1QD, United Kingdom; Letherman, K.M., University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, PO Box 88, Manchester M60 1QD, United Kingdom
Abstract: The paper describes work towards the construction and validation of an accurate and detailed computer model of a commercially available thermal storage system. The model is constructed with the aid of a computational fluid dynamics package, using a minimum of fitted data. The paper also includes a discussion of the reasons for current interest in fabric energy storage (FES), the mechanisms by which it may operate and summaries of operational experience with FES buildings and current research in this field. Some preliminary results from the computer model are presented and the plans for future work are outlined. © 1994, Sage Publications. All rights reserved.

Authors: Strand T.C., Werlich H.
Title: Aberration limits for annular Gaussian beams for optical storage
Affiliations: IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, CA, 95120-6099, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strand, T.C., IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, CA, 95120-6099, United States; Werlich, H., IBM Research Division, Almaden Research Center, 650 Harry Road, San Jose, CA, 95120-6099, United States
Abstract: Annularly apodized beams have been suggested for use in optical storage because of their potential to go beyond the conventional spot size and depth-of-focus limits. One concern for such applications is the effects of small aberrations on beams in which the energy is concentrated in a small annular ring. We present calculations and experimental results that show that annular apodization of a Gaussian beam reduces the sensitivity to defocus as well as balanced spherical and coma aberrations. The sensitivity to astigmatism is increased by a small amount. © 1994 Optical Society of America.
Author Keywords: Aberrations; Annular apertures; Gaussian beams; Optical storage; Superresolution

Authors: MacCormac R., Popper M.
Title: The ruskin library: Architecture and environment for the storage, display and study of a collection
Affiliations: CBE, MA(Cantab), PPRIBA, 9 Heneage Street, London, E1 5LJ, United Kingdom; Rasehill Cottage, Chorleywood Road, Rickmansworth, Hertfordshire, WD3 4EW, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: MacCormac, R., CBE, MA(Cantab), PPRIBA, 9 Heneage Street, London, E1 5LJ, United Kingdom; Popper, M., Rasehill Cottage, Chorleywood Road, Rickmansworth, Hertfordshire, WD3 4EW, United Kingdom
Abstract: A building to house the John Ruskin Collection has been commissioned by Lancaster University, England, with spaces for the storage of the collection, galleries and reading room. The proposals for environmental control will minimize the use of air-conditioning by using the thermal mass of the structure and by the creation of buffer zones. Analysis of thermal performance and stability of conditions will be carried out by computer modelling. The proposals are intended to create a low-energy building with simple services where a collection may be preserved in optimum conditions at minimum capital plant expenditure and operating cost. © 1994, Maney Publishing.

Authors: Baudinette R.V.
Title: Locomotion in macropodoid marsupials: Gaits, energetics and heat balance
Affiliations: School of Biological Sciences, Flinders University, Box 2100, GPO Adelaide, 5001, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Baudinette, R.V., School of Biological Sciences, Flinders University, Box 2100, GPO Adelaide, 5001, Australia
Abstract: This review examines gaits used by marsupials and their coupling with respiratory and cardiac cycles. It also examines the energy requirements and heat balance in exercising marsupials. Marsupials have mass.specific metabolic rates that lie at the lower end of the mammalian range but this is not reflected in locomotory energetics as quadrupedal marsupials fit the predictive model derived from placentals. The group that does not conform to the model contains the larger hopping macropods in which an independence between metabolic rate and hopping speed is achieved on treadmills at most speeds by the storage of elastic strain energy in tendons. This yields a saving of up to 50% of the energy that would be otherwise used for locomotion. The carriage of pouch young appears to reduce the maximum running speed in quadrupedal marsupials but may be cost.neutral in hopping species. Respiration is entrained to the step cycle in wallabies by means of a visceral piston, but no entrainment of the cardiac cycle has been observed. The consequences of these phenomena are discussed. Marsupials appear to exploit their low body temperatures as a means of storing heat generated during running. Paradoxically, this does not lessen their dependence on evaporative heat loss. © 1994 CSIRO.

Authors: Dyila H.F.
Title: Development of ultrahigh vacuum technology for particle accelerators and magnetic fusion devices
Source title: Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology A: Vacuum, Surfaces and Films
Affiliations: Continuous Electron Beam Accelerator Facility, Newport News, Department of Physics, College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Virginia, 23185, Virginia, 23606, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dyila, H.F., Continuous Electron Beam Accelerator Facility, Newport News, Department of Physics, College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Virginia, 23185, Virginia, 23606, United States
Abstract: The development of ultrahigh vacuum technology for high-energy particle accelerators and magnetic fusion devices provided essential contributions to the progress in these two scientific endeavors over the last four decades. Storage rings were first proposed as an efficient means of producing intense high-energy particle beams by G. K. O'Neill in 1956. The milestone demonstrations of the importance of this invention came with the operation of the ISR device at CERN in 1971, a 2 km long vacuum vessel which operated at 10–12 Torr and the SPEAR electron-positron collider at Stanford in 1972. These achievements required development of new materials, materials processing techniques, vacuum components, and vacuum instrumentation. UHV development continues through the present design efforts for the 27 km LHC ring at CERN, and numerous high intensity synchrotron light sources worldwide. A similar progression in UHV development preceded the operation of the present generation of large tokamaks built to demonstrate the scientific feasibility of magnetic fusion energy: The JET device in Europe (U.K.), the JT-60 in Japan, and TFTR at Princeton. Development efforts in UHV compatible first-wall materials, efficient vessel conditioning procedures, and high capacity pumps are essential for the operation of these devices and continue to be active areas of research for the next generation of fusion demonstration devices. © 1994, American Vacuum Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Van Wyk J.H.
Title: Fat body and liver cycles in the large girdled lizard, Cordylus giganteus
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, University of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch 7600, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Van Wyk, J.H., Department of Zoology, University of Stellenbosch, Stellenbosch 7600, South Africa
Abstract: Cordylus giganteus is a large viviparous lizard endemic to the Highveld grasslands of South Africa. Seasonal morphometric changes in fat body mass, liver mass and a carcass condition index in male, female and juvenile C. giganteus are described for a 15 month period. In the adult male and juvenile classes, abdominal fat bodies increase during late summer and autumn followed by a dramatic depletion during winter hibernation. Although that fat body cycles of adult reproducing females are similar to those of males, the magnitude of lipid storage in these females was considerably greater. Adult females showing early vitellogenic activity and significantly larger fat bodies than non-reproductive females. Seasonal liver mass changes paralleled the fat body cycles in all classes. Fat body stores appear to be used by all classes for winter and early spring nutrition. Energy needs during winter vitellogenesis in females and mating activity during spring in males may also benefit from fat body and liver energy stores. The hypothesis that biennial reproduction in females is determined by the magnitude of energy reserves at the onset of vitellogenesis in autumn is upheld. © 1994, Brill. All rights reserved.

Authors: Salbert H., Jungst K.P.
Title: Generation of high power pulses using a SMES
Source title: Conference Record of the 1994 21st International Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1994
Affiliations: Kernforschungszertrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Institut fur Technische Physik, Karlsmhe, D- 76021, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Salbert, H., Kernforschungszertrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Institut fur Technische Physik, Karlsmhe, D- 76021, Germany; Jungst, K.P., Kernforschungszertrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Institut fur Technische Physik, Karlsmhe, D- 76021, Germany
Abstract: A model of a power modulator for linear accelerators that uses a SMES ( Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage ) is being developed. It will generate 2 ms long, 3 kV / 300 A power pulses with a repetition rate of 10 Hz. For this device a fast IGBT-power-switch and a SMES are under development. The IGBT-power-switch consists of IGBT in parallel and in serial connection. The SMES is designed for ramping operations of more than 30 T/s. © 1994 IEEE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBT); Magnetic storage; Pulse repetition rate; Superconducting magnets; High-power pulse; Power modulators; Power pulse; Power switches; Repetition rate; Serial connection; SMES (superconducting magnetic energy storage); Electric energy storage

Authors: Battiti R., Lee P., Sartori A., Tecchiolli G.
Title: TOTEM: A digital processor for neural networks and Reactive Tabu Search
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Microelectronics for Neural Networks and Fuzzy Systems, ICMNN 1994
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Matematica, Università di Trento, Trento, 1-38050, Italy; Electronic Engineering Department, University of Kent, Canterbury, CT2 7NQ, United Kingdom; Ist. Ricerca Scientifica e Tecnologica IRST, Trento, 1-38050, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Battiti, R., Dipartimento di Matematica, Università di Trento, Trento, 1-38050, Italy; Lee, P., Electronic Engineering Department, University of Kent, Canterbury, CT2 7NQ, United Kingdom; Sartori, A., Ist. Ricerca Scientifica e Tecnologica IRST, Trento, 1-38050, Italy; Tecchiolli, G., Ist. Ricerca Scientifica e Tecnologica IRST, Trento, 1-38050, Italy
Abstract: The Reactive Tabu Search (RTS) algorithm permits the training of neural networks with low number of bits per weight, low computational accuracy, no local minima «trapping», and limited sensitivity to the initial conditions. Two architectures for the implementation of multilayer perceptrons based directly on the properties of RTS are presented. They are characterized by high-speed integer computation, tunable precision, I/O balanced design, internal storage of the weights and compact processing units. TOTEM, a silicon implementation which uses only 8 bits per weight and 16 bits per input, is then presented. A triggering problem in high energy physics is used as a test-bed for the algorithm and the processor. The expected performance is briefly compared with those of two alternative processors. © 1994 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Fuzzy inference; Fuzzy logic; Fuzzy systems; High energy physics; Microelectronics; Tabu search; Compact processing; Computational accuracy; Digital processors; Initial conditions; Internal storage; Limited sensitivity; Reactive Tabu search; Silicon implementation; Fuzzy neural networks

Authors: Dhandapani S., Ogot M.M.
Title: Modeling of a leg system to illustrate the feasibility of energy recovery in walking machines
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Design Engineering Technical Conference
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, Piscataway, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dhandapani, S., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, Piscataway, NJ, United States; Ogot, M.M., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey, Piscataway, NJ, United States
Abstract: A key consideration in the design of walking machines is the minimization of energy consumption. Two main avenues of research have been pursued in the past (a) finding an optimal gait which reduces energy consumption or (b) the employment of energy storage devices to recover energy from one step to the next. This study follows the latter approach, which has hitherto concentrated on hopping machines. Several practical design considerations for energy recovery in multi-legged walking machines, where a stance phase prevents the immediate recovery of energy from one step to the next, are investigated. Two schemes, passive and active locking, are introduced. The simplified models presented serve to illustrate the feasibility of these schemes. © 1994 American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME). All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Computer aided design; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Design considerations; Energy recovery; Immediate Recovery; Leg system; Optimal gaits; Walking machines; Recovery

Authors: Rodger A., Divakarla S.
Title: An integrated approach to an energy efficient house
Affiliations: University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, 3052, Australia; Department of Architecture and Building, University of Melbourne, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Rodger, A., University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, 3052, Australia; Divakarla, S., Department of Architecture and Building, University of Melbourne, Australia
Abstract: An energy efficient house has been built in Tasmania. It uses nearly 80% less conventional energy than an average house in the region. The intention of the designer was to demonstrate that if such a house could operate successfully in the coldest state of Australia, similar or even better results could be achieved in other temperate regions of the country. Active solar heating in combination with a heavily insulated light weight building envelope is the main feature of this integrated designfor energy efficiency. The house, simple in construction, has been designed to operate effectively, a) without heat storage, while maintaining thermally comfortable indoor conditions and b) with heat (rock) storage and solar preheating of water in future, which will further reduce conventional energy use. Particularly evident in the design is the direct problem solving approach and innovative use of presently available technology. © 1994 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Conservation; Energy efficiency; Insulation; Solar heating; Tasmania

Authors: Chen J.P., Kiaei D., Hoffman A.S.
Title: Activity of horseradish peroxide adsorbed on radio frequency glow discharge-treated polymers
Source title: Journal of Biomaterials Science, Polymer Edition
Affiliations: Center for Bioengineering, FL-20, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, 98195, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, J.P., Center for Bioengineering, FL-20, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, 98195, United States; Kiaei, D., Center for Bioengineering, FL-20, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, 98195, United States; Hoffman, A.S., Center for Bioengineering, FL-20, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, 98195, United States
Abstract: Horseradish peroxidase (HRP) has been used as a model enzyme in this study of its physical adsorption and residual enzyme activity on radio frequency glow discharge (RFGD)-treated polymers. The specific enzymatic activity of HRP adsorbed on different surfaces was assumed to be an indication of the extent of its conformational alterations on the surfaces. The surfaces studied were poly (ethylene terephthalate) (PET), polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), and tetrachloroethylene and tetrafluoroethylene glow discharge-treated PET, abbreviated as TCE/PET and TFE/PET. All surfaces were characterized by electron spectroscopy for chemical analysis (ESCA) and liquid contact angles in air. HRP adsorbs more strongly onto the two discharge-treated surfaces than onto the untreated polymers, as evidenced by the lower amount of HRP eluted by sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) from the treated polymers. For example, seventy percent of the HRP adsorbed on TCE/PET or TFE/PET remains on the surface after overnight elution with a 1% solution of SDS. In contrast, untreated PET and PTFE each retains only c. 20% of the absorbed enzyme. The enzymatic activity of HRP adsorbed on the different surfaces was studied using hydrogen peroxide (H202) as the substrate. HRP adsorbed on the higher energy surfaces, PET and TCE/PET, retains significantly more activity than the HRP adsorbed on the lower energy surfaces, PTFE and TFE/PET which appear to destroy rapidly almost all of the activity of HRP after it adsorbs. HRP adsorbed on TCE/PET is relatively more stable over time than HRP adsorbed on PET or free HRP in solution. (For example, only 45% of the specific enzymatic activity of HRP adsorbed on TCE/PET was lost after 3 h of storage in phosphate buffer at 37°C, while 70% of that adsorbed on PET was lost.) In summary, when HRP is adsorbed on TCE/PET, it is very tightly bound, and yet it maintains a significant fraction of its initial specific activity and also retains this activity for 3 h in phosphate buffer at 37°C. Thus, tenacious physical adsorption of proteins such as enzymes on TCE glow discharge-treated surfaces may have potential as a new method of immobilization of such molecules, for uses in biosensors, diagnostics, bioseparations, cell culture and bioreactors. © Taylor & Francis Ltd.
Author Keywords: Adsorbed proteins; Enzyme immobilization; Horseradish peroxidase; Radio frequency glow discharge; Surface modification

Authors: Seweryn A., Licznerski B.W.
Title: The anomalous properties of conduction activation energy near the percolation threshold of discontinuous gold films
Affiliations: Institute of Electron Technology, Technical University of Wroclaw, Wybrzeże Wyspianśkiego 27, Wroclaw, 50-370, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Seweryn, A., Institute of Electron Technology, Technical University of Wroclaw, Wybrzeże Wyspianśkiego 27, Wroclaw, 50-370, Poland; Licznerski, B.W., Institute of Electron Technology, Technical University of Wroclaw, Wybrzeże Wyspianśkiego 27, Wroclaw, 50-370, Poland
Abstract: Experimental results concerning the dependence on the storage conditions and temperature of the resistance and conduction activation energy of discontinuous gold films in the vicinity of the percolation threshold are reported. The ultra-thin gold films (1·15 nm) were deposited onto n-type silicon substrates by vacuum evaporation. The silicon substrates were heated from 100°C to 200°C. After evaporation, the samples were stored at 20, 100 and 200°C. In the range from 70 K to 400 K, only one value of conduction activation energy (Ea) has been measured. The relation Ea (d) obeys a percolation-like power law. The anomalous properties of the activation energies of samples stored under various temperature conditions are discussed. © 1994 Taylor and Francis Ltd.

Authors: Friedlmeier G., Wierse M., Groll M.
Title: Titanium Hydride for High-Temperature Thermal Energy Storage in Solar-Thermal Power Stations
Affiliations: Institut für Kerntechnik, Energiewandlung e.V. (IKE e.V.), Pfaffenwaldring 31, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Friedlmeier, G., Institut für Kerntechnik, Energiewandlung e.V. (IKE e.V.), Pfaffenwaldring 31, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany; Wierse, M., Institut für Kerntechnik, Energiewandlung e.V. (IKE e.V.), Pfaffenwaldring 31, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany; Groll, M., Institut für Kerntechnik, Energiewandlung e.V. (IKE e.V.), Pfaffenwaldring 31, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: Titanium forms relatively stable hydrides (TiH2 and TiH) that allow for high operating temperatures (650–750°C) at low pressures (0.1–1 MPa). These conditions are advantageous for thermal energy storage applications where high working temperatures are required. Under practical conditions, up to about 1.05 wt.% of hydrogen can be reversibly absorbed by titanium, which means an energy storage capacity of nearly 0.9 MJ/kg Ti. The possibility of using titanium hydride to improve the efficiency of solar-thermal power stations is investigated. Presently a small-scale solar power station employing a nickel-doped magnesium hydride short-term thermal energy store is being developed. The operating temperature of this material is limited to less than 500°C, at which high working pressures of up to 10 MPa must be withstood. The hydriding and dehydriding behavior of titanium powder between 650 and 730°C. has been investigated; experimental results are presented. Calculated data for solar power systems with a titanium hydride store and a magnesium hydride store are compared. © by R. Oldenbourg Verlag
Author Keywords: Mg hydride; Solar-thermal power station; Thermal energy storage; Ti hydride

Authors: Morrison A., Mehta B., Lyons J.W., Gnaedig G.
Title: Technical and economic evaluation of nominal 280 MW compressed air energy storage plant in salt dome
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo

Abstract: This paper summarizes the results of the technical and economic data of nominal 280 MW Compressed Air Energy Storage Plants (CAES) using caverns in salt domes located in southeastern parts of Mississippi for intermediate duty generation of LOCO hours per year and peaking duty generation of 750 hours per year. The plants are assumed to operate 90% time on Natural Gas and 10% of the time on No. 2 distillate. A weekly cycle of 10 hours of generation and 12 hours of charging daily with 15 hours of weekend charging was the basis for the study. The study includes conceptual layout, optimization, detailed cost analyses, reliability and operation and maintenance of the Compressed Air Energy storage plant. The objective of the study is low capital cost of the CAES plant and optimum performance. © 1994 by ASME.

Authors: Ebeling J., Balsbaugh R., Blanchard S., Beaty L.
Title: Thermal energy storage and inlet air cooling for combined cycle
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME Turbo Expo

Abstract: The paper will discuss the application of Thermal Energy Storage (TES) using ice and inlet air cooling at the Fayetteville (North Carolina, USA) Public Works Commission (PWC) Butler-Warner Generation Plant. The Butler-Warner Generating Plant consists of eight General Electric Frame 5 combustion turbines and a single steam turbine. Six of the combustion turbines exhaust through three Heat Recovery Steam Generators (FIRSG). The project consisted of modifying the inlets of all eight combustion turbines to accommodate plate fm cooling coils and new air filters; and the design and construction of the TES ice production and storage facilities. A feasibility study was completed in June 1992. Detail designed began in August 1992. Initial operation was June 1993. The modifications have been completed and the plant has experienced a 29% capacity increase as a result of the project. © 1994 by ASME.

Abstract: This article describes results of thermally stimulated current (TSC) measurements of XLPE, HDPE and PVC samples, which are used as insulating materials in medium voltage cables used in electrical energy distribution. Systematic investigations have been made in order to correlate physical parameters of charge storage with the breakdown phenomena observed in voltage tracking resistance tests (VTR). Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were also performed in order to verify if some of the TSC peaks arise from relaxation processes associated with eventual morphological and/or structural modifications. A correlation is shown between material conductivity and voltage tracking resistance. © 1994 IEEE.
