Authors: Fitzgerald A.M.
Title: Impact of energy storage system mass on the performance of orbit transfer vehicles using solar elecixic propulsion
Affiliations: Orbital Sciences Corporation, Chandler, AZ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fitzgerald, A.M., Orbital Sciences Corporation, Chandler, AZ, United States
Abstract: A solar powered, electrically propelled transfer vehicle moving payloads between low earth orbit and geosynchronous orbit will be frequently shadowed by Earth. Without an energy storage system, the vehicle would not be able to power its thrusters during eclipse, which would increase the trip time to GEO. The addition of an energy storage system to provide continuous thrust, however, would substantially increase the specific mass of the power plant, also with the result of increasing the trip time. To examine the tradeoffs of using an energy storage system, the mass penalty factor, defined as the ratio between the specific masses of a continuous thrust versus an intermittent thrust vehicle, is introduced. The delivery rate. defined as the ratio of payload fraction to trip time, is used as a measure of vehicle performance. It will be shown that with presently available battery technology, an energy storage system to provide thruster power during eclipse would not be a proximal addition to a solar powered, electrically propelled orbit transfer vehicle. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Altamush Siddiqui M.
Title: Heat and fluid flow studies in the absorber tubes of a thermosyphonic solar water heater
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh, 202 002, India
Authors with affiliations: Altamush Siddiqui, M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Aligarh Muslim University, Aligarh, 202 002, India
Abstract: Heat transfer and fluid flow studies in the absorber tubes of a thermosyphonic Solar Water Heater has been carried out for the experimental data obtained on some days in the months of January, February, March, April and May. The observations were made, keeping the solar collector facing south at 45° from the horizontal, for no withdrawal and withdrawal rates equal to 50 and 60 1/h of hot water from the storage tank for use. The average heat transfer coefficients and the thermally induced flow rates of water in the various tubes mounted on the collector absorber plate have been estimated. Subsequently Nusselt, Reynolds, Grashof and Prandtl numbers were also calculated. The Nusselt and Reynolds numbers, presented against a new dimensionless parameter: Si = S/U1 (Tp -Ta), show a remarkable characteristic. Also, grouping of the various dimensionless numbers in a particular form shows that the system obeys well known behaviour of the natural circulation loops. The collector efficiency data and the collector flow factors verses capacitance rates follow standard trends given in literature. The collector efficiency and flow factors were made bases for the purpose of data analysis. © 1994 by M. Altamush Siddiqui.

Authors: Biryukov S.V., Martin G., Polevoi V.G., Weihnacht M.
Title: Derivation of COM equations for the SAW IDT
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Ultrasonics Symposium
Affiliations: Mints Radiotechnical Inst RAS, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Biryukov, S.V., Mints Radiotechnical Inst RAS, Moscow, Russian Federation; Martin, G., Mints Radiotechnical Inst RAS, Moscow, Russian Federation; Polevoi, V.G., Mints Radiotechnical Inst RAS, Moscow, Russian Federation; Weihnacht, M., Mints Radiotechnical Inst RAS, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The general approach for the consistent derivation of coupling-of-modes (COM) equations for IDT with electrodes of finite thickness is proposed. This approach is based on the surface impedance method and the exact analytic solution of electrostatic problem in the presence of an arbitrary external electric field. At first the scalar self-consistent equation for the electric potential of acoustic waves in the arbitrary gratings of electrodes is obtained. For the periodic structure this equation is reduced to the form of COM equations for slowly varying amplitudes. These equations include naturally the NSPUDT effect description. The dissipation and storage energy terms may be introduced empirically. The solution of the COM equations is represented in the form of P matrix with elements written in a convenient form. The relations among the elements of P matrix are found. A simple formula for calculating the location of maximum transducer frequency response is proposed.

Authors: Wicks F.
Title: Nuclear waste: An international problem and evaluating the antarctic continent as a disposal site
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, Union College, Steinmetz Hall, Schenectady, NY  12308, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wicks, F., Mechanical Engineering Department, Union College, Steinmetz Hall, Schenectady, NY  12308, United States
Abstract: The future of nuclear power as an energy source is now threatened by the inability to develop acceptable nuclear waste management options. Concurrently, the end of the cold war is resulting in dismantling of thousands of nuclear weapons in the United States and the former Soviet Union and an estimated 40, 000 pits of highly enriched uranium and plutonium must be either converted for use in electric power reactors, or continuously guarded, or safely disposed. The purpose of this paper is to suggest that the time has come to reconsider the entire nuclear fuel and material cycles for both the electric power and weapons programs, and further to re-define nuclear waste as a global environmental problem that should be handled by an international agency with responsibility to collect this waste and dispose at a single repository. The best of the bad options may be disposal in the ice of the inland Antarctic Continent. A preliminary identification of existing treaties and potential sites is presented, along with recommendations for further research. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Abstract: High temperature superconductors (HTS) coupled with permanent magnets have been utilized to construct low energy-loss hybrid superconducting magnetic bearings for flywheel energy storage (FES) system applications. The hybrid HTS magnetic bearings use permanent magnets to levitate the rotor weighing 42 lb and superconductors to stabilize the inherently unstable magnet-magnet interactions. The hybrid bearings are brought into action under convenient field-cooled conditions. To explain the concepts and illustrate the feasibility of such hybrid superconducting bearings for low energy loss FES applications, a prototype FES system has been constructed and a preliminary spin-down measurement was performed. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. Authors: Young Jr. William R.
Title: Electric vehicles of yesterday carry us into tomorrow
Affiliations: Florida Solar Energy Cent, Cape Canaveral, FL, United States

Abstract: The basic design of an electric vehicle (EV) has changed little over the years but the design of the components has changed with the continuous advances in motors, controllers and batteries. Efficiencies have increased with advances in technology, but the major problem of energy storage has not been solved. The energy storage system of the EV appears to remain as the major challenge of the future.

Authors with affiliations: Bykat, A., Department of Mathematics and Computer Science, Armstrong State College, Savannah, GA  31419, United States
Abstract: AXAF is a third among NASA’s great space observatories. AXAF’s power system is designed as a single bus system and consists of four major components: a two wing six panel solar array to provide power generation capability, three NiH2 batteries to provide energy storage capability, a single bus to provide power distribution capability, and the associated control electronics. which includes control of battery charge sensing and conditioning circuitry. In this paper we evaluate CLIPS, an expert system development environment, for its suitability to function as the development platform for a monitoring and troubleshooting expert system for the AXAF’s electrical power system. CLIPS is found a suitable though not an ideal environment for such an undertaking. CLIPS capabilities are believed sufficient for representation of the system’s knowledge base, but are lacking in graphics capabilities to develop an user interface, and the reasoning explanation facility. The first drawbacks is ameliorated by the existence of an inputloutput router which is expected to afford integration of an interface written in a different programming language; the explanation facility will have to be programmed from scratch using the CLIPS language. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Burke A.F.
Title: Characterization of electrochemical capacitors for electric/hybrid vehicle applications
Affiliations: Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, Idaho Falls, ID  83415-3830, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burke, A.F., Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, Idaho Falls, ID  83415-3830, United States
Abstract: Energy storage specification requirements are presented for primary energy storage and pulse power units to be used in electric and hybrid vehicles. It is shown that electrochemical capacitors under development in the Department of Energy (DOE) Ultra capacitor program will meet the requirements for the pulse power units. Electrochemical capacitor development using a number of electrode material technologies is in progress and rapid improvement in energy density is being made. Recent tests of 3 V cells delivered on the DOE program indicate an energy density of 5 Wh/kg at a constant power density of 2.5 kW/kg has been achieved. Continued improvement in energy density is expected to result in devices approaching the DOE advanced program goal of 15 W-Nkg by the end of 1994. A simple cost study for carbon-based devices indicates that meeting a cost goal of $ 0.5 to $l/W.h requires a processed carbon cost of $2 to $5/lb. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Kusic G.L., Cull R.C.
Title: A power system design tool for aerospace applications
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA  15261, United States; NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Road, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kusic, G.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA  15261, United States; Cull, R.C., NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Road, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the proof-of-concept version of an Aerospace Power System Planning Program (APSPP). It is part of an effort to develop improved power system design tools for the early design phases. The Space Station Freedom (SSF) design at mid-1 993 is used as an example to define the basic power module and allow options and trade-offs to be explored. Weights and efficiencies of electrical equipment constructed at mid-1 993, or best estimates at that time, are used as data for the building blocks of APSPP--power source, energy storage, bulk power transmission, power conditioning, secondary distribution, and thermal management. The APSPP uses an EXCEL© spreadsheet for easy data entry and display. The user selects the type of primary source and storage, defines the topolgy, and specifies the connecting cables. Primary weight is calculated. Electrical transmission losses and performance plus weight for dc/dc, dc/ac, etc. converters are built-in subroutines. Insolation and load demand periods are user defined. Electrical system performance is calculated from three power flows, energy storage, and converter operation over the specified periods. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Anis W.R., Nour M.A.
Title: Optimum design of a photovoltaic powered pumping system
Affiliations: Electronics and Communication Department, Faculty of Engineering, Ain Shams University, 1 Sarayat St., Abbasia, Cairo, Egypt, Egypt; Electronics Department, Yanbou Industrial College, P.O. Box 30436, Yanbou Al Sinaiyah 21477, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Anis, W.R., Electronics and Communication Department, Faculty of Engineering, Ain Shams University, 1 Sarayat St., Abbasia, Cairo, Egypt, Egypt; Nour, M.A., Electronics Department, Yanbou Industrial College, P.O. Box 30436, Yanbou Al Sinaiyah 21477, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) powered pumping systems are relatively simple and reliable, hence they are applied worldwide. Two conventional techniques are curently in use; the first is the directly coupled technique where a PV array is directly coupled to a d.c. motor-pump group, and the second is the battery buffered PV pumping system where a battery is connected across the array to feed the d.c. motor driving a pump. Recently, a third system is proposed to make use of the advantages of the previously mentioned conventional systems. It is the switched mode PV powered pumping system. The switched mode PV powered pumping system couples the pumping system to the PV array directly when the storage battery is fully charged as explained in Ref. [5]. The objective of such a system is the maximum utilization of available solar radiation to minimize the cost per pumped cubic meter from a given water depth. For a given location, four main parameters affect the design of this system; (1) d.c. motor-pump group parameters, (2) PV array size, (3) battery storage size and (4) water storage tank size. The system designer has to determine the previously mentioned four parameters so that the minimum cost per pumped cubic meter is achieved. It is found that some factors are more effective in reducing the cost than others. The PV array size is the predominant factor, while the battery storage and water tank sizes have relatively less effect. The system installation cost is considered in the detailed economic analysis discussed in this work. © 1994.
Author Keywords: Photovoltaic; Pumping; Simulation and design

Authors: Sieniutycz S.
Title: Thermodynamics of irreversible processes and its relation to chemical engineering: Second law analyses and finite time thermodynamics
Affiliations: Institute of Chemical and Process Engineering, Warsaw Technical University, l Warynskiego Str. PL-00-645 Warsaw, Poland; Physiologisches Institut, Universitat Bern, Bühlplatz 5,CH-3012, Bern, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Sieniutycz, S., Institute of Chemical and Process Engineering, Warsaw Technical University, l Warynskiego Str. PL-00-645 Warsaw, Poland, Physiologisches Institut, Universitat Bern, Bühlplatz 5,CH-3012, Bern, Switzerland
Abstract: We discuss thermodynamic costs and thermodynamic limits for various processes with finite rates important in chemical engineering: The thermodynamic costs are expressed in terms of exergy input, dissipated exergy, or some extension of these quantities including time penalty. We consider processes which occur in a finite time and with equipment of finite dimension. These processes include separation processes and are found in hydraulic systems, heat and mass exchangers, thermal networks, energy convertors, energy recovery units, storage systems, chemical reactors, and chemical plants. Our analysis is based on the condition that in order to make the results of thermodynamic analyses qualitatively closer to those following from economics it is the thermodynamic cost optimum, not the maximum of thermodynamic efficiency, which must be preserved for prescribed process requirements. Our outlook is that, in view of the uncertainty, variability and incompleteness of economic data, thermodynamic costs may be useful until an exact economic analysis can be made. A creative part of this review outlines a general approach to the construction of “finite time potentials” using Bellman’s method of dynamic programming. © Copyright 1994 Walter de Gruyter
Index Keywords: Chemical engineering; Dynamic programming; Separation; Bellman's dynamic programming method; Dissipated exergy; Exergy input; Finite time thermodynamics; Irreversible processes; Second law analyses; Thermodynamics

Authors: Nabors C.D.
Title: Q-Switched Operation of Quasi-Three-Level Lasers
Affiliations: Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Coherent Laser Grour, Santa, Clara, CA Lexington, MA 02173, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nabors, C.D., Lincoln Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Coherent Laser Grour, Santa, Clara, CA Lexington, MA 02173, United States
Abstract: A theoretical model for longitudinally pumped quasi-three-level lasers under Q-switched, repetitively Q-switched, and cw operating conditions is developed. The model is applied using 8% Ho:YAG as the gain medium, and it is found that for typical conditions the effective energy storage time can be much less than the upper state lifetime, in agreement with experiment but not predicted by earlier theories. This effect is attributed to details of laser design and pumping conditions, as opposed to being an intrinsic property of the gain material. © 1994, IEEE.

Authors: Nilsson R., Seetharaman S., Jacob K.T.
Title: A Modified Sulphide Capacity Function
Affiliations: Department of Theoretical Metallurgy, Royal Institute of Technology, 100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Department of Metallurgy, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India
Authors with affiliations: Nilsson, R., Department of Theoretical Metallurgy, Royal Institute of Technology, 100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Seetharaman, S., Department of Theoretical Metallurgy, Royal Institute of Technology, 100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Jacob, K.T., Department of Metallurgy, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India
Abstract: The sulphide capacity as originally defined by Fincham and Richardson is a strong function of composition in pseudobinary oxide melts of interest in extractive metallurgy. From an analysis of data available in the literature, it is shown that sulphide capacity is directly proportional to the activity of the basic oxide in the melt, within the uncertainty of experimental data. A single parameter is sufficient to describe the sulphide capacity of a binary slag system under isothermal and isobaric conditions. The correlation indicates that the activity coefficient of the sulphide ion or the neutral base metal sulphide dissolved in the melt is independent of composition in pseudobinary melts within experimental uncertainty. Structural variations in the melt with composition do not seem to affect the activity coefficient of the sulphide. A modified sulphide capacity function is defined which makes the treatment more elegant and greatly simplifies data storage and retrieval. The modified function is not based on any model for the melt. © 1994, The Iron and Steel Institute of Japan. All rights reserved.

Authors: Minkiewicz V.J., Stasiak J., White R.L., Cornell R.W., Moore J.O., Eaton R., Eldridge J.M., Lee F.C.
Title: Some mechanical and thermal properties of PECVD a-SixC1-x: H and a-SixN1-x: H films prepared by mixed frequency plasma processes
Affiliations: IBM Research Center, San Jose, CA, United States; Lexmark International, Lexington, KY, United States; IBM Storage Systems Division, San Jose, CA, United States; ASM America, Phoenix, AZ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Minkiewicz, V.J., IBM Research Center, San Jose, CA, United States; Stasiak, J., Lexmark International, Lexington, KY, United States; White, R.L., IBM Storage Systems Division, San Jose, CA, United States; Cornell, R.W., Lexmark International, Lexington, KY, United States; Moore, J.O., IBM Research Center, San Jose, CA, United States; Eaton, R., ASM America, Phoenix, AZ, United States; Eldridge, J.M., IBM Research Center, San Jose, CA, United States; Lee, F.C., IBM Research Center, San Jose, CA, United States
Abstract: The thermal coefficient of expansion (TCE) and biaxial elastic modulus (BEM) of a-SixC1-x: H and a-SixN1-x: H films prepared by plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) were studied over a wide range of composition. The films were prepared in a unique PECVD system that uses a controllable mixture of two frequencies (450 KHz and 13.56 MHz) to excite the plasma. The TCE and BEM were determined by neasuring the temperature dependence of the stress of identically deposited films on two substrates having different expansion coefficients. The TCE data are well behaved and relatively straightforward to understand. Silicon-rich carbide films and nitride films with x near 0.5 had TCE values near those of crystalline Si and Si3N4 respectively. However, their moduli were much smaller than the bulk values. For x = 0.5, the carbide and nitride films had BEM values of about 125 GPa while the bulk values are 865 GPa and 482 GPa respectively. Effects of frequency mixing on the hardness of a series of carbide films were determined, using a nonoindenter system and films deposited with a fixed SiH4: CH4 flow rate ratio and temperature. Such effects were quite pronounced in that raising the high frequency component from 15% to 85% reduced the hardness from 28 to 12 GPa. These findings and an explanation for their origins will be discussed, together with a few technological examples showing the use of such films as passivants. For example, dual layers of a-SixC1-x: H/a-SixN1-x: H have been used to protect the resistor structure in thermal ink jet printheads and, as such, are subjected to intensive thermal stress cycles. Thus one can predict that some carbide layers (having certain values of TCE, BEM and thickness) will have an excessive stored energy and thus delaminate during device operation. In another example, such carbide films could be attractive for coating magnetic storage media and recording head structures. Carbide films can have hardnesses comparable with that of a-C: H films but could, in principle, be tailored to a specific slider surface to minimize wear. © 1994.

Authors: Meier A., Uhlendorf I., Meissner D.
Title: Multiple nano contacts: A new way to create highly efficient direct solar energy storage systems
Affiliations: Institute for Solar Energy Research, Sokelantstr. 5, Hannover, D-30165, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Meier, A., Institute for Solar Energy Research, Sokelantstr. 5, Hannover, D-30165, Germany; Uhlendorf, I., Institute for Solar Energy Research, Sokelantstr. 5, Hannover, D-30165, Germany; Meissner, D., Institute for Solar Energy Research, Sokelantstr. 5, Hannover, D-30165, Germany
Abstract: Catalysis is the key problem for the direct storage of solar energy in photoelectrochemical cells as e.g. by direct water electrolysis. Metal deposition at the interface can provide the necessary electrocatalysis for chemical reactions. In photoelectrochemical devices they are driven by the minority charge carriers produced upon illumination. To avoid a simultaneous increase of the majority carrier transfer - the loss current which decreases the efficiency of the photon energy conversion device - a new way of metallizing semiconductor surfaces has been developed. By depositing colloidal metal particles onto semiconductor surfaces, well defined Multiple Nano Contacts (MNCs) are prepared. The surface modification by MNCs changes the catalytic properties of the semiconductor surface dramatically with negligible disturbance of the semiconductor surface energetics. This has been verified here performing electrochemical experiments with gold MNCs of different sizes (6 - 100 nm) deposited on- pGaAs electrodes. For comparison, sub monolayers of gold deposited from gold ion solutions were investigated. They show that for a comparable metal surface area exposed to the electrolyte the majority carrier loss currents are reduced by about 5 orders of magnitude if the electrodes were metallized by depositing MNCs. These results can be understood on the basis of the thermionic emission model for meta~semiconductor devices combined with the electrochemical model for charge transfer processes at metal electrodes. Using the new technique, the particle sizes and the MNC density can be varied independently of each other which is not possible with ordinary metallization procedures. © 1994 by the authors. Published by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. with permission.

Authors: Stadnick S.J., Rogers H.H.
Title: Use of 26% KOH electrolyte for long term Nickel-Hydrogen geosynchronous missions
Affiliations: Hughes Industrial Electronics Company, Hughes Aircraft Company, Torrance, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stadnick, S.J., Hughes Industrial Electronics Company, Hughes Aircraft Company, Torrance, CA, United States; Rogers, H.H., Hughes Industrial Electronics Company, Hughes Aircraft Company, Torrance, CA, United States
Abstract: Nickel-hydrogen battery cells using 26% KOH electrolyte instead of the conventional 31% have previously demonstrated longer life for LEO missions. However, the life increase has also been determined to be valid for high depth of discharge missions using the Hughes designed nickel hydrogen cells for 80% depth of discharge for fifteen years or more in geosynchronous orbit. Recent development of electric ion propulsion systems has also increased the requirements for battery power. In order to propose use of 26% KOH for geosynchronous applications, it was necessary to completely characterize the cells. Testing included initial capacity, storage, charge efficiency vs charge rate and temperature, cold temperature tolerance to-1O°C, trickle charge efficiency, and self-discharge characterization. Results showed that the performance differences between 31% KOH and 26% KOH are minimal, and that the 26% KOH cells can be used to replace 31% KOH cells on Hughes geosynchronous spacecraft without change to either the battery or spacecraft configuration. In addition, data for long term real time synchronous testing has been reviewed, and an additional four cells with 26% KOH electrolyte have been placed in an accelerated synchronous test. These cells are capable of 80% depth of discharge for fifteen years in synchronous orbit, including support for the additional demands of electric ion propulsion. © 1994 by Hughes Aircraft Company.

Authors: Hurwitch Jonathan, Akhil Abbas, Taylor Paula
Title: Utility battery storage applications: Profile and distribution of cycles, power and energy requirements
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Energetics, Inc, Columbia, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hurwitch, Jonathan, Energetics, Inc, Columbia, MD, United States; Akhil, Abbas, Energetics, Inc, Columbia, MD, United States; Taylor, Paula, Energetics, Inc, Columbia, MD, United States
Abstract: Recent analysis of utility battery storage focused on several objectives: to characterize/quantify the current state of knowledge of application requirements, potential benefits, and markets for utility battery energy storage, to identify information deficiencies, respond to as many deficiencies as possible, and prepare an action plan to address them, and to provide adequate information to allow initiation of technology-specific battery studies. The analysis identified thirteen potential utility battery applications, provided estimates of power, energy, and number of duty cycles per year that the applications would demand from a battery system. This report contains a summary table of this and other information about each application. This paper also presents fact sheets that contain one graph that illustrates a utility need that drives the application and a second graph that shows how the battery responds to meet the utility need. Text discusses the rationale for the application, describes the power and energy requirements on the battery system, and highlights the cycle profile and distribution data provided in the graphs. The second section of this document consists of graphs for three combinations of selected applications that can provide utilities with multiple benefits. This information ties utility applications to battery system technology capabilities.

Authors: Cohen F., Dalton P.J.
Title: Space station Nickel-Hydrogen battery oru test
Affiliations: Rockwell Aerospace, Rocketdyne Div, 6633 Canoga Avenue, P.O. Box 7922, Canoga ParkCA  91306-7922, United States; NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Road, Cleveland, OH  44136, United States

Abstract: The International Space Station electrical power system utilizes Nickel-Hydrogen (Ni-H2) batteries as part of its power system to store electrical energy. The batteries are charged during insolation and discharged during eclipse. The batteries are designed to operate at a 35% depth of discharge (DOD) maximum during normal operation. Thierry-eight individual pressure vessel (IPV) Ni-H2 battery cells are series connected and packaged in an Orbit Replacement Unit (ORU). Two ORUs are sexiest connected, a total of 76 cells, to form one battery. The International Space Station will be the first application for low earth orbit (LEO) cycling of this quantity of series connected cells. The Space Station Photovoltaic (P.V.) Electronics Team, consisting of NASA and Rocket dyne personnel began a unique test program at the Power Systems Facility at the NASA Lewis Research Center. The test plan was created to evaluate near and long term performance as a battery as well as charge management characteristics. The testing would also validate the ORU configuration including the ORU box and thermal interface design. This paper describes the test program and the results of the 3, 000 LEO cycles on a Space Station engineering model (EM) battery. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Abstract: Solar energy is one of most promising alternative energy sources. Up until now, solar cells have been used for limited and very diverse applications, such as water pumping irrigation projects. A comparative study between different PV system is carried out in this paper. The steady state and transient characteristics are studied for the different types of DC machines in different system configurations. Abstract: There are currently 168 nickel hydrogen (NiH2) cells on test in a low earth orbit (LEO) application at the Naval Surface Warfare Center, Crane Division, IN. There are 20 NiH2 cells in a special pulse test with 10 at the Aerospace Corporation and 10 cells at Phillips Laboratory. These tests are all designed to demonstrate cell performance in a LEO application and develop a comprehensive data base to support the performance. Along with these life cycle tests there are 10 cells in an extended storage test. This paper describes the LEO life test plans and presents current status of the cells on test. It also discusses acceptance and characterization tests on 70 cells with 26% KOH that were recently added to the test matrix. The life cycle tests at Crane Division were started in 1987. Title: Hydrogen infrastructure: Near-term technologies and implications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Arthur D. Little, Inc, Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bentley, Jeffrey, Arthur D. Little, Inc, Cambridge, MA, United States; Hynek, Scott, Arthur D. Little, Inc, Cambridge, MA, United States; Fuller, Ware, Arthur D. Little, Inc, Cambridge, MA, United States
Abstract: Stationary hydrogen storage will be an important element of hydrogen dispensing stations for hydrogen-powered vehicles. It can also be used as a buffer to accommodate the intermittent nature of renewable energy resources, to facilitate bulk hydrogen transport. Energy efficiency is an important parameter, and neither gravimetric nor volumetric density is as relevant for stationary hydrogen storage as it is for storage on board vehicles. A stationary storage concept using a high temperature metal hydride and a phase change material to provide extremely high energy efficiency is now being developed at Arthur D. Little.

Authors: Penman J., Seddling H.G., Lloyd B.A.
Title: Detection and Location of Interturn Short Circuits in the Stator Windings of Operating Motors
Affiliations: University of Aberdeen, Aberdeen, United Kingdom; Ontario Hydro, Toronto, Canada; Consolidated Edison, New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Penman, J., University of Aberdeen, Aberdeen, United Kingdom; Seddling, H.G., Ontario Hydro, Toronto, Canada; Lloyd, B.A., Ontario Hydro, Toronto, Canada, Consolidated Edison, New York, United States
Abstract: Motors are critical components for electric utilities and process industries. A motor failure can result in the shutdown of a generating unit or production line, or require that redundant plant be utilized to circumvent the problem. One major cause of failures is breakdown of the turn insulation leading to puncture of the groundwall. Early detection of interturn shorts during motor operation would eliminate consequential damage to adjacent coils and the stator core reducing repair costs and motor outage time. In addition to the benefits gained from early detection of turn insulation breakdown, significant advantages would accrue by locating the faulted coil within the stator winding. Fault location would not only increase the speed of the repair, but would also permit more optimal scheduling of the repair outage. This work was successful in practically implementing a theory to predict changes in the axial leakage flux resulting from stator winding interturn shorts and in developing an algorithm to locate the position of the faulted coil. An experimental setup consisting of a 200 hp motor loaded by a generator was used to validate this theory. Suitable transducers were developed and installed on this motor. Measurement using this experimental configuration clearly validated the theoretical model. On the basis of this experimental work, an instrument to continuously monitor for shorted turns is under development. © 1994 IEEE

Title: Battery charger with unity power factor for electric car
Affiliations: Ecole Centrale de Lille, Lille, France
Authors with affiliations: Fauvette, X., Ecole Centrale de Lille, Lille, France; Rombaut, C., Ecole Centrale de Lille, Lille, France; Le Moigne, Ph., Ecole Centrale de Lille, Lille, France; Castelain, A., Ecole Centrale de Lille, Lille, France
Abstract: Electric vehicles can become the solution to the problems of atmospheric pollution and engine noise emission but the main problem is that they have limited storage capacity. The paper proposes the use of a battery charger with unity power factor for use in the electric car. The proposed solution is sinusoidal and in phase with the main voltage so the power factor is almost unity allowing an optimization of the charging time and a decrease in the mains perturbations.
Index Keywords: Electric converters; Electric energy storage; Electric power factor; Electric vehicles; Pollution; Reactive power; Battery chargers; Unity power factors; Charging (batteries)

Authors: Prince F., Winter D.A., Sjonnesen G., Wheeldon R.K.
Title: A New Technique for the Calculation of the Energy Stored, Dissipated, and Recovered in Different Ankle-Foot Prostheses
Affiliations: Department of Kinesiology, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ontario, N2L 3G1, Canada; Department of Surgery, Service of Orthopedics, Faculty of Medicine, University of Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Quebec, J1H 5N4, Canada; Gerontology and Geriatric Research Center, Youville Hospital, Sherbrooke, Quebec, J1H 4C4, Canada; Department of Kinesiology, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ontario, N2L 3G1, Canada; Chedoke-McMaster Hospitals, Prosthetics and Orthotics Department, Hamilton, Ontario L8N 3Z5, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Prince, F., Department of Kinesiology, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ontario, N2L 3G1, Canada, Department of Surgery, Service of Orthopedics, Faculty of Medicine, University of Sherbrooke, Sherbrooke, Quebec, J1H 5N4, Canada, Gerontology and Geriatric Research Center, Youville Hospital, Sherbrooke, Quebec, J1H 4C4, Canada; Winter, D.A., Department of Kinesiology, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ontario, N2L 3G1, Canada; Sjonnesen, G., Chedoke-McMaster Hospitals, Prosthetics and Orthotics Department, Hamilton, Ontario L8N 3Z5, Canada; Wheeldon, R.K., Department of Kinesiology, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ontario, N2L 3G1, Canada
Abstract: Previous research reported calculation of mechanical power of ankle-foot devices using the dot product of the ankle moment times the ankle angular velocity. Unfortunately, there are two errors in this analysis technique. The biomechanical model used assumed a rigid foot articulating around the ankle and there was no accounting for energy storage or dissipation and recovery in the viscoelastic material of the cosmetic cover. The first purpose of this paper is to propose a rigorous technique for the calculation of the net energy efficiency that could be used for any articulated or nonarticulated ankle-foot prosthesis. The second purpose is to quantify the amount of energy stored or dissipated and then recovered in order to discriminate between different ankle-foot prostheses. The SACH, Seattle, Flex-foot, and Golden-Ankle ankle-foot prostheses were evaluated on the same amputee, while walking at his natural cadence. The power entering and leaving the distal end of the prosthetic leg was calculated as the sum of the translational (force-velocity product) and rotational (moment-angular velocity product). All ankle-foot prostheses showed the same distal power pattern. After initial contact, a large energy storage was observed in the cushioned heel, which was followed by some energy recovery. Then, during mid and late stance, another period of storage or dissipation and recovery was observed. Even the SACH foot should be considered an energy storing foot prosthesis since it's cosmetic material was seen to be capable of recovering energy. The balance between the rate of change of foot mechanical energy and the foot powers showed that the new technique takes into account the energy stored or dissipated and then recovered within the compliant material and flexing keel. The new analysis technique can be used by prosthetic designers to assess any type of ankle-foot prostheses. Criteria for ankle-foot prosthesis selection should include, not only the net mechanical efficiency for both rearfoot and forefoot sections, but also the total energy recovered by the ankle-foot prostheses. © 1994 IEEE
Index Keywords: Biomechanics; Calculations; Efficiency; Energy dissipation; Energy storage; Errors; Handicapped persons; Kinematics; Mathematical models; Ankle foot prostheses; Cosmetic cover; Energy recovery; Mechanical efficiency; Mechanical energy; Viscoelastic material; Prosthetics

Authors: Rufer A.Ch.
Title: Modern power conversion for complementary energy storage
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique Federale de, Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Rufer, A.Ch., Ecole Polytechnique Federale de, Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: Similar to the classical solution of hydraulic pump-turbine plants, new means for accumulation of electrical energy are given for lower but respectable quantities by the so called BESS (Battery Energy Storage Systems) and SMES (Super conducting Magnet Energy Storage). Another energy accumulator is given by using mechanical kinetic energy of a fly-wheel. Each system has advantages and disadvantages from the point of view of the quantity of stored energy and magnitude of the instantaneous usable power. A realistic application of energy storage should combine different means of storage, using the advantages of their complementarity. The modern energy conversion techniques allow fast, and flexible power control, and also reactive power compensation.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Electric commutation; Electric rectifiers; Electrochemistry; Mathematical models; Reactive power; Battery energy storage systems; Complementary energy storage; Modern power conversion; Superconducting magnet energy storage; Electric energy storage

Authors: Itoh H., Fushimi K., Kataoka Y., Hashiguchi H.
Title: Zinc/bromine battery for solar stirling power generation system
Affiliations: Meidensha Corporation, 1-17, Ohsaki 2-chome, Shinagawa-ku, Tokyo  141, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Itoh, H., Meidensha Corporation, 1-17, Ohsaki 2-chome, Shinagawa-ku, Tokyo  141, Japan; Fushimi, K., Meidensha Corporation, 1-17, Ohsaki 2-chome, Shinagawa-ku, Tokyo  141, Japan; Kataoka, Y., Meidensha Corporation, 1-17, Ohsaki 2-chome, Shinagawa-ku, Tokyo  141, Japan; Hashiguchi, H., Meidensha Corporation, 1-17, Ohsaki 2-chome, Shinagawa-ku, Tokyo  141, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes an application of the rechargeable Zinc/Bromine battery for the solar stirlirig generator system as one of the new energy utilities. The objective of this program is to generate electric power from renewable energy, such as solar, mind, etc., and to provide storage for practical use. This program has been carried out since 1990 by Meidensha for the batteries, and Aisin Seiki Co., Ltd. for the stirling engines, the generators, and the solar energy concentrators, under the contract of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI). In this system, 3 modules of the 30 kWh (DC) battery were applied to 2 units of the 7 kW (AC) stirling generator. We designed the module as a cubicle type, for ease of practical use. The field test at Miyako island, operated since last year, showed good toleration to the rapid change of the electric power generated by solar energy. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Shaltens R.K., Boyle R.V.
Title: Update of the 2 kW solar dynamic ground test demonstration program
Affiliations: National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Lewis Research Center, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States; AlliedSignal Aerospace Corporation, Fluid Systems, Tempe, AZ  85284, United States

Abstract: The Solar Dynamic (SD) Ground Test Demonstration (GTD) program demonstrates the operation of a complete 2 kWe SD system in a simulated space environment at a NASA Lewis Research Center (LeRC) thermal-vacuum facility. This paper reviews the goals and status of the SD GTD program. A brief description of the SD system identifying key design features of the system, subsystems and components is included. An aerospace industry/government team is working together to design, fabricate, assemble and test a complete SD system. © 1994, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. Authors: Dawson S., Perrone D., Otzinger B., Di Stefano S.
Title: Battery definition for the mars environmental survey mission (MESUR) pathfinder
Affiliations: Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dawson, S., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109, United States; Perrone, D., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109, United States; Otzinger, B., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109, United States; Di Stefano, S., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA  91109, United States
Abstract: Silver Zinc (Ag-Zn) battery technology has been baselined as the energy storage system for the MESUR mission. The mission profile will require the operation of this battery in a manner not usually seen for this technology. In particular, the combination of storage time followed by multiple cycles as a function of fluctuating temperatures and charge/discharge rates, and limited available time for charging has not been previously demonstrated. This paper describes ground testing designed to evaluate this technology under the proposed mission profile. We also present initial results of these tests. Preliminary results of testing (which do not yet take into account the effect of storage) indicate that a modified constant potential method of charging will be able to maintain energy balance during operation on the surface of Mars. © 1994, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. All rights reserved.

Authors: Bart H.-J., Brandsttltter R.
Title: Energy storage in concentrated sodium hydroxide solutions and power generation by using ammonia in a gas turbine/generator system
Affiliations: Institut für thermische Verfahrenstechnik und Umwelttechnik, Christian Doppler Laboratorium, Technische Universiät Graz, Inffeldgasse 25, Graz, A-8010, Austria; Christian Doppler Laboratorium, Technische Universiät Graz, Inffeldgasse 25, Graz, A-8010, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Bart, H.-J., Institut für thermische Verfahrenstechnik und Umwelttechnik, Christian Doppler Laboratorium, Technische Universiät Graz, Inffeldgasse 25, Graz, A-8010, Austria; Brandsttltter, R., Christian Doppler Laboratorium, Technische Universiät Graz, Inffeldgasse 25, Graz, A-8010, Austria
Abstract: In this paper technical feasibility of an energy storage/power generation system will be illustrated using the system NaOH/H2O/NH3. The concept of storage of low-level thermal energy will be demonstrated on aqueous solutions of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) using the concentration difference energy. The concept of generating power by using a turbine/generator system driven by ammonia as the working fluid, which is released from aqueous solutions of ammonia, is investigated. This system was selected to study experimentally its use for energy storage and power generation. Experimental data were used for computer simulation of the turbine/generator unit. After identifying the basic data significant for energy storage and power generation, the aim of this work was to scale-up this system to a technical process. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Lemrani H., Stouffs P.
Title: Dynamic simulation of kinematic stirling engines applied to power control
Affiliations: Lab. Energétique ARTEMIS, Nantes, France
Authors with affiliations: Lemrani, H., Lab. Energétique ARTEMIS, Nantes, France; Stouffs, P., Lab. Energétique ARTEMIS, Nantes, France
Abstract: A decoupled analysis modelisation of a four cylinder double-acting kinematic Stirling engine is briefly presented. The main feature of this modelisation is the use of a software package combining the potentialities of a pre-/post-processor with a DAE solver. This makes the resulting modelisation very flexible and powerful. In order to highlight this versatility, we present the modelisation of the transient response of the modelled engine to a power change. Two different power control systems are compared: dead volume variation by variable angle swashplate and mean pressure variation by fluid flow from a gas storage vessel to the engine or inversely. It is known that unsuitable temporal torque evolutions can be obtained with this latter system. This phenomenon appears very clearly in the simulation results. Consequently, different strategies of supplying the fluid to the engine are examined in order to obtain the required torque evolution. © 1994 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Maveety J.G., Razani A.
Title: Transient exergy analysis and optimal removal time of a storage system
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM  87131, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maveety, J.G., Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM  87131, United States; Razani, A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM  87131, United States
Abstract: In this study we consider the transient analysis of a thermal energy storage system modeled as an isolated cylindrical thermal system. The working fluid is assumed to be incompressible, which passes through a pipe. The energy transfer from the higher temperature surrounding domain to the working fluid is due to conduction in the annulus and by convection to the working fluid. We apply an integral technique to determine the behavior of the different temperature profiles as a function of time. In addition we consider the second law aspects of the system and isolate those irreversibilities which reduce the availability. Lastly, we propose a normalized figure of merit characterizing the optimal energy extraction to irreversibility. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Rossmeissl N.P.
Title: Hydrogen as an energy storage medium for renewable energy
Affiliations: U.S. Department of Energy, Washington, DC  20585, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rossmeissl, N.P., U.S. Department of Energy, Washington, DC  20585, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to present an overview of the role of hydrogen energy storage systems in overcoming intermittency and availability as real bamers preventing renewable energy from becoming a widespread, generalized energy option. In order to promote renewable energy technologies as a viable and significant energy resource and to integrate them into the existing energy infrastructure, we need to develop an energy carrier that could store and transport the energy from renewable sources and deliver it to the end user--easily, cleanly, and efficiently. Many believe that hydrogen can fulfill this role. A detailed discussion of each hydrogen storage option is not possible within the scope of this paper; however, general characteristics needed for relative comparisons are presented. Typical tradeoffs of beneficial use (environmental benefits) and restrictive features (cost and energy penalties) need to be evaluated when considering hydrogen storage in future utility applications such as large central baseload plants, dispersed renewable plants, and distributed generation utilizing fuel cell technologies. © 1994, American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics Inc, AIAA. All rights reserved.

Authors: Roan V.P., Fletcher J.
Title: A comparison of several alternative fuels for fuel-cell vehicle applications
Affiliations: University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, United States; University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roan, V.P., University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, United States; Fletcher, J., University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, United States
Abstract: A comparison is made with respect to many of the more important characteristics of several alternative fuels under consideration for fuel cell-powered vehicles. The primary fuels considered are hydrogen, natural gas, methanol and ethanol. Among the characteristics considered are availability, safety issues and storability as well as energy density, and specific energy for both fuel alone and a fuel water mixture required for steam reforming. It is shown that all of the fuels considered have some desirable and some undesirable characteristics, thus implying that likely: 1) Several fuels will be utilized 2) The fuel selection will depend on the type of transportation system as well as other factors including the type of fuel cell system. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Actual field test of a novel combined system of high efficiency heating and cooling heat pump and clathrate cool storage unit
Affiliations: Kyushu Electric Power Co.Inc, Research Laboratory, Minami-ku, Fukuoka  815, Japan; Mechanical Engineering Laboratory, Tukuba, Ibaraki  305, Japan; National Institute of Materials and Chemical Research, Tukuba, Ibaraki  305, Japan; New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization, Toshima-ku, Tokyo  170, Japan; Shimizu Corporation, Minato-ku, Tokyo  105-07, Japan; Obayashi Corporation, Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo  101, Japan; Kobe Steel Ltd, Takasago, Hyogo  676, Japan; Mitsub ishi Heavy Industries, Ltd, Takasago, Hyogo  676, Japan

Abstract: A novel system that employs a super heat pump with about twice the performance of a conventional one in combination with clathrate cool storage unit was installed in the Kyushu Electric Power Co., Inc, Research laboratory in March FY1992, and field tests were conducted using actual cooling and heating loads which occurred inside the building. The sys tern proved its usefulness by achieving a COP of approximately 6 for the super heat pump, cool storage density of more than 126kJ (30kcal) /kg for the clathrate unit, a heat recovery ratio of more than 90%, and a daily averaged total energy efficiency of more than 5 for the combined system. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Saitoh T.S., Shinomiya J., Hoshi H.
Title: Borehole/solar seasonal energy system to reduce urban warming in Tokyo
Affiliations: Department of Aeronautics and Space Engineering, Tohoku University, Sendai, 980-77, Japan; Hitachi Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Tokyo E1ectric Power Co., Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, T.S., Department of Aeronautics and Space Engineering, Tohoku University, Sendai, 980-77, Japan; Shinomiya, J., Hitachi Corporation, Tokyo, Japan; Hoshi, H., Tokyo E1ectric Power Co., Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, a seasonal solar energy storage system using boreholes which can be applicable to large facilities including the highstory buildings was proposed. The proposed system provides energy for space heating/cooling of the high-story buildings. The three-dimensional computer simulations were carried out for this borehole system in which vertical boreholes as deep as 100 meters are drilled in the ground. The system recovers the heat generated by the space cooling and refrigeration counters utilized in the summer season. During the summer months, this excess heat is used for charging a heat store (borehole unit), and during the winter season, the heats extracted from the borehole unit and solar thermal energy collected by the solar collector are used to heat the high-story buildings. Then, the winter cold energy is stored and utilized for cold energy source in the summer. The thermal performance including transient isotherms in the borehole unit, long-term variation of average temperature of the unit for charging and discharging processes was clarified in detail. Moreover, effects of CO2 reduction by the proposed system on urban warming were suggested. In particular, maximum possible contribution of the solar energy was assessed and discussed in the paper. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Saitoh T.S., Kato H.
Title: Elementary and system performance of cylindrical latent heat storage unit
Affiliations: Dept. of Aeronautics and Space Engineering, Tohoku University, Sendai, 980-77, Japan; Tohoku University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, T.S., Dept. of Aeronautics and Space Engineering, Tohoku University, Sendai, 980-77, Japan; Kato, H., Tohoku University, Japan
Abstract: Close-contact melting heat transfer characteristics, including natural convection in the liquid region in cylindrical capsules, were studied theoretically. Elucidation of such heat transfer mechanism is of much importance from the viewpoint of cost-effective ice storage and heat storage systems employing the latent heat-of-fusion thermal energy storage (LHTES) concept. This paper presents full transient numerical solutions for combined close-contact and natural convection melting heat transfer in cylindrical capsules. Then, the validity of the previous approximate equations is examined. Moreover, the computer simulation of thermal performance for the latent heat thermal energy storage unit using cylindrical capsules was also performed. It facilitates the designing of the practical LHTES systems using various capsules. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Post R.F., Bender D.A., Merritt B.T.
Title: Electromechanical battery program at the lawrence livermore national laboratory
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-640, Livermore, CA  94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Post, R.F., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-640, Livermore, CA  94550, United States; Bender, D.A., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-640, Livermore, CA  94550, United States; Merritt, B.T., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-640, Livermore, CA  94550, United States
Abstract: New materials and new design concepts are being incorporated in a new approach to an old idea - flywheel energy storage - to create an important alternative to the electrochemical storage battery for use in electric vehicles or for stationary applications, such as computer back-up power or utility load-leveling. We visualize such EMBs (electro-mechanical batteries) as being modular in character, with small (1-5 kwh) modules being used for power-conditioning and for vehicular use, and paralleled 25 kwh modules being used for bulk storage, i.e., load-leveling, applications. In a funded program at the Laboratory two fractional kwh, 200 kW (design peak power) modules have been constructed and subjected to shake-down testing. Their design for high peak power was prompted by awareness of a particular commercial need, as a component in a power-line conditioning device. In addition to such stationary applications, the high power capability of our EMB designs makes them attractive for use in hybridelectric vehicles. Important elements of the LLNL program include the development of passive magnetic bearings and the application of new high-efficiency permanent magnet arrays to an ironless generatorlmotor. Use of these particular elements, together with a multiring, design for the flywheel rotor, is particularly conducive to a systemic approach to the design of an EMB module. These particular design developments have been motivated by the economic issues of simplification, lowered cost, and extended maintenance-free service life. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Strumpf H.J., Westelaken B., Shah D., Pogue B., Chin, Jr., Alvarez J., Klucher B.
Title: Fabrication and testing of the solar dynamic ground test demonstrator heat receiver
Affiliations: Allied Signal Aerospace, Torrance, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Strumpf, H.J., Allied Signal Aerospace, Torrance, CA, United States; Westelaken, B., Allied Signal Aerospace, Torrance, CA, United States; Shah, D., Allied Signal Aerospace, Torrance, CA, United States; Pogue, B., Allied Signal Aerospace, Torrance, CA, United States; Chin, Jr., Allied Signal Aerospace, Torrance, CA, United States; Alvarez, J., Allied Signal Aerospace, Torrance, CA, United States; Klucher, B., Allied Signal Aerospace, Torrance, CA, United States
Abstract: A solar dynamic ground test demonstrator space power system is being developed. The system comprises a complete Brayton engine-a heat receiver, concentrator, radiator, recuperator, heat rejection gas cooler, and turboalternator compressor. All of these components will be operated inside a vacuum tank. The engine is powered by simulated sunlight from an external bank of lights. Successful completion of the testing will indicate the readiness of solar dynamic power for space applications. This paper discusses the fabrication and testing of the heat receiver component. The receiver comprises a cylindrical cavity, the walls of which are lined with a series of tubes running the length of the cavity. The engine working fluid, a mixture of xenon and helium, is heated by the simulated sunlight in these tubes. The receiver incorporates integral thermal storage, using a eutectic mixture of lithium fluoride and calcium difluoride as the thermal storage solid-to-liquid phase change material. This thermal storage is required in order to enable power production when the solar simulator is off (equivalent to an eclipse period for a typical low-earth orbit). The phase change material is contained in a series of individual containment canisters. © 1994 by the American Institute of Aeronautic and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Headifen R.N.
Title: Flywheel energy storage for wind turbines
Affiliations: VistaTech Engineering, Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: Headifen, R.N., VistaTech Engineering, Inc., United States
Abstract: An analytical study for flywheel energy storage of the power output for three wind turbines has been performed. The study considered the peak day power produced by three wind turbines over a 24 hour cycle in West Texas. Their power output was modeled as being stored in a mechanical flywheel battery during higher wind, off-peak demand periods and then strategically released during periods of higher demand. Using a storage system of this type enhances the output of a wind farm during peak demand times, increasing the capacity value of the otherwise intermittent wind facility. The economics of the flywheel storage system is compared to power costs without storage and also with other storage alternatives such as chemical batteries. © 1994 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Potter I.J., Reader G.T.
Title: Parametric analysis of the performance of a variable length AUV
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Calgary, Calgary, AB  T2N 1N4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Potter, I.J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Calgary, Calgary, AB  T2N 1N4, Canada; Reader, G.T., Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Calgary, Calgary, AB  T2N 1N4, Canada
Abstract: Over the last ten years or so there has been a renewal of interest in the use of small autonomous unmanned and untethered underwater vehicles (AUVs) for naval and commercial tasks. One of the principal problems encountered in the evolution of such vehicles has been the development of suitable power systems. The onboard power and energy storage requirements are almost entirely dependent on vehicular performance. In many applications, to be cost and mission effective such vehicles must be able to transit large distances (hundreds of kilometres) and stay submerged for tens of hours, maybe several days. These needs represent a challenging task to the power system designer. The powering of an AUV is largely determined by the shape, size and desired speed of the vessel. However, contemporary underwater power systems may take up to a half of the internal space of the vehicle. Thus the size of the power systems is one of the most important factors in the determination of the vehicle's size. This situation represents an iterative loop in the design process. The propulsive power requirements are dependent upon the speed and drag resistance of the vehicle. In turn, the drag is dependent upon the interrelated parameters speed, shape and the nature of the flow over the vehicle. To reduce the drag, but maintain the design speed, the designer can then try to alter the flow regime over the vehicle or the vehicle shape. The latter tactic is the subject of this paper. For the concept reported here it was envisaged that the overall length of an AUV could be changed during its mission by discarding the "empty" energy storage sections and hence reducing the drag. Preliminary calculations indicate that the endurance of such an AUV could be increased by 15%. © 1994 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Uplifting analysis of base plates in cylindrical tanks

Abstract: A method is presented for the analysis of the base plates in cylindrical liquid-storage tanks that are uplifted under the overturning influence of the hydrodynamic wall pressures induced by earthquakes. Due consideration is given to the nonlinear effects associated with both membrane action and material yielding. The method is highly efficient and suitable for dynamic response analyses of unanchored and partially anchored tanks for which the solution of the plate problem must be obtained at numerous time steps. Both axisymmetric and asymmetric conditions of uplifting are examined. A comprehensive parametric study is carried out to elucidate the effects and relative importance of the various system parameters on the uplifting resistance. Cyclic loading patterns are included to highlight the nature of the hysteretic energy dissipation due to yielding. © ASCE.

Abstract: Unchecked fossil fuel consumption both denies future generations the ability to meet their energy needs and causes life threatening pollution. As in the past, solar energy can be exploited to provide health and comfort without endangering future generations. The basic concepts and systems in passive solar design are orientation to the sun and wind, earth coupling to take advantage of the earth's more constant temperature, thermal mass to absorb, store and radiate heat, and an insulating envelope to keep heat in or out. © 1994 Homestead Enterprises.

Abstract: A novel damping scheme using superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit is proposed in this paper to damp subsynchronous resonance (SSR) of the IEEE Second Benchmark Model, system-1 which is a widely employed standard model for computer simulation of SSR. The studied system contains a turbine-generator set connected to an infinite bus through two parallel transmission lines, one of which is series-capacitor compensated. In order to stabilize all SSR modes, simultaneous active and reactive power modulation and a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) damping controller designed by modal control theory are proposed for the SMES unit. Frequency-domain approach based on eigenvalue analysis and time-domain approach based on nonlinear-model simulations are performed to validate the effectiveness of the damping method. It can be concluded from the simulation results that the proposed damping scheme can effectively suppress SSR of the studied system. © 1994 IEEE

Abstract: Stabilization of a synchronous generator through control of firing angle of the converters in the super conducting magnetic systems is considered. An optimum strategy of the firing angle control is designed so as to eliminate the transients in minimum time. A nonlinear model of a synchronous generator, its governor and exciter systems, and a superconducting magnetic system connected to the generator terminal is considered. The optimum firing angle control is derived retaining the nonlinearities of the system dynamics. Digital simulation results indicate that the proposed strategy controls the slowly growing as well as first swing instabilities very effectively. © 1994 IEEE

Abstract: In the present study, a problem concerning operation of a heat storage tank in connection with a combined heat and power (CHP) plant is considered. The heat storage is used to supply the district heating system when the CHP plant is producing electric power alone and also to redistribute optimally over time the required heat production. Stochasticity is assumed attached to the future power production, and it is assumed that accurate predictions of the future heat consumption are available. A receding horizon idea is used. The problem is solved by the Progressive Hedging Algorithm (PHA), a recently developed method to deal with multi-period optimization problems under uncertainty. The application of the method is explained in detail. © 1994.

Abstract: It is shown that a simple structure with vector control and synchronized modulation of both the load side and the line side inverters can minimize the size of the dc link capacitor at a certain maximal acceptable dc voltage ripple. Abstract: The opening process of a long-conduction-time plasma opening switch (POS) was examined with the aid of numerical simulations. In these simulations, a high-density uniform plasma initially bridges a small section of the coaxial transmission line of an inductive energy storage generator. A short section of vacuum transmission line connects the POS to a load. The results presented extend previous simulations in the ne = 1012 - 1013 cm-3 density regime to the higher-density regimes expected in long-conduction-time experiments. For such experiments, a conceptual model is presented describing the transition of POS dynamics from the MHD-dominated conduction phase to the erosion-dominated opening phase.

Title: Eutectic bonding of a Ti sputter coated carbon aerogel wafer to an Ni foil
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jankowski, A.F., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Hayes, J.P., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA 94550, United States; Kanna, R.L., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA 94550, United States
Abstract: The formation of high density, energy storage devices is achievable using composite material systems. Alternate layering of carbon aerogel wafers and Ni foils with microporous separators is a prospective composite for capacitor applications. An inherent problem exists concerning the formation of a physical bond between the Ni foil and the porous carbon wafer. The bond process temperature must be less than 1050°C, at which point the aerogel begins to degrade. The advantage of a low temperature eutectic in the Ni-Ti alloy system solves this problem. Ti, a carbide former, is readily adherent as a sputter deposited thin film on the carbon wafer. A vacuum bonding process is then used to join the Ni foil and Ti coating through eutectic phase formation. The parameters for successful bonding are examined along with structural characterization of the Ni foil-carbon aerogel wafer interface. A 950°C 30 min heat treatment under high vacuum is found to yield bond failure in the aerogel wafer covering one-third the surface area. © 1994.

Authors with affiliations: Vogler, Thomas, Technical Univ of Munich, Munich, Germany; Schlogl, Andreas, Technical Univ of Munich, Munich, Germany; Schroder, Dierk, Technical Univ of Munich, Munich, Germany
Abstract: The application of power semiconductors at cryogenic temperatures has recently gained significance in protection elements of SMES (superconducting magnetic energy storage) operating at LHT (liquid helium temperature). The evolution of HT (high temperature)-superconductors, however, is still proceeding and will provide in the near future magnetic insensitive materials operating at LNT (liquid nitrogen temperature). Due to the low price of LN, it will then make sense to reconsider the additional cooling of power electronic topologies and, consequently, to take advantage of improving characteristics of power semiconductors with decreasing temperature. One objective of this paper is to characterize the temperature dependence of different devices' static and dynamic behaviour both by measurement and physical analysis by means of recently published circuit models. Secondly, physical assumptions in these models are validated, proving their capability to act as the circuit and device designer's right hand.

Abstract: It has been clarified that a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is very effective for power system stabilization. The control methods proposed for power system stabilization by SMES are the pole assignment, the optimal control, and so on, each of which, however, has its drawbacks. This paper is concerned with the power system stabilization by neural network control of the active power of SMES. First, the optimal stabilizing control of the SMES power for the model power system is calculated for various power system operating conditions and fault conditions. Then these optimal controls are used as training data for the neural network. The neural network used is a multilayer type with a feedback from the output layer to the input layer. The trained neural network is examined by untrained operating conditions and faults. Copyright © 1994 Wiley Periodicals, Inc., A Wiley Company

Abstract: When combined with a magnet having a magnetic field gradient (for example, a permanent magnet), a Y‐based oxide superconductor is capable of forming a noncontact bearing with a strong levitational force. Since this bearing exhibits low rotational loss, it is very likely to form a highly efficient power storage system in combination with a flywheel. In this paper, an 8‐MWh power storage system utilizing a flywheel was designed conceptually to examine its applicability and the possible effects of its introduction. Authors: Yang H.T.Y., He C.C.
Title: Three-Dimensional Finite Element Analysis of Free Edge Stresses and Delamination of Composite Laminates
Affiliations: School of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yang, H.T.Y., School of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States; He, C.C., School of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Abstract: A 24-node, 64-degree-of-freedom, solid hexahedronal finite element is used to analyze the interlaminar free edge stresses and delamination of composite laminated plates. The difficulty due to the requirement of large storage space which is frequently encountered in the modeling of contoured delamination problems is resolved by using the preconditioned conjugate gradient method. One of the advantages of this method is that there is no need to store the fill-in elements in the stiffness matrix decomposition process, which leads to a significant reduction in storage space required, thereby making the numerical analysis of the complicated contoured delamination problem feasible as well as effective. To evaluate the accurateness of the present formulation, numerical algorithm and computer program, free edge stress analyses are performed for a [0/901 cross-ply and a [+ 45], angle-ply laminated plate. Both plates are subjected to an axial tensile strain loading. The present three-dimensional results are found to be in good agreement with those obtained using an alternative quasi-three-dimensional methods. To further demonstrate the applicability of the present development, the strain energy release rate of a [+25/90], graphite-epoxy rectangular laminated plate subjected to tensile strain is studied. Two initial delaminations are assumed to be located in the midspan of the two opposite free edges and also at the middle of the thickness. The delamination contour is assumed to be a straight line segment joined by two circular arcs. The strain energy release rates along the delamination front are calculated using the modified crack closure method. As a step beyond the solution using quasi-3D assumption, the present results show the non-uniform distribution of mode I strain energy release rate G1 along the boundary of the delamination front which fluctuates to a maximum value when approaching both ends at the free edge of the laminate. © 1994, TECHNOMIC PUBLISHING CO., INC. All rights reserved.

Title: An assessment of self-(Cold-) supported SMES systems
Affiliations: 1020 Rose Avenue, Piedmont, CA 94611, United States; 2625 Iliff, Boulder, Colorado 80303, USA
Authors with affiliations: Hassenzahl, W.V., 1020 Rose Avenue, Piedmont, CA 94611, United States; Reed, R., 2625 Iliff, Boulder, Colorado 80303, USA
Abstract: The perceived long-range application of Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) has been for large-scale applications. Since SMES is highly efficient and has a rapid response time, it has a significant technical advantage over other storage technologies. Though the cost per unit of stored energy, $/kWh, for several major components, such as the superconductor and the cryostat, decrease as plant size increases, the amount of structural support that is required to withstand the electromagnetic force is directly proportional to the stored energy. Recognition of this fact led to the proposal of warm- or external-supported SMES, which has been the primary technology researched for the past 20 years. Recently, a team led by Bechtel suggested that cold or self support would be cost effective for SMES plants of intermediate size, i.e., from a few to several hundred MWh. This paper evaluates the cold- or self-supported SMES design to determine if it has sufficient material to withstand the electromagnetic forces. The design is shown to meet a criterion derived from the virial equation. Earlier work, which predicted that larger quantities of material are required, is reviewed. © 1994 Butterworth-Heinemann Ltd.

Abstract: This study investigated the effect of addition of polyethylene fibers on the transverse strength, deflection, and elastic modulus of two denture base acrylic resins polymerized by microwave irradiation. Specimens of each resin, Lucitone 199 and Acron MC, were fabricated with 0.0%, 0.5%, 1.5%, and 3.0% fiber loading. Specimens were tested with use of a three-point flexure apparatus with an Instron universal testing machine after storage in water for 10 days at 37 °C. The results showed that polyethylene fibers significantly decreased the transverse strength of Acron MC resin and slightly increased the transverse strength of Lucitone 199 resin at a loading of 0.5% by weight. Fiber loading did not significantly affect the deflection and the elastic modulus of either material. © 1994.

Authors: Andersson M.

Authors with affiliations: Andersson, M., Division of Energy Systems, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Linköping University, S-581 83 Linköping, Sweden
Abstract: Shadow prices for heat generation are used to study the impact of changes in heat demand on the total system cost of an existing district-heating system in Sweden. The energy system may be considered to be both dynamic, because there is energy storage, and time-dependent since the electricity tariff is time-differentiated and the heat demand varies over the year and day. The energy system has been analysed with and without energy storage. The analysis shows that despite a reduction in system cost, the use of energy storage can result in higher shadow prices for heat generation in some time periods. © 1994.
