Authors: Galinanes M., Smolenski R.T., Haddock P.S., Hearse D.J.
Title: Early effects of hypothyroidism on the contractile function of the rat heart and its tolerance to hypothermic ischemia
Source title: Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery
Affiliations: Cardiovascular Research, Rayne Institute, St. Thomas' Hospital, London SE1 7EH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Galinanes, M., Cardiovascular Research, Rayne Institute, St. Thomas' Hospital, London SE1 7EH, United Kingdom; Smolenski, R.T., Cardiovascular Research, Rayne Institute, St. Thomas' Hospital, London SE1 7EH, United Kingdom; Haddock, P.S., Cardiovascular Research, Rayne Institute, St. Thomas' Hospital, London SE1 7EH, United Kingdom; Hearse, D.J., Cardiovascular Research, Rayne Institute, St. Thomas' Hospital, London SE1 7EH, United Kingdom
Abstract: We have investigated the early effects of hypothyroidism on cardiac function and tolerance to hypothermic ischemia. Hypothyroidism was induced by thyroidectomy. Five days after operation, sham-operated and thyroidectomized rats were anesthetized and cardiac function was assessed. At this time, the plasma levels of triiodothyronine and thyroxine had fallen by eightfold and threefold, respectively, in thyroidectomized rats compared with the values in sham-operated rats. In vivo pump function was assessed by measuring mean arterial pressure, cardiac index, and stroke volume index: all were reduced by thyroidectomy (respectively 95 ± 5 mm Hg, 22 ± 2 ml/min/100 gm body weight, and 67 ± 7 μl/beat/100 gm body weight versus 112 ± 4 mm Hg, 35 ± 1 ml/min/100 gm body weight and 85 ± 4 μl/beat/100 gm body weight in the sham-operated group; p < 0.05 in each instance). Systemic vascular resistance index was higher in thyroidectomized than in sham-operated rats (4.4 ± 0.4 versus 3.1 ± 0.2 mm Hg/ml/min/100 gm body weight; p < 0.05). In vivo indices of contractile function were also reduced by thyroidectomy: maximum rate of left ventricular pressure development fell by almost 50% (5190 ± 790 versus 9600 ± 900 mm Hg/sec; p < 0.05) and left ventricular developed pressure and heart rate also fell (respectively 92 ± 8 mm Hg and 340 beats/min versus 129 ± 6 mm Hg and 398 ± 6 beats/min; p < 0.05 in each instance). After excision, hearts were blood-perfused and ex vivo function assessed with intraventricular balloons. Systolic and diastolic functions were significantly impaired in the thyroidectomized group and the myocardial Na+- K+-adenosinetriphosphatase activity was reduced from a control value of 8.3 ± 0.3 to 5.8 ± 0.4 mean integrated extinction x 100. The hearts were then subjected to 2 minutes of cardioplegic infusion, 6 hours of hypothermic (4° C) ischemia, and 40 minutes of reperfusion. In control hearts, left ventricular developed pressure (at an end-diastolic pressure of 8 mm Hg) recovered to 76% of its preischemic value (131 ± 8 versus 173 ± 8 mm Hg; p < 0.05); in hearts from thyroidectomized rats, left ventricular developed pressure recovered to 81% of its preischemic value (110 ± 8 versus 136 ± 12 mm Hg; p = not significant), an absolute value that was not significantly different from that in the sham-operated group. Diastolic function recovered to the same extent in both groups. Myocardial high-energy phosphate content was unaffected by thyroidectomy and was depleted to a similar extent in both sham-operated and thyroidectomized groups by hypothermic ischemia. In conclusion, thyroidectomy leads to a deterioration of systolic and diastolic functions but this does not adversely affect the tolerance of the heart to extended periods of hypothermic ischemic storage.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphatase (potassium sodium); animal experiment; animal tissue; article; calcium homeostasis; controlled study; cryopreservation; enzyme activity; heart contraction; heart function; heart index; heart left ventricle pressure; heart stroke volume; hypothermia; hypothyroidism; ischemia; male; mean arterial pressure; nonhuman; priority journal; rat; vascular resistance

Authors: Schempf Hagen
Title: Houdini: In-tank mobile cleanup robot
Affiliations: Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schempf, Hagen, Carnegie Mellon Univ, Pittsburgh, United States
Abstract: This paper describes design and analysis efforts to develop a new reconfigurable and collapsible working machine, dubbed Houdini, to remotely clean up hazardous-waste and petroleum storage tanks. The tethered robot system is designed to allow remote entry through man-way openings as small as 0.51 m (20″) in diameter, after which it expands its locomotors and opens up its collapsible backhoe/manipulator and plow to subsequently perform waste or product handling operations. The design is optimized to meet stringent site and safety requirements, and represents a viable alternative to the long-reach manipulation systems proposed for hazardous storage tank cleanup. The design analysis was performed on key design parameters such as track-width and -length, vehicle weight and aspect ratio, to insure that the system will be able to be supported and locomote over/through a wide range of amorphous/solid materials. Theoretical and experimental analyses using the Bekker-parameters are presented to support these findings. The system has currently been proposed as an alternative to provide waste mobilization and removal solutions for hazardous waste storage tanks in the Department of Energy (DoE) complex, and we are currently teamed with two major aerospace and robotics companies, trying to obtain funding to develop an operational prototype system for the DoE. Other potential applications areas are the cleanup of heavy-crude petroleum storage tanks for American Petroleum Institute (API) inspection tasks and Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) required cleanup and/or decommissioning activities.
Index Keywords: Hazardous materials; Manipulators; Optimization; Parameter estimation; Remote control; Robot applications; Bekker parameters; Houdini mobile cleanup robot; Mobile robots

Authors: Hisaki H., Kobayashi N., Yonezawa Y., Morikawa A.
Title: Development of ice-thermal storage system using an adsorption chiller
Source title: Proceedings of the International Absorption Heat Pump Conference
Affiliations: Commercial Sales Dep
Authors with affiliations: Hisaki, H., Commercial Sales Dep; Kobayashi, N., Commercial Sales Dep; Yonezawa, Y., Commercial Sales Dep; Morikawa, A., Commercial Sales Dep
Abstract: Recently, there is an increasing number of needs to use energy efficiently in response to the global warming problem. Cogeneration systems are high in total energy efficiency because they generate power using a gas engine and utilize the exhaust heat for airconditioning. Therefore, it is a promising energy system for the future, although the conventional cogeneration systems can't use the exhaust heat when there is no heat demand such as nighttime. To use gas engine's exhaust heat, we developed an ice storage system using an adsorption chiller. The adsorption chiller driven by the exhaust heat makes ice to storage cold energy during the night and chilled water from ice during the day. The 10 RT prototype adsorption chiller ice thermal storage system is examined. It is verified that its performance agrees with specifications. This system promotes total efficiency of cogeneration systems in applications where heat demand does not occur simultaneously with power demand. Thus, this system will be able to apply to the cogeneration system for facilities with no heat demand at night, such as factories, supermarkets and intelligent office buildings.
Index Keywords: Adsorption; Cogeneration plants; Cold storage; Cryogenic equipment; Energy conservation; Gas engines; Heat storage; Ice; Thermodynamics; Waste heat utilization; Absorption chillers; Cogeneration systems; Exhaust heat; Ice thermal storage systems; Refrigerating machinery

Authors: Jovanovic Milan M., Tsang Dan M.C., Lee Fred C.
Title: Reduction of voltage stress in integrated high-quality rectifier-regulators by variable-frequency control
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IEEE Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition - APEC
Affiliations: DELTA Power Electronics Lab, Inc, Blacksburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jovanovic, Milan M., DELTA Power Electronics Lab, Inc, Blacksburg, United States; Tsang, Dan M.C., DELTA Power Electronics Lab, Inc, Blacksburg, United States; Lee, Fred C., DELTA Power Electronics Lab, Inc, Blacksburg, United States
Abstract: The Integrated High-Quality Rectifier-Regulators (IHQRRs) suffer from relatively high stress on the internal-energy storage capacitor and, consequently, on primary-side semiconductors. As a result, they are not practical in applications with the universal input-voltage range. In this paper, a variable-frequency control that reduces the voltage stress and makes the IHQRRs suitable for universal input-range applications is described. Evaluation results of a 90 W, experimental BIBRED converter that uses the proposed variable-frequency control are presented.
Index Keywords: Electric current control; Electric current regulators; Electric frequency control; Electric power factor; Quality assurance; Voltage control; Voltage regulators; Integrated high quality rectifier regulators; Variable frequency control; Voltage stress reduction; Electric rectifiers

Authors: Mamiya Takashi, Nikai Isao
Title: Study on heat transfer in tube plate adsorption reactor
Source title: Proceedings of the International Absorption Heat Pump Conference
Affiliations: Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Mamiya, Takashi, Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Japan; Nikai, Isao, Kajima Corp, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: An adsorption heat pump is composed of safe and natural substances, utilizing silica gels or zeolites as adsorbents and water as refrigerant. Such heat pumps can contribute to energy conservation if waste heat from thermal systems, for example from a cogeneration system, is used to power them because they can operate with low levels of thermal energy. One of the main problems with adsorption heat pumps is that large heat transfer areas are required because of the small thermal conductivity of the adsorbent bed which is composed of solid adsorbent particles. This causes problems related to the performance, cost, and scale of such heat pumps. Tube plate reactors (both adsorber and desorber) have been proposed to solve these problems. The fins on the tube plate of these reactors are intended to enhance heat transfer and COP, and such reactors could be more compact than others. In addition, in order to adjust batch time and to deal with load fluctuation, heat storage capacity is increased by making the adsorbent bed thicker. To design heat pumps which fulfill these potentials, the mechanism of heat transfer at the adsorbent bed must be formulated. The authors believe the diameter of the adsorbent particles is important, and we conducted adsorption and desorption experiments with various kinds of adsorbent beds made with different sizes of adsorbent particles. This paper reports on these experiments. The concept of equivalent thermal conductivity λ is defined, and is obtained through the experiment data and simulations for each adsorbent bed. Conclusions on the most appropriate size of adsorbent particles and equivalent thermal conductivity λ are presented. A thermal design of a reactor is also performed, and finally the effect of the fin pitch and bed thickness on COP and the projected area estimated to be required for heat transfer are discussed quantitatively.
Index Keywords: Adsorbents; Chemical reactors; Fins (heat exchange); Heat transfer; Particles (particulate matter); Refrigerants; Refrigerators; Silica gel; Thermal conductivity; Tubes (components); Water; Zeolites; Adsorbent beds; Adsorbent particles; Adsorption heat pumps; Adsorption refrigerators; Coefficient of performance; Equivalent thermal conductivity; Heat storage capacity; Tube plate adsorption reactors; Water-silica gel pair; Heat pump systems

Authors: Himran S., Suwono A., Mansoori G.A.
Title: Characterization of alkanes and paraffin waxes for application as phase change energy storage medium
Affiliations: Inter-University Center, Pusat Antar University, Bandung Institute of Technology, Jalan Tamansari 126, Bandung, Indonesia; Chemical Engineering Department, University of Illinois, 810 South Clinton Street, Chicago, IL, 60607-7000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Himran, S., Inter-University Center, Pusat Antar University, Bandung Institute of Technology, Jalan Tamansari 126, Bandung, Indonesia; Suwono, A., Inter-University Center, Pusat Antar University, Bandung Institute of Technology, Jalan Tamansari 126, Bandung, Indonesia; Mansoori, G.A., Chemical Engineering Department, University of Illinois, 810 South Clinton Street, Chicago, IL, 60607-7000, United States
Abstract: Latent thermal energy storage is one of the favorable kinds of thermal energy storage methods considered for renewable energy source utilization, as in solar photothermal systems. Heat is stored mostly by means of the latent heat of phase change of the medium. The temperature of the medium remains more or less constant during the phase transition. A large number of materials have been identified for low, intermediate, and high operating temperatures for application as latent thermal energy storage media. In the present paper a method for characterization of alkanes (C1,-C100) and paraffin waxes for application as the low-temperature (298-323 K) phase change energy storage medium is introduced. A computational technique is introduced by which the alkanes and paraffin waxes could be evaluated, and possibly upgraded, as the phase change energy storage media. It is demonstrated that the family of n-alkanes has a large spectrum of latent heats, melting points, densities, and specific heats so that the heat storage designer has a good choice of n-alkanes as storage materials for any particular low-temperature thermal energy storage application. As an example of the proposed method, a particular paraffin wax for which appropriate experimental data are available is analyzed and the results of the analysis are presented. © 1994 Taylor and Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Alkanes; Energy storage medium; Paraffin waxes
Index Keywords: Characterization; Computational methods; Density (specific gravity); Materials testing; Paraffin waxes; Paraffins; Renewable energy resources; Specific heat of solids; Phase change energy storage medium; Heat storage

Authors: Mock J.E., Jelacic A.J., Dorr P.M.
Title: National Advanced Drilling and Excavation Technologies (NADET) Program: A New Collaborative Research and Development Initiative
Affiliations: U.S. DOE
Authors with affiliations: Mock, J.E., U.S. DOE; Jelacic, A.J., U.S. DOE; Dorr, P.M., U.S. DOE
Abstract: Geothermal energy, heat energy stored in the earth, is exploited for the generation of environmentally clean, reliable electric power and for direct heat applications such as space and water heating, aquaculture and agricultural operations, enhanced oil recovery, mining, and industrial processing. With 2800 megawatts of installed electric capacity generating 15 billion kilowatt-hours per year and 18 trillion Btu per year utilized in direct-heat applications in the U.S., expanded market penetration is often hampered by higher costs associated with geothermal energy development. A significant portion of these higher costs is directly or indirectly dependent on drilling wells to discover, delineate, and produce geothermal resources. The Geothermal Division of the U.S. Department of Energy has proposed a national R&D initiative involving government, national laboratory, industry, and academic stakeholders to develop less costly ways of penetrating rock. The goal of this proposed program is to develop an advanced and innovative drilling system by the year 2000 for use by the geothermal industry and other industry sectors including oil and gas, mining, underground storage, and civil infrastructure.
Index Keywords: Excavation; Technology; Excavation technologies; Geothermal energy potential; Innovative drilling system; National advanced drilling; Geothermal wells

Authors: Hoffman P.
Title: Hydrogen-the optimum chemical fuel
Authors with affiliations: Hoffman, P.
Abstract: The preceding paper showed that despite the broad desirability of fusion as a base-load energy source it is necessary to implement a manufactured chemical fuel for energy transport, storage and as a transportation fuel. In this paper it will be shown that hydrogen is certainly the optimum, and maybe the only, choice for the chemical fuel. The fuel use properties of hydrogen will be reviewed along with its detailed chemical and physical properties. © 1994.
Index Keywords: Energy resources; Energy storage; Fusion reactions; Physical properties; Transportation; Chemical properties; Fusion energy system; Manufactured chemical fuel; Hydrogen fuels

Authors: Anis W.R., Abdul-Sadek Nour M.
Title: Switching model photovoltaic pumping system
Affiliations: Electronic and Communication Department, Faculty of Engineering, Ain Shams University, 1 Sarayat Street, Abbasia, Cairo Egypt; Yanbu Industrial College, Electronic Department, P.O. Box 30436, Yanbu AL-sinaiyah 21477, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Anis, W.R., Electronic and Communication Department, Faculty of Engineering, Ain Shams University, 1 Sarayat Street, Abbasia, Cairo Egypt; Abdul-Sadek Nour, M., Yanbu Industrial College, Electronic Department, P.O. Box 30436, Yanbu AL-sinaiyah 21477, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) pumping systems are widely used due to their simplicity, high reliability and low cost. A directly-coupled PV pumping system is the most reliable and least-cost PV system. The d.c. motor-pump group is not, however, working at its optimum operating point. A battery buffered PV pumping system introduces a battery between the PV array and the d.c. motor-pump group to ensure that the motor-pump group is operating at its optimum point. The size of the battery storage depends on system economics. If the battery is fully charged while solar radiation is available, the battery will discharge through the load while the PV array is disconnected. Hence, a power loss takes place. To overcome the above mentioned difficulty, a switched mode PV pumping is proposed. When solar radiation is available and the battery is fully charged, the battery is disconnected and the d.c. motor-pump group is directly coupled to the PV array. To avoid excessive operating voltage for the motor, a part of the PV array is switched off to reduce the voltage. As a result, the energy loss is significantly eliminated. Detailed analysis of the proposed system shows that the discharged water increases by about 10% when compared with a conventional battery-buffered system. The system transient performance just after the switching moment shows that the system returns to a steady state in short period. The variations in the system parameters lie within 1% of the rated values. © 1994.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); DC motors; Electric energy storage; Solar radiation; Systems analysis; Transients; Switched mode photovoltaic (PV) pumping system; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Dienhart H., Siegel A.
Title: Hydrogen storage in isolated electrical energy systems with photovoltaic and wind energy
Affiliations: DLR-Institute for Technical Thermodynamics, System Analysis and Technology Assessment, Pfaffenwaldring 38-40, D-70569 Stuttgart 80, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dienhart, H., DLR-Institute for Technical Thermodynamics, System Analysis and Technology Assessment, Pfaffenwaldring 38-40, D-70569 Stuttgart 80, Germany; Siegel, A., DLR-Institute for Technical Thermodynamics, System Analysis and Technology Assessment, Pfaffenwaldring 38-40, D-70569 Stuttgart 80, Germany
Abstract: Within the Saudi-German project HYSOLAR, system studies have been done to identify potential applications of solar hydrogen. This paper presents an economic system design of autonomous grids including hydrogen storage (made up of an electrolyser, pressure storage and a fuel cell). A renewable energy supply (photovoltaic, wind energy converter) is used to match the electrical load of an island community. The effects of different weather conditions and share of PV/wind energy production on system design are investigated. Overall electricity costs are calculated for different financial parameters. Electricity costs depend strongly on intensity and profile of weather and type of converter, which makes a careful investigation of the optimal mixture of PV/wind power necessary. Even if the calculated electricity costs indicate economically feasible situations, much work is still to be done in order to optimize the system configuration and to demonstrate hydrogen storage working reliably in isolated grids. © 1993.
Index Keywords: Electric power systems; Fossil fuels; Renewable energy resources; Simulation; Solar energy; Systems analysis; Wind power; Autonomous grids; Energy storage

Authors: Matteazzi P., Fame G., Randi G., Leoni M.
Title: Stretch formability in hsla and if steel
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Scienze e Tecnologie Chimiche, Università di Udine, 1-3100, Udine, Italy; Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, Istituto di Chimica Fisica Applicata dei Materiali, Lungobisagno Istria 34, 1-6141, Genova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Matteazzi, P., Dipartimento di Scienze e Tecnologie Chimiche, Università di Udine, 1-3100, Udine, Italy; Fame, G., Dipartimento di Scienze e Tecnologie Chimiche, Università di Udine, 1-3100, Udine, Italy; Randi, G., Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, Istituto di Chimica Fisica Applicata dei Materiali, Lungobisagno Istria 34, 1-6141, Genova, Italy; Leoni, M., Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, Istituto di Chimica Fisica Applicata dei Materiali, Lungobisagno Istria 34, 1-6141, Genova, Italy
Abstract: Stretch formability of steel sheets can be evaluated by the strain hardening exponent. Cold rolled High Strength Low Alloy (HSLA) and Interstitial Free (IF) steels having different compositions and processing histories have been studied. Steels were subjected to controlled strains and the values of strain hardening exponents, microstrains and residual stresses were measured. It was found that a linear correlation exists between residual stresses and the strain hardening exponents. A possible mechanism for work hardening in the presence of misoriented grains is proposed taking in account the storage of elastic strain energy and the dislocation movements. A strain interval (10-15%) is proposed for stretch forming operations to minimize residual stresses. © 1994 by Marcel Dekker, Inc.
Index Keywords: Metal forming; Residual stresses; Strain control; Stresses; Interstitial free (IF) steels; Strain hardening; Stretch formability; Steel

Authors: Herrmann M.R., Ciappa M., Schenk A.
Title: Long term charge loss in EPROMs with ONO interpoly dielectric
Affiliations: Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Herrmann, M.R., Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland; Ciappa, M., Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland; Schenk, A., Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: Charge loss through ONO dielectric is limited by the oxide conductivity. The leakage current is too large to be explained by pure electron injection from the floating gate through the bottom oxide. A trap-assisted model is proposed wherein electrons tunnel to oxide traps and are then emitted. The coupling of the trap level to oxide phonons results in virtual energy levels in the oxide which allow more effective tunneling paths. Holes do not participate, because they are blocked by the top oxide. It has been verified that charge loss is not due to mobile ions.
Index Keywords: Charge loss; EPROM; ONO interpoly dielectric; Oxide traps; Trap assisted model; Dielectric films; Electric charge; Electric conductivity; Electric losses; Electron energy levels; Electron tunneling; Leakage currents; Mathematical models; Oxides; Phonons; Semiconductor device structures; Semiconductor storage; PROM

Authors: Kauranen P.S., Lund P.D., Vanhanen J.P.
Title: Development of a self-sufficient solar-hydrogen energy system
Affiliations: Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Kauranen, P.S., Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland; Lund, P.D., Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland; Vanhanen, J.P., Helsinki University of Technology, Department of Technical Physics, SF-02150 Espoo, Finland
Abstract: This paper describes the status of a photovoltaic hydrogen energy system development project at Helsinki University of Technology at the end of June 1992. The objective of the project is to demonstrate the technical feasibility of a 100% self-sufficient energy system based on solar photovoltaics (PV) and hydrogen technology. Basically, PV electricity is used to produce electrolytic hydrogen, which is stored over the season to be converted back to electricity in a fuel cell. The pilot plant has been designed for a 1-2 kWh day-1 constant electric load in the climate of Helsinki (60°N). The work so far has included component and subsystem testing, as well as optimization of the total system and its control through comprehensive numerical modelling. Experimental results are given for the electrolyser performance as well as for a 1 month operation of the hydrogen production subsystem. The numerical simulation shows excellent agreement with measurements and is used to predict the pilot plant performance over a 1 year time period. © 1993.

Authors: Kimura Mikihiro, Koyama Hiroshi
Title: Stress-induced low-level leakage mechanism in ultrathin silicon dioxide films caused by neutral oxide trap generation
Affiliations: Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Hyogo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kimura, Mikihiro, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Hyogo, Japan; Koyama, Hiroshi, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Hyogo, Japan
Abstract: Stress-induced low-level leakage current in ultrathin silicon dioxide films is correlated with neutral oxide trap generation based on first-order kinetics. The conduction mechanism is explained by Fowler-Nordheim tunneling from the leakage spot, generated at the cathode interface, to the neutral oxide trap level, lower in energy than the SiO2 barrier height.

Authors: Williams G.J., Jenkins G.J., Rose M.F.
Title: Preliminary design of a space propulsion system utilizing stored thermal energy
Affiliations: Auburn University, Auburn, AL, 36849, United States; Department of Aerospace Engineering, United States; The Space Power Institute, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williams, G.J., Auburn University, Auburn, AL, 36849, United States, Department of Aerospace Engineering, United States; Jenkins, G.J., Auburn University, Auburn, AL, 36849, United States, Department of Aerospace Engineering, United States; Rose, M.F., Auburn University, Auburn, AL, 36849, United States, The Space Power Institute, United States
Abstract: A space propulsion system utilizing stored thermal energy is analyzed with emphasis on the preliminary design of the heat exchanger and on the general performance of engines incorporating this concept. A highenergy propellant is developed by heat transfer from a phase-change material (Si) to a low-density gas (H2) through a concentric cylinder heat exchanger. The phase-change material is heated by a radioisotope (PoGd) over a period of time which is significantly longer than the firing time. It is shown that such an engine can most efficiently operate just above and just below a propellant flow regime defined by gradual flow transition in the heat exchanger. Two designs are developed to illustrate each distinct operating scenario. A 10-N engine utilizing laminar flow is shown to be an attractive alternative to chemical and electric systems for the maneuvering of a vehicle in the vicinity of a larger space structure. A 450-N engine utilizing primarily turbulent heat transfer is shown to be an alternative to other systems for orbit transfer. Rapid cooling of the thermal storage material in the entrance region of the heat exchanger, which can be mitigated by varying the flow area or increasing the length of the engine, is a primary limitation on an engine utilizing thermal storage. © 1993 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.

Authors: Baring-Gould Edward, Manwell James F., Jeffries William Q., Stein William M.
Title: Experimental validation of the university of Massachusetts wind/ diesel system simulation code, HYBRID1
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baring-Gould, Edward, Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; Manwell, James F., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; Jeffries, William Q., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States; Stein, William M., Univ of Massachusetts, Amherst, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the recent progress in the experimental validation of the wind/diesel hybrid power system simulation code, HYBRID1. The code was developed by the Renewable Energy Research Laboratory to elucidate the performance of a variety of wind/diesel and hybrid power system configurations. HYBRID1 is a combined probabilistic/time series model designed to study systems comprised of one or more diesel generators, one or more wind turbines, and (optionally) battery storage and an array of photovoltaic cells. Four different operating strategies have been considered, two of which use storage, and two of which do not., The validation effort consisted first of upgrading RERL's existing wind/diesel system simulator to allow a wide range of tests to be carried out. A series of tests were then performed and the results compared to the corresponding predications from the model., The paper describes in detail the upgrades made to the wind/diesel system simulator, the test conditions, and comparisons with the model's predictions, including the effects of the different operating strategies for a single diesel and wind turbine. The focus of ongoing work, which involves comparisons using multiple wind turbines and diesel generators, is also discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Diesel engines; Probability; Renewable energy resources; Time series analysis; Wind turbines; Software package HYBRID1; Wind power

Authors: Bollmeier II Warren S., Huang Ning, Trenka Andrew R.
Title: Wind/pumped-hydro integration and test project: preliminary system test results
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Pacific Int Cent for High Technology, Research, Honolulu, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bollmeier II, Warren S., Pacific Int Cent for High Technology, Research, Honolulu, United States; Huang, Ning, Pacific Int Cent for High Technology, Research, Honolulu, United States; Trenka, Andrew R., Pacific Int Cent for High Technology, Research, Honolulu, United States
Abstract: On Hawaii and other islands, the penetration of windpower has been limited partly due its intermittent and fluctuating nature. It has been postulated that wind power penetration could be increased if it can be 'smoothed' or 'firmed.' Addition of storage components, such as pumped-hydro and a battery, is being investigated as a possible solution on the 'Wind/Pumped-Hydro Integration and Test (WPHIT)' project. WPHIT was initiated by the Pacific center for High Technology Research in April 1992 at the Renewable Energy Storage and Test Facility on the Kahua Ranch, Island of Hawaii, in cooperation with the state of Hawaii's Department of Business, Economic Development and Tourism, Hawaiian Electric Light Company, Hawaii Natural Energy Institute and Kahua Ranch Limited. The specific objectives are to develop and utilize the REST Facility to: simulate utility-scale applications, investigate alternative system architectures, operational modes and control strategies, and demonstrate techniques for power smoothing and firm power delivery. The first year's activities are summarized, including the conceptual design of a utility-scale (20 MW) WPHIT and the results of small scale component and preliminary system testes at the REST Facility.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Pumps; Renewable energy resources; Testing; Water power; REST facility; Wind/pumped-hydro integration; Wind power

Authors: Kinoshita K., R. Landgrebe A.
Title: Analysis of power and energy for fuel cell systems
Affiliations: Energy and Environment Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Office of Transportation Technologies, US Department of Energy, Washington, DC 20585, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kinoshita, K., Energy and Environment Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; R. Landgrebe, A., Office of Transportation Technologies, US Department of Energy, Washington, DC 20585, United States
Abstract: The relationship between power and energy for a fuel cell system consisting of a fuel cell stack and reactant storage subsystem, and operating at constant power or variable power, was analyzed. The characteristic parameters of the fuel cell stack and the reactant subsystem are considered to be independent variables, which are functions of the power and energy of the fuel cell cystem, respectively. Mathematical expressions were derived for determining the minimum weight of the fuel cell system when the cells operate at constant power and the cell voltage varies linearly with the current density. The relationship between the weight of a fuel cell system and variable power levels was also determined. These mathematical models were used to analyze the experimental results reported in the literature for an alkaline fuel cell and a polymer electrolyte fuel cell. © 1994.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electricity; Mathematical models; Polyelectrolytes; Systems analysis; Fuel cell stack; Reactant storage subsystem; Fuel cells

Authors: Yasillo N.J., Mintzer R.A., Aarsvold J.N., Matthews K.L., Heimsath S.J., Ordonez C.E., Pan X., Wu C., Block T.A., Beck R.N., Chen C.-T., Cooper M.
Title: Single-tube miniature gamma camera
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yasillo, N.J., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Mintzer, R.A., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Aarsvold, J.N., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Matthews, K.L., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Heimsath, S.J., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Ordonez, C.E., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Pan, X., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Wu, C., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Block, T.A., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Beck, R.N., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Chen, C.-T., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States; Cooper, M., Univ of Chicago, Chicago, United States
Abstract: In certain medical gamma imaging applications, conventional cameras are too large for practical use. To address these situations, we have constructed a clinically usable miniature gamma camera for photon energies up to 160 keV. The camera has outer dimensions of 92 mm × 92 mm × 190 mm and weighs 5 kg. Included in that mass is a collimator, an internal high-voltage power supply, and all shielding. The camera also has a position-sensitive photomultiplier tube (PSPMT) coupled to an 8-mm thick NaI(Tl) crystal; this crystal/tube combination provides signals to internal processing circuits. External electronics and analog-to-digital conversion circuits are connected to a Macintosh Quadra computer where additional processing, storage, and display of the signals takes place. Because the PSPMT has non-uniform energy response that results in geometric distortion if conventional position-arithmetic calculations are used, we have implemented a maximum-likelihood position-estimation calculation that produces undistorted images. The present version of the camera has a usable field of view of 48 mm × 48 mm and an intrinsic spatial resolution of 2.4 to 3.8 mm full width at half maximum.
Index Keywords: Analog to digital conversion; Computers; Crystals; Data storage equipment; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electronic equipment; Estimation; Medical imaging; Optical collimators; Shielding; Signal processing; Internal high voltage power supply; Internal processing circuits; Macintosh quadra computer; Position sensitive photomultiplier tube; Single tube miniature gamma camera; X ray cameras; Internal high voltage power supply; Internal processing circuits; Macintosh quadra computer; Position sensitive photomultiplier tube; Single tube miniature gamma camera

Authors: Dell'Acqua A., Alippi C., Appelquist G., Benetta R., Berglund S., Bezemat J., Blouzon F., Bohm C., Breveglieri L., Brigati S., Carlson P., Cattaneo P., Dadda L., David J., Engstrom M.
Title: Digital front-end readout MIcrosystem for calorimeters at LHC
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Dell'Acqua, A., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Alippi, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Appelquist, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Benetta, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Berglund, S., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Bezemat, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Blouzon, F., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Bohm, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Breveglieri, L., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Brigati, S., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Carlson, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Cattaneo, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Dadda, L., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; David, J., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Engstrom, M., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: The Front-End Read-out MIcrosystem (FERMI) for calorimeters at LHC presented last year has been further developed with the aim to achieve a full silicon implementation early 1994. Each microsystem will, as before, contain 9 channels with 15-16 bits dynamic range using 10-bit AD converters sampled every 15 ns. The function is accomplished by using a non-linear amplifier in front of the ADC to compress high amplitude signals, reversing the transformation to obtain overall linearity in a look-up table after the digitisation. The direct first-level trigger output for digitally filtered energy data is equipped with pulse recognition capability. The main data flow enters a pipeline memory from which relevant portions are extracted to second and third-level triggers via an adaptive 7-tap digital filter. The module is presently developed as 14 ASICs to be mounted on a silicon substrate (Multi-chip module, MCM). Circuit solutions to all analogue parts have already been implemented, tested and found to conform to specifications. The first digital ASIC will shortly be sent to fabrication. Fault tolerance strategies, i.e. redundancy, reconfigurability, concurrent processing and error corrections have been defined and integrated into the design.

Authors: Martin J.B., Knoll G.F., Wehe D.K., Dogan N., Gormley J.E.
Title: Imaging multi-energy gamma-ray fields with a compton scatter camera
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Martin, J.B., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Knoll, G.F., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Wehe, D.K., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Dogan, N., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Gormley, J.E., Univ of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Abstract: Multi-energy gamma-ray fields have been imaged with a ring Compton scatter camera (RCC). The RCC is intended for industrial applications, where there is a need to image multiple gamma-ray lines from spatially extended sources. To our knowledge, the ability of a Compton scatter camera to perform this task had not previously been demonstrated. Gamma rays with different incident energies are distinguished based on the total energy deposited in the camera elements. For multiple gamma-ray lines, separate images are generated for each line energy. Random coincidences and other interfering interactions have been investigated. Camera response has been characterized for energies from 0.511 to 2.75 MeV. Different gamma-ray lines from extended sources have been measured and images reconstructed using both direct and iterative algorithms.

Authors: Budnick J.
Title: Ignitron-based tune-jump power supply/magnet
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: Indiana Univ Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Budnick, J., Indiana Univ Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, United States
Abstract: A flexible, fast pulsed power supply/magnet system for general accelerator physics studies was developed using an ignitron switch tube topology and a ferrite, Panofsky picture-frame magnet. For modest jitter applications the ignitron approach gives considerable benefits in supply simplicity and ruggedness. Use of commercially available stackable high-voltage diodes simplifies circuit design for the high-voltage to low-voltage transition after current ramp-up. By using parallelled energy storage capacitors the supply can be easily adjusted to meet a wide variety of magnet inductance and current risetime requirements. Following a similar philosophy, the magnet was designed with easily changeable winding interconnections. This allows for considerable configuration flexibility, allowing use as a horizontal dipole, vertical dipole, or quadrupole; higher order sextupoles and octupoles have also been modeled in POISSON. The magnet and system have been successfully used in several accelerator physics runs, meeting all design expectations.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric currents; Electric network topology; Electric windings; Magnets; Mathematical models; Mercury vapor rectifiers; Particle accelerators; Synchrotrons; Circuit design; Fast current ramp-up; Ignitron; Ignitron switch tube topology; POISSON; Power supply/magnet system; Slow current decay; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Circuit design; Fast current ramp-up; Ignitron; Ignitron switch tube topology; POISSON; Power supply/magnet system; Slow current decay

Authors: Ohgaki H., Noguchi T., Sugiyama S., Yamazaki T., Mikado T., Chiwaki M., Yamada K., Suzuki R., Sei N.
Title: Linearly polarized quasi-monochromatic photon beams from compton backscattering of laser lights at ETL
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohgaki, H., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Japan; Noguchi, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Japan; Sugiyama, S., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Japan; Yamazaki, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Japan; Mikado, T., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Japan; Chiwaki, M., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Japan; Yamada, K., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Japan; Suzuki, R., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Japan; Sei, N., Electrotechnical Lab, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: Linearly polarized quasi-monochromatic photons have been generated by Compton backscattering of linearly polarized laser beams against the relativistic electrons in a storage ring. The polarized photon energy ranges from 1 to 20 MeV by using the Nd:YAG laser and the 250-750 MeV electron storage ring TERAS at ETL. When we change the laser polarization axis in a high repetition rate to change the polarization axis of the Compton backscattering photon, we can measure the polarization of the Compton backscattering photon with a single detector. The polarization of the backscattering photon beam has been measured with a Compton polarimeter consisting of a single detector. Almost completely polarized photon beam can be confirmed with this system.

Title: The combi heat store- a combined rock cavern/borehole heat store
Source title: Tunnelling and Underground Space Technology incorporating Trenchless

Box 108, SF-02151 Espoo, Finland; Sellberg, B., Björn Sellberg, Swedish Council for Building Research (BFR), P.O. Box 12866, S-11298 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: Since 1988, Sweden and Finland have collaborated bilaterally on thermal energy storage with respect to information exchange and collaborative R&D projects. The two countries have both investigated underground thermal energy storage for nearly two decades, and have similar bedrock-the Fenno-Scandian granitic rocks. This paper reviews the work performed in the field of combined rock cavern and borehole heat stores, concerned with construction technology, costs and design principles. One example is an asymmetric store, in the form of 40- to 60-m-long horizontal boreholes between two rock caverns, with the caverns themselves comprising only about 10% of the total storage volume. This design has a specific cost of $US0.40 million/ GWh and $US0.24 million/ GWh for storage capacities of 6 GWh and 36 GWh, respectively. Half of the total construction cost relates to the rock cavern part of the store. © 1994.

Authors: Mwendera E.J., Feyen J.
Title: Effects of tillage and rainfall on soil surface roughness and properties
Affiliations: Institute for Land and Water Management, Faculty of Agricultural Sciences, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven (K.U. Leuven), Vital Decosterstraat 102, 3000 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Mwendera, E.J., Institute for Land and Water Management, Faculty of Agricultural Sciences, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven (K.U. Leuven), Vital Decosterstraat 102, 3000 Leuven, Belgium; Feyen, J., Institute for Land and Water Management, Faculty of Agricultural Sciences, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven (K.U. Leuven), Vital Decosterstraat 102, 3000 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: The effects of tillage and rainfall on soil surface changes were investigated by subjecting ploughed, harrowed, rolled, and untilled plots of a silt loam soil (Typic Hapludalf) to five 150-min simulated rainstorms. The storms were applied every 24 hours at a constant rain intensity of 70 mm·h-1. The soil parameters studied were random roughness, bulk density, and total porosity. After 875 mm of rainfall, random roughness degraded to constant values of 3.7, 1.5, and 0.8 cm below the initial values for the ploughed, harrowed, and rolled treatments, respectively. Bulk density increased by 0.16, 0.26, 0.15, and 0.08 g·cm-3, while total porosity decreased by 0.08, 0.13, 0.07, and 0.03 cm3·cm-3 for the ploughed, harrowed, rolled, and untilled treatments, respectively. Ploughing produced a rough surface that withstood rainfall energy while harrowing, and rolling produced smoother and less resistant surfaces. The results showed that, under rainfall conditions similar to those studied here, a ploughed soil is likely to maintain high water storage capacity on the surface without appreciable runoff or soil loss while overtillage may have deleterious effects on both soil and water conservation. Regression equations to predict changes in surface roughness, bulk density, and total porosity due to rainfall were developed. The equations can be incorporated in soil water balance and hydrological models for cultivated fields. © 1994.
Author Keywords: Rainfall, effect on soil surface; Soil surface properties; Soil surface roughness; Tillage, effect on soil surface

Authors: Banwart S., Gustafsson E., Laaksoharju M., Nilsson A.‐C., Tullborg E.‐L., Wallin B.
Title: Large‐scale Intrusion of shallow water into a vertical fracture zone in crystalline bedrock: Initial hydrochemical perturbation during tunnel construction at the Äspö Hard Rock Laboratory, southeastern Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Banwart, S.; Gustafsson, E.; Laaksoharju, M.; Nilsson, A.‐C.; Tullborg, E.‐L.; Wallin, B.
Abstract: On March 13, 1991, construction of the entrance tunnel to the Äspö Hard Rock Laboratory opened a vertical fracture zone at a depth of 70 m. This provides an opportunity to study geochemical changes resulting from shallow water inflow into a crystalline bedrock aquifer as anticipated during construction and operation of a deep repository for spent nuclear fuel. Chloride ion is a natural conservative tracer for mixing between the dilute ([Cl−] < 10 mg L−1) shallow groundwater and the saline ([Cl−] = 5000 mg L−1) native groundwater of the fracture zone. A sharp dilution front, corresponding to 80% dilution of the native groundwater, indicated arrival of shallow groundwater in the entrance tunnel after 3 weeks. In spite of this large input of shallow water, the fracture zone remains predominantly anoxic. Major element hydrochemistry and carbon and oxygen stable isotope data indicate large inputs of alkalinity and biogenic CO2(g). Input of organic carbon with shallow groundwater provides a possible energy and carbon source for anaerobic respiration. There is no evidence for sulfate reduction, and Fe(III) oxyhydroxide fracture minerals are the only other dominant electron acceptor observed. Copyright 1994 by the American Geophysical Union.
Index Keywords: Bedrock; Construction; Fractures; Radioactive Wastes; Tunnels; Water Influx; Crystalline Rocks; Fracture Zones; Intrusive Rocks; Storage; Tunnelling; Sweden, Aspo Hard Rock Laboratory

Authors: Mihailović D.T., Jeftić M.
Title: An efficient but simple biophysical scheme UNICOS for use in different scale atmospheric models
Affiliations: Department of Meteorology, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Novi Sad, 21000 Novi Sad
Authors with affiliations: Mihailović, D.T., Department of Meteorology, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Novi Sad, 21000 Novi Sad; Jeftić, M., Department of Meteorology, Faculty of Agriculture, University of Novi Sad, 21000 Novi Sad
Abstract: This paper is a description of the biophysical scheme named UNICOS, which has been developed with the joint efforts of University of Novi Sad and Colorado State University. The scheme is designed as a software package which can be run as part of an atmospheric model or a stand-alone model. For the physical and biological model backgrounds we have chosen so a "sandwich" representation of single layer approach. The model has seven prognostic variables: temperature for the canopy vegetation, temperature for both the ground cover and soil surface; two interception water stores (one for canopy and one for the ground cover); and three soil moisture storage variables. All these variables fully determine: mass, energy and momentum transfer across the lower part of atmosphere. The net radiation absorbed by the canopy is partitioned into sensible, latent heat and storage terms. From these equations temperature for both the ground cover and soil surface is solved by an implicit scheme. The soil model part is designed as a three-layer isothermal model which is used to describe the vertical transfer of water in the soil. The energy terms in the energy balance equation are calculated using resistance representation. For the foregoing calculations we completed aerodynamic characteristics in accordance with "K-theory". Then, these values are used in the calculation of three aerodynamic resistances for transfer of heat and moisture from the canopy to reference height. In parameterization of evapotranspiration the three surface resistances are calculated. Finally, the performance of the designed scheme is tested in one point by time integrations using real data. The set used for 18 August 1988 at the experimental site in De Sinderhoeve (The Netherlands) was a part of flux measurements over maize field. However, for more general conclusion about quality of scheme additional tests with the high quality data sets are needed. © 1994.
Author Keywords: Atmospheric models; energy exchanges; Environmental modeling; Land-air parameterization; Mass

Authors: Just T.
Title: Settlements as sources of pollution in the watershed of the Želivka drinking water storage reservoir in the Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Just, T.
Abstract: In 1991-1992 the T.G.M. Water Research Institute, Prague, carried out systematic research on the watershed of the drinking water reservoir of the river Želivka to gain data for planning protection of this resource. The register of concentrated pollution sources, including an inventory of the shortcomings and suitable protection measures, reflect the general bad state of the reservoir and the intensity of the pollution. They show that single investments of a technical character are not sufficient to sustain the drinking water resource. In addition, they are not always effective and also usually make great demands on energy resources. It is therefore necessary to introduce a suitable method for the entire watershed, including an appropriate way of life for the inhabitants. © 1994.

Authors: Kulkarni A., Sant G., Krishnayya J.G.
Title: Urbanization in search of energy in three Indian cities
Affiliations: Systems Research Institute, Energy Research Group, 17 A Gultekdi, Pune, 411 037, India
Authors with affiliations: Kulkarni, A., Systems Research Institute, Energy Research Group, 17 A Gultekdi, Pune, 411 037, India; Sant, G., Systems Research Institute, Energy Research Group, 17 A Gultekdi, Pune, 411 037, India; Krishnayya, J.G., Systems Research Institute, Energy Research Group, 17 A Gultekdi, Pune, 411 037, India
Abstract: In the summer of 1989 a survey was conducted to collect data on household-energy consumption in Indian cities. The survey was conducted in three urban areas of varying sizes. The end-uses considered were cooking, water heating, lighting, air cooling, entertainment, cold storage, and washing/laundry. The surveys involved examination of the types and quantities of energy used to satisfy each of these services. The survey sample in each of the three cities was broken down by income group, allowing for a careful examination of the influence of household income on lifestyle patterns and related energy use choices. Among the houses surveyed were 75 households in Pune, India, that took part in a 1982 household energy study as well. The re-surveying process allowed for an analysis of longitudinal changes in residential energy use. Based on the survey findings, a number of recommendations are provided for improving the provision and use of energy in urban households in India. © 1994.

Authors: Raha S., Dalal B., Biswas S., Biswas B.B.
Title: Myo-inositol trisphosphate-mediated calcium release from internal stores of Entamoeba histolytica
Affiliations: Department of Biophysics, Molecular Biology and Genetics, Calcutta University, 92, A.P.C. Road, Calcutta, 700 009, India; Department of Biochemistry, Bose Institute, Centenary Building, P-1/12, C.I.T. Scheme VII-M, Calcutta 700 054, India
Authors with affiliations: Raha, S., Department of Biophysics, Molecular Biology and Genetics, Calcutta University, 92, A.P.C. Road, Calcutta, 700 009, India; Dalal, B., Department of Biochemistry, Bose Institute, Centenary Building, P-1/12, C.I.T. Scheme VII-M, Calcutta 700 054, India; Biswas, S., Department of Biochemistry, Bose Institute, Centenary Building, P-1/12, C.I.T. Scheme VII-M, Calcutta 700 054, India; Biswas, B.B., Department of Biophysics, Molecular Biology and Genetics, Calcutta University, 92, A.P.C. Road, Calcutta, 700 009, India, Department of Biochemistry, Bose Institute, Centenary Building, P-1/12, C.I.T. Scheme VII-M, Calcutta 700 054, India
Abstract: Calcium mobilisation from internal stores of the parasitic protozoan Entamoeba histolytica was studied by fluorescence measurements of the calcium indicator quin 2 and 45Ca2+ incorporation studies in saponin-permeabilised amoebae. Prior energy-dependent calcium sequestration was found to be necessary for subsequent release of calcium by inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (Ins(1,4,5)P3). Both Ins(1,4,5)P3 and inositol 2,4,5-trisphosphate (Ins(2,4,5)P3) could release calcium equally well from permeabilised E. histolytica with similar EC50 (concentration which produced half maximal release) values for calcium release. Ins(1,4,5)P3-mediated calcium release occurred from a vesicular store, was sensitive to prior treatment by heparin and was attenuated by prior addition of a lower concentration of Ins(1,4,5)P3. cAMP failed to influence inositol trisphosphate induced calcium release, indicating the absence of control mechanisms through cAMP-dependent phosphorylation. GTP neither induced calcium release nor could potentiate inositol trisphosphate mediated calcium mobilisation. A saturating concentration of Ins(1,4,5)P3 could release 50% of radiolabelled calcium sequestered by energy-dependent mechanisms in E. histolytica. The energy-dependent calcium sequestration was inhibited by vanadate and the calcium antagonist Diltiazem but not by dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCCD), suggesting the involvement of an endoplasmic reticulum-like structure in calcium storage. Binding studies showed specific association of [3H]Ins(1,4,5)P3 to crude membrane fractions of E. histolytica, which was significantly inhibited by heparin in a dose-dependent manner. IC50 (concentration which produced half-maximal inhibition) values for displacement of radiolabelled Ins(1,4,5)P3 binding by unlabelled Ins(1,4,5)P3 and Ins(2,4,5)P3 were estimated to be 0.99 μM for both isomers. Our results suggested that Ins(1,4,5)P4-mediated calcium release from internal stores of E. histolytica most probably occurred in an inositol trisphosphate receptor-dependent manner. © 1994.

Authors: Gin S., Godon N., Mestre J.P., Vernaz E.Y., Beaufort D.
Title: Experimental investigation of aqueous corrosion of R7T7 nuclear glass at 90°C in the presence of organic species
Affiliations: Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique (CEA), Rhône Valley Research Center, DPR, B.P. 171, 30207 Bagnols-sur-Cèze Cedex, France; Université de Poitiers, URA CNRS 721, LPAH, 20 avenue du Recteur Pineau, 86000 Poitiers, France
Authors with affiliations: Gin, S., Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique (CEA), Rhône Valley Research Center, DPR, B.P. 171, 30207 Bagnols-sur-Cèze Cedex, France; Godon, N., Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique (CEA), Rhône Valley Research Center, DPR, B.P. 171, 30207 Bagnols-sur-Cèze Cedex, France; Mestre, J.P., Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique (CEA), Rhône Valley Research Center, DPR, B.P. 171, 30207 Bagnols-sur-Cèze Cedex, France; Vernaz, E.Y., Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique (CEA), Rhône Valley Research Center, DPR, B.P. 171, 30207 Bagnols-sur-Cèze Cedex, France; Beaufort, D., Université de Poitiers, URA CNRS 721, LPAH, 20 avenue du Recteur Pineau, 86000 Poitiers, France
Abstract: The initial dissolution kinetics of the French "R7T7" inactive LWR reference glass was investigated in organic media at 90°C by static experiments at imposed pH values. Tests were conducted with various organic acids or acid salts (formic acid, citric acid, humic acids, sodium citrate and sodium formate) at different concentrations and at pH values ranging from 3 to 9. The leachates were submitted to ICP-AES analysis, and the alteration films on the glass specimens were examined by SEM (equipped with an energy-dispersive chemical analysis systm) and XRD. Results are discussed for the following areas. Effect of pH: different mechanisms are involved at pH 2.5 and pH 9, but in both cases, the R7T7 glass dissolution kinetics are always controlled by a surface reaction mechanism. The most significant effects of the organic acids on the glass dissolution kinetics were observed at pH 3, which was not unexpected. Nature of the acid (or acid salt): this is an essential parameter. Formic acid (monoacid) and sodium formate had no effect on the initial glass dissolution rate nor on the nature of the alteration film; conversely, citric acid (triacid) and sodium citrate significantly affected glass dissolution. The role of citric acid in the surface reaction mechanism has been demonstrated experimentally at pH 2.5; it is also known to favor that extraction of Si (directly or indirectly) and Zr and probably of Fe. The humic acids are strong catalysts of the R7T7 glass dissolution reaction. The conclusions drawn from these observations corroborate other published findings, suggesting that the catalytic effect is appreciable only for species with at least two carboxylic acid functions. Effect of concentration: the effect of the concentration was observed at basic pH values in the presence of sodium citrate and humic acids. This parameter may thus be quantified and incorporated in the glass dissolution kinetic law. © 1994.
Index Keywords: dissolution; glass; organic acid; radioactive waste storage; Carboxylic acids; Catalysts; Chemical variables control; Corrosion; Glass; Iron; Organic acids; pH effects; Reaction kinetics; Scanning electron microscopy; Silicon; Zirconium; Aqueous corrosion; Citric acid; Concentration effect; Dissolution kinetics; Glass dissolution kinetic law; Humic acid; Leachate; Nuclear glass; Surface reaction mechanism; X ray diffraction; Dissolution

Authors: He W.
Title: Simulation model for wind-diesel systems with multiple units
Affiliations: Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: He, W., Delft Univ of Technology, Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: This paper describes a simulation model for optimal operation and design analysis of wind-diesel systems with multiple unit. The energy flow control in the wind-diesel system is based on minimizing the fuel (or cost) consumption. More specifically, control is approached at two levels: the high level deals with the total energy from wind turbines, diesel generators, storage and dump load; the low one contains three independent controllers, which respectively determine each wind turbine state, power dispatch among the diesel generators in the wind-diesel system and power dispatch among the parallel pure diesel generators. Thus, a marked improvement has been achieved in optimizing energy flow among multiple diesel units. Further, the simulation model has been applied to a practical wind-diesel system in Denmark that includes multiple diesel units, and the simulation results have provided valuable insight into the design and operation features of wind-diesel systems.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Control equipment; Diesel engines; Electric generators; Electric load dispatching; Fuel consumption; Mathematical models; Optimization; State assignment; Systems analysis; Energy flow; Wind diesel systems; Wind turbines; Simulation Model; Wind/Diesel Systems

Authors: Brown D.A., Kamineni D.C., Sawicki J.A., Beveridge T.J.
Title: Minerals associated with biofilms occurring on exposed rock in a granitic underground research laboratory
Affiliations: Department of Microbiology, University of Guelph, CBS, Guelph, Ont. N1G 2W1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Brown, D.A., Department of Microbiology, University of Guelph, CBS, Guelph, Ont. N1G 2W1, Canada; Kamineni, D.C., Department of Microbiology, University of Guelph, CBS, Guelph, Ont. N1G 2W1, Canada; Sawicki, J.A., Department of Microbiology, University of Guelph, CBS, Guelph, Ont. N1G 2W1, Canada; Beveridge, T.J., Department of Microbiology, University of Guelph, CBS, Guelph, Ont. N1G 2W1, Canada
Abstract: The concept of disposal of nuclear fuel waste in crystalline rock requires the effects of microbial action to be investigated. The Underground Research Laboratory excavated in a pluton of the Canadian Shield provides a unique opportunity to study these effects. Three biofilms kept moist by seepage through fractures in granitic rock faces of the Underground Research Laboratory have been examined. The biofilms contained a variety of gram- negative and gram-positive morphotypes held together by an organic extracellular matrix. Nutrient levels in the groundwater were low, but energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy has shown biogeochemical immobilization of several elements in the biofilms; some of these elements were concentrated from extremely dilute environmental concentrations, and all elements were chemically complexed together to form amorphous or crystalline fine-grained minerals. These were seen by transmission electron microscopy to be both associated with the surfaces of the bacteria and scattered throughout the extracellular matrix, suggesting their de novo development through bacterial surface-mediated nucleation. The biofilm consortia are thought to concentrate elements both by passive sorption and by energy metabolism. By Mossbauer spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction, one of the biofilms showed that iron was both oxidized and precipitated as ferrihydrite or hematite aerobically and reduced and precipitated as siderite anaerobically. We believe that some Archean banded-iron formations could have been formed in a manner similar to this, as it would explain the deposition of hematite and siderite in close proximity. This biogeochemical development of minerals may also affect the transport of material in waste disposal sites.
Index Keywords: calcium sulfate; ferric hydroxide; ferric oxide; silicon dioxide; article; bacterial growth; bacterium; biofilm; geology; rock; Bacteria (microorganisms); Negibacteria; Posibacteria; biofilm; ferrihydrite; granite; radioactive waste storage; siderite; underground laboratory

Authors: Birkett S.H.
Title: On the interconnection of ecological system models
Affiliations: School of Engineering, University of Guelph, Guelph, N1G 2W1 Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Birkett, S.H., School of Engineering, University of Guelph, Guelph, N1G 2W1 Ont., Canada
Abstract: This paper presents the conceptual basis for representing the material and energy flows of an ecosystem using bondgraphs, a well-established and successful method for modelling multi-domain physical systems (a summary is provided). Materials may flow into or out of the ecosystem, be spatially transported, be stored or delayed, or be processed so as to change their biological, chemical, or technical attributes. The material flows are driven by energy, determined by an ecological potential, defined as an energy density by analogy with electrical potential difference. Ecosystem processes define corresponding bondgraph processes to be connected as subsystems according to the interconnection topology of the ecosystem. Input-output transfer functions for processes may be obtained through theoretical analysis, empirical or time-series methods, or by some other method. The dynamic response of an ecosystem to changing inputs is included by incorporating storage and delay processes with associated state variables available as a measure of the quality of an ecological system. By generalizing the concept of energy to include human labour and economic value, human systems and their economic controls may be interconnected with ecological systems. This human/natural interface permits direct analysis of the effects of political and social controls on the quality of natural systems. © 1994.
Index Keywords: bondgraph; ecosystem model; energy flow

Authors: Waite T.A., Ydenberg R.C.
Title: What currency do scatter-hoarding gray jays maximize?
Affiliations: Behavioral Ecology Research Group, Department of Biological Sciences, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, V5A 1S6, B.C., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Waite, T.A., Behavioral Ecology Research Group, Department of Biological Sciences, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, V5A 1S6, B.C., Canada; Ydenberg, R.C., Behavioral Ecology Research Group, Department of Biological Sciences, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, V5A 1S6, B.C., Canada
Abstract: Gray jays (Perisoreus canadensis) cache thousands of food items during each summer for use during the subsequent winter. Previous work on the economics of gray jay scatter-hoarding behavior was based on the assumption that the jays maximize the rate at which they store food energy; alternative currencies were not considered. Here we develop and test models based on two currencies, net rate (net recoverable energy stored per unit time) and efficiency (recoverable energy stored per unit energy expended). Our experiment involved providing gray jays with two options. After collecting a single food item upon arrival at a feeding apparatus, a jay could wait for two additional food items to become (simultaneously) available and then transport all three items for storage in scattered arboreal sites. Alternatively, the jay could immediately transport the single item to a storage site and return to the source repeatedly for additional single-item loads. By incrementally increasing the amount of time jays were required to wait for multipleitem loads, we were able to determine how long jays would wait before switching from multiple- to single-item caching trips. In contrast with the finding in a variety of species that efficiency-maximization models provide a better account of foraging behavior, the net rate-maximization model was a better predictor of the jays' switching point than was the efficiency-maximization model (Figs. 2 and 3). We discuss these conflicting results in the context of recent theory that describes the conditions favoring rate- versus efficiency-maximizing behavior (Ydenberg et al. 1994). © 1994 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Foraging theory; Gray jays; Hoarding; Rate maximization
Index Keywords: grey jay; optimal foraging; scatter hoarding; Perisoreus canadensis

Authors: Loch R.J.
Title: Effects of fallow management and cropping history on aggregate breakdown under rainfall wetting for a range of queensland soils
Affiliations: Natural Resource Management Unit, Queensland Department of Primary Industries, P.O. Box 102, Toowoomba, QLD, 4350, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Loch, R.J., Natural Resource Management Unit, Queensland Department of Primary Industries, P.O. Box 102, Toowoomba, QLD, 4350, Australia
Abstract: This paper reports changes in stability of soils to wetting under a range of fallow management/cropping treatments for eight experiment sites in Queensland. Because of its greater relevance to dryland soils, and its better correlation with field soil behaviour, wetting with high energy rain (HER) was used to wet samples and cause aggregate breakdown. The water-stable size fraction considered was that <0-125 mm, with the proportion of particles <0-125 mm referred to as P125. To study interactions between wetting method and tillage management, several other wetting methods were applied to some or all of the eight soils. These other methods were immersion (IMM), wetting by rainfall of low energy (LER) or under tension (TENS). Where fallow management treatments significantly reduced P125 under HER wetting, those reductions were generally small, and likely to increase steady infiltration rates of high energy rain into bare soil by only 2-6 mm h-1. In contrast, steady infiltration rates could be increased by 15-42 mm h-1 if those same soil surfaces were completely covered by stubble so that they received low energy rain. At least under Queensland conditions, retention of crop residues to protect soils from drop impact is therefore likely to be of much greater importance in improving water storage during fallows than any improvement in soil aggregation under ‘improved’ fallow management practices. Effects of fallow management and cropping history on P125 under HER varied across the sites. Three out of four virgin soils were more stable than corresponding cropped soils; stubble retention improved stability to HER wetting on three out of four sites where it was tested, and direct drill or reductions in tillage frequency improved stability at two out of eight sites. IMM showed responses to treatments that, for some soils, differed greatly from those obtained using HER. Neither LER nor TENS appeared useful, as LER gave occasional inconsistent results, and TENS caused little aggregate breakdown for most soils. © 1994, CSIRO. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Fallow management; Infiltration; Surface cover; Tillage; Water stability

Authors: Benton M.J., Nimrod A.C., Benson W.H.
Title: Evaluation of growth and energy storage as biological markers of DDT exposure in sailfin mollies
Affiliations: Environmental Toxicology Research Program, Research Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences, University of Mississippi, University, MS 38677, United States; Department of Pharmacology, University of Mississippi, University, MS 38677, United States
Authors with affiliations: Benton, M.J., Environmental Toxicology Research Program, Research Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences, University of Mississippi, University, MS 38677, United States; Nimrod, A.C., Department of Pharmacology, University of Mississippi, University, MS 38677, United States; Benson, W.H., Environmental Toxicology Research Program, Research Institute of Pharmaceutical Sciences, University of Mississippi, University, MS 38677, United States, Department of Pharmacology, University of Mississippi, University, MS 38677, United States
Abstract: Direct and indirect measures of growth and energy storage were evaluated as indicators of subchronic 1,1,1-trichloro-2-(o-chlorophenyl)-2-(p-chlorophenyl)ethane (o,p′-DDT) exposure in juvenile sailfin mollies (Poecilia latipinna). Three-day-old mollies were exposed to 0, 1, 10, 25, 50, 75, and 100 μg/liter o,p′-DDT for 21 days. Tissue residues, percentage weight gain, RNA and DNA content, RNA:DNA ratio, percentage total lipid, percentage triglyceride, percentage total protein, and triglyceride:total lipid ratio were measured following exposure. Mortality was concentration and time dependent, with 100% mortality at 75 and 100 μg/liter. Among controls and remaining treatments, tissue residues (0.50 to 363 ng/mg dry wt), percentage weight gain (116 to 596%), percentage total lipid (2.84 to 4.33%), and percentage triglyceride (1.01 to 3.22%) were significantly different. Tissue residues were positively correlated with concentration, while percentage weight gain, percentage lipid, percentage triglyceride, and triglyceride:total lipid ratio were negatively correlated with concentration. Direct measures are likely to remain the method of choice for evaluating effects of toxicants on growth in laboratory exposures because of their relative simplicity and reliability. However, indirect measures of energy storage, such as triglyceride:total lipid ratio, rather than direct measures of various lipid fractions may be more reliable indicators of the energetic cost of toxicant stress. © 1994.

Authors: Metz W.C.
Title: Potential Negative Impacts of Nuclear Activities on Local Economies: Rethinking the Issue
Affiliations: Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, Illinois, 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Metz, W.C., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, Illinois, 60439, United States
Abstract: Surveys of public opinion about perceptions of risk associated with the nuclear fuel cycle have shown that the public professes a widespread feeling of dread, a fear of associated stigmas, and a concern about possible catastrophic nuclear accidents. Various interest groups and state governments that oppose congressionally mandated siting of centralized high‐level radioactive waste (HLW) storage and disposal facilities are using this negative imagery to create a powerful, emotional obstacle to the siting process. From statistical analyses of images and location preferences, researchers have claimed that possible significant economic losses could potentially accompany the siting of HLW facilities. However, several paradoxes, or self‐contradictory statements, apparently exist between the responses expressed in surveys and the actual economic and demographic behavior evidenced in the marketplace. Federal policymakers need to evaluate whether the request for a change in siting policy is based on subjective fear of a potential negative economic effect or on proven negative effects. Empirically observed behavior does not support predicted negative economic effects based on survey responses. Copyright © 1994, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Swisher J.N.
Title: Forestry and biomass energy projects: Bottom-up comparisons of CO2 storage and costs
Affiliations: UNEP Collaborating Centre, Risø National Laboratory, P.O. Box 49, DK-4000 Roskilde, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Swisher, J.N., UNEP Collaborating Centre, Risø National Laboratory, P.O. Box 49, DK-4000 Roskilde, Denmark
Abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive and consistent methodology to account for the costs and net carbon flows of different categories of forestry and biomass energy projects and describes the application of the methodology to several sets of projects in Latin America. The results suggest that both biomass energy development and forestry measures including reforestation and forest protection can contribute significantly to the reduction of global CO2 emissions, and that local land-use capacity must determine the type of project that is appropriate in specific cases. No single approach alone is sufficient as either a national or global strategy for sustainable land use or carbon emission reduction. The methodology allows consistent comparisons of the costs and quantities of carbon stored in different types of projects and/or national programs, facilitating the inclusion of forestry and biomass energy projects in a possible CO2 emission reduction regime. © 1994.
